fields.headline: £750,000-a-goal Weah aims parting shot
fields.trailText: George Weah last night packed his bags and walked out of Manchester City - after securing a £500,000 golden handshake. Together with wages earned, that makes the Liberian's one league goal something of a rip-off.
fields.body:
George Weah last night packed his bags and walked out of Manchester City - after securing a £500,000 golden handshake.

The former World Player of the Year lasted 10 weeks at Maine Road before falling out with City's manager Joe Royle. He was unhappy about being left out of the starting line-up and complained that Royle showed him a lack of respect.

City insiders revealed that terminating his contract - worth £2.5m over two years - cost the club £500,000. Added to the £250,000 he picked up in wages during his 10-week stay, that represents an outlay of £750,000 for one league goal.

Weah, a substitute for four of City's last six games, scored three times in the Worthington Cup but his only Premiership goal was in the 3-2 defeat at Liverpool. Royle said: "He brought some moments of magic with him but it was always going to be a delicate situation with him.

"He's 34 years old and he just wants to play all the time. I can understand that fully but I have to do what I think is best for Manchester City.

"It is always regretful when things do not work out between club and player. George is a true professional who has a great stature throughout European football and we wish him well."

Weah, however, was less complimentary last night about Royle, branding him "unprofessional and disrespectful".

He also claimed that, after being dropped for four of City's last six league games, he felt like "the worst player that ever existed".

Weah went on: "I'm not willing to subject myself to feeling small in front of the younger players that I hope to be an example and an inspiration to.

"I will not accept being at a club where the manager names me in the team and then calls me five hours later to tell me that I am not in the team. In my opinion that is unprofessional and disrespectful and shows a lack of confidence in me."

He denied that being left on the bench was a problem for him and that he had come back to England - after a loan spell at Chelsea - purely for the £25,000-a-week wages which made him City's highest-paid player ever.

Weah said: "I'm not upset just because I'm not playing. I do accept because of my age that I won't play all the games.

"I didn't come for the money. I could have stayed at AC Milan but instead I sacrificed $2m [£1.4m] from them in order to come here. I didn't leave that for somebody to tell me to shut up and fuck off.

"I was made to feel old and of no real use to the club. I felt I was being used for publicity to attract other players."

Weah went on: "I respect the people I work with and I expect the same in return. My reasons for leaving are the lack of respect, the lack of communication and the dishonesty shown to me by Joe Royle."

fields.headline: Newcastle pay for Fletcher years
fields.trailText: Newcastle fell £18.9m into the red last season and have revealed that controversial former chairman and chief executive Freddie Fletcher left the club with a £532,000 pay-off
fields.body:
Newcastle United yesterday revealed Freddie Fletcher, the former chairman and chief executive who quit the club earlier in the year after becoming a hate figure among some fans, had walked away with a £532,000 pay-off.

The club said it had racked up a further £647,000 in legal costs relating to the departures of Fletcher and the former manager Ruud Gullit. The costs emerged as United reported they had fallen £18.9m into the red last season. Turnover climbed1% to £45m.

Fletcher, 59, was dubbed "the Rottweiler" for the way he stood firm against six fans who claimed that the £500 bonds they bought as season ticket-holders in 1994 should have guaranteed them the same seats for 10 years. Six years into the bond the fans, with 4,000 others, were asked to move to the newly built upper tier of St James' Park to make way for new corporate hospitality facilities. The row led to a high-profile court case.

"Last year was a year of immense change but one that is now bearing fruit," the plc chairman John Fender insisted. "There is no doubt that the legal action by a relatively small number of supporters impacted on us. We hope to settle the issue once and for all very shortly."

Fender said moves to increase the capacity of St James' Park to 52,000 and the media alliance with the cable television firm NTL should soon improve future revenues.

Frank Gilmour, chairman of the Independent Newcastle United Supporters' Association, said: "The whole Save Our Seats issue certainly affected the figures because the club have not been able to sell the seats in question. You can see the empty seats in the corporate areas at St James' Park every week, so they have obviously lost revenue."

The football club chairman Freddy Shepherd was yesterday promoted from a non-executive director of the plc to a part-time executive director.

Chelsea Village yesterday warned of a "difficult" year ahead as it looks to strike a balance between rising player wages and the need to complete building work at Stamford Bridge. In the year to June 30 pre-tax losses rose from £507,000 to £3.5m, despite a jump in turnover from £91m to £106m.

In a statement to the stock exchange the chairman Ken Bates predicted that Chelsea's media partnership with BSkyB and the opening of new corporate hospitality facilities would soon boost revenues.

However, he warned that, if the European Union scrapped transfer fees, Chelsea might decide to cut spending on youth development. "There is little point in spending huge sums of money in developing youth talent if they can walk out at any time, without any form of compensation," he said.

Manchester City clinched a £3m deal to sign the Everton and Ireland defender Richard Dunne last night - one hour after releasing their former world player of the year George Weah. The Liberian striker said: "It is not a situation I thought would arise. However, having spoken to Joe Royle, we have amicably agreed it would be best for both parties to terminate my contract."

Bobby Gould's six-week spell in charge of Third Division Cardiff City ended yesterday when he was relieved of his first-team duties by the club's new owner Sam Hammam, although he retains his title of manager. After speaking to Gould by telephone yesterday, Hammam met the assistant manager Alan Cork, who will now pick the team, in a London car park.

Gianluca Vialli has turned down an offer from the Nottingham Forest manager David Platt to become a player-coach at the City Ground.

webTitle: Brown sent to the stands for Scotland qualifier

fields.headline: Brown sent to the stands for Scotland qualifier
fields.trailText: Craig Brown will be banned from the touchline for Scotland's World Cup qualifier against Belgium in March unless an appeal to Fifa's disciplinary committee is successful.
fields.body:
Craig Brown will be banned from the touchline for Scotland's World Cup qualifier against Belgium in March unless an appeal to Fifa's disciplinary committee is successful.

Brown was sent from the dugout for an outburst against the referee during Scotland's 1-1 draw in Croatia last week and, although Fifa is yet to study videos of the incident and has not received the Scottish Football Association's version of events, it confirmed yesterday that Brown will be banished to the stands for one match.

No date has yet been set for the committee to make a final ruling. "The disciplinary committee did not want to rush the decision, so decided to wait for all the evidence," said a Fifa spokesman. "But one thing is for sure: Craig Brown is suspended for the next match.

"We have heard what Craig Brown has said in interviews, that he is innocent, and we want to study the case fully. We will check the video."

Police have been called in to investigate Jim McLean's alleged assault on the BBC Scotland reporter John Barnes. Tayside police have been asked by the Procurator Fiscal at Dundee to provide a report of the incident which resulted in McLean resigning as Dundee United chairman, managing director and board member.

Celtic have agreed a fee in the region of £1.5m with Dundee for the goalkeeper Robert Douglas, who had also been wanted by Rangers. Douglas will undergo a medical today.

webTitle: Tourists wary of breaking new ground

fields.headline: Tourists wary of breaking new ground
fields.trailText: England were desperately seeking clarification last night about Sri Lanka's avowed intention to stage a one-day international against them this winter on a ground not yet built.
fields.body:
England were desperately seeking clarification last night about Sri Lanka's avowed intention to stage a one-day international against them this winter on a ground not yet built.

The Dambulla stadium, little more than a foundation stone on the edge of a village in Sri Lanka's dry zone, has been officially named by the Sri Lankan Board as the venue for the opening limited-overs international against England on March 23.

The England and Wales Cricket Board has not been informed. "We don't know anything about this," said a spokesperson. The ECB must now consider whether to make official representations that five months is too short a time to guarantee even basic facilities - not to mention transforming scrubland into a pitch of international standard.

The Dambulla concept, championed by the board's chief executive Thilanga Sumathipala, should eventually prove a sound one. The aim is to establish an all-year-round venue. Sri Lanka's recent attempts to extend their programme outside the traditional confines of November to March have been disrupted by rain.

Sumathipala, recently re-elected, is determined to force through the 25,000-capacity stadium, costing £2m, while his authority is at its highest. A school band and Kandyan dancers marked the ceremonial laying of the foundation stone in the hamlet of Ibbankatuna less than three weeks ago.

"I have had to face giant obstructions to my undertaking to build a stadium in the dry zone," he said. "But Colombo is wet for so much of the year. I accept the challenge that this ground will be ready in time. I have faith in my construction team who are working at a tremendous pace to host the England team."

Tour operators are aghast at a potential switch to Dambulla, four hours from the original venue in Colombo, which leaves their plans for England's thousands of travelling supporters in chaos; Dambulla lies near to the Sigiriya Rock Fortress, and Sumathipala might be advised to follow the example of the old Kandyan kings and retreat there forthwith.

Barry Dudleston, a first-class umpire and director of the Sunsport Tours, said: "Nothing ever amazes me these days but the prospect of last-minute uncertainty is horrendous." John Snow, the former England fast bowler now offering tours, through John Snow Travel, said: "It's a mess."

fields.headline: The Waterboys come rocking back
fields.standfirst:
Corn Exchange, Cambridge
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Corn Exchange, Cambridge
Rating: ***
fields.body:
By the simple expedient of only emerging in public once a decade, Mike Scott has managed to chisel himself a small but enduring niche in the cobwebby vault of the rock biz. His new Waterboys album, A Rock in the Weary Land, is his first since 1993. This tour is the band's first jog round Blighty since 1990.

And do they sound much different? Well bigger, basically. Scott, always enamoured of the so-called "Big Music", seems to have embraced the role of Rock Star less ambiguously than in the past. Thrashing away at his guitar under his circa-1968 Jeff Beck haircut and giving cues to the band by kicking a leather-clad leg out at right angles, Scott looks less like the Celtic minstrel of yore and more like a man ready to fill arenas and kick some ass. The only flaw in his masterplan is that the band are currently playing agreeably sized venues like this one.

But there's no doubt that the Waterboys have been gulping down handfuls of rock'n'roll steroids. After an introductory dirge on acoustic guitar, Scott unleashed his backing quartet on Let it Happen, a dramatic maelstrom of swirling keyboards and piledriver percussion. Dumbing Down the World was a furious rant against what Scott describes as "those who would reverse our evolution and dumb us all down" (Richard and Judy? S Club 7?).

When the band finally got around to playing the title track of the new album, it arrived like a heavy metal avalanche, equipped with a road-drill bassline and swaggering like a squadron of tanks.

Long-time fans will be relieved to hear, therefore, that Scott hasn't abandoned his folkish roots. He dabbled in a spot of acoustic jigging, and played Church Not Made With Hands as a solo piece with acoustic guitar. He sang Strange Voyage as though it were some ancient fable he'd stumbled across in a dusty old attic.

But the big beat was never far away. As Scott chipped out powerchords and chunks of lead guitar, the band pumped away on a battery of instruments, with Richard Naiff on Hammond organ leaping between gurgling Spencer Davis-type vamps and even a bit of Bach.

For the encores, they tore into Go Bang the Drum, and let its whirling momentum spin out into a protracted instrumental rave. Finally, Scott heeded the hecklers who'd been screaming for Whole of the Moon all night, and delivered it with the stomp factor turned up to 11. Not subtle, but effective.

 Waterboys are at the Civic Hall, Wolverhampton (01902 552121), tonight, then tour.

fields.headline: Empty gestures from Halifax
fields.trailText: Halifax tried to pull a publicity stunt yesterday saying it will not increase premiums for any of its buildings and contents policy holders as a result of the flooding which has hit parts of the country.
fields.body:
Halifax tried to pull a publicity stunt yesterday saying it will not increase premiums for any of its buildings and contents policy holders as a result of the flooding which has hit parts of the country.

Unfortunately the offer is not as generous as it seems. MoneyUnlimited contacted other big UK insurers, including Direct Line and Nationwide, and found that none of them had any intention of raising premiums either.

In addition, a spokesperson for the Association of British Insurers said it would be unusual for insurers to hike their premiums as a result of the floods because the damage has not been widespread.

Insurers base premiums on the number of claims they've had across the whole book of business. If the entire country had been flooded premiums would probably go up, but as only a handful of each insurers' policyholders will be making claims, the companies can absorb the losses without having to increase premiums.

That's the good news. The bad news is that there are lots of ways for insurers to justify premium increases, so don't be surprised if yours does actually rise when you come to renew your policy.

A spokesperson for Halifax said: "We will not increase premiums as a direct result of the floods, but there are other factors, including changes to tax and legislation, which we take into account when setting premiums."

In short, insurers could increase premiums across the board and blame the rise on a variety of factors as long as the floods are not one of them. Halifax and the other insurers were unable to say if other factors would lead to premiums increases, only reiterating that increases would not be because of the floods.

Stuart Cliffe from the Association of Bank and Insurance Customers said: "Halifax have gone a step too far with this move. The whole point of insurance is that it protects you against one-off events, so when a one-off event like flooding happens why should customers worry about premiums increases. It's almost fraudulent to make claims like this in the hope of getting new customers. Insurers can never guarantee rates won't increase because anything can happen and lots of issues affect the premium."

Meanwhile, the floods have once again raised the issue of climate change and the impact it will have on the insurance industry.

Environmental campaigner Friends of the Earth has been talking with the industry explaining the link between burning fossil fuels, climate change and destructive weather patterns in the hope that insurers will see it is not in their long-term interests to insure oil companies as their activities result in huge losses for the insurers.

And the industry itself is starting to take notice. Andrew Dlugolecki from CGNU has been working on the links between climate change and insurance losses for some time and says he was expecting flooding like the ones witnessed in recent weeks. "The industry will be working closely with developers and planners to make sure the three million new homes to be built in the next 20 years are not built in flood prone areas," he says, before adding "climate change is obviously a factor as well and the insurance industry needs to accept this."

fields.headline: Chaotic comic genius from Bill Bailey
fields.standfirst:
Grand Opera House, York
Rating: *****
fields.trailText:
Grand Opera House, York
Rating: *****
fields.body:
He may be on his way to superstar status - a film debut alongside Brenda Blethyn in Saving Grace, a burgeoning double-act with Dylan Moran in Channel 4's latest cult sitcom, Black Books - yet still Bill Bailey in the flesh looks like a Hawkwind roadie on a bad night.

This is not the only horrifying aspect of Bailey's all-new, post-Edinburgh tour. There is Carol Vorderman's saliva, for example, which Bailey has sampled from her consonant announcments on Countdown and gleefully replays at great amplification and reduced speed until it sounds like Richard Whitely being boiled in his own gastric juices.

Then there is an entire improvised section inspired by an afternoon visit to the dungeon-theme museum opposite the theatre. "I wanted to see the Pit of Despair" he complains. "But it was shut. Still, I spent some quality time in the Cafe of Misery and the Gift Shop of Disillusionment".

If there is anything resembling a theme to this year's show it's the concept of time; and if there's anything wrong with that it's because, in Bailey's company, it disappears too quickly. Alarmed at the apparent brevity of the first half, the audience could be seen checking their watches to discover that Bailey had been on stage for a good 50 minutes. It is simply that an hour at the speed of Bailey's thought seems barely the length of a quick tea-break.

Perhaps it's because Bailey has been reading a Brief History of Time - in the spirit, he explains, of relaxed empiricism, whereby if someone vaguely describes what might have been the case he is prepared to believe it. So if Steven Hawking concludes that the universe is saddle-shaped, he'll accept that on the basis that Hawking is the cleverest man on the planet.

Surprisingly, Bailey spends more of this show behind a mic stand than at his synthesiser: which is a pity, because the sheer joy of hearing him mutate the Moonlight Sonata into a cockney knees-up cannot be surpassed. Nevertheless, his aural demonstration of the ambulance sirens of Europe is a new tour-de-force. "Out of the way everyone", it seems to proclaim: "baldy-beardy genius sauntering through".

 Bill Bailey is at the Junction, Cambridge (01223 511 511), tomorrow, then tours to Sheffield and Leeds.

This is not the only horrifying aspect of Bailey's all-new, post-Edinburgh tour. fields.headline: Uri Caine
fields.standfirst:
Norwich Playhouse
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Norwich Playhouse
Rating: ****
fields.body:
When Uri Caine, the big, rumpled Philadelphia pianist, toured his jazz treatment of Mahler's most celebrated melodies a couple of years ago, some of the late composer's devotees told him that what he was doing was particularly indecent because Mahler was dead and couldn't even retaliate. Caine's octet (including a roof-raising gospel singer, trumpet, sax and turntables) launched its UK tour this week with a British premiere of the leader's version of JS Bach's Goldberg Variations. It was the last night of a Norfolk and Norwich arts festival that had begun two weeks previously with a straight account of the same work.

On his Mahler project, a driving idea in the whole thing was that Mahler had taken many melodic motifs from vernacular settings and the jazz band could be used to restore the spontaneity, idiosyncrasy and rough edges to the source material. With the Goldberg Variations, Caine has inclined more toward pretty respectfully delivered accounts (often in duet with his classical violinist Joyce Hamman) that shine like separated beacons over the turbulent landscape in between, his piano sound growing freer and splashier around her imperturbably elegant delivery as the show went on.

But for the most part, the real departures from the Goldberg stemmed from an even looser sequence of tangentially-related notions than occurred with the Mahler. Bach's use of the dance-forms of his time led Caine to use the dance-forms of his own - and some of the most exuberant and exhilarating passages in the 90-minute unbroken set were raucous salsa explosions, sinister tangos, jubilant New Orleans stomps. In some hands, a venture like this could simply be an uncomprehending enforced cohabitation between utterly dissimilar sensibilities - but Uri Caine's passion, wit, expertise and shrewd sense of when to bend his beautiful borrowings and when to leave them be, makes a triumph out of it.

 Uri Caine is at the Wardrobe, Leeds (0113 245 5570), tonight, then tours.

webTitle: Canary Wharf climbs into the FTSE 100

fields.headline: Canary Wharf climbs into the FTSE 100
fields.standfirst: They talked of a white elephant. Ten years on, Paul Reichmann may even bid for the Dome site
fields.trailText: Almost ten years to the day since then environment secretary Michael Portillo gleefully "topped out" the steel cap to Canary Wharf, the Docklands monument to capitalism has come of age. In a low-key announcement yesterday, the stock exchange confirmed that Canary Wharf is to join the FTSE 100 index.
fields.body:
Almost ten years to the day since then environment secretary Michael Portillo gleefully "topped out" the steel cap to Canary Wharf, the Docklands monument to capitalism has come of age. In a low-key announcement yesterday, the stock exchange confirmed that Canary Wharf is to join the FTSE 100 index.

It has been a long, bumpy road, but the tallest building in Britain is finally winning acceptance. The main tower at 1 Canada Square is 99.9% full, two more towers are nearly finished and Canary Wharf has this week agreed to take control of a further slice of land on the bank of the River Thames.

A recent surge in the company's share price has taken the value of Canary Wharf to £3.8bn, which means the family of chief executive Paul Reichmann is sitting on a stake worth £255m. The group is even considering a bid for the site of the Millennium Dome.

However, it has hardly been an easy ride. On the windy November day in 1990 when the tower was completed, Mr Portillo declared: "The prophets of doom, with their nonsense about white elephants, have already been proved wrong."

He was soon to swallow his words, as the site's Toronto-based developer Olympia & York put Canary Wharf into administration. It became a symbol of the unsustainable excess of Thatcherism.

Too many buildings had gone up in London, causing a collapse in rents when the economy slowed down. It was years before demand for office space caught up with supply. Canary Wharf acquired an image problem that it has never truly shaken off - of soulless nightlife, poor transport links and hostile surrounding neighbourhoods.

Yet for all its critics, Canary Wharf has bounced back. Mr Reichmann, the former boss of Olympia & York, led a consortium which bought the company back for £800m five years ago.

Since then, the company has been helped by the continuing growth of the financial services sector and more recently, the birth of thousands of dot.com companies in search of space in central London.

Consolidation among banks and stockbrokers has created larger organisations in search of bigger buildings than ever. Canary Wharf has been able to respond more quickly and cheaply than its rivals, partly due to the underground infrastructure of pipes, networks and plumbing laid by its ambitious founders.

Meanwhile, developers finally appear to be running out of space in the Square Mile. Just 2m sq ft of offices are due to become available in the City in the next six months - a figure which has fallen 52% in the last year, and is at its lowest level since 1988.

Property analyst John Atkins of HSBC says: "There is a growing shortage of office space in central London, more particularly of high quality space, and more specifically in large units."

Surging demand has allowed Canary Wharf to bring forward its plans and it will complete the next stage of its development - towers for HSBC and Citigroup - early next year.

Mr Atkins says: "The one advantange they've got above all the others is speed. They know exactly what's under the ground - they don't have to worry about any archeological remains, unlike the City, and they can throw things up quickly and not too expensively."

Canary Wharf's estate is creeping out towards both edges of the Isle of Dogs. In its latest expansion, the company yesterday said it was paying £34m to buy out Singapore-based Pidemco and Hotel Properties, its joint venture partners in a riverside site to the west of the main Canada Square.

This will provide space for further shops and restaurants - the group is anxious to counter complaints that the area is a graveyard for entertainment. In fact, it already has 130 shops and is classed a "sub-regional shopping centre". Most of the main bar chains are in evidence. A Canary Wharf insider boasts: "You can never get into All Bar One here these days - it's heaving."

The extension of the Jubilee Line has been crucial in attracting new businesses. In the early days, Canary Wharf was only served by the Docklands Light Railway, which stopped in the early evenings and never ran at all over the weekends.

The arrival of the tube has been one of the only indisputable improvements for local communities. For, despite its belated financial success, critics point out that Canary Wharf has struggled to fulfil one of the original aims of the Thatcher-inspired enterprise zone - to help lift Docklands out of poverty.

Tall storeys 12 towering years

May 1988 Construction begins at Canary Wharf

August 1991 State Street first tenant to move in

May 1992 Canary Wharf's developer, Olympia & York, goes into administration

October 1993 Rescued by consortium led by Lloyds Bank

October 1994 Working population reaches 10,000

December 1995 Sold for £800m to group including current boss Paul Reichmann, Prince al Waleed and Franklin Resources

February 1996 IRA bomb explodes at nearby South Quay, killing two people

November 1997 Tony Blair holds summit with President Chirac at Canary Wharf

April 1999 Flotation values Canary Wharf at £2.2bn

September 1999 Jubilee line station opens

September 2000 Canary Wharf makes first full-year profit

October 2000 Joins FTSE 100

fields.headline: New Contemporaries 2000
fields.standfirst:
Cornerhouse, Manchester
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Cornerhouse, Manchester
Rating: ****
fields.body:
New Contemporaries is an annual exhibition selected from the work of students and graduates of fine art degree courses in the UK. Hosted by the Cornerhouse for the sixth year running, the 33 successful artists have been chosen by Sarah Kent, visual arts editor of London magazine Time Out, Jeremy Millar, a freelance curator, and artist Gavin Turk. Damien Hirst, a previous New Comtemporaries exhibitor, is one of the project's patrons.

Much of the work here seems to harbour a fascination with urban-pastoral landscapes or concepts. Can we take the city to the country and vice versa? Josephine Butler's huge atmospheric photographs of peaty groves could depict October days in any rural area, but she tells us in the title that they are all somewhere in the City of London. With the industrial detritus of bricks, hose-pipes, buckets and glass, James Ireland sets up Tableau, a DIY waterfall, cheekily based on an accompanying photograph of the real thing.

Beata Veszley, meanwhile, brings animals to the city by constructing five life-size plastic horse-heads replete with manes and glass eyes. She mounts these on wooden poles and the viewer is encouraged to step inside the cast and wear one like a mask. If you're with a friend, equine conversations are welcomed.

Of the video installations, Nikolaj Larsen's Love is a fuzzy-pictured shot of a couple kissing in the rain, with a maniac occasionally shouting "I love you" in the background. It is at once intimate and horrible. Also intriguing is Vali and Ameneh by Johannes Maier, a chat between two bilingual Iranian speakers, and you have to listen carefully to hear them slip between the colloquialisms of the two languages. If the video work seems to wisely eschew political content, then this is counteracted by Phil Collins's How to Make a Refugee, a two-screen documentary showing a lifestyle magazine photographing refugees. In a rather obvious indictment of the media, Collins clearly reveals the humiliation of the young boy being photographed.

Of course, there is much playfulness on show too. Edward Weldon's small but chunky oil paintings of envelopes, cash tills, and skips are grubby delights, while Cable Car by an artist known simply as Eric is a life-size model in wood. Jennifer Beattie's sculpture, Beautiful Tree, is made of varnished branches which look like barbecued ribs and boast Sellotape clusters for blossom. It might sound like a Blue Peter special, but it's rather stunning. Also striking are Marta Marce's post-Hirst canvases of bold lines and spirals.

fields.headline: Guilty Pleasures
fields.standfirst:
BAC, London
Rating: *
fields.trailText:
BAC, London
Rating: *
fields.body:
Chocolate is one for most people; long, scented hot baths another. But who can put their hand on their heart and say that the plays of TS Eliot are a guilty pleasure. On the contrary, The Cocktail Party is one of the nastiest plays ever written. But then maybe wallowing in misery is a guilty pleasure.

Here, theatre company Imitating the Dog take Eliot's 1939 country house drama, The Family Reunion, and give it a video once-over. The evening's inspiration may be the haunted Harry's line: "Oh, there must be other ways of talking that would get us somewhere," but Imitating the Dog don't succeed in taking us either to unexplored emotional country or one of innovative theatrical practice. This feels like student work, good quality student work, but nonetheless derivative and lacking an original spark or even an original way of looking at the world.

Eliot's play concerns the homecoming of Lord Harry Monchensy to his northern family home after an absence of eight years and the drowning of his young wife that leaves him guilt-stricken. The house is ruled over by his domineering mother and is full of dependent relatives. In the course of the evening Harry faces up to the expectations of his family and in rejecting them is released from guilt and ghosts. He heads off into the dawn in search of "the bright angels".

Imitating the Dog speak Eliot's lines into microphones and intercut them with snippets from the 1965 recording of the play with Flora Robson and Paul Schofield. Pretty soon the stilted, dated dialogue ("a very few cocktails went a very long way with m'lady,") becomes quite the most interesting thing about a production that goes from bad to worse as the cast sing Neil Diamond songs, vomit and stuff heads down the toilet. This is more bathroom sink than kitchen sink drama.

All the time in the foreground of the stage a video screen takes us on a very long car journey. The headlights eat up the miles as night turns into the grey of early morning and then the promise of a bright new dawn. Regrettably, by this time the young company had lost their way in the dark so completely that I longed for the RSC to appear in their cocktail frocks and give us their recent production of the play. There is something very wrong with new theatre when it starts making you think of the old and creaky rather fondly. The real trouble with work such as this is that it has become as cliched in its own way as the traditional theatre and sensibility that it mocks. Guilty Pleasures is as much a dodo as The Family Reunion.

fields.headline: A Faustian pact with Colin Davis
fields.standfirst:
Damnation of Faust
Barbican, London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Damnation of Faust
Barbican, London
Rating: ****
fields.body:
Colin Davis's monumental, year-long Berlioz Odyssey has finally reached The Damnation of Faust, one of the composer's greatest, if most perplexing works. Berlioz took Goethe as his source, though his adaptation is nothing if not radical. A vague pall of decadence hangs over the piece, pre-empting Baudelaire and the relentless moral questioning of the late 19th century.

Goethe redeems his Faust through love. Berlioz exposes him to a series of sensually evoked artificial paradises which fail to satisfy his selfish thirst for experience, then sends him ironically hurtling to the abyss as moral awareness begins to dawn. Faust's consignment of his soul to Mephistopheles coincides with his first altruistic act, namely his decision to save the life of Marguerite whom he has ruined.

It's a work with a bleak, mordant vision, couched in music of sensual beauty and garish violence, which serves throughout to befuddle the listener as it does its hero. No one has ever penetrated its ambivalent heart of darkness as well as Davis, the Berlioz conductor par excellence, who takes us on a roller-coaster ride to hell, only pausing to summon up occasional landscapes of sexual and emotional beauty.

Berlioz has frequently been described as episodic, but here you're swept away by the inexorability of it all, by the relentless dramatic logic that holds you firmly in its grip. The London Symphony Orchestra respond to him with playing of restless, flickering eloquence that gleams with the deceptive allure of infernal fire. It's a magisterial achievement, in short, though it's not achieved without a few peripheral problems.

The London Symphony Chorus sings with supreme intelligence and a sense of bristling excitement, though occasionally the men sound too few in number, while the tenors, thrilling at full throttle, are less assured in quieter passages. I also had doubts about Davis's decision to encourage "silly voices" and coarse, open-vowelled pronunciation for the proletarian choruses - the drinkers in Luther's tavern, the peasant women praying at the wayside shrine.

The soloists aren't always quite ideally matched, the weak link being the Albanian mezzo Enkelejda Shkosa as Marguerite. It's a fabulous voice, no question, but she's ultimately miscast - there's voluptuousness in the tone that suggests sexual knowledge from the outset rather than questioning innocence in danger of destruction.

In her love scenes with Giuseppe Sabbatini's Faust, there is, however, a powerful erotic charge. He, at this point, making alarming noises, is a rutting animal. Elsewhere, he's athletic and virile rather than mellifluous, very much the Byronic, existential rebel rather than the usual self-pitying drip. Opposite him is the Mephistopheles of Michele Pertusi, taking on the role shortly after his awkward incarnation of Hoffmann's demonic nemesis at Covent Garden. He's happier here, avoiding the self-conscious irony that marred his Opera House performances.

His Mephistopheles is initially seductive, his voice hovering round "my beloved Faust" with seditious, caressing beauty. Later, he eggs Faust on with brutal obscenity. He's pretty stunning throughout, turning in a disquieting, enthralling performance at the centre of a disquieting, enthralling evening.

In her love scenes with Giuseppe Sabbatini's Faust, there is, however, a powerful erotic charge. He, at this point, making alarming noises, is a rutting animal. Elsewhere, he's athletic and virile rather than mellifluous, very much the Byronic, existential rebel rather than the usual self-pitying drip. Opposite him is the Mephistopheles of Michele Pertusi, taking on the role shortly after his awkward incarnation of Hoffmann's demonic nemesis at Covent Garden. He's happier here, avoiding the self-conscious irony that marred his Opera House performances. His Mephistopheles is initially seductive, his voice hovering round "my beloved Faust" with seditious, caressing beauty. Later, he eggs Faust on with brutal obscenity. He's pretty stunning throughout, turning in a disquieting, enthralling performance at the centre of a disquieting, enthralling evening.

fields.headline: Loss-making Egg expands
fields.standfirst:
Net news
Special report: e-finance
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: More than £400m of deposits were removed from telephone-cum-internet bank Egg over the past three months as investors chased higher savings rates at rival banks.
fields.body:
More than £400m of deposits were removed from telephone-cum-internet bank Egg over the past three months as investors chased higher savings rates at rival banks.

The defectors had high average balances of up to £100,000 in their accounts.

But the bank, in which Prudential has a majority stake, tried to put a positive gloss on the news by insisting that the lost customers were being replaced by a larger number of younger, potentially more profitable ones.

Egg admitted that its losses had widened by 7% in the nine-months to the end of September to £115m. But, Mike Harris, the chief executive, said the business remained on track to break into profit in the fourth quarter of 2001.

The losses during the third quarter of £34.4m were lower than the same period the previous year of £38.2m and its operating income has started to rise. For the first time, it said its operating income had been greater than operating and administrative expenses.

The bank, which upstaged the traditional high street players with its launch two years ago, attracted 120,000 new accounts in the third quarter. This is despite the £443m fall in deposits caused by investors moving their accounts elsewhere.

"Even the decline in total deposits is on the whole positive for Egg, as it reflects a transition to a more valuable customer base with a high propensity to transact over new channels, especially the internet," Mr Harris said.

The bank sells on average just over one product to each customer and needs to hit two per customer by the final quarter of next year if it is to meet its profitability targets. It has already expanded beyond its saving account to personal loans, credit cards, insurance and a fund supermarket as well as on-line shopping.

At the start of next year Egg intends to launch its first current account, which will operate differently to traditional accounts by allowing customers to offset the interest on their savings with their debts. This operates in a similar way to Halifax's Intelligent Finance and Virgin's One account.

Paul Gratton, the deputy chief executive, said this account would start to heap pressure on the big four clearing banks who dominate the current account market. He expects the clearing banks to come under pressure to increase the interest rates they offer on current accounts as competition mounts from Egg and banks such as Halifax, which offers 4% rates on current account deposits.

The bank, which is spending £3m on advertising, will launch the next offensive later this week through a heavy-weight television and press campaign for its online general insurance supermarket Egg Insure.

Mr Gratton said Egg was looking at expansion opportunities in Europe, through a joint venture or strategic alliance rather than an outright acquisition.

One analyst said that the latest figures from Egg were broadly positive. "They showed an increase in customer numbers, wider spreads and margins. They did have a net outflow of deposits but explained why," the analyst said.

Eggs shares rose 4.5p to 130.5p but remained well below the 160p at which they were sold to investors.

webTitle: The game that changed the face of cricket

fields.headline: The game that changed the face of cricket
fields.standfirst:
England arrive in Pakistan today for their first tour there since Mike Gatting's row with Shakoor Rana during the ill-fated 1987 series. The men in the middle of that drama recall the incident

Mike Selvey offers his version of events
fields.trailText: England arrive in Pakistan today for their first tour there since Mike Gatting's row with Shakoor Rana during the ill-fated 1987 series. The men in the middle of that drama recall the incident.
fields.body:
Mike Gatting
England captain

"I really don't want to inflame old wounds and make things difficult for the team when they get to Pakistan. It wasn't an easy tour, everyone knows that and they can all draw their own conclusions why. We were not the first side to experience difficulties. The New Zealanders walked off the field, and so did India. I think Australia came close to it.

"I'm not saying we were the catalyst for it but a lot of things have changed now with good facilities for practice, match referees and independent umpires. It was hard when we switched from the World Cup, which was excellently organised, to the tour. But Nasser Hussain's side should not be reminded of that. They need to be positive."

Shakoor Rana
Pakistani umpire

"I do not regret what happened. England should regret it. They lost a day's play from a match they were winning. Mike Gatting is not a cheat. But that day in Faisalabad he cheated. I don't know why. I think he lost his temper after losing the first Test in Lahore. And after cheating he started abusing me. It was sad what happened. Today the match referee would sort it out. But he wrote me an apology and now it is a closed chapter. I would never have agreed to apologise. Why? I was 100% right."

Peter Lush
England team manager

"We tried to get the problem sorted out overnight and on the third day it looked like a solution had been reached, but it all fell through. I needed to talk to the Pakistan Board secretary Ijaz Butt at that stage but he had decided to go back to Lahore, so that evening I drove there myself with the aim of speaking to him and the board president Lt-Gen Safdar Butt about providing alternative umpires if these would not stand.

"It was a terrifying journey down that road at night but also a curious one because in the car with me was Javed Miandad and I remember thinking that things could not be too bright, as he ought to have been at the ground.

"For some reason the general was not available when we reached Lahore and I had to spend the night there before meeting next day with him as well as Ijaz Butt and Hasib Ahsan. It was supposed to be a private meeting but two journalists arrived and a radio fellow and interviews were conducted. I was told by the general that it had all been sorted, that the impasse had been solved but of course it hadn't. I returned to Faisalabad and nothing had changed.

"We felt very isolated. There was no one to turn to and time was against us. Calls home had to be booked so that was difficult, as was the habit of officials suddenly switching their conversations to Urdu so that we could not understand them. I can't recall anything worse in my experience. It was all very harrowing."

Hasib Ahsan
Pakistan team manager

"I arrived in Faisalabad at 2am. I had been asked by the Pakistan board, at the behest of England's tour manager Peter Lush, to mediate between Mike Gatting and Shakoor Rana. I told Gatting that the umpire was the boss and that he had been insulted. All he had to do was apologise. Then England would have gone on to win the match.

"The problems were partly an offshoot of the World Cup, which had been a disappointment for both teams. Gatting had played that hopeless reverse sweep in Calcutta when England lost the World Cup final to Australia. And there had been bad feeling between players and umpires on both sides for years. I was heavily involved in Pakistan's fight for neutral umpires and match referees and I'm proud that their introduction began to put things right.

"I don't anticipate any problems this time. Nasser Hussain is a refined person and most of the England players accompanying him are good sports. The ICC code of conduct also ensures that misbehaving players are no longer tolerated.

"England 's 13-year absence from Pakistan is too big a gap. We need England teams to set a good example. I'm sure this time they will."

Chris Broad
England opener

"I batted for a few hours in the first innings of the Lahore Test and saw plenty of strange things from the non-striker's end. There were at least four decisions that I couldn't believe. Then came the second innings - and another opportunity for the umpires to get involved in the game.

"I was given out caught behind by Shakeel Khan. It was an unreal situation: I didn't hit the ball and I'd never experienced that sort of thing before. I didn't see why I should go, so I stood my ground. With hindsight I'm not very proud of what happened but I should imagine some of the Pakistanis are not very proud of the way they behaved either.

"Eventually Graham Gooch came down the pitch from the non-striker's end and told me I had to go. There was nothing I could do. The strange thing was that, even though there was five minutes to go until tea, the umpires removed the bails and walked off.

"At Faisalabad I wasn't within earshot of Gatt's exchange with Shakoor Rana. But I believe his version of events and certainly he had the full support of his team. Not many people remember this - but I actually scored a century in that Faisalabad Test - one of the more forgotten hundreds.

"Time heals and I suppose I can smile about things now. Nothing like that will happen again, because there are neutral umpires, match referees and I know the Pakistanis are keen to make England feel welcome this winter."

Graham Gooch
Broad's opening partner

"The problems in Faisalabad were on the back of the first Test in Lahore. I was batting at the other end to Chris Broad when he staged his protest. We were seething a bit after Shakeel Khan, the umpire, had sawn us off in the first innings. Iqbal Qasim was bowling his slow left-arm spin from over the wicket. A ball went past the outside edge, there was a noise and they all went up with a big appeal. Shakeel gave him out but Broady just stood there and said: 'I'm not going for that.' They all went into a huddle and had a few words with him. After about half a minute I wandered down to him and said: 'Look, mate, I think you've got to go' and ushered him off. On reflection I should have left him there, then we could all have gone home.

"The Shakoor Rana thing was a storm in a teacup really. We thought he'd nicked Gatt's lunch, that was all. We actually took the field next morning, expecting them to come out. We ended up sitting around on the roller waiting. Later we had a meeting and the players were solid in not wanting to carry on with the tour. As one of the more experienced players I told them they would be in breach of contract and should consider what it could do to careers. We compiled a statement and then took the field."

David Capel
England all-rounder

"It was a tour I shall never forget. The first two matches, in Lahore and Faisalabad, were only the second and third Tests of my career. In Lahore I didn't touch the ball with my bat in the entire match, but was twice given out caught. And of my four dismissals in those matches they got me out, properly, just the once.

"It was unbelievable stuff. Of the first 30 wickets we lost we reckoned that we had been "sawn-off" on about 15 occasions. And we always felt that to take 10 of their wickets we really had to take 15. We had won the three one-day matches 3-0, so we went into the Test series feeling pretty confident. And they were without Imran Khan, too. Mind you, Abdul Qadir bowled so well on pitches that suited him that Pakistan might have won the series even if everything had been normal.

"It was a pity about what happened in Faisalabad because the incident came right at the end of a long, hot day, the penultimate over of the second day. If we had been able to avoid a big scene we were in a winning position.

"Mike Gatting called me in from deep square-leg and told the batsman, who was Salim Malik. But Shakoor Rana accused him of cheating and used swear words that I had not heard from an umpire before or since. My only wish for the current England players is that they let history alone. They should let sleeping dogs lie and go into the series with a positive attitude."

webTitle: 'I hadn't a clue what was going on out there'

fields.headline: 'I hadn't a clue what was going on out there'
fields.standfirst:
Guardian cricket correspondent Mike Selvey had a box seat for the whole affair

The game that changed the face of cricket
fields.trailText: Mike Selvey had a box seat for the whole affair. Here is his version of events.
fields.body:
From a personal perspective the end of the cricket world as we knew it came from modest beginnings. As the second day of the second Test was drawing to its conclusion on December 8 1987, I was summarising for Test Match Special. When play was suspended, truthfully, I had not got a clue what was going on out there between Mike Gatting and Shakoor Rana.

"Perhaps they had more than two men behind square on the legside," I ventured, although dead ball, rather than no-ball, had not been called. Anyway the entry in my notebook reads: "Gatting discussion with umpire". "Full and frank," I might have added.

Earlier in the day we had played a trick on a colleague who had missed the first session by inventing a spoof incident in which Javed Miandad and Gatting had been involved in a fight. If ever fate had been tempted, it was then.

The kerfuffle had been simmering for some time, an explosion waiting to happen. Its roots were tangled. England mistrusted the level of probity of sub-continental umpires who, Keith Fletcher used to say, had rewritten the laws and gave you lbw when you hit it and caught when you did not.

Pakistan nurtured their own grievances from the Test series between the two sides during the English summer of 1987. They felt England had been arrogant in refusing to allow them to object to the English umpires David Constant and Ken Palmer - whom they mistrusted and despised - while they were under pressure to remove their own umpires at home. Pakistan were keen to see independent umpires in all Tests.

To complicate matters further, their captain Javed was determined to outdo his predecessor Imran Khan and beat England by more than a solitary win.

The first Test, in the words of those who played in it, was a joke. Countering the imposition on them of Constant and Palmer the previous summer, Pakistan ignored England's objection to Shakeel Khan. Abdul Qadir, who took nine for 56 in the first innings, would have embarrassed England anyway but the umpire made doubly sure.

In the second innings Chris Broad was given out caught at the wicket off the slow left-arm spinner Iqbal Qasim but refused to leave the crease for a full minute, and then not until he was persuaded to do so by his partner Graham Gooch. That Broad received no more than a "stern reprimand" from the England management, who in turn were publicly scathing about the umpiring following the defeat, further incensed the Pakistanis.

A Pakistan side that goes ahead at home can usually be relied on to sit on the lead. But Javed, sensing easy prey, wanted a second win. However, having called for a helpful surface in Faisalabad, he came unstuck as England posted a competitive score of 292, with Broad making 116 and Gatting clubbing 79 from 81 deliveries.

Then, despite some more questionable umpiring, England made good inroads into Pakistan's innings on the second day, reducing them to 77 for five. They were only 29 runs further on as the day drew to a close, with Eddie Hemmings bowling his off-spin to Salim Malik.

He was getting towards the end of his over when the fuse was lit. Keen to get an extra over in before stumps to get at the debutant Aamer Malik, Gatting, at short-leg, summoned David Capel in from the square-leg boundary to save a single, telling the batsman that this was what he was doing.

Salim Malik acknowledged. Hemmings was about to start his run-up when Gatting, realising Capel had come too far, gestured from behind his back for him to stop.

Shakoor Rana at square-leg decided to intervene, halting play and accusing Gatting of sharp practice. "It is unfair play," he said. "What is?" asked a puzzled Gatting. "You are waving your hand. That's cheating," replied Shakoor. Gatting said he had not been waving, merely telling the fielder to come no closer, that he had informed the batsman the fielder was moving but in any case it was the duty of the non-striker to keep his partner up to speed, and that, as he was the square-leg umpire, he should not interfere, go back there and let everyone get on with the game.

Shakoor walked away but then could contain himself no longer. "You are a fucking cheating cunt," he snarled. Gatting lost his temper and the finger wagging began.

Next day Shakoor refused to take the field unless he received an apology, which Gatting was prepared to offer if it was reciprocated. The two had reached agreement when Javed, recognising an opportunity to get off the hook in the game, told the umpire he and his family had been insulted and that he should not apologise. So an impasse was reached, with the tour manager Peter Lush undergoing an abortive overnight mission to see officials in Lahore, and Shakoor unshakeable in Faisalabad.

Finally, under pressure from the Foreign Office, who were wary of anti-British feeling, and mindful that they had yet to be paid their tour guarantee, the Test and County Cricket Board issued instructions for Gatting to get the game going "at any cost" by apologising unilaterally. Under protest, and to the disgust of his players, who broke their contract to issue a statement of their own, he did and the game resumed with a day lost. It promptly rained.

There was a bizarre finale to it all. Gatting received a letter from Shakoor later on the tour which expressed regret but had had the word "apologise" scrubbed out (at the time Gatting chose to keep quiet about this).

The TCCB chairman Raman Subba Row, to the incredulity of the England team, who thought they were being fined - the churlish behaviour was not one-sided - awarded them £1,000 each as a "hardship bonus". It was widely interpreted as conscience money.

Shakoor Rana at square-leg decided to intervene, halting play and accusing Gatting of sharp practice. "It is unfair play," he said. "What is?" asked a puzzled Gatting. "You are waving your hand. That's cheating," replied Shakoor. Gatting said he had not been waving, merely telling the fielder to come no closer, that he had informed the batsman the fielder was moving but in any case it was the duty of the non-striker to keep his partner up to speed, and that, as he was the square-leg umpire, he should not interfere, go back there and let everyone get on with the game. Shakoor walked away but then could contain himself no longer. "You are a fucking cheating cunt," he snarled. Gatting lost his temper and the finger wagging began. Next day Shakoor refused to take the field unless he received an apology, which Gatting was prepared to offer if it was reciprocated. The two had reached agreement when Javed, recognising an opportunity to get off the hook in the game, told the umpire he and his family had been insulted and that he should not apologise. It was widely interpreted as conscience money.

webTitle: More cash on way for counties

fields.headline: More cash on way for counties
fields.trailText: The England and Wales Cricket Board, under fire from players and counties alike, has pledged to make up the £50,000 shortfall in the revenues that each county will receive this year.
fields.body:
The England and Wales Cricket Board, under fire from players and counties alike, has pledged to make up the £50,000 shortfall in the revenues that each county will receive this year.

The 18 first-class counties and the 400 members of the Professional Cricketers' Association have expressed dissatisfaction at the board increasing central expenditure while cutting payments to the counties.

In an attempt to defuse the crisis, the ECB has now decided to gamble with profits that it ought to make in the future. It is expected to draw on money due to be paid by Channel 4 and Sky as part of their Test deal and pay it to the counties.

The board is pleading a £3m shortfall in profits this year because of early finishes to Test matches and, as a result, each county was warned that they could face a cut in income of around £50,000 each. There is anger too that no sponsors have materialised to replace Cornhill and NatWest.

The PCA, unhappy at the prospect of pay freezes and job losses, sent a vehement letter to the ECB chairman Lord MacLaurin last week demanding the removal of the board's chief executive Tim Lamb. They are believed to have a more militant strategy ready should they be ignored.

There is an element of risk to all this, though, for although the board is insistent that sponsorship replacements will be announced by the end of the year, the silence on the subject has been deafening. Furthermore, there is a strong possibility that either PPP Healthcare, who sponsor the County Championship, or CGU, who sponsor the National League, will not renew their contracts when they are up for renegotiation.

It could be then that the ECB administration is heading for some bloody times. Lamb is under severe pressure from counties and players, and the feeling within the board's hierarchy is that he will do well to survive.

The same applies to the ECB's marketing director Terry Blake, who failed to sell the requisite level of sponsorship during last year's World Cup and has yet to find new domestic sponsors. His asking price, according to a source, of £4.5m a year has been around 50% higher than interested parties believe the sponsorships are worth.

David Graveney's position as chairman of selectors may also become untenable should Lamb survive. As the PCA chief executive, Graveney is one of four signatories on their letter and, although he is reflecting the views of his membership, his relationship with Lamb must already be strained. If Lambstays and the PCA demands further action, it would be impossible for Graveney to remain in both camps.

Meanwhile MacLaurin, in Nairobi for today's International Cricket Council executive board meeting, will call for tougher measures against Pakistan cricketers, including Wasim Akram, implicated in match-fixing in the Qayyum Report.

The report recommended life bans for Salim Malik and Ata-ur-Rehman, but little more than slapped wrists for Wasim, Mushtaq Ahmed and others. Lord Griffiths, chairman of the ICC's code of conduct commission, has studied the findings and could recommend stronger action, but the latest indications are that he will not.

The ICC president Malcolm Gray was not about to hypothesise, but suggested that bans should be administered according to the agreement reached at last summer's full members' meeting at Lord's.

David Richards, the ICC chief executive, gave notice yesterday that he plans to quit, saying: "It is time for a new chief executive to take the ICC forward."

fields.headline: Cairns carries Kiwis to victory
fields.standfirst:
India 264-6
New Zealand 265-6
New Zealand win by four wickets
fields.trailText: The final New Zealand defeated India by four wickets yesterday to win the final in Nairobi and with it secured their first major one-day competition.
fields.body:
New Zealand stretched their necks at the death yesterday to beat India in the ICC Knockout Trophy final, a match in which they were chasing all day, and secure their first major one-day competition. Led by a brilliant unbeaten century from Chris Cairns, they won with two balls to spare, showing yet again that a well-organised team can punch above its weight in one-day cricket.

Sourav Ganguly was both the hero and villain for India. He scored a spectacular 117 from 130 balls but ran out the flower of his batting - Sachin Tendulkar and Rahul Dravid - and so contributed to a total at least 40 runs shy of what had earlier looked likely.

After disappointing crowds throughout the tournament Nairobi's large south Asian population turned out in force yesterday, greeting every run and wicket with uproar.

Tendulkar showed the way early, driving good-length balls and cutting anything remotely short. During his innings he became the heaviest scoring one-day batsman ever but he was run out for 69 when Ganguly called for a sharp single, then changed his mind. The innings faltered towards the end but their 264 still looked enough.

Nathan Astle and Roger Twose thought differently, attacking with gusto as the Kiwis raced to 61 off the first 10 overs. But two wickets apiece from Venkatesh Prasad and Anil Kumble put them on the back foot at 109 for four, at which point Cairns took control.

Despite a knee injury he batted first for respectability and then upped the tempo, putting on 122 with Chris Harris. Cairns brought up his century off 106 balls and, by the time Harris fell for 46, the deficit had been reduced to 11 runs. Three were required when Ajit Agarkar started the final over and, as the crowd chanted "we are losing it", Cairns and Adam Parore picked them off in singles.

webTitle: Year of Blanchflower's flourish when Spurs stood for style

fields.headline: Year of Blanchflower's flourish when Spurs stood for style
fields.trailText: Forty years ago this Saturday Tottenham Hotspur were managed by Bill Nicholson and captained by Danny Blanchflower. The club went on to win the double - what a time that was.
fields.body:
Forty years ago this Saturday Tottenham Hotspur drew their 12th First Division match of the season with Manchester City at White Hart Lane. They had won the first 11 and were to win their next four. By January 1, with 82 goals for and only 27 against, Spurs had 46 points from 25 matches - the only blemishes being a single defeat by Sheffield Wednesday and another draw, 4-4 against Burnley after the London club had led 4-0.

By that time bookmakers were accepting bets only on the points margin of the championship victory. They settled it by the middle of April with four matches to play. They had just one player booked throughout the season and only a single penalty awarded against them.

Tottenham then won the FA Cup, at a leisurely 2-0 stroll against Leicester City, and in so doing achieved the "impossible double" for the first time in the century. (Newcastle in 1905, Sunderland in 1913 and Manchester United in 1957 had each won the League but lost the Cup final).

Spurs were managed by Bill Nicholson, a gruffly avuncular Yorkshireman, and captained by a right-half, Danny Blanchflower, who was Northern Ireland's 1958 World Cup captain and a Celtic dreamer alive to football's creative possibilities.

Nicholson, son of a Scarborough horse-drawn cab driver, had been a half-back in Tottenham's Championship team a decade previously - the talented "push-and-run" side created by Arthur Rowe. He played for England once, in 1951, but cried off from a second appearance, saying his priority was to keep fit not for England but for Tottenham, who paid his wages.

When he took over as manager from Jimmy Anderson, Nicholson set down his philosophy: "The game has become tense and bound in fears. Everyone's trying to catch sparrows. I aim to recreate Mr Rowe's simple gospel: 'Make it plain, make it accurate, make it quick - especially quick.' First-time passing is the No1 secret; No2 is, 'when not in possession, get into position'."

In Nicholson's first full season, 1959-60, Tottenham had finished third (behind Burnley and Wolves) and were knocked out in the fifth round of the FA Cup by Blackburn. So he had inherited an impressive squad but before the start of 1960-61 Nicholson crucially added three Scots: the dependable goalkeeper Bill Brown, the delicate touch player John White and, to play alongside Blanchflower in midfield, the tirelessly aggressive Dave Mackay.

Returning from a short pre-season tour in Europe, Blanchflower struck a wager with the Tottenham chairman Fred Bearman. "We will win the Double for you. The game needs it to be achieved and, thanks to your spending in Scotland, we are now the team to achieve it."

The next day Bernard Joy quoted Blanchflower in the Evening Standard: "Mind you, football is not really about winning, or goals, or saves or supporters. It's about glory. It's about doing things in style, doing them with a flourish. It's about going out to beat the other lot, not waiting for them to die of boredom. It's about dreaming of the glory of the Double."

Within a week the Tottenham of Nicholson and Blanchflower set off on that League passage, still a First Division record, of 11 straight wins. Nor was it so much the victories but the glistening manner in which they were achieved. By the season's end in 42 League matches Spurs had scored an astonishing 115 goals. The runners-up Sheffield Wednesday scored 78.

Two-and-a-half million people watched Tottenham in their League and Cup games - an average crowd of 51,266 - believed to be the greatest number of spectators in British football history to watch a club in a single season.

Those of a certain generation - and not only in London but a host of football folk all over the world - can, at the drop of a beret or sunhat, recite trippingly off the tongue (Tottenham were fortunate with injuries) the Double side's enduring litany of 11: Brown, Baker, Henry, Blanchflower, Norman, Mackay, Jones, White, Smith, Allen, Dyson.

In February Tottenham visited Aston Villa on two successive Saturdays. First, in the League, they prevailed 2-1, the following week more easily in the FA Cup fifth round by 2-0. Between times the Daily Mail interviewed Nicholson and asked him his "Seven Steps to Spurs' Success". The manager replied:

1. Build-up of pressure through unorthodox moves;

2. All-round ability of every player;

3. Confidence bordering on cockiness;

4. Ability to vary game;

5. Failure of opponents to smother attacks;

6. Uncanny positional sense of Blanchflower, White and Mackay;

7. Intelligence to know when particularly intense pressure must be maintained;

Spurs took six points (only two for a win then) from their three Easter matches - 5-0 against Tom Finney's Preston and two strutting victories against Chelsea. When they defeated Wednesday, who had been nagging at them all winter, at an ecstatic White Hart Lane, the League title was achieved.

Three Fridays later, on the night before the Cup final at Wembley, Nicholson took his team to the Odeon cinema, Leicester Square, for a special late-night screening of The Guns of Navarone. Afterwards most of the players further relaxed with a couple of beers at their hotel. An Evening News reporter asked Blanchflower if such a pre-final preparation was not taking over-confidence a shade too far. Replied Danny:

"I can only tell you the story of Walter Hagen the golfer. He was up late before a crucial play-off match, and somebody told him, 'I suppose you know your opponent's been long in his bed?' 'Sure,' said Hagen, 'but do you think he's sleeping?'"

webTitle: New direct approach brings only pay-per-blues

fields.headline: New direct approach brings only pay-per-blues
fields.trailText: After the trials and tribulations of u>direct's pay-per-view coverage, I have come to a sobering conclusion - it's much more fun watching Scotland.
fields.body:
Was I the only person in Britain to watch the England match live in the comfort of my own home on Wednesday? I ask only because three separate radio stations, including the British Forces Broadcasting Service, rang me on Thursday morning to interview me about the experience. Fortunately I was able to reassure our plucky lads overseas (the forces, that is, not the England team) that, to paraphrase WC Fields, on the whole I would rather have been in Akrotiri.

I can understand why the world's media beat a path to my door. Given England's performance against Germany and the team chosen by Howard Wilkinson, the only people likely to go to the trouble of signing up for an away match in Helsinki were going to be television critics or inveterate masochists - and a lot of them tend to be ex-directory.

And for something that was not exactly the hottest ticket in town, you really did have to go to an awful lot of trouble to buy it. u>direct, as well as forcing us to search for the > symbol on our typewriters, require us to register with them before we can order a match.

To do this you have to remove your Sky viewing card, and key in on your telephone keypad a series of numbers, roughly the length of Bill Gates's monthly tax deduction . They don't tell you that you are going to have to do all this until you start the whole registration process, which means you have to put the telephone down while you look for your reading glasses, which you finally track down to the bathroom.

You also have to give them your credit card details, which I was rather uneasy about doing. The way I saw it this was more than making just one purchase on the telephone. These u>direct people now have my Visa number for all eternity, and could in theory charge me for all sorts of broadcasts. Whom do I complain to when Debbie Does Dallas shows up on my bank statement?

I pose the question because at no time in my convoluted telephone dealings with u>direct was I allowed the privilege of human communication. A mechanical voice quizzes you on vital personal details, such as address, post code, favourite member of the group Steps and so on, moving you on after each answer and giving you no chance to ask questions of your own like, "Is there a refund if he doesn't bring Owen on?", or "Can I get a receipt so I can claim the money back from The Guardian?"

This was of special interest to me, as I find it particularly hard in these tough times to justify £10 of the family budget going on an England match. I was toying with the idea of asking u>direct if they could disguise the purchase as late night pornography so as not to embarrass me, but there is no evidence that they actually employ a human being that I might ask.

Even their presenter Angus Scott, on the surface a human presence, raised doubts. He was perfectly relaxed and confident but bore a worrying resemblance to Steve Scott, who fronts Channel Five's football. Perhaps they are brothers but another explanation could be that a factory somewhere is turning out these Scotts for minority television channels who do not want to shell out for a Gary or Des.

What aroused my suspicions that Scott might be the result of an Invasion Of The Body Snatchers style scenario was his delivery of the words "And that result lifts us above Albania in the table" (true at the time), which he managed without any signs of the normal human impulse to emit a hollow laugh or at least to raise an ironic eyebrow. Actually, if he had really wanted to empathise with his poor customers at home, he would have broken down and wept, and started banging his head on the table.

It is so much more fun supporting Scotland. This week you could not only watch them for free achieve a creditable draw against Croatia but also enjoy a cracking documentary in which Alan Hansen relived the agony and ecstasy of their recent international history.

The programme was not much more than Hansen chatting to his old mates - Graeme Souness, Ally McCoist, Gary Lineker - about the habit of Scottish teams over the years of confounding all expectations but it was hugely enjoyable nostalgia.

Obviously, to get the flavour of all the unexpected triumphs and crashing disappointments, Hansen had to visit Argentina and Spain, where Scotland competed in the World Cups of 1978 and 1982.

I am not altogether sure, though, he needed to go to rural Virginia to see Robert Duvall, who is starring in a film about Scottish football. It reminded me of the Monty Python sketch, where Eric Idle strides towards the camera and says, "I"ve come to the Bahamas to show how expensive it can be to make these documentaries."

Still, Hansen picked up some interesting tales on his travels, including the cocktail waiter in Cordoba, who ran out of beer and vodka during Scotland's 1978 World Cup campaign. Apparently, some of the fans drank rather a lot as well.

martin@kelner.demon.co.uk

The programme was not much more than Hansen chatting to his old mates - Graeme Souness, Ally McCoist, Gary Lineker - about the habit of Scottish teams over the years of confounding all expectations but it was hugely enjoyable nostalgia. Obviously, to get the flavour of all the unexpected triumphs and crashing disappointments, Hansen had to visit Argentina and Spain, where Scotland competed in the World Cups of 1978 and 1982. I am not altogether sure, though, he needed to go to rural Virginia to see Robert Duvall, who is starring in a film about Scottish football. It reminded me of the Monty Python sketch, where Eric Idle strides towards the camera and says, "I"ve come to the Bahamas to show how expensive it can be to make these documentaries." Still, Hansen picked up some interesting tales on his travels, including the cocktail waiter in Cordoba, who ran out of beer and vodka during Scotland's 1978 World Cup campaign. fields.headline: Third Division  round-up
fields.trailText: Rochdale finally put some pressure on the leaders Chesterfield when they beat Hartlepool 2-1 to close the gap at the top to five points. The 41-year-old forward Tony Ford gave Rochdale the lead on his 885th league appearance before a Gary Jones penalty sealed the win.
fields.body:
Rochdale finally put some pressure on the leaders Chesterfield when they beat Hartlepool 2-1 to close the gap at the top to five points. The 41-year-old forward Tony Ford gave Rochdale the lead on his 885th league appearance before a Gary Jones penalty sealed the win.

Rochdale's promotion hopes were further boosted as Chesterfield's six-match winning streak came to an end at Exeter after an Andy Rawlinson penalty in the 87th minute earned the home side a 1-1 draw.

Paul Bracewell had an unhappy start to his new job at last-placed Halifax as they lost 2-0 to Brian Little's Hull. It was Hull's first away win of the season.

"It's not been easy so far," Little said. "I think people can lose confidence when you're not picking up the points away but this was a good result and I hope it's a sign of things to come."

But while Hull ended their losing streak, Carlisle's continued. Stuart Niven scored the fastest goal of the day in England - after just 44 seconds of his debut for Barnet - and Scott McGleish headed in Tony Richards's cross early in the second half to give the London club a 2-0 win - and Carlisle a seventh successive defeat.

Leyton Orient, who appear revitalised after a terrible time last season, kept up their challenge for a top-six place with a 2-1 win over Cardiff and there was a goal feast at Sincil Bank, where Lincoln drew 3-3 with Jan Molby's Kidderminster . Gavin Gordon scored twice for the home side, who have gone six games without a win.

fields.headline: Second Division  round-up
fields.trailText: Mark McGhee's first home game in charge of Millwall ended in a 4-0 win that moved his new charges to within one point of their opponents Bury and closed the gap between them and the division's leaders Walsall to five points.
fields.body:
Mark McGhee's first home game in charge of Millwall ended in a 4-0 win that moved his new charges to within one point of their opponents Bury and closed the gap between them and the division's leaders Walsall to five points.

Millwall's striker Neil Harris continues to shine, scoring twice to increase his tally for the season to nine. Headers from Lucas Neill and David Livermore completed the victory.

McGhee praised his side's use of their "creative licence", but Bury's player-manager Andy Preece felt hard done by. "This was never a 4-0 game," he said.

Reading moved into second place with victory over Wycombe. The Second Division's highest attendance of the season, 15,443, watched Martin Butler score his ninth goal of the season and Adi Viveash his first for Reading. Wanderers had Steve Brown sent off for violent conduct in the 64th minute.

Bristol City's impressive away form - they have conceded just one goal on their travels - continued as they held Walsall to a goalless draw at the Bescot Stadium.

Oxford United remain three points adrift at the bottom after losing 4-3 at home to Wrexham. "Our display mirrored the way things are here - a shambles," said Oxford's caretaker manager Mike Ford.

Notts County and Bristol Rovers are still without home wins. County had Andy Hughes and Mark Stallard sent off during their 2-2 draw with Wigan and Rovers lost 1-0 to Northampton at the Memorial Ground.

fields.headline: First Division  round-up
fields.trailText: Fulham may be stealing the headlines, but the rest of the division is refusing to give up the chase - the top eight all played at home on Saturday, and all but one won.
fields.body:
Fulham may be stealing the headlines, but the rest of the division is refusing to give up the chase - the top eight all played at home on Saturday, and all but one won.

Watford briefly rose to the top of the First Division with their seventh consecutive victory against QPR on Saturday, only to be toppled by Fulham's win yesterday.

Neil Cox put the home side in front, arriving unmarked to head in Paul Robinson's corner in the second minute. The same combination worked again 20 minutes later for Cox's second, and though Karl Connolly briefly gave Rovers hope, Gifton Noel-Williams's superb strike sealed the win.

Bolton and Birmingham both won 2-1, over Wolves and Crystal Palace respectively, to stay in touch with the leaders - although both have played one game more than the top two.

Despite three 1-0 scorelines, there were 39 goals in Saturday's 11 games. Eight of them came at Selhurst Park, where Gillingham held Wimbledon to a 4-4 draw. The Dons, twice a goal down, came back to steal the lead before Carl Asaba's 86th-minute equaliser ensured a share of the spoils for Andy Hessenthaler's side.

There was another goal feast at Oakwell. Neil Shipperley matched Chris Bart-Williams's two goals in the space of seconds in the second half but Nottingham Forest held on to beat Barnsley 4-3.

Grimsby climbed out of the bottom three by beating Steve Bruce's Huddersfield 1-0. Stockport took their place in the relegation zone after losing 2-1 at Burnley, who stay seventh.
