webTitle: McLean ends his career with a punch

fields.headline: McLean ends his career with a punch
fields.trailText: Jim McLean has called it a day at Tannadice. He decided to sever all ties with the club after lashing out at a reporter in the wake of the club's 4-0 home defeat to Hearts.
fields.body:
The former Dundee United chairman Jim McLean yesterday offered an unreserved public apology to a BBC television reporter after lashing out at him at Tannadice.

McLean, who subsequently quit as chairman, managing director and board member, struck John Barnes during an interview following Saturday's 4-0 home defeat by Hearts.

"I very much regret what has happened and I have offered my sincere apologies to John Barnes," said McLean. "I am particularly sorry that it was John of all people who was involved - he is an honest, hard-working lad who was only trying to do his job, as I was trying to do mine.

"Anyone who knows me, however, will know the passion I have for Dundee United and for football and I deeply regret that I allowed those feelings to cloud my judgment, albeit for one brief moment."

On Saturday night's Sportscene Match of the Day, BBC Scotland ran the unedited footage of McLean's interview with Barnes, in which McLean grew increasingly agitated. The interview concluded with McLean swearing at Barnes before side-stepping the camera and landing a blow on the reporter.

Barnes suffered a cut lip and had to be treated by the Dundee United club doctor. McLean, in the mean time, was dragged into hurried consultation with the rest of the United board, who were faced with no option but to request his resignation.

United issued a statement yesterday confirming that McLean had stepped down. It is understood that Barnes and the BBC will not be pressing charges. A Tayside Police spokesman confirmed yesterday that no complaint had been filed.

The Scottish Football Association, whose remit covers discipline within the Scottish game, are also in an odd position, given that McLean's resignation means there is now no longer any club official to be investigated.

The episode follows months of discomfort for McLean. His glory days as United manager have quickly been forgotten as the club's decline continued apace under his chairmanship. Saturday's humiliating defeat left them marooned at the bottom of the Premier League on two points from 11 matches, having scored only six goals.

The controversy is a sad way for McLean to end a magnificent career in football. In 1983 he broke the Old Firm stranglehold by winning the title. The following season, United were unlucky not to reach the European Cup final, being beaten 3-2 over two legs by Roma in the semis. Three years later United reached the Uefa Cup final, where they again lost out, this time to IFK Gothenburg.

Saturday's incident hogged all the headlines, unfortunately for Hibs, who beat Rangers 1-0 at Easter Road. Alex McLeish's side won through a David Zitelli goal in a rousing match that saw six players booked and Andrei Kanchelskis sent off. The result kept Hibs ahead of Rangers in the Premier League.

To complete a surreal Saturday Claudio Caniggia scored a 90th-minute goal to give Dundee a 2-0 win at Aberdeen in the Argentine forward's first appearance for the Dens Park club since his bewildering signing.

fields.headline: Heskey grabs triple crown
fields.standfirst: Owen's head injury takes gloss off stylish Liverpool show
fields.trailText:
Derby 0 - 4 Liverpool
Emile Heskey's hat-trick helps Liverpool into fourth.
fields.body:
A first senior hat-trick for Emile Heskey was counterbalanced by a head injury to Michael Owen as Liverpool elevated themselves to fourth place in the table yesterday at the expense of an exceptionally poor Derby team.

Owen was taken to hospital with six stitches in the back of his head, and possible mild concussion. "The boy is strong," Gérard Houllier said afterwards, refuting the suggestion that this had been the last straw in a fairly catastrophic week for Owen.

Owen was injured in the instant that Heskey scored the first of his goals from Gary McAllister's corner on 17 minutes. As Heskey slipped in front of Rory Delap at the near post, Owen fell in the goalmouth m lée and was raising his eyes to watch his fellow striker's glancing header hit the net when Chris Riggott's knee smashed into the back of his skull.

The referee, Stephen Bennett, immediately signalled for a stretcher. According to Heskey, Owen was out cold for a moment or two, but he had revived sufficiently by the time the stretcher bearers had carried him to the tunnel to make gestures indicating his desire to return. Instead he was taken to Derbyshire Royal Infirmary for an examination.

Owen's misfortune apart, this was a highly satisfactory afternoon for Liverpool's all-England strike force. To judge them by their performance against the bottom club might be ill advised, but Heskey was virtually irresistible while Robbie Fowler, who has started only one Premiership match in 13 months, took Owen's place and made the most of his extended opportunity. His instant through-ball eight minutes after half-time allowed Heskey to smash a spectacular right-foot shot past Mart Poom from just outside the penalty area, and his intuitive flick to Nick Barmby after 66 minutes inspired the low cross from which Heskey bundled the ball home to complete his scoring.

Barmby was also involved in the fourth goal, dummying Danny Murphy's pass 10 minutes from the end to give Patrik Berger the opportunity to score with a characteristically splendiferous left-foot drive from 20 yards. But almost the entire Liverpool team deserves the credit for that one, which came at the end of a long and patient build- up that revealed the extent of Derby's mental exhaustion. As the ball pinged around between the red shirts, the home players could only stand and stare.

"I hope today we started our season," Houllier said. "We haven't been satisfied with the play we've played so far. Today we gave a good team performance. The finishing was good, but mainly the passing and movement were better. I give a lot of credit today to the defence, because it's not often you deny any sort of a chance to the opposition. And when you defend well, you can attack freely."

McAllister and Murphy, who came off the bench when Veggard Heggem stretched a hamstring after five minutes, provided a solid platform for the strikers, who enjoyed themselves at the expense of a highly porous Derby rearguard. After Riggott had left the field just before half-time, Delap and Bjorn Otto Bragstad were unable to cope with the strength of Heskey and the fleetness of Fowler.

Both Jim Smith, the Derby manager, and Darryl Powell, his captain, used the word "passive" to describe their team's display. "The way Liverpool played today," Smith said, "we had to be at our very best, and we weren't. We were poor in the first half. That's what did my head in. We just sat off them. We felt after the first half if we stepped up we could get back into the game, but they got stronger. And they were very professional. They didn't showboat. They never stopped closing us down. They are good players and if you allow them to knock the ball around you're going to be in trouble."

Smith had sent Derby out with five players strung across midfield, but although the Finnish international Simo Valakari, who played against England on Wednesday, showed some nice touches, only the England Under-21 wing-back Seth Johnson displayed the kind of commitment that the manager was demanding. At the back they were simply undermanned, Malcolm Christie was outnumbered up front, and Georgi Kinkladze lost interest.

Having asked the fans to save their criticism for the final whistle, Smith was forced to listen to the inevitable boos from those who stayed to the end. "I can't blame them," Powell said. "This is my fifth year in this league and today is as bad as it's felt. We never really threatened them at any stage. It hurts."

For Heskey - with only one goal to his name in the league this season - the match represented a thorough justification of Houllier's faith. "Emile is too nice a guy," the manager said. "He has tremendous assets - he's quick, he's powerful and he's more skilful than he thinks. He needs to believe in himself more, and sometimes he needs to be more selfish."

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Weah on his way as City march on

fields.headline: Weah on his way as City march on
fields.trailText:
Man City 2 - 0 Bradford
George Weah set to walk as City march on.
fields.body:
George Weah's marriage of convenience with Manchester City is teetering on the brink of divorce after he demanded talks with Joe Royle that are likely to precipitate his departure from Maine Road.

Weah is scheduled to meet the City manager this morning and the likelihood is that his contract will be terminated after he indicated that he is unwilling to stay at Maine Road unless he can be guaranteed first-team football.

This was the fourth match of the season that he has been left on the bench and for a man of his amour propre, a weekly salary of three, four or five times that of his team-mates is only intensifying his frustration.

Indeed, only three months after becoming the highest-paid player in City's history he has let it be known that he has become disillusioned with Royle.

Weah failed to make a scheduled appearance as the guest analyst on a Granada football show last night and Royle, having emphatically denied there was a problem 24 hours earlier, confirmed they would be holding talks. "I'll be meeting George to discuss his future," he said.

The unlikely figure of Paul Dickov is keeping Weah on the bench and he vindicated Royle's faith with another excellent display against beleaguered Bradford, scoring with a sumptuous strike to open the scoring after 30 minutes.

Coincidentally, City will take a duster to its trophy cabinet this week and clear a gap among the gleaming relics of happier days for a new keepsake: the patch of Wembley grass where Dickov scored that goal 94 minutes into their Second Division play-off final against Gillingham.

The snorts of derision emanating from Old Trafford no longer rankle quite so much. For City, it was that moment more than any other that can be traced back as was the catalyst for their remarkable transformation. The turf will be watered lovingly

Two-and-a-half years on and Dickov's longevity is surprising everyone - not least Weah. The man who could not hold down a regular place in the Second Division two seasons ago is now the man who is keeping the former World Footballer of the Year on the bench.

"I never have a wage sheet with me in the dug-out," Royle stated before the extent of Weah's disaffection became more widely known. "Because George is the star, there will always be questions asked when he is left out. But Manchester United have Dwight Yorke on the bench and no one makes a fuss of it.

"There will be times when George plays and times when he doesn't. But that goes for everyone. Kevin Horlock is an international player and he was on the bench as well."

Comparing Weah to Horlock is similar to assessing the different merits of Pavarotti and a karaoke champion but everyone knew what Royle meant. City are ego-free and happy to stay that way.

Besides, if possession is nine tenths of the law, Dickov's case would no longer be laughed out of court. The indefatigable little Scottish international striker has added a new dimension to his game and his volleyed goal, catching a dropping ball with the outside of his right foot, illuminated an otherwise murky affair.

"Even now, at the age of 27, he is still learning," said Royle. "It was a goal that would probably have gone in the stands a couple of seasons ago."

Functional rather than inspirational, Royle's men should survive with something to spare if they can avoid suspensions and injuries. Otherwise this could be a First Division fixture next season.

So far this season Bradford have averaged a league goal every three hours 37 minutes and once Alfie Haaland's shot had deflected in off Stuart McCall to double the lead just before half-time the win bonuses could have been counted out there and then.

webTitle: Spurs in dark without Sol power

fields.headline: Spurs in dark without Sol power
fields.trailText:
Coventry 2 - 1 Tottenham
Tottenham find themselves in the dark without Sol power.
fields.body:
Sol Campbell returns to Tottenham's training ground this morning to continue his recuperation from a dislocated shoulder after being given the week off. George Graham will be hoping the holiday snaps are from Lourdes rather than Lanzarote.

A miraculous recovery for Tottenham's totem seems to be the main hope Graham has of reviving a season which began with sights on a place in Europe but which already seems to be coming apart at the seams. The chants of "Graham out" and even "Graham for England" on Saturday showed what Tottenham's fans think of it.

The weaknesses in Spurs' defence - which has conceded six goals in the last two games - compounded by a willingness on the part of several players, not least the captain Tim Sherwood, to criticise errors, gave Tottenham the air of a side ill at ease with itself on Saturday.

Coventry were able to cruise into a 2-0 lead by half-time. That they were clinging on at the end after Sergei Rebrov scored for Tottenham was less to do with the away side or even the dismissal of Carlton Palmer but more to do with a nervousness born out of not previously having achieved a league win at home all season.

Graham agreed afterwards that Campbell had been sorely missed but, while he admitted his squad needed "five or six" players, he claimed that recent searches had proved fruitless.

"We're way behind the Arse nals and Uniteds in the squad we've got. There's a lot of clubs in a similar position - Everton and Newcastle are also big clubs - and we're playing catch-up," Graham said.

"We can't afford to lose our most influential players for long periods. We just don't have the squad to carry it. I know there's a problem; the solution is the difficulty but there's a lack of quality players, not just domestically but in Europe as well."

Steffen Freund, the Tottenham midfielder, described his side's first-half performance as "terrible and our attitude was wrong" but he offered his support to Graham. "It's not about the manager, nor one player. It's the team and everyone has to look at himself."

They could perhaps take inspiration from John Aloisi, who scored his fifth goal in three games since returning to Coventry's starting line-up with a rasping shot from 25 yards after 12 minutes.

City doubled their lead when Craig Bellamy got away with a high-footed challenge on Chris Perry before rounding Ramon Vega and squaring the ball for John Eustace to slot home.

Rebrov's emphatic finish gave Spurs hope of rescuing the game, and their cause was helped when Palmer was sent off with 20 minutes remaining for kicking out at Perry. Les Ferdinand sent a clear header from six yards tamely wide before Sherwood headed on to the bar, but City held on.

Graham hopes Campbell will return the weekend after next when Tottenham begin a run of games against six of last season's top-eight teams. It may just be in time to save Graham's and Tottenham's season.

fields.headline: Ipswich benefit from plain English
fields.trailText:
Ipswich 1 - 1 West Ham
Ipswich let 'sloppy' West Ham of the hook.
fields.body:
Everyone has a view on England and the West Ham manager Harry Redknapp has a view on everything. Ipswich, though, quietly making their place in the Premiership, may have the answer.

Redknapp is in no doubt that Terry Venables is the man - "We want him to coach our football team, not govern the Bank of England" - and that the team should be built around Rio Ferdinand. "He is what English football has been crying out for, someone who can come out from the back with the ball. If he was French, we'd be saying 'what a player'."

And, if he was German and playing in the middle of the back three, instead of on the right, we would have a better chance to judge whether he is the new Kaiser. Ferdinand has long been cool on the ball and promising. Alongside Igor Stimac he seldom ventured upfield and exerted little influence. It is time he moved forward.

That chance to judge may come by misfortune. Stimac suffered a gashed leg in the last minute, leaving Redknapp thin at the back. It was a hapless day for the Croatian. He was caught napping as Marcus Stewart nipped in for a sharp, glancing header that West Ham took more than an hour to cancel through Paolo di Canio's clinical, angled volley.

"We walked into positions and didn't pull the trigger," said Redknapp, quaintly believing that West Ham were worth their point. "It's so hard to work with our front two [Di Canio and Frédéric Kanouté] when they and Joe Cole play off the cuff. They're not like normal strikers. You take what you get."

But he made it clear it was more fun taking the unexpected than pumping balls up to a big man who can only knock them down. So John Hartson can turn his mobile off.

On a day when all uncapped Englishmen might have felt the spring of opportunity in their step, Cole was subdued and Michael Carrick frustrated on the bench as West Ham's midfield laboured in the hands of Nigel Winterburn and Steve Lomas, newly cropped as a teasel. "We started sloppy," said Redknapp. "It's impossible after internationals. We didn't see nine of our players until Friday."

It did not impair Ipswich, who had nearly as many away. They started slick and maintained it through a system as lullingly rhythmic as knitting, maddening to opponents in its simple denial of possession before bursting from patience to urgency. The constant movement of players off the ball gave the man on it the confidence of options to spare.

It revolved round Jim Magilton and Matt Holland, both Irishmen, and was inclusively comfortable. Titus Bramble, a better bet than Ferdinand for England, was absent but Jamie Clapham, happily left-footed, crowned a fine game with an impish nutmeg and backheel.

The system, carried faithfully from the First Division, is as clear as plain English. Redknapp, back in his hat of perspective, was impressed: "They've nice shape, good passing, loads of movement." England should beat a path and see how. It is Venables' type of game.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Harris lives in fear of the drop

fields.headline: Harris lives in fear of the drop
fields.standfirst: Card trouble may see referee leave Premier League list
fields.trailText:
Arsenal 1 - 0 Aston Villa
Referee Bob Harris under fire as Arsenal go joint top.
fields.body:
It is one of football's favourite clichés, much loved by struggling managers, that no one is relegated by Christmas. After embarrassing himself again on Saturday, the referee Rob Harris could discover the saying does not hold true in his case.

The Oxford official extended his impressive list of recent cock-ups by somehow forgetting he had booked Aston Villa's Lee Hendrie twice and is now in serious danger of being demoted from the panel of Premier League referees when it is reassessed at the end of next month.

Harris was removed from the list for a month at the start of the year for allowing Tranmere to substitute a player he had sent off against Sunderland in the FA Cup. But this is the first time mid-season relegation has been introduced and he can hardly be confident of survival.

A year ago he wrongly dismissed Liverpool's Steve Staunton, ironically against Villa, for encroaching at a free-kick. At Tottenham in April he was at the centre of more controversy involving John Gregory's side when he missed a penalty for handball, spotted by his assistant, and seemed ready to send off Stephen Clemence for an offence he had not committed.

The opposite would have been the case here had Arsenal's players, led by Gilles Grimandi, not reminded Harris that Hendrie's foul on Robert Pires had brought him a second caution in nine minutes. Perhaps the official thought he had a didgeridoo rather than a whistle, imagined he was in fact Rolf Harris and had asked: "Can you guess what it is yet?"

The Premier League is expected to look into the incident today and should consider introducing memory tests, never mind fitness tests, for referees. It will hardly help Harris's cause that among those watching were Mike Foster and Adrian Cook, the secretary and assistant secretary of the Premier League, as well as the match assessor Gerald Ashby.

"He's not a referee," Gregory said tartly of Harris, adding of the dismissal: "Everyone in the ground knew. There's a bloody great scoreboard in the corner with a yellow symbol next to Lee's name."

To Villa's credit they refused to blame Arsenal for reminding Harris of Hendrie's fate. Gregory described the midfielder as "a prat" for throwing the ball away to earn his first booking and Gareth Southgate's analysis hinted at the same conclusion. "He's got to learn," he said. "He can be a bit tempestuous."

Harris' sideshow stole some of the limelight from Thierry Henry, who scored another spectacular winner to put Arsenal level at the top with Manchester United, and the outstanding Southgate.

Abused by his own fans this season for wanting to leave, misused by Kevin Keegan for 45 minutes against Germany and accused of lacking passion against Finland, the Villa captain performed here as if he had not a care in the world.

"It's been a tough week because everyone's been sniping," Southgate said. "Ex-players have been having a go at us." For the snipers who claimed England played without passion Gregory had some simple messages: "absolute tosh" and "quite appalling". Villa were neither. Indeed, if they had had a cutting edge to go with their organisation and Paul Merson's inspiration they might have won.

In the first half in particular Arsenal looked vulnerable and out of sorts. But Henry, as against Manchester United, came to his side's rescue.

Given a rare sight of goal from Pires's pass, he shot expertly across David James and, when Hendrie departed five minutes later, there was no way back for Villa.

As Henry celebrated his winner and Wenger's decision to ignore England - "he's the most important thing to this club" - the striker also hinted at the psychological burden involved in chasing Manchester United.

"You expect them to win, so that puts you under pressure," he said. But unlike Harris he knows nothing will be decided by Christmas.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Leeds hopes land in Robinson's hands

fields.headline: Leeds hopes land in Robinson's hands
fields.trailText:
Leeds 3 - 1 Charlton
Viduka gets a brace as Leeds lose their 'keeper for four weeks.
fields.body:
It is a good job that Paul Robinson has broad shoulders because for the next four weeks Leeds United's hopes of a successful season will rest squarely upon them.

The reserve goalkeeper was called off the bench in the 71st minute when Nigel Martyn injured his groin and now England's No2 will be watching from the sidelines as his replacement forms the last line of defence in a series of games that could make the labours of Hercules look like a beach party in Corfu.

During that time Leeds play, among others, Manchester United, Barcelona, Liverpool, Milan and Chelsea - some key to the first-team door for a back-up keeper with just five first-team appearances behind him before Saturday and who turned 21 only yesterday. But he was not about to let it faze him.

"The lads have just made me aware of it in the dressing room," he said. "But if you want to play for Leeds you have got to play in these sort of games. It's my job to pick up where Nigel left off and do the best I can for the club and hopefully some good results will come my way. I'll just try my best, that's all I can do."

At 6ft4in and 14st plus he does not look the type to be easily unnerved and he would, he promised, take each game as it comes - and that includes next Wednesday's potentially volatile Champions League match in Turkey. "It's funny how it works out. But you've got to play in these matches if you want to be in contention for the first team."

His appearances in the Premiership may be limited but as the England Under-21 goalkeeper the genial giant from Beverley is used to handling pressure and he acquitted himself well in the 20 minutes he played on Saturday. He was, admittedly, beaten by Claus Jensen's speculative long shot but that was almost a freak occurrence for Charlton, whose overall play was disappointing and who were two goals down at that stage anyway.

As usual it was Robinson's Under-21 team-mate Alan Smith who was at the thick of things at the end of a week that was eventful even by his standards. Sent off after scoring against Finland on Tuesday, he again threw down a marker in the race for the showers with a horrible lunge on Richard Rufus in the 65th minute.It was definitely a red card offence but curiously the referee Mike Dean chose to take no action.

David O'Leary adopted the usual manager's stance and said it did not merit a sending-off, and Rufus, who later limped off, reducing his side to 10 men, and who reappeared outside the dressing-room door with heavy white strapping around his ankle, said he would need to see the incident before he could comment.

The better side of the striker was seen to impressive effect in the 38th minute when he thumped in Mark Viduka's lay-off, left-footed. In the 73rd minute Smith chased what appeared to be a lost cause, pulled the ball back from the byline and Viduka executed an audacious pirouette to flick the ball into the top of the net with his heel. Four minutes into injury-time and Smith's glancing header set up Viduka for the third.

It was the Australian's fourth league goal in five games and the Englishman's seventh in eight and they are turning into a fearsome combination. "An understanding takes time but I think we've started off pretty well," said Viduka, a £7m buy from Celtic in the summer.

Charlton showed few signs of taking the game to Leeds. Several times they broke with swift assurance only to put their foot on the ball at the killer moment and allow the home side to regroup. Their next four weeks are considerably easier for them than Leeds and games against Middlesbrough, Bradford and Ipswich should at least allow them to consolidate their top-half position.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: The inside track:
fields.standfirst: Fundraising
fields.trailText: Fundraising
fields.body:
Many people approach charitable bodies - including the arts, which are largely subsidised by donations from public and private money - under the assumption that an organisation that lives off hand-outs will be grateful for any assistance, and will accordingly bend job descriptions to suit the skills of the applicant. They will invariably be disappointed.

Another resentment that donors harbour concerns the amount of money sucked into administration. Retired people chipping in for good causes, children on sponsored walks and those who have been wheeled around town in a bath of baked beans gasp on hearing that the head of fund-raising at their favourite charity earns £40,000 pa.

But fundraising is a competitive business. It is not that charities hold small donors in contempt. High-profile events, such as Comic Relief and Children in Need, do as much to mask the generosity of the public as to celebrate it. The sums raised sound highly impressive, but in fact are typical of the amount handed over every day.

The corporate wallet is equally important: Britain's flint-hearted capitalists are a valued source of revenue. They have no more inclination to squander their donations than anyone else and will judge a charity by the professionalism and efficiency of its administration.

While they have little room for amateurs, non-profit making organisations tend to be relaxed, egalitarian places. They are dedicated to a cause, and a certain esprit de corps is naturally built up. The job is a reward in itself - just as well, because as surprising as the salaries of top charity professionals may be to donors, the charity sector lags behind the pay scales of most other sectors.

But it does offer one advantage: promotion prospects are good. Charities tend to recruit employees with experience of other charities, so the gap between support staff and mangement is less pronounced than in business.

webTitle: Showdown that showed up the hype

fields.headline: Showdown that showed up the hype
fields.trailText:
Leicester 0 - 3 Man Utd
Leicester brought down to earth by under-strength United.
fields.body:
Until Christmas the Premiership table should carry an extra column. A simple Y or N, for yes or no, would indicate whether or not teams have played Manchester United.

Not only would this add a sense of reality to the league positions, it would also prevent the sort of match Filbert Street witnessed on Saturday being hyped up as a "top-of-the-table clash", a "showdown" or a "summit shoot-out".

No fair person would have begrudged Leicester City their fortnight's leadership of the Premiership, nor their pleasure of anticipation in taking on the champions as top dogs. But, as a United side lacking six of its regular players dismantled Leicester's presumptuousness with the routine efficiency of a surgeon removing an appendix, it became clear that Peter Taylor's side, far from belonging to the upper table, were definitely below the salt.

Nothing should be taken away from Leicester's excellent start to the season. Having lost Martin O'Neill's passionate style of management to Celtic the team were expected to take a while to settle under the pragmatic, less emotional Peter Taylor. Instead Leicester have thrived on the coaching and organisational skills which Taylor brought first to the England Under-21s and later to Gillingham.

Before Saturday their defence had conceded two goals in eight Premiership matches and in the league they have yet to let one in away from home. In Neil Lennon, Robbie Savage and Muzzy Izzet, moreover, they have a better midfield than most.

None of which cut much ice with Manchester United, who controlled Saturday's match from start to finish without seriously breaking sweat. With Roy Keane directing operations in the massively authoritative manner of a regimental sergeant-major in the Irish Guards, Teddy Sheringham drifting into space at will, link ing the play and scoring twice, and youngsters like Wes Brown and Quinton Fortune gaining in stature all the time, the game struggled to become a serious contest.

It was a timely victory for United, who since beating Everton 3-1 at Goodison four weeks earlier had been held to 3-3 at home by Chelsea before losing in quick succession to PSV Eindhoven in the Champions League and 1-0 at Arsenal. "We needed a good performance," said Ferguson, now contemplating Wednesday's return match against PSV followed by Leeds United's visit to Old Trafford on Saturday.

Especially pleasing for the United manager was the way his spare parts responded after a similar selection had suffered such a demoralising defeat in Eindhoven. "I was criticised for the team I picked against PSV," Ferguson said, "but I felt I had to do it.

"You have to keep an eye on the big picture. It's a long season and there are always big games coming up. You've got to trust your players. We had 10 internationals out there today and they don't get those caps for nothing."

It seems reasonably safe to assume that most of those who missed Saturday's match will return on Wednesday night. Ryan Giggs, who played for the last 18 minutes against Leicester, and Paul Scholes will be there and so will Andy Cole provided an ankle injury has healed.

Ferguson also expects David Beckham, who missed Eng land's World Cup match in Finland with a knee injury, to be fit. "He could have played today," the United manager admitted. But Jaap Stam, who has had exploratory surgery on a ruptured achilles, looks unlikely to be available until February.

The lack of Stam's presence at centre-back is bound to be a handicap as United strive to reach the second group phase of the Champions League while maintaining their challenge in the Premiership. Yet the maturing qualities of the 20-year-old Brown could go a long way towards making up for the Dutchman's absence.

"Wes Brown has got the class to become a top player," Ferguson enthused on Saturday. "He may have the odd rash moment but you get that in young players."

Brown and Ronny Johnsen dealt easily with most of Leicester's attacks, the best chance falling to Gary Rowett in the first half when a free-kick from Lennon found the defence concentrating on Matt Elliott and leaving Rowett free. But from a narrowish angle he lifted his shot over the bar.

The rest was largely down to Sheringham, who nodded United ahead from Denis Irwin's cross eight minutes before half-time and increased their lead 10 minutes after the interval when he followed up after Tim Flowers had parried Irwin's long shot. Ole Gunnar Solskjaer accepted a return ball from Dwight Yorke to complete the scoring in stoppage time.

webTitle: Happy Phillips turns the spotlight on Chelsea's lack of firepower

fields.headline: Happy Phillips turns the spotlight on Chelsea's lack of firepower
fields.trailText:
Sunderland 1 - 0 Chelsea
Two see red as Kevin Phillips highlights Chelsea's lack of firepower.
fields.byline: Dominic Fifield at the Stadium of Light
fields.body:
Conspiracy theories abounded as the red-and-white army of Mackems waited patiently to gain entry to the ground on Saturday afternoon. Rumour had it that the careless underground worker who had drilled through an electricity cable on the Metro extension - plunging the Stadium of Light into darkness - was a mischievous Chelsea supporter haunted by last December's 4-1 thrashing here and anxious to avoid further embarrassment.

If so, his efforts came to naught as the home side, when given the chance 45 minutes late, found Chelsea somewhat easier to overcome than the stadium's draconian fire regulations. "By the time we finished I thought they might have appointed a new England manager," said the Sunderland manager Peter Reid.

For their third successive trip to Wearmouth, Chelsea were outplayed and well beaten. That the margin of the home side's victory was so slender was a travesty - Julio Arca had what appeared to be a legitimate goal ruled out, à la Ray Parlour in Helsinki, when his shot cannoned off the underside of the crossbar, and the visitors' goalkeeper Ed de Goey was at full stretch to deny Niall Quinn on three occasions.

Indeed, Quinn should have opened the scoring after 62 minutes but, under challenge from Mario Melchiot, his point-blank header was clawed out by De Goey. The referee Jeff Winter penalised Melchiot's tug on the Irishman's shirt and Kevin Phillips thumped home the penalty.

Phillips had been linked with a move away from Wearside to further his England chances, much to his man ager's amazement."If he has got a problem, he hasn't told me," said Reid. "On the whole big club thing, Andy Cole plays for Manchester United and he struggles to get into the England team. They're a fairly big club, wouldn't you say?"

"I was misquoted," said Phillips. "I want to set things straight. I'm very happy at Sunderland. I've played for England while I've been here and it would be daft of me to want to leave. We've showed we can mix it with the big boys."

And mix it they did, although the 66th-minute fracas that left both sides a player short was probably not what Phillips had in mind. Graeme le Saux, who had been booked for a foul on Kevin Kilbane earlier in the half, flung his right arm back and caught the Irish winger in the face. The assistant referee signalled for a throw-in, prompting Kilbane to shove the Chelsea left-back to the ground. Winter dispersed the resulting ruck by dismissing the pair.

"The referee had no choice, but the sending-off actually unsettled our balance," said Reid, who watched Phillips do a tidy job at right-back. To complete the surreal scenario, Chelsea's full-back Albert Ferrer finished the game playing as a third striker.

But the Spaniard's foray forward was indicative of his side's inability to make an attacking impression. Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink was substituted at half-time, and the incisive verve that yielded six goals in their previous Premiership games against Manchester United and Liverpool was non-existent.

"We would have liked to have created more to hurt Sunderland, but I was pleased with the spirit and I would like to compliment my players," said Ranieri, who thumped the roof of the dug-out in frustration near the end.

fields.headline: Fernandes keeps Fulham flying
fields.trailText:
Fulham 2 - 1 Blackburn
Back to the top for ten-out-of-ten Fulham.
fields.body:
And the next one please. Fulham duly dispatched Blackburn Rovers yesterday afternoon to extend their perfect start to the Nationwide season to 10 games. On this form it is hard to see anyone preventing Jean Tigana's team stretching that run to 46.

By common consent, there is no other side in the First Division on the same plane as Fulham when it comes to "playing football". Though Rovers ran the London side close in the second half, there was always an inevitability about the result, even against a side who themselves spent £4m on players over the summer and were the pre-season favourites to win the division.

The partnership forged between Tigana and Mohamed al Fayed has, it seems, all but guaranteed Fulham's return to the top flight for the first time since they were relegated from the old First Division in 1968. The team's immediate aim, however, is to beat Reading's league-record start to the season of 13 wins.

If they do eventually go up, Fulham will be the most heavily bankrolled side to graduate since Blackburn themselves, eight years ago. Al Fayed has forked out £20m on players since arriving at the club and, like the late Jack Walker at Rovers, has discovered that money can buy success.

More cash will be needed to make an impact in the Premiership, but Al Fayed's pockets are bottomless and Fulham can emulate Blackburn who, three years after being promoted, were league champions.

The Frenchman Tigana has shown himself to be not so much a quick learner about British football, as possessed with the strength of character to impose his own views on how the game here should be played. His team, back on top of the division, are all comfortable in possession, imaginative in their passing and movement and willing to run at opponents with the ball.

Confidence has grown and though they went behind to a fourth-minute goal, Fulham hit back with such an array of attacking options that Rovers were bamboozled. As a result they sat far too deep and allowed the home side to control the midfield.

The player who best took advantage was Fabrice Fernandes, a two-footed 20-year-old left-winger on loan from Rennes whose skills caused Rovers all sorts of problems.

Tigana believes in width, and on the other wing the strength and pace of the former Chelsea player Bjarne Goldbaek was equally devastating. Combined with the runs and turns of the front two Luis Boa Morte and Barry Hayles, the Rovers defence were left in a right old spin.

All this after Blackburn, seeking their first away win since March, had taken the lead when Matt Jansen was allowed to waltz through the Fulham defence and plant the ball past Maik Taylor.

Jansen then nearly put Noel Blake in for a second, before Fulham got a grip and equalised through Fernandes. Jeff Kenna allowed him to run into the area and fire a shot which John Filan should have stopped but which nonetheless nestled in the net.

Hayles then went close on several occasions before the break, Fernandes shot just wide and the referee Uriah Rennie declined Fulham what seemed a penalty when Gary Flitcroft brought down Lee Clark.

But once Rovers had sorted out their midfield in the second half, they went close to taking the lead. Blake headed just over, Craig Hignett hit the bar and Stig Bjornebye forced Taylor into a rare save.

Ironically, it was during this period that Fulham scored again. Goldbaek fed Louis Saha and the division's leading scorer, on as a substitute, was felled in the area by Henning Berg. Saha duly converted the penalty for his 11th goal of the season, to keep Fulham on the road to the Premiership.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Claridge bets on temperance society
fields.trailText:
Portsmouth 2 - 1 Sheff Wed
Player-manager Steve Claridge helps anchor Wednesday to the bottom.
fields.body:
Those expecting to see a change in Steve Claridge now that he is calling the shots at Portsmouth were quickly disabused of the idea as he filed on to the pitch with his right sock trailing around his ankle.

Pompey's maverick player-manager has come a long way, nine league clubs and 11 moves, in fact, since the then manager Alan Ball released him as a 17-year-old and the heartbroken local lad promptly went out and blew his £500 severance pay at the bookies.

The gambling, he says, has been curbed; players borrowed by his predecessor Tony Pulis have returned to their clubs; the veteran Guy Whittingham has been recalled from loan at Oxford to help with coaching; and everyone in the squad has been promised a chance.

Scott Hiley, transfer-listed and a former team-mate of Claridge's at Birmingham, was the first recipient of the player-manager's largesse, and he duly played a full part in a win that was more one-sided than the scoreline suggests.

"The dressing room is a more joyous place now," Hiley said. "That's Steve's strength. All the lads want to do it because the manager wants to play football, not just keep sticking it in the corners."

To that end, Claridge has asked the goalkeeper to throw rather than kick the ball out and has decreed that the team play down both flanks. He has also imposed a weekday alcohol ban on his players.

"I'm not having them coming in to training stinking of booze, which has happened with a couple of them this season. This is our job," he said, ever mindful of the fact that he may be back in the ranks in four months, depending on the outcome of Pulis's sabbatical.

"We're not as good as Fulham but we want to play some semblance of football. I was at Leicester for two years and I think we gave away one cheap game in that time. That's what I want here."

What Paul Jewell wants for his Wednesday team right now is a point, any old point, after this their seventh successive league defeat, which matched a club record set in 1893 and left them four points adrift of safety at the bottom of the table.

Jewell cited a lack of confidence but hopes to give the club a lift it by signing a striker before tomorrow's trip to Burnley.

"We urgently need somebody up front to give us a bit of firepower and a cutting edge," he said. "We need someone who can get in behind defences and hopefully I can sort that out by the Burnley game."

His team did shape up briefly, however, after Terry Cooke appeared and the on-loan substitute soon played in Owen Morrison to score from the left of the area, but Pompey were two goals ahead by then.

The first was a well-taken shot by Thomas Thogersen, who was set up by Claridge, the second a close-range header by the player-manager. Some things never change.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Bolton to reward vintage Marshall
fields.trailText:
Bolton 2 - 1 Wolves

Bolton keep up the chase behind the division's pace-setters.
fields.byline: Christopher Stocks  at the Reebok Stadium
fields.body:
Ian Marshall is one of football's survivors: an honest and hard-working character without the petulance and pretensions of the more high profile among his profession.

He may never have been considered for a place in the England squad, but his experience in defence and attack with Oldham, Ipswich and Leicester makes him a valuable asset to Sam Allardyce's Bolton.

Released by Leicester in the summer, three days before Martin O'Neill departed for Celtic, the 34-year-old journeyman turned down a move to US Major League Soccer before opting for Bolton on a pay-per-play, non-contract deal.

After being an integral part of Joe Royle's promotion-winning Oldham side in 1991 and then fighting to establish himself in the Premiership with Ipswich and Leicester, his experience could prove vital to Bolton's top-flight ambitions.

Marshall has switched to central defence in a bid to prolong his career, and on Saturday he was omnipresent in a Bolton win that helped keep up the pressure on the early pace-setters, Fulham and Watford.

From his position in the centre of defence, Marshall saw his team-mate Dean Holdsworth put Bolton ahead on 27 minutes with a curler from 25 yards. However, after the former Wimbledon man was forced off with a groin strain a minute from the interval and replaced by Mark Fish, Marshall was forced to take up a more familiar attacking role.

Fish was caught cold, upending upended the lively Michael Branch to allow Tony Dinning to put the visitors back on terms from the penalty spot after 53 minutes, but 15 minutes later Marshall set up Gudni Bergsson with a sublime return pass that allowed the Icelander to chip the advancing Michael Oakes and seal Bolton's first win in three games.

Allardyce praised the contribution of Marshall, who finished the game back in defence, and confirmed that the player would be rewarded with a contract next week. "I'm sure that we can get him signed up," he said.

For his part, Marshall feels that his present club can achieve the success that Leicester experienced under O'Neill. "There's a lot of mirror images with Leicester," Marshall said. "Bolton have a good fighting spirit, there's no big stars in the team and everyone pulls together and works with each other.

"I'd regard it as an achievement in the summer, even if I did get released, to help get Bolton to the Premier League - that's the main aim."

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

"I'm sure that we can get him signed up," he said. For his part, Marshall feels that his present club can achieve the success that Leicester experienced under O'Neill. "There's a lot of mirror images with Leicester," Marshall said. "Bolton have a good fighting spirit, there's no big stars in the team and everyone pulls together and works with each other. "I'd regard it as an achievement in the summer, even if I did get released, to help get Bolton to the Premier League - that's the main aim."  You've read the piece, now have your say. webTitle: Ball bounces back to mask Everton's shortcomings

fields.headline: Ball bounces back to mask Everton's shortcomings
fields.trailText:
Everton 1 - 1 Southampton
Michael Ball bounces back to mask Everton's shortcomings.
fields.body:
For just £4, those Everton supporters whose sense of taste is eclipsed by unswerving devotion to the cause can now buy a rather scary plastic mask that purports to resemble the finely chiselled features of Duncan Ferguson.

The obvious conclusion is that these less than flattering replicas have been mass-produced to remind Merseysiders that the towering Scot is still at the club. But who knows, with Halloween coming up there might just be a darker, more sinister motive at work.

The injured Ferguson may be more talisman than match-winning striker, but how Everton miss him. It is widely believed that their fortunes will improve markedly once the light infantry currently deployed on the front line is replaced by the heavy artillery that lingers within the Goodison MASH unit.

But the return of men like Ferguson, Richard Gough and Francis Jeffers may come too late to move Everton's season from hard shoulder to fast lane; the damage to aspira tions and morale may already be too severe.

Their campaign - a fitful Premiership sequence and a pitiful Worthington Cup exit to Bristol Rovers - has been shot to pieces by the sort of buttock-clenchingly dumb blunders normally associated with schoolboy football. The manager Walter Smith has been criticised for asking key players to undertake unfamiliar duties, and he was at it again on Saturday, installing the Danish midfielder Thomas Gravesen at centre-back.

But given that a wretched game had appeared over once Jason Dodd's magnificent, thunderous volley edged Southampton in front with 14 minutes remaining, Smith all but got away with it this time.

"I thought we'd done enough because we never really looked like conceding," said the Southampton manager Glenn Hoddle. "But one lapse of concentration cost us dear."

That lapse came nine minutes from the end when Kevin Davies chose to wrestle Alex Nyarko to the ground as he shaped to steer in a shot. Michael Ball confidently swept home an uncontested penalty and Everton were saved. "To come back and get a point was a bonus for us," Smith admitted, "because neither side created much today."

Smith will at least take solace in the performance of Paul Gascoigne, who was brought to Everton as a bit-part player but is now, in Ferguson's absence, very much the leading man.

The pace has gone and with the weight loss so too has the strength, but Gascoigne ran himself stupid, chasing down both lost and good causes with outrageous enthusiasm. One can only hope his younger and fitter colleagues were suitably embarrassed at being upstaged by a man not deemed worthy of celebrity-mask status.

webTitle: Baggies' bubble bursts about Butler's head

fields.headline: Baggies' bubble bursts about Butler's head
fields.trailText:
WBA 2 - 3 Norwich
Buoyant Baggies deflated at the death.
fields.body:
A Wolves supporter told the Radio WM phone-in that reports of a bomb in West Bromwich had been exaggerated. It was merely, he said, the bubble bursting.

Wolves fans cannot be begrudged whatever little amusement they can find this season but they should be warned that any glee they have experienced at their neighbours' first defeat in nine games is likely to be returned to them tomorrow night, when their patched-up team must brave the Hawthorns.

Results may not lie much but they mislead and digress all the time. Albion are not the thoroughbred dark horses their surge through the First Division field suggested and neither are they the hopeless nags this defeat would indicate. After their struggles last season Gary Megson has given them a sturdier spine and better balance and movement. They can dazzle going forward, they finish efficiently and until Saturday they looked as though they could defend respectably too.

They pretty much outplayed Norwich, who have not been flattered by many of their results this season, but fell behind virtually every time they were required to defend. They proved suckers for any cross played beyond the far post and especially vulnerable on the right, where Des Lyttle's bearings quickly disappeared along with his confidence.

It was a wonderful day for Bryan Hamilton, a former national team manager who is not devoid of tactical ideas. He picked a five-man midfield to deal with Albion's stratagem of having Ruel Fox drift inside, then countered big Bob Taylor's introduction by bringing on Malky Mackay, a former Celtic centre-half in the brick outhouse tradition. "I think it worked very well," Hamilton said.

"If we play as well as we can play we're a very good side," he claimed. "We were better than Fulham when we played them."

Albion equalised twice, first through a 25-yard blast from the splendid Neil Clement, then from a penalty apparently awarded for a push by Iwan Roberts, and they made plenty of other opportunities but could find no answer to Norwich's goal five minutes from time, when Mackay was allowed an unchallenged header and Darren Kenton beat James Chambers to the knock-down.

Kenton's and Chris Llewellyn's goals were both set up by free-kicks and free headers which, Megson calculated, makes 10 goals Albion have conceded from set pieces this season.

"A team that can throw it in the box will cause us problems," he admitted. And a team like Norwich that can throw it in the box and avoid Tony Butler's head can enjoy a field day, though Wolves had better not be counting on it.

webTitle: The ICC Knockout: a big hit

fields.headline: The ICC Knockout: a big hit
fields.trailText: The first ICC Knockout or mini-World Cup, held in Bangladesh two years ago, was a roaring success on a local scale but a mere sideshow for the wider cricket world. The second, which ended in Nairobi on Sunday, was just the opposite: it made only limited impact in Kenya but it was a big hit globally.
fields.body:
The first ICC Knockout or mini-World Cup, held in Bangladesh two years ago, was a roaring success on a local scale but a mere sideshow for the wider cricket world. The second, which ended in Nairobi on Sunday, was just the opposite: it made only limited impact in Kenya but it was a big hit globally.

In fact it was a big hit almost literally. After the 1999 World Cup, which belonged to the bowlers, Nairobi was the batters' revenge. It was a Knockout, but not a jeu sans frontieres: the boundaries, which were invitingly short, shaped the game, rewarding strokeplay and punishing any bowler who couldn't offer a blend of high precision and wily variation. A rule of thumb emerged early on which held good for all 11 games: the team batting first were dead meat if they got less than 265. (The lowest-scoring game, somewhat predictably, was the only one in which England batted first.)

India, led in every sense by the prince of Calcutta, were the undisputed kings of the qualifying rounds, conquering both the world's top two teams, Australia and South Africa, by the classic method of batting first, piling up a big score, and letting the pressure do the rest. But in the final, when they were hot favourites, they batted first and got 264, which was just low enough for New Zealand to squeeze past them to the greatest triumph in their one-day history.

It seemed a shame that India should go home without the trophy. But New Zealand beat them by playing the same game, trusting their eyes and the refreshingly durable surface of the Gymkhana. By the time Chris Cairns reached his hundred, the Indian buccaneers had been out-buccaneered. If Sourav Ganguly and Saeed Anwar were the men of the tournament, each making back-to-back hundreds, the slightly les glamorous Roger Twose was not far behind: Ganguly and Anwar both hit their runs at a rate of 84 per 100 balls, Twose at 82. The world will think twice now before accusing New Zealand of being dour.

Both the finalists were a revelation. What made them suddenly so dashing, so carefree? It can't have been the fact that this was the first cricket tournament to carry big prize money, can it?

The reason for that was Hansie Cronje and the match-fixing scandal. Cronje was a ghost at this feast, repeatedly popping up in the news as he met Nelson Mandela, copped his life ban, and then waited to see if the ban extends to commentating. (It shouldn't - as long as his employers are satisfied that he has come clean, and that he intends to use his earnings to pay back all his ill-gotten gains.) But no whiff of match-fixing arose inside the Gymkhana. If any result looked dodgy, it was Australia's collapse against India. And it is just unthinkable that a team of Steve Waugh's could be on the take. They lost because of a great performance, at the crease and in the field, from India's teenage discovery Yuvraj Singh, who is either the new Mohammad Azharuddin, or the new Ben Hollioake.

The tournament had its faults, as all tournaments do. The home team were knocked out on day one. ICC couldn't do much about the result, since Kenya were facing what turned out to be the might of India, but they could have made sure that the game was held at the last possible moment rather than the first one. Ticket prices were far too high. The ICC has half a billion US dollars to play with from selling the broadcasting rights to the next two World Cups and smaller events such as this one. It should have used a little of that cash to make sure that the average curious Kenyan could afford to get in.

Overall, however, the Knockout hit the spot. Most one-day tournaments go on too long; this one left you wanting more.

Tim de Lisle is editor of wisden.com. To read his previous piece, a verdict on England's hammering by South Africa, click here

webTitle: Lib Dems agree Welsh assembly power sharing deal

fields.headline: Lib Dems agree Welsh assembly power sharing deal
fields.trailText: 16 October: Liberal Democrats in Wales yesterday seized the long awaited opportunity of putting their policies into practice in government by voting overwhelmingly in support of a three year partnership agreement with the minority Labour administration in the Welsh assembly.
fields.body:
Liberal Democrats in Wales yesterday seized the long awaited opportunity of putting their policies into practice in government by voting overwhelmingly in support of a three year partnership agreement with the minority Labour administration in the Welsh assembly.

The junior partners in the new coalition will take up two seats in the nine strong assembly cabinet in a reshuffle due to be announced by Labour first secretary Rhodri Morgan today.

As part of the new arrangement the Liberal Democrat leader in the assembly, Mike German, will become deputy first secretary. Discussions on the division of cabinet portfolios were taking place between the party leaders last night.

The coalition, modelled on the agreement between the two parties in Scotland, is due to remain in force until the next assembly elections in 2003.

It was thrashed out in secret talks earlier this month in a bid to usher in a period of stable government in Cardiff following the turbulence that has marked the past 17 months of minority rule.

The agreement, which triggered the resignation of the Labour education and culture secretary, Tom Middlehurst, in protest at the offer of cabinet seats to the Liberal Democrats, is founded on a partnership document that includes many of the policies on which the Lib Dems fought the 1999 assembly elections.

Despite the initial disquiet of some Liberal Democrat members at the clandestine nature of the discussions, delegates to the party's autumn conference yesterday voted 130 to 11 in favour of the deal.

Labour assembly members and the Labour executive in Wales had already given their approval.

The Liberal Democrat leader, Charles Kennedy, hailed the vote as a good day for Wales and for devolution. He said the assembly now had the stability it had lacked.

"Today's decision will increase confidence in the assembly and allow it to deliver changes - most of them in the Liberal Democrat manifesto - which will make a real difference to the lives of the people of Wales."

Among the initiatives to have been agreed is the recruitment of 700 teachers to help reduce class sizes for eight to 11 year olds, the provision of an extra £60m to support farmers and rural communities, and an immediate investigation into student hardship and funding.

Agreement has also been reached on a review of voting systems for local government elections in Wales with a committment to pressing Westminster to bring forward assembly sponsored legislation to implement the review's conclusions.

webTitle: Classrooms that keep a light aglow in ashes of conflict

fields.headline: Classrooms that keep a light aglow in ashes of conflict
fields.standfirst: Historic school struggles to revive an era of learning
fields.trailText: Half a century ago, Rumbek secondary school was the only secondary school in southern Sudan, and it was the pride of British colonialism. Its long, low brick classrooms were built around a large courtyard shaded by giant mango trees.
fields.byline: Victoria Brittain  in Rumbek, southern Sudan
fields.body:
Half a century ago, Rumbek secondary school was the only secondary school in southern Sudan, and it was the pride of British colonialism. Its long, low brick classrooms were built around a large courtyard shaded by giant mango trees.

Catholic and Protestant chapels stood just beyond the central courtyard, with dormitories, a refectory, an orchard, a vegetable garden, offices and teachers' houses spread out over a large area; it was the orderliness of Surrey transported to one of the wildest parts of the empire to forge a new elite on the British model.

"This school was the manufacturer of the first generation of politicians in the south. All the officers of Anyanya 1 [the group of insurgents that led the first southern rebellion, which started in 1955 before the British left] passed through this school," said one graduate and a former commander of the organisation into which Anyanya evolved, the Sudan People's Liberation Army (the SPLA).

As the rebellion grew in the south in the 1960s, schools were closed and Rumbek secondary, with all its pupils and staff, was taken to the north. When peace was signed between north and south in 1972, the pupils organised the immediate return of the school.

"We came down all together by train, leaving the teachers to follow," said one of the move's organisers, later to become an SPLA commander.

Once war broke out in the south in 1983 following the declaration of sharia Islamic law by Khartoum, the school's brief life as the cradle of the southern elite ended abruptly; its grounds became a government military barracks.

The soldiers built a mosque, and pulled down the outlying buildings and the teachers' houses. The empty chapels now have Arabic slogans written on the walls. A broken-down military truck occupies a corner of the courtyard, where the odd bullet shines in the dust, and the laboratories have become the kitchen, housing two great vats of sorghum porridge and broth for cooking soup. Dozens of vultures perch on the roof.

Three years ago the SPLA took Rumbek town and, as the town began to revive, the people reopened the secondary school. "We had to, it is the identity of the south, the nucleus of our struggle," said one teacher.

The reopening was a community effort, but there were few resources. Last year when the harvest was good, the townspeople contributed food. But this year southern Sudan faces another serious food deficit and the people have none to give. The students' food must be bought using some of the £30 fee each pupil pays a year.

How their families find the battered and torn Sudanese pound notes in this society, where life is mainly subsistence farming and barter and most adult males are dead or in the SPLA, is a mystery.

In the classrooms, the students sit on home-made bamboo chairs, packed 80 or 100 to a room. There are now 380 students, in their late teens to late 20s. The school has only nine permanent teachers and 11 part-time ones. Three of these were released from the military by the SPLA at the request of the headmaster. Most of them are graduates, but not trained teachers. None draws a salary, nor any equipment except for a very few books.

The teachers' greatest frustration is not only the consistent lack of books, but the fact that the students are often completely unprepared. Although primary schools have been reopened in the liberated areas for several years, their standards are minimal.

"The children arrive here with no background. Their teachers are so poorly educated that it is often like starting from scratch with boys in their 20s," said one English literature teacher.

He is teaching George Orwell's Animal Farm and Alan Paton's Cry the Beloved Country, the books he was taught and loved himself a generation ago. But to his class, even much of the vocabulary is new.

"We have completely lost the battle for education," said one priest. "Suppose peace comes, how can we even begin to negotiate with the northerners when they have degrees and we are coming from the village?"

The older generation were so well educated in this school that it hurts them deeply to know the next generation have lost out so dramatically.

"Before the war we had the British Council giving us scholarships and teachers," said one teacher. "What's happened to you people that you do not bother now, when we are so much in need?"

Oxfam and Unicef have dug pit latrines, provided a grinding mill and some exercise books. The school's main donor looks like being the US Agency for International Development, which has promised $300,000 (£210,000) for teacher training and curriculum development; it has emphasised the importance of including girls.

Endorsing this, one foreign aid official declared: "We want many, many Margaret Thatchers, and many, many Indira Gandhis to come out of this school."

There are now just three girls in the school, one of whom is 29 and a mother of three. The second, a tall determined-looking young woman who speaks English as impeccably as the first generation of Rumbek students, wants to be a doctor.

She is following a tradition in the south: the first female graduate, the first female commissioned officer, and the first female doctor all came from Rumbek. "But this was before the war spoiled everything," said one teacher bitterly.

How the war destroys normal life

1955 First rebellion by southern Anyanya insurgents (an event known as Anyanya 1)

1956 Sudan becomes independent from Britain

1972 Addis Ababa peace agreement between north and south

1981 Anyanya 2 rebellion starts in south

1983 Khartoum proclaims Islamic sharia law

1983 Sudan People's Liberation Army/Anyanya merge

1980s SPLA takes large parts of south

1986 SPLA talks with northern opposition

1989 National Islamic Front military coup in Khartoum

1995 Asmara agreement brings northern opposition and SPLA together in National Democratic Alliance

Sudan's long history of civil war means that:

 Successive generations of children - more than 3m - have grown up without access to adequate primary education. Today more than 80% of all children, and some 90% of girls, do not attend school

 Agricultural production is below subsistence level, leaving many dependent on emergency aid. Subsistence is difficult, especially for those with depleted cattle stocks. There is no working agricultural extension or veterinary system.

 Forced population movements are increasing pressure on the environment and reducing access to resources, deepening already extensive poverty for most families

 Health services are almost non-existent, and people die of preventable or curable diseases. Furthermore, in this environment, little is being done to counter the Aids pandemic

 There is no electricity or telecommunication system. The transport system consists of rudimentary tracks which even four-wheel drive vehicles find it hard to negotiate. Many areas are completely isolated and most people travel by foot

 There is little commerce and trade. In the few urban centres, lorries bring some manufactured goods from further afield to be sold at astronomical prices, well beyond most people's means

How their families find the battered and torn Sudanese pound notes in this society, where life is mainly subsistence farming and barter and most adult males are dead or in the SPLA, is a mystery. In the classrooms, the students sit on home-made bamboo chairs, packed 80 or 100 to a room. There are now 380 students, in their late teens to late 20s. The school has only nine permanent teachers and 11 part-time ones. Three of these were released from the military by the SPLA at the request of the headmaster. Most of them are graduates, but not trained teachers. None draws a salary, nor any equipment except for a very few books. The teachers' greatest frustration is not only the consistent lack of books, but the fact that the students are often completely unprepared. Although primary schools have been reopened in the liberated areas for several years, their standards are minimal. "The children arrive here with no background. Their teachers are so poorly educated that it is often like starting from scratch with boys in their 20s," said one English literature teacher. He is teaching George Orwell's Animal Farm and Alan Paton's Cry the Beloved Country, the books he was taught and loved himself a generation ago. But to his class, even much of the vocabulary is new. "We have completely lost the battle for education," said one priest. "Suppose peace comes, how can we even begin to negotiate with the northerners when they have degrees and we are coming from the village?" The older generation were so well educated in this school that it hurts them deeply to know the next generation have lost out so dramatically. "Before the war we had the British Council giving us scholarships and teachers," said one teacher. "What's happened to you people that you do not bother now, when we are so much in need?" Oxfam and Unicef have dug pit latrines, provided a grinding mill and some exercise books. The school's main donor looks like being the US Agency for International Development, which has promised $300,000 (£210,000) for teacher training and curriculum development; it has emphasised the importance of including girls. Endorsing this, one foreign aid official declared: "We want many, many Margaret Thatchers, and many, many Indira Gandhis to come out of this school." There are now just three girls in the school, one of whom is 29 and a mother of three. The second, a tall determined-looking young woman who speaks English as impeccably as the first generation of Rumbek students, wants to be a doctor. She is following a tradition in the south: the first female graduate, the first female commissioned officer, and the first female doctor all came from Rumbek. "But this was before the war spoiled everything," said one teacher bitterly. How the war destroys normal life 1955 First rebellion by southern Anyanya insurgents (an event known as Anyanya 1) 1956 Sudan becomes independent from Britain 1972 Addis Ababa peace agreement between north and south 1981 Anyanya 2 rebellion starts in south 1983 Khartoum proclaims Islamic sharia law 1983 Sudan People's Liberation Army/Anyanya merge 1980s SPLA takes large parts of south 1986 SPLA talks with northern opposition 1989 National Islamic Front military coup in Khartoum 1995 Asmara agreement brings northern opposition and SPLA together in National Democratic Alliance Sudan's long history of civil war means that:  Successive generations of children - more than 3m - have grown up without access to adequate primary education. Today more than 80% of all children, and some 90% of girls, do not attend school  Agricultural production is below subsistence level, leaving many dependent on emergency aid. Subsistence is difficult, especially for those with depleted cattle stocks. There is no working agricultural extension or veterinary system.  Forced population movements are increasing pressure on the environment and reducing access to resources, deepening already extensive poverty for most families  Health services are almost non-existent, and people die of preventable or curable diseases. Furthermore, in this environment, little is being done to counter the Aids pandemic  There is no electricity or telecommunication system. The transport system consists of rudimentary tracks which even four-wheel drive vehicles find it hard to negotiate. Many areas are completely isolated and most people travel by foot  There is little commerce and trade. In the few urban centres, lorries bring some manufactured goods from further afield to be sold at astronomical prices, well beyond most people's means

webTitle: Oxbridge's state school admissions still vary wildly

fields.headline: Oxbridge's state school admissions still vary wildly
fields.standfirst: Donald MacLeod on the huge variance between colleges in their admission of state pupils
fields.trailText: Donald MacLeod on the huge variance between colleges in their admission of state pupils.
fields.body:
Cambridge colleges vary widely in the number of state school and further education college students they admit, according to figures published by the university today. The fluctuations, mirrored at Oxford, will deepen the unease the government has over the discrepanies in admissions procedures and will also heighten the distrust of the elite universities in the state school sector.

At Cambridge, the figures show that King's college took 79% of its students from state schools last year and Churchill admitted 76%, while at the other end of the scale Corpus Christi and Gonville and Caius colleges drew 39% of their intake from the maintained sector.

Oxford has already revealed huge discrepancies in the practices of the individual colleges over admissions. Earlier this year, the university was at the centre of a furious political row when Laura Spence, a comprehensive school pupil from the North East, was turned down by Oxford and gained a scholarship at Harvard.

Oriel college in Oxford offered four out of ten places to state school and college pupils this year and St Edmund's Hall showed a similar picture (42% of its offers). In contrast 70% of offers from St John's and 74% from Mansfield went to state sector applicants.

Although the Oxford figures report offers rather than final admissions - applicants might fail to get the required A level grades - the university said that in general, admissions closely shadowed offers. This year 53% of offers overall went to state schools and colleges and they accounted for 52% of admissions.

Today, the universities and colleges admissions service (Ucas) was opening a final batch of 5,000 applications for Oxbridge and for medical, dental and veterinary courses after the October 15 deadline. A spokesman said no one yet knew whether applications for Oxbridge had gone up or down after the Laura Spence affair.

Ministers, then alarmed by the apparent social chasm between prestigious universities including Oxford and Cambridge and the new universities, did their best to increase pressure for wider access - to the anger of independent schools who said their pupils might be discriminated against.

But today's figures showing will only confirm the distrust and confusion surrounding the complex Oxbridge admissions process in the minds of many young people at state schools and colleges - and the minds of the teachers who advise them.
