webTitle: Plea for help to school young Sudan in peace

fields.headline: Plea for help to school young Sudan in peace
fields.standfirst:
Roger Riddell of Christian Aid and David Bryer of Oxfam appeal for development aid so war-torn communities can rebuild

Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Sudan is suffering one of the longest civil wars in the world. The conflict has gone on there ever since independence from Britain in 1959, with only a short hiatus between 1972 and 1983.
fields.byline: Roger Riddell of Christian Aid and David Bryer of Oxfam
fields.body:
Sudan is suffering one of the longest civil wars in the world. The conflict has gone on there ever since independence from Britain in 1959, with only a short hiatus between 1972 and 1983.

Southern Sudan, home to more than 6m people, has been the centre of hostilities, but the war has spread to the north and east of the country as well. Two million Sudanese have already died due to the conflict. A further 4m people are estimated to have been displaced, primarily from the south, but also from northern areas such as Kordofan. Around 2m of them live in miserable conditions in camps around Khartoum and other cities in the north.

Chronic conflict has destroyed the social fabric - the institutions sustaining food, security, education and healthcare - in the south, leaving two generations of Sudanese dependent on relief. It has also made them vulnerable to the war economies that sustain the conflict. Poverty is extensive, deep and growing. Underdevelopment has become institutionalised. Southern Sudan now constitutes one of the most glaring examples of development failure in the whole of sub-Saharan Africa.

The tragedy and scandal of Sudan's poverty and underdevelopment is not that nothing can be done, but rather the opposite. Many of the country's problems can be addressed. Key aspects of development can be promoted, especially people-focused development. Despite severe constraints, civil society and community institutions in southern Sudan have arisen and undertaken notable initiatives. Even in the context of continuing war and conflict, non-governmental agencies have access to most of the people for most of the time, and have attempted to expand their activities from relief to longer-term development. There are sizeable pockets of peace within southern Sudan where such development investment does not risk being disrupted by fighting.

Local development initiatives can be supported, people can be trained and educated, community institutions and administrative structures can be built and strengthened, and poverty can be reduced. The lack of books, of pencils and chalks, a lack of trained teachers, the absence of teachers' pay, and the lack of an effective administration have stopped children from learning in southern Sudan. More than one generation of children has been denied the right to education in the south. We cannot and must not allow further generations of children to be denied their right to education, too.

Many donors, including Britain's Department for International Development, will provide only limited development funding while the war continues. They may have coherent arguments to defend this policy: they may wish to avoid the diversion of aid towards further military purchases fuelling the war, and to use aid as a lever to move the warring parties towards a peace settlement.

Our interpretation of the British government's current policy of reduced development assistance while the war continues is that it has done little to further the pursuit of peace. It cannot be justified once its real costs are measured in terms of the deepening poverty and suffering of the southern Sudanese.

There is a growing body of civil organisations in Sudan investing in the development of their war-ravaged communities; they could receive increased assistance to sustain their efforts. Investment in longer-term development, particularly in education and health services, would sow the seeds for peace and prepare a generation of people to build reconciliation and peace once an agreement is reached. Development is essential to reduce the need for relief and to lay the foundation for peace. Development is imperative to give hope to generations of Sudanese who have little to look forward to now.

Britain has a particular moral responsibility to be at the forefront of international development efforts in southern Sudan - because of its historical links with Sudan, because of its stated commitment to poverty reduction and education for all, and because of its commitment to human rights.

We British non-governmental organisations working in southern Sudan acknowledge the British government and the EU's recent efforts to review their policies on aid to Sudan and urge them to expand their development assistance significantly. We call for a three-track approach from the British government.

The government needs to sustain and step up its efforts to promote a negotiated solution to the conflict, based on the Igad declaration of principles [agreed by the government and rebels in 1993 as a basis to negotiate peace], on behalf of the people of Sudan. The government needs to sustain the provision of humanitarian assistance to people still in dire need, respecting the obligations of international humanitarian law.

We call urgently on the government to respond now to the development disaster in the Sudan, and to provide people-centred development assistance to help lay the foundation for a sustainable future for the people there. This should be provided through local civil society and other bodies, and not through any warring party.

Without increased assistance from the government and the EU, the current work done by non-governmental agencies supporting peoples' livelihoods, building resilience, reducing vulnerability to conflict and addressing development need will remain inadequate.

We urge the British government to be in the vanguard of international donor efforts to tell the story of southern Sudan's development disaster and to respond to it with vigour. We can - and must - address the problem now.

Roger Riddell is the international director of Christian Aid. David Bryer is the director of Oxfam in Britain

fields.headline: Burma to free jailed Briton
fields.trailText: British human rights campaigner James Mawdsley is to be released from jail in Burma and deported back to the UK, the Foreign Office minister John Battle said tonight.
fields.body:
British human rights campaigner James Mawdsley is to be released from jail in Burma and deported back to the UK, the Foreign Office minister John Battle said tonight.

The 27-year-old was imprisoned a year ago for carrying pro-democracy leaflets and has been in solitary confinement at the notorious Keng Tung prison ever since.

Mr Battle said Burmese ambassador Dr Kyaw Win had informed him today that James would be deported.

"I am relieved that the Burmese regime has recognised that there is no justification in keeping James in prison and has decided to deport him as soon as possible," said the minister.

webTitle: Milan pay the price for Bologna's late blast

fields.headline: Milan pay the price for Bologna's late blast
fields.trailText: Juventus moved to the top of Serie A, Bayern Munich continue to slide and John Toshack makes a losing start to his French coaching career.
fields.body:
Bologna sprung the surprise of the weekend in Italy by beating Milan 2-1. The winning goal, a long-range effort from the defender Giovanni Piachentini, was scored four minutes into injury-time.

Juventus moved to the top of Serie A after beating Bari 2-0 at the Stadio Degli Alpi despite having their first-choice front line of Alessandro del Piero and Filippo Inzaghi ruled out with the flu. Lazio, Fiorentina and Internazionale all won, also at home.

Milan must now recover in time for their midweek Champions League fixture with Barcelona, who had a much more pleasurable weekend.

Playing Real Sociedad with an injury-ravaged team and on the back of a four defeats in five games, the Catalan side won 6-0, scoring all their goals in the first half. Rivaldo and Alfonso each scored twice.

Barcelona' visit to Milan is followed by a home game against Real Madrid, who won 3-0 against Deportivo La Coruna, the Spanish champions.

Bayern Munich lost their third consecutive game against newly promoted Energie Cottbus. The Hungarian defender Vilmos Sebok scored the game's only goal, and the defeat would have been more comprehensive but for the good form of Oliver Kahn, the Bayern and Germany goalkeeper. Werder Bremen scored twice in the last two minutes to hold Bayer Leverkusen to a 3-3 draw.

John Toshack made a losing start to his French coaching career when Sedan beat his St Etienne side 2-1 on Saturday night. Paris St-Germain moved to the top of the league on Friday when they beat Marseille for only the second time in 10 years - their sixth successive home victory.

The winning goal, a long-range effort from the defender Giovanni Piachentini, was scored four minutes into injury-time. Juventus moved to the top of Serie A after beating Bari 2-0 at the Stadio Degli Alpi despite having their first-choice front line of Alessandro del Piero and Filippo Inzaghi ruled out with the flu. Lazio, Fiorentina and Internazionale all won, also at home. Milan must now recover in time for their midweek Champions League fixture with Barcelona, who had a much more pleasurable weekend. Playing Real Sociedad with an injury-ravaged team and on the back of a four defeats in five games, the Catalan side won 6-0, scoring all their goals in the first half. Rivaldo and Alfonso each scored twice. Barcelona' visit to Milan is followed by a home game against Real Madrid, who won 3-0 against Deportivo La Coruna, the Spanish champions. Bayern Munich lost their third consecutive game against newly promoted Energie Cottbus. The Hungarian defender Vilmos Sebok scored the game's only goal, and the defeat would have been more comprehensive but for the good form of Oliver Kahn, the Bayern and Germany goalkeeper. Werder Bremen scored twice in the last two minutes to hold Bayer Leverkusen to a 3-3 draw. John Toshack made a losing start to his French coaching career when Sedan beat his St Etienne side 2-1 on Saturday night. Paris St-Germain moved to the top of the league on Friday when they beat Marseille for only the second time in 10 years - their sixth successive home victory.  You've read the piece, now have your say. fields.headline: Zac under attack
fields.standfirst: After two games of the season, Alberto Zaccheroni is running out of time as Milan coach.
fields.trailText: Milan's 2-1 defeat at Bologna on Sunday has intensified the clamour for Alberto Zaccheroni's head.
fields.body:
Milan's 2-1 defeat at Bologna on Sunday has intensified the clamour for Alberto Zaccheroni's head.

The Milan coach is already under fire after two games of the Serie A season. Without Paolo Maldini and Fernando Redondo, his team looks timid and uninspired. And there is no relief in sight. Next up for the beleaguered coach and his colourless rossoneri: Juventus at San Siro on Saturday night.

The flu is going around Serie A at the moment and while Zaccheroni could blame the bug for removing Maldini from his defence, it could hardly explain the collective listlessness of his midfield.

Bologna's much-travelled defender Giovanni Bia opened the scoring from close range after half an hour. Milan looked better for the introduction of Zvonimir Boban in the second half and Andriy Shevchenko headed an equaliser from Jose Mari's cross in the 62nd minute. Then Federico Giunti was sent off a quarter-hour from the end.

Nevertheless, Milan looked as though they would earn a point, until Giovanni Piacenti scored with a 30-yard drive four minutes into injury time.

Juventus, who beat Bari 2-0, and Roma, who romped to a 4-0 victory at Lecce, are now the only teams to have won both their games.

Gabriel Batistuta scored his first two goals for Roma on Sunday - the 153rd and 154th of his Serie A career. Most have been scored with his right foot, but these were comparative rarities: a header and a left-foot drive.

Francesco Totti completed the rout with a penalty in the final minute after Marco Delvecchio had been brought down.

Juventus were without their first-choice strikers - Alessandro Del Piero and Filippo Inzaghi had both succumbed to the flu - but once again Darko Kovacevic proved to be an effective stand-in.

The Yugoslav put Juve ahead in the second minute by bundling home a Zinedine Zidane cross at the near post. Zidane completed the scoring from the penalty spot in the final minute after Antonio Conte was brought down by Giuseppe Mazzarelli.

Fiorentina, on four points, earned a place in the chasing group with two goals in the final four minutes on Sunday that earned them a 2-1 win over Reggina.

Reggina, who beat Inter Milan on the opening day of the season, looked set for another upset after Massimo Marazzina gave them the lead with a diving header in the 68th minute. But Nuno Gomes, Fiorentina's Portuguese international striker, equalised in the 86th minute, volleying home an Enrico Chiesa cross, and Brazilian Leandro completed the comeback, heading home a Rui Costa corner in the final minute.

fields.headline: Just who are the Hinduja brothers?
fields.standfirst: The Hinduja Group is reported to have offered £100m for the Express newspaper titles. But who are they? Jessica Hodgson finds out.
fields.trailText: The Hinduja Group is reported to have offered £100m for the Express newspaper titles. But who are they? Jessica Hodgson finds out.
fields.body:
Who are they?
Four Indian-born brothers, Srichand, Gopichand, Prakash and Ashok. Estimated to be worth £1.3bn collectively, they made it into last week's Sunday Times Rich List at number eight.

What do they do?
Their interests across the Indian sub-continent and in Europe span a range of activities from Gulf Oil through Lufthansa to Bollywood. They live the lives of international playboys, rubbing shoulders - in Britain - with the likes of Tony and Cherie Blair, who were guests of honour at their Alexandra Palace Diwali party, and minister for Europe Keith Vaz.

What do we know about them?
The Hindujas attracted opprobrium when it was disclosed that they had sponsored the Dome's Faith zone to the tune of £1m without paying any VAT. Earlier this month they were charged by the Indian Central Bureau of Investigations with corruption, cheating and criminal conspiracy in connection with arms sales in the 1980s.

Who are they up against?
The Hindujas have registered their interest to bid for the Express newspapers, estimated to be worth £100m, but have not formally tabled a bid. They top the list of suitors for the paper - in terms of value - with former Mirror Group chief executive David Montgomery said to have offered £90m and the Barclay brothers, owners of the Scotsman and Sunday Business, thought to have offered "between £75m and £100m". Some sources say the Barclays' bid is driven more by Scotsman editor-in-chief Andrew Neil than by the Barclays themselves, and therefore the brothers may impose a ceiling over which they are not prepared to bid.

What are their chances?
Despite public assertions that the Express newspapers are not for sale, insiders say Lord Hollick is keen to dispose of them to the highest bidder, and so far the Hindujas are the only ones to have made public their intention to bid. Suggestions of corruption in India may not endear the brothers to the Labour peer Lord Hollick, but the brothers have promised that if their bid was successful they would install a board of trustees guaranteed to protect their independence.

webTitle: Can Arafat rein in the militias?

fields.headline: Can Arafat rein in the militias?
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: In an office on the edge of Balata refugee camp, Hussam Khader keeps a nickel-plated Kalashnikov on his desk, an amulet for the men trooping in with assault rifles and bullet-proof vests. "These people are going to fight with the Jews, but it is my job to use that in the negotiating table," the Palestinian official said.
fields.body:
In an office on the edge of Balata refugee camp, Hussam Khader keeps a nickel-plated Kalashnikov on his desk, an amulet for the men trooping in with assault rifles and bullet-proof vests. "These people are going to fight with the Jews, but it is my job to use that in the negotiating table," the Palestinian official said.

That combustible mix of guns and talk, born in the back streets of refugee camps in the West Bank and Gaza, comes into the full glare of international diplomacy today when Israel's prime minister, Ehud Barak, and the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, sit down with world leaders in Egypt to try to end 18 days of violence.

Yesterday, Mr Barak said he would insist at the summit that the armed militias of Mr Arafat's Fatah faction, called the tanzim, which means organisation in Arabic, be disbanded, and that freed Hamas and Islamic militants be returned to Palestinian jails.

Can Mr Arafat comply? Amid the wreckage of the peace process, many Palestinians believe that force is their only means of equalising the gross imbalance in international support and firepower between them and Israel.

That argument is expressed most forcefully in Nablus, a stronghold of Hamas, as well as the tanzim.

Hardliners

Officially, the tanzim operate with Mr Arafat's sanction, but there are no guarantees he can rein them in. Key figures in the tanzim preach a far harder line than the Palestinian leader, and want to seal off his options of returning to negotiations. They are seeking alliances with Hamas, and other Islamist groups which have opposed the peace process from the outset, and are now calling for violent action.

In addition, the refugee camps are full of armed men whose allegiance is unclear. "Most of the Palestinian people have a gun like you have a degree certificate from the university hanging on the wall," said Mr Khader.

In Balata, where posters of the Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein now hang as a symbol of Arab defiance, the tanzim leaders say they have just begun to fight. They predict a long and bloody guerrilla war against Israeli soldiers, and armed extremists in the 145 Jewish settlements in the West Bank and Gaza.

The tanzim raised their first militia of 500 armed men in Nablus a week ago, and it has already been blooded in clashes with local Jewish extremists. Additional chapters are being raised in Gaza and in the West Bank cities of Jenin, Hebron and Ramallah.

On the other edge of Nablus, which sits in a bowl formed by the surrounding hills, other forces are stirring. A day after his release from prison, Jamal Mansour, the Nablus leader of Hamas, is passing around a giant bowl of sweets to well-wishers.

Detained for more than three years without charge at Israel's behest, Mr Mansour is edgy. Mr Arafat can order him back inside in an instant. Thirty-four Hamas prisoners were re-arrested in Nablus at the weekend. But for now, the Hamas leader believes he enjoys Mr Arafat's favour: among the callers on Saturday were several leaders from Mr Arafat's Fatah faction.

"Sometimes, in his mind, he needs signals to show he is still interested in the Palestinian national issue," he said.

Such signals are Israel's greatest fear. When the Palestinian leader opened his jails on Thursday, hours after combat helicopters rocketed the perimeters of his Gaza headquarters while he was inside, Israeli officials accused Mr Arafat of giving a "green light" to Hamas suicide bombers.

They also claimed he had released Mohammed Deif, the most dreaded Hamas bomber.

That is untrue. Several dangerous militants, including him, were not freed, but transferred to house arrest for fear, the Palestinians said, they would be killed in additional Israeli attacks on their security installations.

However, Israel remains in a state of high alert.

"It is clear that we have found ourselves in a situation where there is a great will to carry out a terrorist attack," Amos Malcha, the head of military intelligence said. "It is possible that such an attack could interfere with a summit."

For the Hamas, Mr Mansour is not revealing his hand.

But he said: "If there is still an occupation, what can we do? We will resist." That is his code for saying that the bombers have been activated.

Although Israel says the resort to guns is inexcusable, it has an irresistible logic for the Palestinians. Under the terms of the peace process, the 30,000 armed police and security forces under Mr Arafat's control in the West Bank and Gaza are barred from turning their guns on Israel. He is also committed to easing Israel's constant sense of insecurity by keeping Hamas in check.

The tanzim give him force, coupled with deniability. "Officially, as soldiers in the Palestinian Authority, we can not use our guns against the Israelis because they will use this to attack us more and more. But if you have a militia made up of civilians, then the people will sleep well," said the Nablus tanzim leader, who would give only his first name, Nasser.

Unlike regular forces, the tanzim are free to operate in areas of the West Bank under the control of the Israeli security forces. They also have an explosive charge, on a much greater scale than the last few days of skirmishes between the tanzim and settlers' groups would suggest.

"This is a game of chicken. It is saying: 'If you don't pull me back, I will go to the brink'," said Khalil Shikaki, director of the Palestinian Centre for Policy and Survey Research. "Hamas is Mr Arafat's playing card. But this is a very risky game because if Hamas has a massive suicide bombing, it could spell the end of the peace process."

webTitle: 'The Palestinians have long argued that all Israel understands is force'

fields.headline: 'The Palestinians have long argued that all Israel understands is force'
fields.trailText: Press review: what the Middle East papers say.
fields.body:
"Gloom" is the word that best describes the Israeli papers' coverage of the Sharm el-Sheikh summit. On the Palestininian and Arab side, the word is "anger".

The Khaleej Times, in the United Arab Emirates, reports a rare outbreak of Palestinian anger against their own leader, Yasser Arafat: "Many Palestinians voiced anger yesterday at President Yasser Arafat's agreement to attend an emergency Middle East summit, accusing him of wasting the sacrifices of more than two weeks of clashes with Israel.

"The United States and the European Union have pushed Arafat to meet Israeli Prime Minister Ehud Barak and try to end 17 days of bloodshed in which 100 people have been killed, all but seven of them Palestinians or Israeli Arabs. To many Palestinians, today's Sharm el-Sheikh summit is an attempt to defang an Arab summit scheduled for October 21-22, called to bolster the Palestinians' refusal to accept Israel's terms for peace, notably on the thorny issue of Jerusalem."

Arafat's own ministry of information offers its usual roundup of local headlines and adds a bonus, its own editorial take on the summit: "The success of this summit from a Palestinian point of view is for the summit to end the military and economic siege imposed on the Palestinian occupied territories, stopping the threats and accusations levelled against the Palestinian people and leadership and the establishment of an international commission of inquiry to investigate the bloody massacres of Palestinians, and the provocative visit of [Likud leader Ariel] Sharon to the Al-Aqsa mosque."

The Jordan Times wants more from the summit. It comments sadly that even a few weeks ago all the people of the region thought that violent confrontation had been consigned to history. Now, says the paper, it's not just the Israelis and Palestinians who are searching again for peace.

"Jordanians are right in saying their country stands to lose the most after the Palestinians and Israelis if violence does not stop and dialogue does not resume, to find a just and lasting settlement accepted by both peoples. The latest outbreak of violence has yet again shown all of us that our efforts to join the global economy and further boost economic reform to ease the impact of poverty and unemployment could suddenly be harmed by yet another war."

The Jerusalem Post believes that Arafat and the Palestinians are no longer interested in negotiation or in peace. The paper urges Israel to recognise this, and, in effect, to reoccupy the Palestinian territories: "The Palestinians have long argued that all Israel understands is force. The Israeli corollary to this assumption is that all the Palestinians understand is facts on the ground. The hard-learned lesson of the last seven years is that Israel could well have to return to the policies of the previous 26 years: that of slowly creating facts on the ground that increase the territorial price of the Palestinian refusal to negotiate peace."

Even Israel's Ha'aretz, normally the voice of moderation and optimism, can see little good coming of the summit: "With respect to Israel, it appears that Barak has not yet closed the door on a resumption of the negotiations. But from the Palestinian side, no peaceful voices have been heard. And Arafat, caught in a militant mood, is sending no indications of wanting an agreement. As things look on the eve of the summit, there appears to be no guarantee of its success, and the chances of continuing the diplomatic process appear slim."

webTitle: 'Inclusive' Tories must reject PC Britain - Hague

fields.headline: 'Inclusive' Tories must reject PC Britain - Hague
fields.trailText: William Hague today described Britain as "a nation of immigrants" - but insisted that the Tories would not bow to "political correctness" in their efforts to celebrate ethnic diversity.
fields.body:
William Hague today described Britain as "a nation of immigrants" - but insisted that the Tories would not bow to "political correctness" in their efforts to celebrate ethnic diversity.

The Conservative party leader, speaking to newspaper editors in Cardiff, ridiculed last week's report by the Commission on the Future of Multi-Ethnic Britain which suggested the term "British" should be dropped because it is overladen with "racial overtones".

But Mr Hague emphasised his determination to lead an inclusive party. In his address to a Society of Editors conference, he said his party believed in personal freedoms, but at the same time understood the importance of social cohesion.

"I do not accept the false distinction that is sometimes made between respecting the lifestyle decisions of individuals and championing mainstream values," Mr Hague said.

"Conservatives should do both - for we are neither libertarians nor authoritarians. We believe passionately in the personal and economic freedom of the individual, but we also understand that as individuals we owe rights to others and that we live in a society with a history and traditions."

Consequently, Mr Hague argued, there was no contradiction in saying that while Conservatives would not dictate how people should live their lives, a Tory government would use the tax system to support the institution of marriage; and that while Tories respected people of different sexual orientation, they wanted to keep section 28.

And he continued: "I see no contradiction, and nor do most people, in saying that we celebrate the different ethnic communities that make up Britain, but that we won't be a prisoner to political correctness.

"Our nation is a nation of immigrants. Celts, Picts, Saxons, Angles, Normans, Jews, Huguenots, Indians, Pakistanis, Afro-Caribbeans, Bengalis, Chinese and countless others.

"These are British people, all of them. It is what makes our country such an exciting and varied place to live. So we are proud of our ethnically diverse culture, but like British blacks and British Asians, we totally reject ludicrous government reports that say that the word 'British' is racist, or that the so-called 'Rule Britannia mindset' seen at the Last Night of the Proms is 'a major part of the problem of Britain'.

"I say that the problem when it comes to tackling issues of race and ethnic diversity is not the Rule Britannia mindset but the Cool Britannia mindset that pigeonholes people with quotas and thinks that the idea of nation is dead."

Last week's race report, produced by a commission led by Labour peer Lord Bikhu Parekh, called for Britain to rename itself as a multicultural society and rewrite its national story to be more inclusive.

The home secretary, Jack Straw, distanced the government from it, saying he was "proud to be English and proud to be British".

Consequently, Mr Hague argued, there was no contradiction in saying that while Conservatives would not dictate how people should live their lives, a Tory government would use the tax system to support the institution of marriage; and that while Tories respected people of different sexual orientation, they wanted to keep section 28. And he continued: "I see no contradiction, and nor do most people, in saying that we celebrate the different ethnic communities that make up Britain, but that we won't be a prisoner to political correctness. "Our nation is a nation of immigrants. Celts, Picts, Saxons, Angles, Normans, Jews, Huguenots, Indians, Pakistanis, Afro-Caribbeans, Bengalis, Chinese and countless others. "These are British people, all of them. It is what makes our country such an exciting and varied place to live. So we are proud of our ethnically diverse culture, but like British blacks and British Asians, we totally reject ludicrous government reports that say that the word 'British' is racist, or that the so-called 'Rule Britannia mindset' seen at the Last Night of the Proms is 'a major part of the problem of Britain'. "I say that the problem when it comes to tackling issues of race and ethnic diversity is not the Rule Britannia mindset but the Cool Britannia mindset that pigeonholes people with quotas and thinks that the idea of nation is dead." Last week's race report, produced by a commission led by Labour peer Lord Bikhu Parekh, called for Britain to rename itself as a multicultural society and rewrite its national story to be more inclusive. The home secretary, Jack Straw, distanced the government from it, saying he was "proud to be English and proud to be British".

webTitle: Racism in Catholic Church 'driving minorities away'

fields.headline: Racism in Catholic Church 'driving minorities away'
fields.standfirst:
Special report: race issues in the UK
Special report: religion in the UK
fields.trailText: The Roman Catholic church in England and Wales has been accused of discrimination against ethnic minorities by the director of the church's association for racial justice.
fields.body:
The Roman Catholic church in England and Wales has been accused of discrimination against ethnic minorities by the director of the church's association for racial justice.

The move comes a month before a conference, called by the church itself, to review how it deals with multiracial issues and may cause concern to bishops still reeling from child abuse convictions among the clergy.

The association told the Guardian it will be pressing for an independent inquiry within the church similar to one recently appointed under Lord Nolan to review its procedures for dealing with accusations of paedophilia.

Stephen Corriette, the association's director, claims that there are fewer than 30 black parish priests out of more than 5,600 in the 22 dioceses of England and Wales, just six of them British-born, and that Catholics from ethnic-minority communities are being frozen out of positions of responsibility in parishes. The church itself acknowledged last week that the figures were "probably correct" and admitted that its most recent statistics for priests in training showed just 16 black priests being ordained and a further 21 in seminaries.

Roman Catholicism in Britain is perceived as the most white of the major denominations - the majority of British immigrants have not come from Catholic countries - though the association estimates that 12% of its communicants are from ethnic minority backgrounds.

At a service at Westminster Cathedral, celebrating the 150th anniversary of the restoration of Catholic bishops to Britain, earlier this year, none of the 300 priests in attendance was black nor any of the altar servers or choir boys.

Mr Corriette, born in Britain of Caribbean parents, said: "It is ironic that the Catholic church calls itself universal when it is driving black people away by its attitudes."

Mr Corriette has compiled a dossier of racist incidents. A priest told a young unmarried black couple that he would not baptise their child "because you people believe in babies outside marriage and then expect me to christen them". Another refused a family a requiem mass because they wanted to sing a Caribbean song during the service.

Another told the association that he would refuse to have refugees in his presbytery "because everything of value would be gone in five minutes".

Mr Corriette said: "Priests have told me, 'We don't have a problem with racism here because we don't have any black people'. They always talk of us as a problem.

"I heard a seminarian say that he did not need racism awareness training because he did not intend to work in a parish where there would be black people. These attitudes do not exist just among the elderly - there is a culture that is almost colonialist."

The church has come close to acknowledging the problem. Earlier this year, guidelines for parishes to review their practices described institutional racism as "a form of structural sin and primarily a sin of omission".

It added: "We can't assume that Catholic organisations... are unaffected. In such a situation we become culpable if we fail to take stock and examine carefully the nature of the service we offer."

A spokesman for the Catholic media office said: "There is no evidence to suggest deliberate exclusion of minorities but nor are a great number coming forward for training as priests."

webTitle: Middle East summit: Clinton calls upon Arafat, Barak to 'move beyond blame'

fields.headline: Clinton calls upon Arafat, Barak to 'move beyond blame'
fields.body:
The Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, and the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, sat face to face at a table with the US president, Bill Clinton, and other leaders at the Middle East emergency summit in Egypt today. "We have to move beyond blame," Mr Clinton declared.

The atmosphere this afternoon remained tense as clashes continued in the Middle East, while the two leaders, who have yet to meet bilaterally, gathered in the resort of Sharm el-Sheikh.

At the beginning of the summit, Mr Clinton declared: "We cannot afford to fail."

The sombre-faced leaders posed silently for photographs and Mr Clinton ignored a reporter's question about prospects for the meeting before making his opening statement.

"The future of the peace process and the stability of the region are at stake," Mr Clinton said, urging both sides to remember how far they had come since 1993 when they agreed to resume the peace process.

The summit was called to end the recent mayhem on the West Bank and Gaza that has cost nearly 100 lives and fractured whatever trust remained between Israel and the Palestinians.

On a key issue, Mr Clinton called for a fact-finding mission to probe the causes of the most serious fighting between the Israelis and Palestinians in years and to prevent a recurrence. "We want to get negotiations started again," he said.

The Egyptian president and host of the summit, Hosni Mubarak, called for "saving what is left of the credibility of the peace process".

After Mr Clinton and Mr Mubarak made opening remarks, the meeting took a recess.

Each country's team kept to itself. Mr Barak stood up and talked to his advisers. Mr Clinton turned in his chair to speak to the national security adviser, Sandy Berger, and the secretary of state, Madeleine Albright.

The leaders sat about 10 feet apart around a horseshoe table, with Mr Clinton and Mr Mubarak sitting at the head of the table.

Meanwhile, Palestinian militiamen opened fire on Israeli soldiers during two West Bank protest marches, and rock-throwing clashes erupted elsewhere in the Palestinian territories.

Two Palestinians were seriously injured by Israeli fire, Palestinian doctors said.

South of the West Bank town of Nablus, around 1,500 Palestinians marched toward an Israeli army checkpoint.

Around 500 broke away from the march and began throwing stones at three Israeli army jeeps. Several gunmen, shooting from olive groves, fired on Israeli soldiers, drawing return fire.

Eight Palestinians were injured in total, including the two who were in a serious condition with bullets to the head and chest respectively, said a doctor at a Palestinian field clinic.

On the outskirts of the West Bank town of Ramallah, Palestinian gunmen opened fire on Israeli soldiers manning a checkpoint.

Across the West Bank and Gaza strip, thousands of Palestinians joined protests against a renewal of contacts with Israel.

With a little more than three months left in his presidency, Mr Clinton still hopes to broker a peace accord. But for this summit, the most optimistic outlook is for a truce and a date set for new negotiations between the two sides.

"We shouldn't give it all up for what has happened in the last few weeks," he said.

Mr Barak was first to arrive for the emergency summit at the Egyptian Red Sea spa report, followed by Mr Clinton and Mr Arafat.

Also at the emergency summit were King Abdullah of Jordan, the UN secretary general, Kofi Annan, and Javier Solana, the EU security chief.

Mr Arafat, Mr Barak and Mr Clinton each met separately with Mr Mubarak before the summit gathering.

Mr Clinton hopes to return home in time for a memorial service on Wednesday in Norfolk, Virginia, to honour the 17 US sailors killed in an attack last Thursday on a US destroyer at the southern tip of the Arabian peninsula.

fields.headline: Huddersfield sack Bruce
fields.trailText: Huddersfield Town have sacked Steve Bruce following a disastrous start to the season.
fields.body:
Huddersfield Town have sacked Steve Bruce following a disastrous start to the season.

The Terriers, who narrowly missed out on the play-offs last year, have slumped to second from bottom in the First Division and Saturday's 1-0 defeat at Grimsby was the final straw.

In a statement issued by the club, Huddersfield chairman Barry Rubery said: "We have mutually agreed that it is in both the club's and Steve's best interests that this amicable agreement has been reached."

Reserve team manager Lou Macari will take over in a caretaker capacity for tomorrow night's trip to Sheffield United - ironically the club Bruce left to join Huddersfield in June 1999. First team coach John Deehan will act as assistant to Macari.

Macari said this morning, before confirmation of Bruce's departure, that he would not accept the job on a permanent basis without the blessing of the departed manager.

"I didn't expect to be taking the team to Sheffield and both myself and John Deehan are not happy about it, but we are employed by the club and we have to get on with it," he said.

"I would not take the job permanently, if it was offered, without Steve's blessing."

webTitle: Shooting, Shooting off, and Shooting the breeze

fields.headline: Shooting, Shooting off, and Shooting the breeze
fields.trailText: GUNS, GOLF AND GREAT GAMES
fields.body:
GUNS, GOLF AND GREAT GAMES

At 10.29pm last night, Sander Westerveld was in Liverpool's trendy Jalons Wine Bar, debating whether to stay rooted to his seat or make a dash for the toilet. A minute later - with Westerveld still undecided - all hell broke loose. Three masked men burst into the bar and opened fire, wounding one man in the leg and another in the foot as the Liverpool keeper and five of his team-mates looked on in horror.

Fortunately, none of the players were injured and they were later driven away in a mini-bus. A statement released by Liverpool FC this morning said: "A number of players were enjoying dinner with their wives on Sunday evening at a restaurant they have previously visited a number of times when the shooting occurred. Markus Babbel, Didi Hamann, Sami Hyypia, Erik Meijer, Sander Westerveld and Christian Ziege all provided their details to the police before leaving the premises. The group were obviously shocked by events but were thankfully all unhurt."

The two casualties were treated in hospital for their injuries, which are thankfully not too serious. The gunmen, who wore balaclavas, escaped in a silver Vauxhall car, which was later found burned out in nearby Greenbank Road. Police are asking anyone with any information to contact them.

Westerveld makes no mention of the shooting in his consistently entertaining website column today. "Personally, I like to think I am on something of a winning streak at the moment," he says, blissfully ignorant of the fact that he could have been killed. "Before we played Derby I managed to win at golf on my computer! I always enjoy winning. Long may it continue!"

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

WEAH WALKS

Yesterday, George Weah failed to turn up as a guest on Granada Television's flagship football programme Soccer Sunday. The Manchester City striker's absence was explained thus: he had walked out on the club. The Fiver, however, dismissed this cynical analysis out of hand - after all, would you choose to spend your day off sitting in a sweaty studio with Elton Welsby? But sadly, it possibly looks as though we may have made a slight misjudgement, perhaps, because Weah has been released from his two-year contract with immediate effect.

The former world player of the year and AC Milan legend had become disillusioned at his amazing inability to push Paul Dickov and Paulo Wanchope down the first-team pecking order. Having to sit on the bench for the duration of Saturday's win over Bradford wouldn't have helped his mood, and watching Dickov turn into a better version of Ronaldo for the day may have been the last straw. Crisis talks were held during the past 48 hours, with divorce the inevitable result.

"It is not a situation I thought would arise," Weah said today with a knapsack on his back. "However, having spoken to Joe Royle, we have amicably agreed it would be best for both parties to terminate my contract. I will review my own situation at a later date." Meanwhile, Joe Royle remained surprisingly calm. "It is always regretful when things do not work out between club and player. George is a true professional who has a great stature throughout European football and we wish him well," said the City manager, without once accusing his former charge of being a self-centred prima donna.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"I don't think Arsenal's French players are more targeted than others" - Gilles Grimandi tells He Was He Is Emmanuel Petit to shut his mouth and stop whining. Pretty much.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

WHAT HAPPENS NEXT?

Today Chelsea Village PLC (Chelsea FC's parent company, and run by some white-bearded bloke) announced a loss of £3.5m in the last year. This is an increase on losses of £500,000 from the year before, and comes despite a 12-month period in which Chelsea football club received £50m of investment from BSkyB and enjoyed a successful run in Big Cup, the most lucrative football trophy of all.

Charting these figures on a graph with "money spent" on one axis and "length of time a middling club like Chelsea can keep spending money on Winston Bogarde's wages before they go bust" on the other, the Fiver would like to know: should Ken Bates stick to running hotels? Answers on an electronic postcard please.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TEL IT TO THE MOUNTAIN

It's a great time to be Terry Venables. Since the departure of Kelvin Koogan esq, everybody in the country has muttered the phrase "It's got to be Tel" at least once, and all types of pundits are supporting him too. Heck, even the paper with which he has an exclusive weekly column - "he talks, you listen" - has come out in favour of the former Portsmouth boss. But when it comes to garnering support for the "impossible job", what you really need is the endorsement of a top building society. And today, Tel got it.

"We understand what people might say about the connection between us and England if Terry Venables got the job," said Chris Hull, spokesman for the Nationwide building society, sponsors of Team England, and eminently qualified advisors on issues of financial probity. And football coaching. "They are not looking for an accountant or director of finance," Mr Hull said. "They are looking for a national coach and I think the FA will choose the right man." And if not then they can forget about getting the best mortgage at the lowest rate.

Of course, Mr Hull's musings were to be expected - they're simply one way of making sure Nationwide get value for their sponsorship money. (Imagine a board meeting in five years' time: "Gentlemen, over the past six months we have seen increasing losses leading to the threat of bankruptcy. But on the bright side, I think we got the formation right against Albania".) But how does one explain away this ringing endorsement, from a more unexpected source? "As a football coach I am told that Terry Venables is one of the best around and from what I have seen I don't disagree," Alan Sugar said this weekend. And if he's backing Venables, something's got to be up.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Leeds are once more in talks with Monaco with a view to signing Norwegian international John Arne Riise. According to Planet Football, the Yorkshire club are hopeful of signing the 20-year-old before Christmas.

Richard Dunne will open talks with Manchester City tomorrow after Everton accepted a £3m offer for him.

Chelsea, Newcastle, Everton, Ipswich and Manchester City are all keen on 18-year-old Falkirk midfielder Mark Kerr.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Steve Bruce's has left Huddersfield Town by "mutual agreement". Chairman Barry Rubery said "It is in both the club's and Steve's best interests that this amicable agreement has been reached." Lou Macari and John Deehan will take charge of the team against Sheffield United tomorrow.

Newcastle have insisted the club's future is bright despite announcing a pre-tax loss of £18.9m in the last financial year. The club predicts that the increased 52,000 capacity at St James' Park, the £25m deal with NTL and the new £1.6bn Premiership TV deal will soon turn things round.

Patrick Kluivert will miss Barcelona's Big Cup matches against AC Milan and Leeds after picking up a hip injury playing for Holland against Portugal.

Manchester United have appointed Patrick Harverson as director of communications following the embarrassing exit of Alison Ryan earlier this month. Harverson, the sports correspondent of the Financial Times, will replace Ryan, who resigned the post after it was found that she had lied about her qualifications.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

ITV: Uefa Big Cup Weekly (11.30pm) Last week, the show featured the Bayern Munich players dressed in lederhosen and celebrating the Oktoberfest. What next? The Helsingborg side enjoying a steamy sauna?

Football Extra (12.30am) Perhaps ITV could borrow the idea. Steve Claridge visiting Ladbrokes, anyone?

Sky Sports 1: Football League Review (6.30pm, 11.30pm) And hands up who wants to see Kirsty Gallagher learning how not to vomit when Dave Clark is in the room?

Monday Night Football (8pm) Alen Boksic and ten journeymen take on Newcastle.

You're on Sky Sports (10.30pm) If you're sad and lonely, perhaps.

Sky Sports 3: Brian Moore Interviews (11pm) Speaking of sad and lonely Brian is comforted by former Sheffield Wednesday, Leicester and Southampton player Peter Rodrigues.

British Eurosport: Eurogoals (10.15pm) Or Balticgoals to be more precise.

webTitle: King of the kitchen: Adam Garcia

fields.headline: King of the kitchen
fields.standfirst: Even washing dishes in a Jerry Bruckheimer movie is a ticket to fame - Imogen Tilden finds Coyote Ugly's resident dab hand in the kitchen Adam Garcia about to hit the big time.
fields.trailText: Even washing dishes in a Jerry Bruckheimer movie is a ticket to fame - Imogen Tilden finds Coyote Ugly's resident dab hand in the kitchen Adam Garcia about to hit the big time
fields.body:
My arrival is accompanied by a waiter bearing a large bloody mary. Gracious as his greetings are, I get the feeling Adam Garcia is more pleased to see the drink. Last night was the UK premiere of Coyote Ugly. "I had a bit of a heavy night. 30 of my friends were there at the aftershow party," he tells me. "Oooh, and there were almost five people shouting out my name." But despite his insistence that he's far from a megastar, the big times can't be far off for this 27-year-old Australian actor.

Already a veteran of the British stage, Coyote Ugly is Adam Garcia's first Hollywood film, after a bit part in 1997's Wilde and the lead in Australian tap-dancing movie Bootmen (due for UK release next year). But a career in Hollywood seems all but assured: he's already working on Riding in Cars with Boys with Drew Barrymore (I play an "orbital character with a relationship to Drew Barrymore" was all he would reveal).

And his performance as the cheeky dishwasher who wins the heroine's heart makes him one of the most watchable elements in Coyote Ugly, a New York-based contemporary fairytale about the bar-top dancing antics of a wannabe songwriter and her not-unattractive colleagues.

The film's tagline proudly announces "Tonight they're calling the shots", but the reality is a little more ambivalent; the movie tries to have its cake and eat it. While it features nubile young women indulging in little short of lapdancing to a roomful of male punters and the heroine gives up her job because her daddy and her boyfriend disapprove, it also tries to preach a feminist message of empowerment and strength - these women are tough and use their sexuality for their own enjoyment, and - hey - this is the 21st century - wear tight clothes and dance on the bar because they want to.

Garcia acknowledges that there are double-edged swords in the film - how far do these sort of bars exploit or empower women? "It's a difficult one because obviously it's a Hollywood film and they need to drive it with sex, and sex sells everything, let's face it. But I think we have to face the realities, that women's sexuality is a lot of their power, and to deny that would be stupid, and men are slobbering idiots around women."

However, matters are turned nicely on their heads by Garcia's character Kevin O'Donnell, who, in one scene, is "sold" in a slave auction to the hysterical female with the most readies, gets to dance on the bar, and - get this - he really is topless. So it's OK for men to be sex objects then? "Yeah , they abused me," said Adam, with a wicked grin. "I'm a tart. I'm a dancer. Most dancers are tarts anyway."

So how did this Australian dancer, who's lived in London for the past six years, and played Tony Manero in the stage version of Saturday Night Fever, end up in a Jerry Bruckheimer production? "I don't know why they cast me," he shrugs, "I never asked." He was cast on the strength of an audition tape only; producer Bruckheimer didn't even realise that his star was a trained dancer. The enormously entertaining scene of his impromptu bar routine was unscripted.

"Throughout filming, I kept on being annoying and tap dancing, because they gave me really nice hard-soled shoes, and it was a concrete floor, and then someone said 'I saw him in Saturday Night Fever - he's a dancer'." So the dancing element was added as an afterthought. It's a shame we don't have more, I ventured. Adam couldn't possibly comment, but he did admit that it was only him and actress Izabella Miko who did all their own dancing.

So what attracted him to the project? Simple - "One, it was going to be a good amount of cash, and two, I really did like the story. It really is sweet I liked this character because he's genuinely nice, an affectionate and genuine person - altruistic to the point he doesn't care about himself."

Garcia displays similar insouciance when pressed for the reason for his recent success. He seems have riden on the back of a wider recent trend in the film industry though. This has, after all, been Australia's year in film. While Russell Crowe is still wowing worldwide audiences in Gladiator, fellow Ozzies Heath Ledger, Hugh Jackman, Cate Blanchett and Guy Pearce, to name but a few, are winning critical and commercial acclaim.

So, does he have a theory behind this sudden antipodean invasion of our screens? "I've been asked this a lot" says Garcia. "It's because we're cool." But seriously, he points out that many of these "new" actors have in fact been around for ages, but the recent explosion of technology has made films everywhere more accessible.

"Hollywood producers are suddenly realising, 'Oh my God [other nationalities] are not idiots, they're talented, bless them'." But he's still touchingly modest about his career: "It's literally luck. I just happened to be in the right place at the right time. I am ambitious, I guess, in that when I do a job I'm very focused, but I've never had any real plan about what to do."

I ask him about the "new Travolta" tag. Not only did he play a part forever associated with Travolta in the London stage play Saturday Night Fever, but he shares the former's dark good looks and cute dimpled chin. It's inevitable, he says, but "I'm happy to take it because I believe he's a wonderful actor".

Unlike Garcia, Travolta is purely an actor by trade, who happened to be a great dancer. "I've been dancing for 20 years... I'm not the best dancer in the world, but I love it. It's how I express myself, and has been for many years of my life. As for acting, I'm still learning." So would he call himself an actor or a dancer? He corrects me. Dancers are in fact actors. "We're the plebian cast of the entertainment hierarchy we're the lowest paid, we have no union."

Such worries and frustrations must be fast receding. At the moment he's spoilt for choice. "I want to carry on doing theatre and movies and dancing I want to be doing everything." And what about the future - where does he see himself in 25 years time?

"I'd like to be making a movie every two years for an incomparable amount of money, being like a Brando-esque living on an island with my 40 children. That would rule."

He crunches a celery stick and grins at me. Flights of fantasy aside, I would safely predict that there will be more than five people screaming his name at his next premiere.

fields.headline: Liverpool stars witness bar shooting
fields.trailText: Two men were shot last night in a Merseyside bar where a number of Liverpool players were relaxing after their Premiership victory over Derby.
fields.body:
Two men were shot last night in a Merseyside bar where a number of Liverpool players were relaxing after their Premiership victory over Derby.

Three masked men wielding a pistol burst into Jalons Wine Bar, in the Wavertree area of the city, at around 10.30pm yesterday. They opened fire, wounding one man in the leg and another in the foot.

None of the six Liverpool players in the bar were injured - they were later driven away in a mini-bus.

A statement released by Liverpool FC this morning said: "A number of players were enjoying dinner with their wives on Sunday evening at a restaurant they have previously visited a number of times when the shooting occurred.

"Markus Babbel, Didi Hamann, Sami Hyypia, Erik Meijer, Sander Westerveld and Christian Ziege all provided their details to the police before leaving the premises.

"The group were obviously shocked by events but were thankfully all unhurt."

The two casualties, both customers in the bar, were treated in hospital for their injuries. The gunmen, in balaclavas, escaped in a silver Vauxhall car, which was later found burned out in nearby Greenbank Road, close to the entrance to Sefton Park.

"At this stage the motive to the shooting is not clear and police are appealing for anyone to come forward," said a spokesman for the Merseyside Force.

webTitle: Jamie Shea declares spin is dead

fields.headline: Former Nato press officer declares spin is dead
fields.trailText: 12pm: Nato's former chief press officer this morning said he tore up a script during briefings on the Kosovo conflict because he doubted its truth, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Nato's former chief press officer, Jamie Shea, this morning said he tore up a script he was about to deliver to journalists during briefings on the Kosovo conflict because he doubted its truth.

Speaking at the Society of Editors' annual conference in Cardiff, Mr Shea said spin had been dealt a fatal blow by recent high-profile political stories such as the fuel crisis and Ann Widdecombe's embarrassment in the face of revelations about prominent Tories having smoked cannabis.

"All we have at present are the shifting sands of lobby briefings and the views of unidentified insiders," he said.

Senior journalists and spin doctors discussed the changing relationship between them in a session called "the first casualty - the truth."

The Liberal Democrats' director of communications, David Walters, said that if politicians were more honest with the public about their failures they would reduce the level of distrust.

And veteran Australian journalist Phillip Knightley blamed the culture of big business that he said now pervades journalism for the growth of spin and declining standards.

"It's all big business now," Mr Knightly told fellow journalists. "They used to believe in public service to their readers, telling them what was going on and how they could play their part in the democratic process. We may have rumbled spin. But now distortion is more likely to come from within newspapers themselves. We must restore journalism to its original public service function."

The Society of Editors' conference continues. More details are available at www.ukeditors.com.

fields.headline: It's official: Britons are miserable
fields.standfirst: Interactive quiz: Are you happy?
fields.trailText: Britons are more miserable and down-trodden than anyone previously dared to believe, a new survey says today.
fields.body:
Britons are more miserable and down-trodden than anyone previously dared to believe, a new survey says today.

A quarter of the population fear a "hopeless future", one in three feels "downright miserable", and one in 10 thinks he or she would be better off dead.

The online survey by internet site NetDoctor.co.uk involved 400 men and women answering 80 questions to assess their emotional health.

A quarter said life was unfair, and more than one in 10 felt they had been dealt a miserable lot which they were powerless to alter.

In the questions on work, one in four was unhappy in the job, while one in three felt exhausted, unappreciated or underpaid.

In relationships, a quarter were unsatisfied with their sex lives. One in six people in relationships were "sometimes or often" unhappy.

Some 10% of men reported being emotionally, verbally or physically abused by their partners, but for women the figure is only 6%.

Psychotherapist and agony aunt Christine Webber, who carried out the survey, said: "It seems people's lives do not live up to their extremely high expectations and it is particularly worrying to see so many people dwelling on morbid thoughts, with a large proportion just plain exhausted by life."

fields.headline: £100m bid lined up for Express titles
fields.trailText: 8.30am: India's Hinduja Brothers yesterday confirmed that they are preparing a bid for United News & Media's Express newspaper group.
fields.body:
India's Hinduja Brothers yesterday confirmed that they are preparing a bid for United News & Media's Express newspaper group.

The Hinduja Group registered initial interest with Dresdner Kleinwort Benson, United's financial advisers, last Friday and was expected to make a formal offer of about £100m this week.

David Montgomery, a former chief executive of the Mirror Group, is also understood to be putting together a bid, backed by the venture capital group 3I and HSBC Bank.

fields.headline: Weah walks out on City
fields.trailText: George Weah, the former world player of the year, has been released by Manchester City.
fields.body:
George Weah, the former world player of the year, has been released by Manchester City.

Weah's two-year contract was cancelled yesterday, after less than three months at the club. "It is not a situation I thought would arise," he said. "However, having spoken to Joe Royle, we have amicably agreed it would be best for both parties to terminate my contract."

The 34-year-old Liberian striker scored four goals in nine games for City but lost his place to Paul Dickov, who scored City's opening goal in their 2-0 win at home to Bradford City on Saturday.

After spending all that game on the substitutes' bench, Weah requested a meeting with Royle, the manager who signed him when he was released by Milan in the summer.

Weah has not yet decided on his next move. "I will review my own situation at a later date," he said.

"It is always regretful when things do not work out between club and player," Royle said. "George is a true professional who has a great stature throughout European football, and we wish him well."

webTitle: BBC2 Comedy Zone takes weekend slot

fields.headline: BBC2's Comedy Zone set for weekend slot
fields.trailText: 10.15am: BBC2's Friday night Comedy Zone is expected to move to a new weekend slot in the new year, reports Jason Deans.
fields.body:
BBC2's Friday night Comedy Zone, which over the past five years has premiered hit programmes including The Fast Show, Shooting Stars and The League of Gentlemen, is expected to move to a new weekend slot in the new year.

The Comedy Zone's move to a Saturday or Sunday night berth on BBC2 will take place by mid-January, according to a source close to the channel.

The repositioning would leave the way clear for BBC1 to develop a post-9pm Friday night line-up majoring on comedy. Already this week, the first of its new 10pm news schedule, BBC1 will run former BBC2 Comedy Zone stalwart Have I Got News for You? and a Vicar of Dibley repeat from 9pm, and new Mark Addy sitcom Too Much Sun after the news at 10.35pm.

The new BBC2 Comedy Zone line-up for next year will include 'Orrible, the sitcom co-written by and starring Johnny Vaughan, which is being executive produced by BBC head of comedy Geoffrey Perkins.

Rob Brydon's follow-up to Marion & Geoff, Keith Barret Under Observation from Steve Coogan and Henry Normal's indie Baby Cow; a League of Gentlemen special; and Suicidal Dog, a Paul Merton comedy short, will also feature.

In addition, BBC2 controller Jane Root is lining up another Perkins project, new sitcom World of Pub; the second series of Hartswood Films' Jack Davenport sitcom Coupling; and new comedy shows from stand-ups Dave Gorman and Simon Munnery, executive produced by UK Play channel editor Myfanwy Moore, for the revamped weekend Comedy Zone.

fields.headline: Newspaper Society names new lobbying chief
fields.trailText: 3pm: The Newspaper Society's Santha Rasaiah has been promoted to head of political, editorial and regulatory affairs, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Santha Rasaiah, the Newspaper Society's head of legal and regulatory affairs, has been promoted to head of political, editorial and regulatory affairs.

The move comes in the run-up to the retirement of Sandy Park, the society's head of employment and regulatory affairs.

The Newspaper Society's director, David Newell, described the promotion as "richly deserved", adding that Ms Rasaiah had made a "unique contribution to the Newspaper Society's lobbying work for the newspaper industry" in the run-up to the freedom of information and local government bills.

Ms Rasaiah will take control of legal and lobbying work for the society in the UK and on continental Europe with a brief that includes press freedom issues, advertising and employment.

The move comes in the run-up to the retirement of Sandy Park, the society's head of employment and regulatory affairs. The Newspaper Society's director, David Newell, described the promotion as "richly deserved", adding that Ms Rasaiah had made a "unique contribution to the Newspaper Society's lobbying work for the newspaper industry" in the run-up to the freedom of information and local government bills. Ms Rasaiah will take control of legal and lobbying work for the society in the UK and on continental Europe with a brief that includes press freedom issues, advertising and employment.

fields.headline: Slow start to Panorama's Sunday service
fields.standfirst: Nine O'Clock News bows out
fields.trailText: 12.15pm overnights: The first Sunday night Panorama did not travel well, losing a million viewers last night after the controversial move, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
The first Sunday night Panorama did not travel well from its regular Monday night BBC1 slot, losing a million viewers last night after the controversial move.

Last night's investigation into Gap and Nike's production practices drew 3.2m/20% from 10.15pm, while last Monday's controversial Omagh bombing edition had averaged 4.2m/23%, according to unofficial overnights.

The BBC1 current affairs flagship had averaged 4.1m/22% over three outings in the 10pm Monday slot this autumn.

Last night it was up against ITV's After they were Famous, which took 5.4m and a 31% share from 10.10-10.40pm, and the news (3.7m/25% from 10.40-10.55pm).

A BBC news spokeswoman pointed out that Panorama's average audience last night was only 0.4m viewers below the programme's 3.6m average for 1999.

webTitle: Imagine Media lands rights to Microsoft games console

fields.headline: Imagine Media lands rights to Microsoft games console
fields.trailText: 1pm: Imagine Media has signed a deal giving it the rights to be the exclusive worldwide publisher of Microsoft games console Xbox, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Future Networks' parent company, Imagine Media, has signed a deal giving it the rights to be the exclusive worldwide publisher of forthcoming Microsoft games console Xbox.

The three-year contract, which is believed to represent an unprecedented global publishing deal, has an automatic extension of two years, subject to the magazine hitting circulation targets. The deal covers all territories apart from Japan.

The magazine will launch in the UK, US, Germany, Italy and France in summer next year, ahead of the product which launches in autumn 2001.

Chris Anderson, chairman of Imagine Media, described the deal as "the most significant games magazine licence ever granted".

A Future Networks spokeswoman said it was too early to give details about editorial or marketing budgets, or plans for the magazine launches.

fields.headline: Summits - what's the point?
fields.standfirst: As Middle East peace talks get under way in Egypt, Simon Tisdall looks at summits that have been much less momentous
fields.trailText: As Middle East peace talks get under way in Egypt, Simon Tisdall looks at summits that have been much less momentous.
fields.body:
Summit meetings, like that taking place today in the Egyptian resort town of Sharm el-Sheikh between the Israelis, the Palestinians and the US president, fall into several different categories, ranging from useful to pointless. Summits also tend to work in very different ways.

1. The crisis summit. After two weeks of barely controlled violence that has left more than 100 dead, the Palestinian-Israeli summit falls into this category. Arranged at very short notice, principally by the UN secretary general, Kofi Annan, and US envoys, its minimalist objective is to stop the two sides killing each other and to get them talking again.

The fact that President Bill Clinton broke off other engagements and flew overnight to Egypt from Washington underlines the emergency nature of this meeting. In the past, a US leader would not get personally involved in such a meeting unless something truly momentous was on the cards. Yet even Mr Clinton is not looking to achieve more than a ceasefire.

A quick resumption of the peace-process negotiations was not in prospect - and certainly not the conclusion of a final settlement on which Mr Clinton pinned his hopes at last July's Camp David summit. On the other hand, a summit collapse was not ruled out.

Today's summit, where a series of bilateral meetings between the participants is expected to precede lunch and an afternoon plenary session, also typifies the modern trend towards proximity talks - that is to say, summits within summits. Under this system, it is not unknown, if things do not go well, for the principal summiteers never to meet each other, but to talk instead to intermediaries and go-betweens.

2. The chummy summit. This type of meeting was pioneered by Ronald Reagan and Mikhail Gorbachev in the days when there were still two global superpowers - the US and Soviet Union - and regular superpower summits.

Reagan and Gorbachev got on so well that, to the great alarm of their advisers and military top brass, they nearly agreed, at a summit in Reykjavik in the mid-80s, to sweeping reductions in each other's nuclear arsenals.

Other superpower summits were notable for the evolution of the "walk-in-the-woods" approach, when top negotiators would desert the conference room and their aides and try and work out problems one-to-one. This sometimes led to enormous confusion, when their private deals were disowned by their leaders.

3. The rolling summit. These are the sort of meetings that give summits a bad name, devaluing their importance and raising questions about the point of such gatherings.

The European Union is one of the worst offenders in this regard. Until recently, the Council of Ministers held a six-monthly, heads-of-government summit at the end of each country's presidency. (The presidency revolves between the 15 EU member states.)

But a new trend is to hold secondary or even tertiary summits within the six-month period. This happened earlier this year during the Portuguese presidency, which held the "dot-com" summit on IT halfway through its term. The French pulled the same trick last week, convening a summit in Biarritz to discuss the forthcoming December summit in Nice. According to most reports, Biarritz merely served to emphasise how little of the Nice agenda is agreed. So what was the actual point of the summit?

4. The mini-summit. People such as Tony Blair and the French president, Jacques Chirac, just love this format. Despite their many public policy differences, they regularly get together over a quiet dinner for a private chat about what matters most to each. Only the other day, Mr Chirac popped over to Downing Street one evening to talk about EU reform and defence cooperation.

This trend has caught on in a big way with all international leaders whose instinctive response to a crisis or emergency is to hold a meeting of two or three leaders, then make it sound more important by calling it a summit.

Lower-ranking government officials like foreign ministers and finance ministers, and officials from big international organisations, such as the World Bank and IMF, have not been slow to follow suit.

Sometimes, however, as in Prague last month and Seattle last year, those not invited to attend such summits - which usually means everybody but the self-selected, favoured few - get uppity, demonstrate, and play party-poopers. The usual response is, however, to plan yet another summit which will be less easy to subvert.

5. The summit of ambition. Really historic summits are much rarer than one might think. The meeting earlier this year between the leaders of the two Koreas, after a virtual state of war lasting more than 50 years, could be said to be a truly significant event that will have a direct, positive impact on millions of lives. That was recognised last week when President Kim Dae-jung of South Korea was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize.

6. The silly summit. Perhaps the opposite of the Korean summit meeting was the truly ridiculous UN millennium summit in New York last month. This was attended by the leaders of more than 150 countries and, basically substance-free. Despite the best efforts of Kofi Annan, it became a jamboree turned photo-op. There were lots of fond hopes expressed, but no discernible benefits accrued to anyone except perhaps the participants and their partners - who got to go shopping in the Big Apple.

fields.headline: Lastminutetravel.com - bags packed and ready to fly to the UK
fields.standfirst: US website Lastminutetravel.com has delayed its UK launch until it finds a suitable partner. Amy Vickers reports on a company waiting for the right moment.
fields.trailText: US website Lastminutetravel.com has delayed its UK launch until it finds a suitable partner. Amy Vickers reports on a company waiting for the right moment.
fields.body:
Lastminutetravel.com, the US website that made headline news a few months ago when it said it planned to launch in the UK, has delayed the launch until it finds a suitable partner.

However, David Vis, managing director of Europe, Middle East and Asia for Lastminutetravel.com, said he was close to signing a deal that would enable the company to move into the UK.

Mr Vis said he was considering three options: finding a partner with an existing sales force; working with a travel company; or seeking investment from an external partner.

Mr Vis said Lastminutetravel.com was not over-protective about its brand name in international markets and was flexible about working with partners and competitors. Given the similarity in name with Lastminute.com - which, in Mr Vis' words had "two-thirds of the best name in the business" - this is a sensible strategy, particularly since Lastminute.com had voiced its objections to the US site over its UK plans.

This is even though Lastminutetravel.com has been using its name for more than a year longer than lastminute.com. Mr Vis said he was talking to a number of aggregator-type travel companies that hadn't made an impact in the online space about partnership deals.

"We can co-exist with everyone else. All the big travel companies have to have an online presence and we're not the people to take those away," Mr Vis said. "We can work in tandem."

His modest attitude is a far cry from the bullish arrogance everyone has come to expect from American companies planning to take on Europe. "Lastminutetravel.com works well in the States because it has been prudent and grown organically, rather than spent a fortune on marketing and expansion," he added.

In the US, Lastminutetravel.com lists between 200,000-1m flights and breaks each day. Its business model is based on fixed fees for advertising inventory listings, rather than commission on sales like Lastminute.com.

Mr Vis pointed out that the entry point to the site could be as low as $100 per month to $50,000 for larger companies with more inventory to list. "No one will object to paying you if you provide a valuable service."

Meanwhile, Thomas Cook today redesigned its website, thomascook.com, adding a new flights channel to allow it to compete with the likes of ebookers and Expedia.

fields.headline: Garlic
fields.standfirst: All you need to know about the stinking rose, and why one's head of state will not be doing as the Romans do
fields.trailText: All you need to know about the stinking rose, and why one's head of state will not be doing as the Romans do.
fields.body:
1. The Queen is in Rome, visiting the Pope. As is customary, she has let it be known, discreetly of course, that seafood will not be on the menu. This is not, as Alan Coren suggested on Radio Four, because she is Jewish.

2. Somehow it has also been rumoured that she does not care for garlic.

3. That's a shame, we respectfully suggest, because garlic is not only nice, but tremendously good for you. Indeed, it's chic to reek.

4. It has any number of medicinal properties, some of them rather obscure.

5. It is known to reduce cholesterol, and may even help prevent cancer.

6. It's also terribly good for pregnant women, ma'am.

7. There are a great many myths about garlic. Like how it is bad for vampires, but good for conceiving girls.

8. It can be consumed, in a non-monarchical context, in any number of delicious ways, some of them decidedly novel.

9. In short, it's easy to grow, it's very good for you, and it is an important part of one's heritage.

10. Oh, and Greeks like it.

fields.headline: Ebookers posts record results
fields.trailText: 10.30am: Online travel firm Ebookers.com has said it is on track to turn in a profit at the end of 2001, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
European online travel firm Ebookers.com has said it is on track to turn in a profit at the end of 2001.

The company has reported record financial results for the third quarter to September 30, beating analysts' expectations by an average of 11%.

The company's sales for the third quarter were worth $32.6m (£21.2m), 303% up on the same period last year. Its number of registered users grew to 740,000, up from 500,000 in the second quarter, with 7.5m page impressions.

While Ebookers is London-based, it chose to list on Frankfurt's NeuerMarkt and the US Nasdaq.

Ebookers' chairman and chief executive, Dinesh Dhamija, added that fourth-quarter bookings have begun well, leaving him optimistic that Ebookers will deliver strong growth again next quarter.
