webTitle: In brief: Winslet family gets one bigger

fields.headline: Winslet family gets one bigger
fields.trailText: Plus: Beckett fans think Day-Lewis is Krapp, first-round KO pending for Ali project, Kirsten Scott-Thomas in the House and Paquin for Buffalo Soldiers
fields.body:
 Kate Winslet has given birth to a baby girl. The baby, who weighed 3.9kg [8lb 9oz], was born at a London hospital at 5.40am on Thursday morning. The Titantic star and her husband director Jim Threapleton have named her Mia, after deciding against any of the ten names on their shortlist. Winslet's New York-based agent Robert Garlock, said: "There is no family significance, they just thought it was a really beautiful name." Mother and daughter are doing well and will be out of hospital tomorrow. Winslet will take a seven-month career break so she can raise her daughter.

 Fervent fans of Irish playwright Samuel Beckett are furious that Daniel Day-Lewis is to play their idol in a new biopic, according to Ananova. Although the British star now lives in Ireland and holds an Irish passport, fans claim he is as "Gaelic as spaghetti" and believe Irish actors Gabriel Bryne, Liam Neeson or Adrian Dunbar should be considered for the role. However producer Noel Pearson, who cast Day-Lewis in the award-winning My Left Foot, believes he is the right man for the job: "Daniel is my first choice. Nobody can doubt his pedigree."

 Will Smith's regular work-outs at the gym may have been in vain as the future of the Muhammed Ali biopic looks shaky. According to Yahoo news, producers Sony are on the verge of scrapping the Michael Mann-directed project, because it looks set to go over the $105m budget mark. Studio execs are holding a final meeting today with Mann (Oscar-nominated this year for The Insider) to see if the cost can somehow be trimmed.

 Kristin Scott Thomas has signed up to star alongside Kevin Kline in a new family drama called Life as a House, according to Yahoo news.Thomas will play the divorced wife of Kline, who after alienating the most important people in his life, sets out to fulfil his lifelong dream of building the perfect house. The house becomes the foundation for cementing the relationships he's neglected, most importantly with his ex-wife and his son. Irwin "At First Sight" Winkler will direct

 X-Girl Anna Paquin is in final negotiations to star in the dark comedy Buffalo Soldiers alongside Joaquin Phoenix and Ed Harris, which is slated to begin shooting next week in Germany. Based on Robert O'Connor's cult novel of the same name, the story deals with a criminal subculture among a group of young US soldiers in West Germany, during the fall of the Berlin Wall in 1989.

fields.headline: Cave quits Lowe Group
fields.trailText: 11.15am: Marc Cave, the executive vice-president of the Lowe Group, has resigned to launch his own venture, writes Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Marc Cave, the executive vice-president of the Lowe Group, has resigned to launch his own venture.

Louise Higgins, corporate communications director at the Lowe Group, confirmed that Mr Cave left the agency on Friday but declined to release details about his plans.

Sources say that Frank Lowe, the agency's founder, is planning to assist Mr Cave's start-up with financial backing. Ms Higgins denied these rumours.

Mr Cave joined the Lowe Group in 1988 as an account manager.

Ms Higgins added that at this stage there were no plans to replace Mr Cave, whose main area of responsibility was digital development.

fields.headline: Mandelson loan row reignited
fields.standfirst:
Ex-minister Robinson gives his side of controversy but No 10 hopes memoirs will be one-day wonder

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText:
Geoffrey Robinson's long-awaited attack on Peter
Mandelson for "lying" over the circumstances of his
£373,000 home loan turned into a political damp squib
early today when an account given in the former
paymaster general's memoirs proved to be only slightly
different from Mr Mandelson's own version.
fields.body:
Geoffrey Robinson's long-awaited attack on Peter Mandelson for "lying" over the circumstances of his £373,000 home loan turned into a political damp squib early today when an account given in the former paymaster general's memoirs proved to be only slightly different from Mr Mandelson's own version.

Despite extensive pre-publicity and predictions that the Northern Ireland secretary would be forced to resign for a second time from Tony Blair's cabinet, the supposedly "explosive" serialisation of Mr Robinson's book in today's Daily Mail gave Downing Street hope that it will prove a one-day wonder.

Last night the shadow chief secretary to the Treasury, David Heathcoat-Amory, demanded a fresh Commons investigation. But the Tories had earlier shot their own fox by rashly reissuing a detailed eight-page critique of Mr Robinson's chequered business record that will make it much harder to say his version should be preferred.

In any case, the discrepancies appear to be those of tone and detail only, which may also help justify David Blunkett's pre-publication complaint yesterday that the former Treasury minister - whom even Gordon Brown had asked not to write An Unconventional Minister - is engaged in self-important point-scoring.

In today's extract, Mr Robinson describes how the two men, then friends, met for dinner at the millionaire businessman's Park Lane flat in May 1996. "He was looking for a loan. He initiated the discussion of his financial circumstances and of his flat. He told me how miserable he felt there. What I heard from Peter was a cri de coeur," he writes.

After hearing Mr Mandelson say he how had set his heart on living in fashionably expensive Notting Hill and that he had no one to help him Mr Robinson admits: "At this point I said financially I was in a good position and that I might be able to assist if he wanted me to."

Though some details are at odds with what Mr Mandelson told Donald Macintyre in his biography and what he told the Commons standards watchdog, Elizabeth Filkin, after the secret loan was revealed in the Guardian in 1998, the main thrust is clearly the same: that Mr Mandelson raised his home-hunting problems, but that Mr Robinson, a famously generous colleague, made the initial offer.

Mr Robinson, who quit the government with Mr Mandelson in December 1998, but did not - unlike the old friend he now regards as an enemy - return to office 10 months later, also repeats well-aired complaints about Mr Mandelson as a "divisive and destabilising" figure in the Blair inner circle - the view of Gordon Brown's allies which is reciprocated. Tony Blair has often blamed both sides.

Mr Robinson's former colleague Mr Blunkett, the education secretary, used a BBC1 interview to slap him down. "My view is that those who have benefited a great deal from politics, or are in a position because of their wealth to be able to enjoy a comfortable life whatever happens, need to bear in mind the people in constituencies like mine who rely on a Labour government to have a job, to have a decent education, to have a health service to be proud of, and then reflect on what self-indulgence means for those people we represent," he said on Breakfast with Frost.

Ministers and officials who have suffered a series of autumn embarrassments from political books this year endorsed Mr Blunkett's view that the millionaire businessman's book was irrelevant to most voters.

One aide to Gordon Brown called it "ancient history" and another minister called it "Geoffrey's revenge".

The book may not prove to have any lasting political damage given two weekend opinion polls. They confirmed that Labour is back in front after the fuel crisis, at 42%, to 35% for the Tories and 17% for the Liberal Democrats, according to a Sunday Times/NOP poll, and by 40%/38%/19% according to Mori in the Mail on Sunday.

There remains deep resentment that Mr Robinson's sense of grievance at not being restored to office has prompted him to go public, albeit with a book that will mainly deal with dry policy matters. Mr Blair is grappling with the fallout from Donald Dewar's death, while Mr Mandelson, now Northern Ireland secretary, faces crucial negotiations to save the peace process.

One of Mr Robinson's allies, Paul Routledge, the Daily Mirror commentator and Brown biographer, told Sky Television that Mr Robinson was "not a man who tells lies. I think we should respect his truth."

fields.headline: News leaves nine with a whimper
fields.standfirst: Panorama's Sunday service
fields.trailText: 12.45pm overnights: The last ever BBC1 9pm news bowed out on a downbeat note on Friday night with disappointing ratings, writes Jason Deans.Panorama's Sunday service
fields.body:
The last ever BBC1 9pm news bulletin bowed out on a downbeat note on Friday night with ratings subdued despite a bumper news day with the Middle East crisis and much of the south-east of England under water.

The final 9pm BBC News, anchored by Peter Sissons with George Alagiah reporting live from Tel Aviv, averaged 5m and a 22% share, according to unofficial overnights.

Following on at 9.30pm, the last Friday night outing for Parkinson before its move to Saturday night was also disappointing, taking 5.5m/25%. Both BBC1 programmes lost out to ITV's 9pm Bond movie repeat, Tomorrow Never Dies (9.2m/43%).

On Sunday night, BBC1 premiered Superhuman (6.3m/27%), Professor Robert Winston's follow-up to The Human Body, from 9.10pm. The human anatomy documentary lost out to the third part of ITV's Ross Kemp police drama, Without Motive (8.6m/38%), which moved seamlessly from its 9pm Monday night berth (where last week it attracted 8.3m/36%).

There were two terrestrial film premieres on other channels last night. Channel 4 had The People vs Larry Flynt (1.5m/14%) from 10.10pm, while Channel 5 debuted Jackie Chan's First Strike (2m/9%) at 9pm. At 9.10pm on Channel 4, the Witness religious documentary strand returned with a look at the rise in violent crime in South Africa that has been linked to Satanists (1.1m/5%).

Earlier on Sunday night, BBC1 aired the concluding episode of a two-part Casualty special featuring an Aids scare and British TV drama's first gay wedding (7.9m/30%), from 8.10pm. The drama lost out to a 60-minute Who Wants to be a Millionaire? (13.4m/51%) on ITV.

The previous evening, the first instalment of the Casualty special (9.2m/40%) beat ITV's Family Fortunes (6.7m/29%) from 8.05pm. But later in the evening, ITV terrestrial movie premiere, Speed 2: Cruise Control (6.9m/35%), got the better of a BBC1 Dalziel and Pascoe repeat (7m/32%) and Match of the Day (4.3m/28%) from 9pm.

Channel 4's Saturday night line-up included a third annual outing for The Power List (0.9m/4%) from 8pm and Top Ten: 1990 (2.1m/10%), a slight revision of the broadcaster's successful Top Ten format, from 9pm.

Channel 5 gave viewers a double dose of the US drama import, Charmed (0.9/4% and 0.9m/5%) from 9-10.50pm. The show stars Shannon Doherty as one of three sisters who inherit witchcraft powers from their grandmother,

webTitle: JK Rowling to write Hogwarts textbooks

fields.headline: JK Rowling to write Hogwarts textbooks
fields.trailText: Harry Potter author JK Rowling is to write two short books for charity. They won't, however, feature the adventures of her world-famous boy wizard, but the curriculum for his magic lessons.
fields.body:
Harry Potter author JK Rowling is to write two short books for charity. They won't, however, feature the adventures of her world-famous boy wizard, but the curriculum for his magic lessons.

The multimillionaire writer has promised to produce Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them and Quidditch Through the Ages in time for Comic Relief Day on March 16 2001.

The titles will be instantly recognisable to Harry Potter fans, as they already feature in the Potter books as textbooks at the school for wizards, Hogwarts, where Harry's adventures take place.

Rowling, who is currently on a book tour in the United States, said: "I have always had a secret hankering to write these two books, so when Richard Curtis [of Comic Relief] wrote to me, I thought it was a wonderful opportunity to be involved with a charity I have always supported."

The Harry Potter books have been a national and international success, making Rowling the UK's top woman earner. She originally planned to write a Harry Potter book a year, one for each year Harry attends Hogwarts, but isn't keen to follow him into adulthood.

webTitle: Nicholas Watt on Labour women MPs

fields.headline: Race and gender prove a hindrance
fields.standfirst:
Labour Party picks a man over three women to fight byelection

Special report: New Labour in power
Special report: Parliament
fields.trailText: Labour Party picks a man over three women to fight byelection, reports Nicholas Watt.
fields.body:
They are all making outstanding contributions to their professions and they represent a cross section of multicultural Britain. Yet none of the three women who made it onto the shortlist for the Labour nomination in Betty Boothroyd's seat will be going to Westminster.

After a short but intense battle last month, Labour selected Adrian Bailey, a local stalwart, to fight the byelection in West Bromwich West.

Few have a harsh word to say about Mr Bailey, the deputy leader of the local Sandwel borough council. But the overwhelming selection of a male local worthy, ahead of three impressive women, provides Millbank with an uncomfortable illustration of the difficulties faced by women trying to win Labour nominations.

All three women who made the shortlist of six, have impressive CVs which would place them above many MPs at Westminster.

Valerie Vaz, the sister of the Europe minister Keith Vaz, is a highly articulate lawyer who had been tipped as the front-runner for the nomination. Susanna McCorry, 47, a Birmingham city councillor who is married with two children, has a strong record on housing in the city where she runs a housing trust. Sandra Samuels, 42, is a cardiac nursing sister from Wolverhampton with a 20-year NHS track record.

The three candidates, who are all still hoping to win one of the few remaining Labour nominations, choose their language carefully when they recall their experiences in West Bromwich West. Labour officials drew up the shortlist, using the party's byelection procedure, after interviewing the candidates at Millbank. Local members then had the final say at a meeting last month.

Ms Vaz, a veteran of the 1999 European parliamentary elections and the 1987 general election when she contested the hopeless seat of Twickenham, said she did not encounter blatant sexism. The local party had made up its mind that it wanted a local candidate who was a man. However, the twin disadvantages of being Asian and a woman appear to have counted against her.

"I knew it was going to be difficult because I was told that they could not run an Asian candidate in the byelection because of the threat from the National Front," Ms Vaz said. "I would have been a high-profile Asian woman and that counted against me."

Ms Vaz said her experience shows that the Labour party suffers from the sort of "institutional racism" identified in the Macpherson report. "People are not racist to your face," she said. "But there is an inherent culture in the Labour party where many do not see an Asian woman as MP potential. Thankfully, there are many people in the party who are supportive."

Her rivals also felt that the party had already made its mind up to select someone in the same mould as male local members. Ms McCorry said: "I am concerned about how local members decide on candidates generally. In West Bromwich West there were three women who were very competent and were up to the job. But it is difficult to say whether there was sexism. Certainly in my field in local government, there is not."

Ms Samuels, who was delighted to reach the shortlist on her first outing, was not put off. She felt that the Millbank interviews had been fair, although she hopes that the party will step up its efforts to ensure there are more women MPs.

"The Labour party has far more male MPs and the old boys' network is something the party will have to address," she said. "We have a lot of female MPs leaving the house and I hope that there will be far more coming through."

The winner dismissed any suggestion that sexism had worked in his favour.

Mr Bailey said: "Given that the neighbouring MP is a woman - Sylvia Heal - I can say that is not the issue."

fields.headline: The Way You See It
fields.trailText: Premiership highs and woes
fields.body:
Premiership highs and woes

After yesterday's 4-0 trouncing of Derby, Liverpool are in sniffing distance of Manchester United and Arsenal. And Nicholas Bawden for one, is starting to believe that it might just their year. "Last season, Liverpool's start was dire despite playing much better football," he says. "Maybe now they've developed a Manchester United-esque knack of getting results while playing badly. And when we click - boy we click. If we get on a similar roll as the period just after Christmas last year, the rest of the league - even United - had better watch out."

But elsewhere the mood is gloomy, as early season optimism gives way to mid-October reality. Martin Thain is an exasperated Spurs' fan, unhappy at George Graham's reluctance to blood his young reserves. "The lack of mobility, pace and vision from Freund and Sherwood in midfield is obvious and yet still there is no call up for King or Davies who have been starring for the reserves," he laments.

"Vega's routine mistakes are now exactly that, routine, and are causing at least a goal a game. Thelwell, Gardener and Young are all surely more adequate understudies in Campbell's absence. And, by all accounts, Doherty would show more effort, skill and guile at partnering Rebrov than Ferdinand.

"The whole country has been impressed by the way Leeds have shaped up since Graham left the club, with O'Leary giving all the promising youngsters a chance. It's just a shame that Tottenham can't do the same."

Richard Williams: The Backlash

On Friday, a majority of readers seemed to agree with Richard Williams, who argued that 24 out of England's 27-man squad that faced Germany and Finland should be culled, and the high-fliers from Peter Taylor's U-21 squad brought in.

However, over the weekend the tide has turned.

"Thank God Richard Williams isn't England coach," writes Simon Kitson. "His idea is little short of ridiculous. The problem against Germany was purely a tactical one. The England side lacked width (particularly in the first half) and all the midfield players were playing too centrally.

"Barmby should have been instructed to peel left whilst Beckham should have occupied the right flank. It is as simple as that. That is why we saw nothing of Scholes and Barmby - they were all stepping on each other's feet.

"The problem was repeated against Finland: again we had no width and too many central midfield players. Yes, I agree get rid of some of the has-beens. But to have a wholesale clear-out is simply ridiculous - particularly when you are replacing them with untried elements who can't even get a game at club level."

And Robin Phillip agrees: "I think Richard Williams the jazz critic (I remember that Sun Ra article in '68) got loose on this one. As a strategy for putting England back where they belong it was true sixth-form stuff.

"The new Turks of English football have not proved themselves and are likely to be lesser players than their predecessors by the time they take part in the finals of a major championship.

"There has been no great golden past for English football and perhaps it would be more instructive to see this as a period very similar to the seventies when England didn't qualify for any of the major tourneys. Plus ca change."

webTitle: Reuters chairman faces embarrassment over tribunal

fields.headline: Reuters chairman faces embarrassment over tribunal
fields.trailText: 11.30am: Reuters chairman Peter Job is expected to be quoted at an industrial tribunal describing senior women at the company as "adding a bit of spice to the pie". By Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Reuters' chief executive, Peter Job, is expected to be quoted in an industrial tribunal next year describing senior women working within the organisation as "adding a bit of spice to the pie".

The remark was alleged to have been made by Mr Job to former Reuters employee Kim Usher. It was read out by lawyers at a pre-tribunal hearing for Ms Usher and Jonathan Birt, another former employee, who are bringing charges of constructive dismissal, sexual discrimination and bullying against the news organisation.

Ms Usher will claim sexual discrimination was behind Reuters' failure to find her a position of "equivalent seniority" within the organisation after it axed Project Sunrise, one of its internet ventures, last February.

A date has been set for the tribunal of May 1 2001. Solicitors for Ms Usher and Mr Birt refused to confirm reports that ITN chairman and managing director, Reuters content, Mark Wood will appear voluntarily as a witness, but said Mr Wood "indicated that he was willing".

Reuters has been ordered to hand over documents relating to job offers made to Ms Usher and Mr Birt, who were given jobs on the now-defunct Project Sunrise. The company will also have to hand over documents relating to the decision to give jobs to "men of equivalent seniority" to Usher, who occupied a senior business development and marketing position.

The company will also be asked to justify the financial reason for its decision to axe Project Sunrise a project set up to provide analysis of corporate developments for private investors, which was quickly superseded by a similar joint venture with German financial newspaper Handelsblatt, codenamed Project Meteor.

Ms Usher will claim that she was induced to stay on at Reuters after revealing she had been offered a similar position, only to be made redundant months later.

Referring to the statement alleged to have been made by Mr Job, the solicitors said: "The quote was made at the hearing. Whether it was accurate is something which will have to be decided when the case comes to court."

In addition to the claims of sexual discrimination, the company faces further embarrassment with regard to its internet strategy. This morning it was reported that Reuters has shelved plans to float its internet start-up fund the Greenhouse Fund.

Reuters declined to comment.

webTitle: Meet the Parents holds out at the top

fields.headline: Meet the Parents holds out at the top
fields.trailText: The Robert De Niro/Ben Stiller comedy Meet the Parents has held onto the box office spot for the second week running in the States
fields.body:
The Robert De Niro/Ben Stiller comedy Meet the Parents has held onto the box office spot for the second week running in the States.

Fighting off stiff competition from football drama Remember the Titans and new Winona Ryder horror Lost Souls, Meet the Parents took around $21.3m this weekend, having grossed around $53m in total.

A remake of the 1993 comedy of the same title, a young woman brings her fiancée (Ben Stiller) home to meet her parents. Her father (Robert De Niro) takes an instant dislike to him and a disastrous family weekend follows thereafter.

The Denzel Washington vehicle Remember the Titans, about a racially mixed football team in the early 1970s, has kept the number two spot, taking around $13.5m.

Despite the supernatural significance of Friday 13, the Winona Ryder's Lost Souls - the story of a young woman's possession by the devil - only managed to debut at number three, taking $8.4m.

The Ladies Man, starring comedian Tim Meadows in a big-screen version of his Saturday Night Live womanising character, came in fourth with $5.7m and the Gary Oldman/Jeff Bridges political thriller The Contender debuted in fifth place with $5.5m. The reissue of The Exorcist came in at number six with $5.4m, while Robert Altman's tale of a gynaecologist's struggle with the many women in his life, Dr. T and the Women, was at number seven with $5.2m.

Despite not entering the top 10, Billy Elliot received mostly favourable reviews when it opened last Friday. The New York Times called it "real and consequential", while Matinee Magazine declared "The quality of the performances help pardon the uneven slushiness of the story."

webTitle: Get Carter director deems remake out of shape

fields.headline: Get Carter director deems remake out of shape
fields.trailText: The director of the original Get Carter has expressed his disappointment that Michael Caine agreed to appear in the recent remake
fields.body:
The director of the original Get Carter has expressed his disappointment that Michael Caine agreed to appear in the recent remake.

Mike Hodges told Ananova: "I don't know why they decided to remake it. For the amount of money spent on it they could have made plenty of original films. Unfortunately I couldn't stop them re-making it."

In the new version of the 1971 film, Sylvester Stallone takes Michael Caine's role as Jack Carter, with Caine in the minor role of Cliff Bumby. Hodges said: "I was surprised Michael agreed to be in the new version. I always thought his performance in my film was the best thing he ever did."

Hodges also said he was surprised at the success of the original and that it has stood the test of time: "The whole process of making the film took about 36 weeks from me being sent the script to Michael coming onboard, filming and everything. It all happened so fast, I never expected it to become the so-called classic it is now."

It looks like Hodges could have been right about the remake; when it opened in the States a few weeks ago, the critics were unrelenting. "How does a numbing mishmash of a movie like this get made?" asked one, with another claiming, "The original was a great movie that reeked of despair and emptiness. This one is just damp and mildewy."

fields.headline: Kirtley waits for the call
fields.standfirst: Every Monday wisden.com talks to a cricketing figure about his plans for the close season. This week we ask Sussex seamer James Kirtley to spill the beans
fields.trailText: James Kirtley, 25 is a right-arm seamer. He has played six seasons at Sussex and topped their first-class bowling averages in 2000 with 63 wickets at 24.75. He toured Bangladesh and New Zealand with England A last year and has just been named one of the standbys for this winter's England A tour of West Indies.
fields.body:
James Kirtley, 25 is a right-arm seamer. He has played six seasons at Sussex and topped their first-class bowling averages in 2000 with 63 wickets at 24.75. He toured Bangladesh and New Zealand with England A last year and has just been named one of the standbys for this winter's England A tour of West Indies.

"Being on standby for the A tour is a bit of a bonus. Last year they announced the standbys a couple of days after the main squad, so when I didn't hear anything for a while [they announced the main squads in September] I had visions of a long winter lay-off.

"I've had to make some slight changes to my plans: I'll have to keep some sort of form and fitness now. Up until a couple of weeks ago I'd thought of going away in January and February to Zimbabwe, but now I won't obviously. It's not frustrating though - certainly better than not being on standby. I was on standby last year and managed to get the call-up. There are four of us in reserve this time; hopefully I might be the lucky one.

"I'm in the middle of moving house at the moment. I'm staying in Eastbourne but going to a nicer part of town. I've got to buy some furniture, and make an effort to learn a little bit about DIY and wallpaper. I did a little bit in my old place but didn't really know what I was doing - just slapped on a bit of paint to make it look different. This is a longer-term thing. It's got three bedrooms and a little box room. When my brother comes back from university he'll live in one of them.

"I'm rushing around with solicitors' letters trying to exchange contracts at the moment before I go on holiday. We fly out to Cape Town on Tuesday [tomorrow] for three or four days of parties and beaches and stuff - all the things you can't do when you have to worry about cricket - and then go on to Namibia. I'm going with a few friends - it's the first time I've had a decent, proper holiday for ages and it's going to be pure pleasure.

"I've spent the last two winters coaching in Namibia, and I want to do all the things like going on safari which you have no chance to do if you actually live over there. The Namibian national team plays in the South African 2nd XI competition. They are allowed to play an overseas player so I had some games too. They play about five three-day games over six months, so you just do enough to keep your fitness up.

"I'm doing bits of coaching at Eastbourne College (a public school in Sussex). I did a little bit last year which I really enjoyed, but I tend to enjoy coaching the more talented players. It sounds really awful but I get frustrated with the others, but it isn't a bad lesson for me to work with the less talented kids.

"I've been away for the last two winters so I didn't really see that much of my team-mates. We made the big promises at the end of the season but I'm not sure whether it will happen. People like Mark Robinson and Tony Cottey go off to Yorkshire and Glamorgan so the chance of seeing them is pretty remote. We all live in each other's pockets during the season so it is quite nice to get away from it all.

"I'll be following what England get up to quite avidly - I kept an eye on what went on in Kenya. I might try and do a computer course too if I can, there are a world of opportunities once you know what you're doing with them."

James Kirtley was talking to Tanya Aldred

webTitle: Man Utd signs new PR chief

fields.headline: Manchester Utd signs FT man as PR chief
fields.trailText: 11.45am: Manchester United has hired Patrick Harverson as its new director of communications. By Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Manchester United has hired Patrick Harverson, the sports business correspondent of the Financial Times, as its new director of communications.

The news comes less than a month after the Premier League club picked Alison Ryan to be its new PR chief. Ms Ryan was dismissed before she had even started the job after it emerged that she had been banned from practising law because of serious professional misconduct.

Peter Kenyon, the new chief executive of Manchester United, said he would make communications his "number one priority" when he took over from Martin Edwards in July. Mr Harverson, who has been a United supporter since he was seven years old, joins on December 2 and faces the difficult task of improving the club's relationship with the media and its own supporters.

webTitle: The man in the moustache takes Madrid to the top

fields.headline: The man in the moustache takes Madrid to the top
fields.standfirst: Real head onwards and upwards, as Javier Clemente gets ready for the boot
fields.trailText: Vicente del Bosque, the man who has successfully cultivated the world's greatest moustache, also appears to have put together a pretty good football team. His new look Real Madrid took advantage of Celta Vigo's 1-1 draw at home to Alavés to go top of the table with a comfortable 3-0 victory against champions Deportivo la Coruña at the Santiago Bernabéu on Saturday night. (Although some would no doubt argue that replacing the skinny, floppy-haired floating midfielder Steve McManaman with the, er, skinny floppy haired floating midfielder Guti hardly represents a new look).
fields.body:
Vicente del Bosque, the man who has successfully cultivated the world's greatest moustache, also appears to have put together a pretty good football team. His new look Real Madrid took advantage of Celta Vigo's 1-1 draw at home to Alavés to go top of the table with a comfortable 3-0 victory against champions Deportivo la Coruña at the Santiago Bernabéu on Saturday night. (Although some would no doubt argue that replacing the skinny, floppy-haired floating midfielder Steve McManaman with the, er, skinny floppy haired floating midfielder Guti hardly represents a new look).

Raúl opened the scoring with an almost apologetic finish from Figo's run and cross, Hierro converted a penalty after Roberto Carlos was brought down, and on-form Guti wrapped it up in the second half, scoring his forth of the season with a header (ok, so there is a difference between Guti and Macca).

The Madrid fans' delight must have been tempered by the scores coming in from the Basque Country, though. Rivals Barcelona were busy filling their boots, handing out a 6-0 thrashing to Real Sociedad at the Anoeta Olympic Stadium.

The home side were undone in just forty minutes. The star of the show was Portuguese winger Simao, who has shown so far this season that he may just about be able to step into Luis Figo's shoes, if not his bank account. It was he who beat Aranzabal for pace, creating an easy opener for Rivaldo. Alfonso, Barcelona's summer signing from Betis, added two more in quick succession, shooting home after a Luis Enrique corner on 16 minutes and beating Mattias Asper from distance five minutes later.

Real appeared to give up at that point. Rivaldo, from the penalty spot, Luis Enrique and Simao completed the scoring before half time. Even Real Sociedad's magnificent second-half clean sheet couldn't placate the fans, who booed their side from the field.

The result was a huge blow to Javier Clemente, the man Spaniards love to hate. He now looks set to become the second managerial casualty of the season after Zaragoza's Juan Manuel Lillo - sacked after his side threw away a 4-1 second leg second half lead in the Uefa Cup.

Perhaps scared that what goes around comes around, Barcelona manager Llorenç Serra Ferrer wouldn't criticise Clemente's side, insisting that the result was a reflection of "our quality not their failings." Mind you, the ex-Betis coach, another manager under pressure, would say that: rumours continue to suggest that he is soon to be replaced by Valencia coach Héctor Cúper or ex-Chelsea boss Gianluca Vialli.

Elsewhere, Valencia, like Celta, passed up the chance to move to the top of the table, only managing a 1-1 draw at newly promoted Villarreal. Meanwhile, Real Mallorca picked up their first win of the season, coming from behind to beat Racing Santander 2-1. Las Palmas (as in Vinny Samways) defeated Málaga by the same scoreline, and delighted fans were treated to torrential rain and no goals between Espanyol and Rayo, Zaragoza and Valladolid, Numancia and Athletic and Osasuna and Oviedo.

Attention now turns to this weekend's 'derbi' encounter between Real and Barca. And what attention. Readers of the Spanish sporting press will be subjected to merciless hyperbole for the rest of the week and beyond. We'll see who sits next to who on Madrid's flight to the Catalan capital, what the scores were in the training-ground five-a-sides, and every other piece of pointless information you could wish for..

Real Madrid captain Fernando Hierro somewhat inevitably claimed that Barça's 6-0 victory "doesn't scare us." Maybe not, but team-mate Luis Figo may be just a tad nervous. 'The world's most expensive player' is in line for a hot reception in the Camp Nou, where Real Madrid haven't won for seventeen years.

Barcelona president Joan Gaspart insists he will suppress his "true feelings" in the directors box, but wouldn't make any guarantees about the supporters, or "culés": "who am I to say how the fans should behave?" he said. "I hope they express how they feel, that they are true to themselves ... Figo should be made to realise that in life you simply can't do what he did to us."

Rumours in the Spanish press suggest that over 300,000 whistles will be distributed to Barcelona fans keen to welcome Figo back. Questions must remain over the Catalans' ability to count, though - the Nou Camp's capacity is only around 90,000.

fields.headline: Oldman angered by Democrat slant
fields.trailText: Gary Oldman is apparently furious with Stephen Spielberg's DreamWorks company for turning his new political drama The Contender into a propaganda film for the Democrats
fields.body:
Gary Oldman is apparently furious with Stephen Spielberg's DreamWorks company for turning his new political drama The Contender into a propaganda film for the Democrats.

The film, which opened in the States last Friday, stars Jeff Bridges as a dying US president about to hand the reins of power over to his female deputy Joan Allen.

Oldman appears as an extreme right-wing Republican congressman, who tries to dig up dirt on Allen in the hope that the administration will collapse.

However, Oldman claims the film, directed by Rod Lurie, has been "tampered" with and "dumbed down" according to Ananova

Oldman has apparently told friends that DreamWorks, which is run by Spielberg, David Geffen and ex-Disney chief Jeffrey Katzenberg, had turned the story into a "propaganda exercise".

A friend said: "He thought they were getting a message across about The System. Instead, they've delivered a promotional film for the Democrats close to the election. It's so obvious."

The Contender opens in the UK in the New Year.

webTitle: Vivendi sacrifices BSkyB stake for Seagram success

fields.headline: Vivendi sacrifices BSkyB stake for Seagram success
fields.standfirst:
End of the line for uneasy alliance between Messier and Murdoch

October 16: Vivendi Seagram count the cost of their union
October 13: Jean-Marie Messier poised to sell BSkyB stake
October 13: BSkyB shares hit
October 12: Messier's global vision
October 11: Deal faces EC scrutiny
Special report: Merger mania
fields.trailText:
Vivendi, the French media and telecoms group, yesterday agreed to sell its 23% holding in BSkyB as a means of gaining approval for its £66bn merger with Canada's Seagram. By David Teather and Jon Henley in Paris.
October 16: Vivendi Seagram count the cost of their union
October 13: Jean-Marie Messier poised to sell BSkyB stake
October 13: BSkyB shares hit
October 12: Messier's global vision
October 11: Deal faces EC scrutiny
Special report: Merger mania
fields.byline: David Teather and Jon Henley in Paris
fields.body:
Vivendi, the French media and telecoms group, yesterday agreed to sell its 23% holding in BSkyB as a means of gaining approval for its £66bn merger with Canada's Seagram.

The European commission set three conditions as it gave approval to the creation of what will be called Vivendi Universal. It has already been cleared in the US.

The business will span mobile phone networks, the Universal Hollywood studios, Universal Music, internet portals and pay television in Europe. The deal had been hailed in June as the first European media group which could meet rivals in the US eye to eye.

The agreement to divest the BSkyB shares ends what has on occasion been an uncomfortable relationship between Rupert Murdoch, whose News Corporation controls the company, and Jean-Marie Messier of Vivendi.

The divestment, which was announced yesterday morning, had little effect on the BSkyB share price, which closed up 7p at 907p. The sale could also mean that Vivendi will no longer become a significant shareholder in Sky Global Networks, the holding company for all of Mr Murdoch's satellite pay-television businesses which is due for a stock market flotation later this year.

Mr Messier hinted that he could still play a part in the new SGN company, however, and said: "All doors remain open". BSkyB's link to the Fox film studios through News Corp was the EC's main cause for concern. Vivendi has two years to sell its stake. "We will take our time and examine together with Rupert Murdoch the best way to exit from BSkyB for both us and News Corp," Mr Messier said.

The divestment, he added, would be made with a view to maintaining "the excellent quality" of their relationship.

Under the second EC stipulation, Vivendi must offer to rival pay-TV operators access to Universal's film output . It has guaranteed that its own pay-TV operation, Canal+, will not hold first rights to more than 50% of Universal's film production.

The Canal+ commitment covers the French, Belgian, Italian, Dutch, Spanish and Nordic countries over a five-year period. The third issue was Vivendi's multi-access internet portal, Vizzavi, which caused competitive concerns over the emerging online music market. To answer that worry, Vivendi will offer rival portals access to Universal's online music content, also for five years.

Last year Mr Messier attempted to broker a merger between Canal+ and BSkyB but the talks ended in acrimony over which side would emerge in control of the combined operation. Mr Messier then rattled Mr Murdoch by building a stake of 25% in BSkyB, which has since been diluted by new shares being issued. Relations between the two men though are said to have warmed.

A BSkyB spokesman said: "Vivendi has been a very supportive shareholder over the past year. We now intend to enter into discussions with Vivendi with a view to ensuring an orderly disposal of their stake."

The deal cements Mr Messier's position as one of the most powerful media figures worldwide. Since he took the helm of what was then Générale-des-Eaux in 1996, Mr Messier has reshaped the utility as a media and communications business.

Seagram's Universal music publishing business is the largest in the world and includes artists Boyzone, Elton John and Shania Twain, while its film business has scored hits with The Mummy and Gladiator.

Its television arm produces shows including Xena Warrior Princess and has a library of programmes such as Kojak, Murder She Wrote and Miami Vice providing a wealth of content for Vivendi's pay-TV networks.

Mr Messier hinted that he could still play a part in the new SGN company, however, and said: "All doors remain open". BSkyB's link to the Fox film studios through News Corp was the EC's main cause for concern. Vivendi has two years to sell its stake. "We will take our time and examine together with Rupert Murdoch the best way to exit from BSkyB for both us and News Corp," Mr Messier said. The divestment, he added, would be made with a view to maintaining "the excellent quality" of their relationship. Under the second EC stipulation, Vivendi must offer to rival pay-TV operators access to Universal's film output . It has guaranteed that its own pay-TV operation, Canal+, will not hold first rights to more than 50% of Universal's film production. The Canal+ commitment covers the French, Belgian, Italian, Dutch, Spanish and Nordic countries over a five-year period. The third issue was Vivendi's multi-access internet portal, Vizzavi, which caused competitive concerns over the emerging online music market. To answer that worry, Vivendi will offer rival portals access to Universal's online music content, also for five years. Last year Mr Messier attempted to broker a merger between Canal+ and BSkyB but the talks ended in acrimony over which side would emerge in control of the combined operation. Mr Messier then rattled Mr Murdoch by building a stake of 25% in BSkyB, which has since been diluted by new shares being issued. Relations between the two men though are said to have warmed. A BSkyB spokesman said: "Vivendi has been a very supportive shareholder over the past year. We now intend to enter into discussions with Vivendi with a view to ensuring an orderly disposal of their stake." The deal cements Mr Messier's position as one of the most powerful media figures worldwide. Since he took the helm of what was then Générale-des-Eaux in 1996, Mr Messier has reshaped the utility as a media and communications business. Seagram's Universal music publishing business is the largest in the world and includes artists Boyzone, Elton John and Shania Twain, while its film business has scored hits with The Mummy and Gladiator. Its television arm produces shows including Xena Warrior Princess and has a library of programmes such as Kojak, Murder She Wrote and Miami Vice providing a wealth of content for Vivendi's pay-TV networks.

fields.headline: AA forecasts 40% growth in ad expenditure
fields.trailText: 11.30am: The Advertising Association has predicted a rise of more than 40% in ad expenditure over the next 12 years. By Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
The Advertising Association has predicted a rise of more than 40% in advertising expenditure over the next 12 years.

Its 2000 edition of the Long Term Advertising Expenditure Forecast covers annual expenditure trends to 2012 in nine media - television, national newspapers, regional newspapers, consumer magazines, business magazines, directories, outdoor, radio and cinema - and seven product sectors including recruitment, other classified, retail, industrial, financial/services, durables and consumables.

Andrew Brown, the AA's director-general, said: "The good news is that there are excellent prospects of economic growth throughout the forecast period, with growth being higher and more stable than has been the norm in the past. Since advertising revenue usually follows the economy but is more volatile, this would normally suggest a generally prosperous future for the industry.

"The more problematic issue, at least as far as some existing media are concerned, is that technological change is likely to have an impact on current revenue sources. The two key areas here, which the forecast considers, are the internet and the fragmentation of TV audiences."

The report claims that the internet would be likely to eat into the classified advertising market, which provides a significant proportion of the revenue of media such as the quality national press, regional newspapers and business magazines.

A similar problem faces commercial television, with a considerable proportion of TV revenue arising from its success as a mass medium. The report concludes that if audience fragmentation makes the medium less attractive to some advertisers, losses could ensue.

The report also shows that contrary to past trends, the minor media - outdoor, radio and cinema - are expected to show the highest and most stable growth rates.

The Advertising Association Long Term Advertising Forecast is available from NTC Publications, Farm Road, Henley-on-Thames, Oxon, RG9 1EJ (Tel - 01491 411000) at £950, or £495 for members of the Advertising Association.

webTitle: Wheels: farewell to the Mini Cooper

fields.headline: The god of small things
fields.standfirst: Giles Smith  bids an emotional farewell to the Mini Cooper - the tiny design marvel that was more than just a car
fields.trailText: Giles Smith bids an emotional farewell to the Mini Cooper - the tiny design marvel that was more than just a car.
fields.body:
I would have liked to have driven the very last Mini Cooper but Lulu beat me to it. Fair enough, I guess. A fortnight ago, in a special ceremony, she drove Mini number 5,387,862 off the belt at Longbridge, whence it was directed straight to the Heritage Motor Museum in Graydon. I settled instead for one of the last batch - just to say goodbye and mark the end of the line. Henceforth, like so much of the British car industry, the Mini will be German - a peculiar fate for a car so boiling with pride in its origins that it comes with "GB" bolted to its boot in chrome.

There will still be new Minis: BMW has been showing one off that will go on sale next year, built at Cowley. But we will have to learn to call them MINIs, BMW having decided that the most efficient way to make a break with the past is if everyone starts referring to the car in capital letters. Apparently queasy in general about the mini-ness of the Mini, BMW has also elected to make it longer by a foot and a half. How many people can you get in a BMW MINI? Quite a few, probably. It will also have big plastic spoilers on the back. There's no easy way to say this without causing lovers of the traditional Mini to drop to their knees: the new BMW MINI will have drinks holders.

The old Mini's association with the 60s seems to have kept the car alive even while quietly throttling it. It's worth remembering that the Mini was created in 1959, well before anyone wore a mini skirt or watched The Italian Job. It may be hard to grasp now, but Sir Alec Issigonis was concerned to design a functional small car rather than something to put underneath Twiggy. But the 60s took a fast grip on the Mini's image and would not be shaken off. Now people can't talk about the car for more than five minutes without doing an impression of Michael Caine.

The Mini Cooper I drove was painted British Racing Green with white stripes on the bonnet and with the laurel wreath logo painted on the side. Even so, it clearly came, not from some wild and crazy era, but from a time when cars were plain and designers sharp. There were no drinks holders. It's just not that kind of car. Coffee to go? Tough.

Time has washed right past it. Different needs now apply. The cabin, for instance, is definitively pre-ergonomic. In the golden age of the Mini, people seem to have had other things to worry about than the long-term future of their spines. The steering wheel tends unusually towards the horizontal, in the manner of bus steering wheels, and would encourage a stooped driving position even if the low roof didn't already demand one. The limited scope offered by the windscreen also seems to incline one to sit forwards and bring one's nose as close as possible to the glass. It is clear that one's posture, as a Mini driver, would win no awards from the British Orthopaedic Association. Indeed, a couple of hours continuously at the wheel and you have to be straightened out with wooden bats.

These days people want cars with cargo holds; the boot on a Mini would fit a small cat. The contemporary driver is nagged by safety issues, too. Rover has gamely stuffed in a driver's airbag and run some additional steel into the doors but the car would still be unlikely to rise to the modern car buyer's expectations of near crash-proof motoring.

The Mini calls for effort from its driver, too, which is deeply unfashionable now. The gear stick is exactly that - not a dinky little stub in a leather pochette, but a metal stick rising out of the floor of the car with a gearknob on the end of it. Miss your gear and it pretty much tears your arm off. Getting the car into reverse requires the deployment of complex muscle groupings in the shoulders, stomach and thighs. I developed a two-hand back-hand motion for this, very much reminiscent of Monica Seles, and with complementary grunt. Doctors advise me the inflammation will subside by Christmas.

But what a thrill to drive: nippy, neat, responsive. There is no namby-pamby power steering on a Mini. These days even the Ford Ka, which is as light as a cereal box, comes power-assisted, which makes driving it just about the least gritty experience you could have on the road - the motoring equivalent of listening to Kenny G. With the Mini, you have to wrestle the thing around - barking, inevitably, your elbows on the window, door and fellow passengers. But at least you know you have been driving.

And it's still a great city car - the best ever. At a London junction, I came up behind the usual confused or plain belligerent road user, straddling two lanes. Being no wider than a lawn-mower, the Mini casually passed on the inside and continued on its merry way. Behind me, a big, dumb ordinary car could only honk and fume. It felt good. I'm going to miss it when it's gone.

The lowdown

Mini Cooper

Price: £8,995 (includes 10% "closing down" reduction)

Top speed: 90 mph

Acceleration: 0-60mph in 12.2 seconds

Consumption: 43 mpg (combined)

At the wheel: Nobody

On the stereo: Nothing

En route for: Nowhere

webTitle: Comment: Harold Evans looks at Gore's new found sycophancy

fields.headline: How Gore lost his head
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: October 14 2000: The second big presidential debate was like nothing so much as the Charge of the Light Brigade at Balaclava in 1854. Instructed to seize the guns, the 600 rode suicidally in the wrong direction, and Al Gore did the same when he faced George Bush in Boston.
fields.body:
The second big presidential debate was like nothing so much as the Charge of the Light Brigade at Balaclava in 1854. Instructed to seize the guns, the 600 rode suicidally in the wrong direction, and Al Gore did the same when he faced George Bush in Boston. The guns he seized were his own. He sacrificed his superior knowledge and experience on all aspects of policy. He fell over himself to assure the watching millions that he agreed with Bush on this and that. And when Bush laid himself open to charges of ignorance and hypocrisy, Gore spared him.

It was the most depressing spectacle and a disservice to the several million fence-sitters who will decide who will be the next president.

How did it come about? Everybody and the polls agreed the day after the first debate that Gore won easily. Then three things conspired to change the result, manifest in a sharp rise in the polls for Bush. First, instant replay. When it came to anything other than a vacuous generalisation in that first debate, Bush was open mouthed like a fish gasping for air. The trouble was Gore showed his contempt by rolling his eyes and shaking his head. In the week following, television replayed this image without illustrating the provocation. "Where were the man's manners?" became a staple of conversation, instead of focusing the question on Bush: "Where was the man's mind?"

Next, the Dick Cheney-Joe Lieberman encounter. The press and the Democrats had written off Cheney, but he scored big time. His directness and dry wit were much more convincing than the treacly lovefest Lieberman initiated with his friend "Dick". It was hailed as a gentleman's discourse but it had no virtue except that, for the Republicans, it blurred the differences.

And then, the Republican war room swung into action and scored a major success with a lazy press. Once again, caught in story mode syndrome, they pounded a drumbeat all week on the narrative line that Gore is a liar.

Gore's staff panicked. They made him watch a parody of his debating style from television's Saturday Night Live. They abjured him to avoid anecdotes where he might misstep. Gore would indeed have been well advised to make a small correction in his style towards deference, but he over-compensated. Unlike Bill Clinton, he is tone deaf to nuance. He did not merely control his facial reactions; he put his brain on ice. He grovelled. He was utterly out of character for two-thirds of the debate and it represented a sell-out to his convictions. There were cheers across the land when he woke from his sycophantic narcolepsy, but it was too late.

And now to the campaign on lying that so rattled the Democrats. The first thing to note is that the people calling Gore a liar are liars themselves. The Gore "lies" are not so much lies as irrelevant and inconsequential misremembering of circumstance. No, on one particular visit to a Texas forest fire he was not accompanied by the director, but by a deputy. But yes he did visit Texas disaster areas many times and that was the point.

The main attack by the Republican spin machine has proven false itself. Gore quoted a newspaper report about a girl who had to stand up because she had no desk at school. The school principal, embarrassed by the revelation, denied it and the credulous national media accepted that denial as evidence of a Gore fib without any further inquiries. In fact, as the Sarasota Herald Tribune has made clear, a dramatic budget cut has high school students going without desks for weeks. Good politics for the Republicans maybe, but lousy journalism.

The most sickening thing about the Republican fib factory is that while the moralisers have been regurgitating the propaganda, they have ignored really substantive lies by Bush. Forget amazing small errors like saying, with glee, that Texas would execute three men for a hate crime, when it's two men, and he is supposed to stand aloof pending appeals. There are examples of his mendacity - or his faculty for memory-loss and myth-making - that will affect people's lives. He said in the debate that he is in favour of hate-crime laws, but he has rejected them in Texas. He asserted that the percentage of people insured for health was going up in Texas but down nationally when both have risen. He described the Kyoto agreement on global warming as imposing controls only on the US, but it is multilateral. He says he is for clean air, but has given in to the polluters in his own state. He said he favours checks on guns bought at shows, but rejects the three-day waiting period that would enable them to be effective. He says he will pay for popular new programmes by using a quarter of the budget surplus, but his own budget shows he has allocated less than half that much.

Will the real Al Gore stand up before America sells itself short to the spinners?

webTitle: Vivendi Seagram count the cost of union

fields.headline: Vivendi Seagram count the cost of their union
fields.standfirst: Vivendi has been forced to sever links with BSkyB to join forces with Seagram, so which media baron has gained most in the new media landscape? Dan Milmo investigates.
fields.trailText: Vivendi has been forced to sever links with BSkyB to join forces with Seagram, but who has gained most from the deal? By Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
The European Commission's clearance of the AOL and Time Warner merger was a complex, drawn-out process which had commentators guessing and double-guessing the outcome until they tied themselves into knots. But no-one came near predicting the outcome of the £66bn corporate marriage between the French media company, Vivendi, and Seagram of Canada, the owner of Universal studios. To get to the altar, Vivendi was forced to serve divorce papers on one of its key interests: British Sky Broadcasting.

Vivendi has agreed to sell its 23% holding in the company over the next two years to assuage EC concerns that Vivendi Universal, as the new company will be known, will not link up with Fox studios, which is a sister company of BSkyB as Rupert Murdoch owns both. Attention will now turn to one of the more fractious relationships in the media world: that between Mr Murdoch and the Vivendi chairman, Jean-Marie Messier.

Sky said: "Vivendi has been a very supportive shareholder over the past year. BSkyB now intends to enter into discussions with Vivendi with a view to ensuring an orderly disposal of their stake. Any disposal has no effect on the fundamental business success of BSkyB."

But the rapport between Mr Murdoch and M Messier has cooled over the past 12 months since an attempt to merge Canal Plus, Vivendi's pay-TV arm, and BSkyB foundered on disputes over who would control the company. The relationship seemed to be warming up recently after Mr Murdoch made conciliatory noises in press briefings, but the EC has thrown things up in the air again.

The centre of the dispute has been Vivendi's role in Sky Global Networks, the company formed by the satellite TV operations in Mr Murdoch's News Corporation. M Messier had threatened to sell his stake in BSkyB unless Mr Murdoch allowed it to be converted into shares in SGN. M Messier has now been forced to give up a useful lever against his rival.

The Frenchman is now a very powerful global media player, and Mr Murdoch's star may be waning, but SGN is a significant global satellite platform which will be the ideal carrier for Vivendi Universal's masses of content. A stake in SGN, which is expected to float at the end of the year, will confirm M Messier's ascendancy. The tenacious owner of News Corp has already shown his willingness to share out interests in SGN by selling 4.7% of it to US cable giant Liberty Media.

The rest of the concessions forced out of Vivendi and Seagram have fewer ramifications. The second stipulation states that Vivendi must offer other pay-TV companies access to Universal's film output, which includes blockbusters such as The Mummy and Gladiator. A recent deal between the cable operator, NTL, and Universal Studio networks to set up a UK movie channel shows this is already being done.

The third issue covers Vizzavi, Vivendi's pan-European, multi-access internet portal, a joint venture with Vodafone. Seagram*s Universal music publishing business is the largest in the world and Vivendi has promised it will offer rival portals access to Universal's online music content for five years.

This final concession might leave the music companies, EMI and Warner Music, feeling hard done by, as the combination of internet access and back catalogues was enough to put their proposed merger on the back burner. However, Vizzavi has barely 1m subscribers at the moment and Warner Music found it hard to settle concerns over its links with AOL, which came from parent company Time Warner. Vizzavi's potential customer base is 80m, thanks to the presence of Vodafone and Vivendi's Cegetel telecoms subsidiary, but the EC clearly did not think it was of paramount inportance.

It has been an exhausting process for M Messier, but the deal marks a stunning turnaround for his company. When he took over as chairman in 1996, Vivendi was predominantly a utilities firm. Four years later, it is one of the world's most powerful media conglomerates and only the AOL Time Warner merger has managed to overshadow it, though it may struggle to keep Vivendi Universal out of the limelight.

Seagram*s Universal music publishing business is the largest in the world and Vivendi has promised it will offer rival portals access to Universal's online music content for five years. This final concession might leave the music companies, EMI and Warner Music, feeling hard done by, as the combination of internet access and back catalogues was enough to put their proposed merger on the back burner. However, Vizzavi has barely 1m subscribers at the moment and Warner Music found it hard to settle concerns over its links with AOL, which came from parent company Time Warner. Vizzavi's potential customer base is 80m, thanks to the presence of Vodafone and Vivendi's Cegetel telecoms subsidiary, but the EC clearly did not think it was of paramount inportance. It has been an exhausting process for M Messier, but the deal marks a stunning turnaround for his company. When he took over as chairman in 1996, Vivendi was predominantly a utilities firm. Four years later, it is one of the world's most powerful media conglomerates and only the AOL Time Warner merger has managed to overshadow it, though it may struggle to keep Vivendi Universal out of the limelight.

webTitle: Forum for the Future appoints Fishburn Hedges

fields.headline: Forum for the Future appoints Fishburn Hedges
fields.trailText: 10.30am: E-commerce think-tank Forum for the Future has hired Fishburn Hedges to handle the PR for a major research project, reports Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Forum for the Future, the e-commerce think-tank launched in February by e-minister Patricia Hewitt, has hired Fishburn Hedges to handle the PR for a major research project.

The Digital Futures project aims to explore the social impact of e-commerce and establish how it might benefit the UK. It is being put together by a consortium of 25 organisations, including three government departments, eight think-tanks and major corporations such as Unilever, BT and Amazon.co.uk.

A final report, to be published in February 2001, will recommend ways in which government and business can benefit from the dot.com revolution. It will report on the implications of the internet for everything from jobs and local communities to transport and the environment.

James Wilsdon, senior policy adviser and co-ordinator of Digital Futures, said: "The world of e-commerce is having a profound affect on business, government and consumers, and the Digital Futures report will explore this impact. We are relying on Fishburn Hedges to help us communicate our recommendations effectively to these key audiences."

Martin Le Jeune, head of Fishburn Hedges's corporate responsibility practice, said: "This is a fascinating study backed by some major players."

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: It's a miserable day, and today's transfer talk is soaked to the bone
fields.trailText: Howard Wilkinson will be asked to continue as England's caretaker manager for November's friendly with Italy, according to the Daily Mail.
fields.body:
Howard Wilkinson will be asked to continue as England's caretaker manager for November's friendly with Italy, according to the Daily Mail.

The Express claim Bobby Robson would walk out on Newcastle if he was offered the England job on a full-time basis.

Arsenal have lodged a £9m bid with Juventus for Edgar Davids, according to Planet Football. Other reports suggest the 27-year-old Dutch international would be a makeweight in a larger deal which would see Patrick Vieira move to Juventus - but the website thinks this unlikely.

Struggling Derby want Celtic defender Alan Stubbs to shore up their defence. The 29-year-old, previously linked with Everton and Sunderland, would be available at a low price as he will be entitled to leave on a Bosman free at the end of the season.

Chelsea, Newcastle, Everton, Ipswich and Manchester City are all keen on 18-year-old Falkirk midfielder Mark Kerr.

Celtic will make a £3.25m bid for Bordeaux's Herve Alicarte. Everton and Charlton are also interested in the 26-year-old central defender.

Blackburn are preparing a bid for Scotland international Colin Cameron. The Hearts midfielder would cost £2m.

Tottenham are in a race with PSV Eindhoven and Udinese to sign 18-year-old Swedish midfielder Kim Kallstrom.

Aston Villa striker Julian Joachim may withdraw his transfer request after clear-the-air talks with John Gregory. Speaking to Teamtalk, Joachim said: "We agreed there should be no grudges. The boss must rate me otherwise I would have been totally ignored this season. I wouldn't rule out withdrawing my transfer request at some stage."

fields.headline: Xoo hires Agency.com's Brewis
fields.trailText: 10am: Xoo has poached Agency.com's vice president of project management, David Brewis, to be chief operations officer. By Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
New media consultancy Xoo has poached Agency.com's vice-president of project management, David Brewis, to run the operational side of the company.

Mr Brewis joins as Xoo's first chief operations officer with responsibility for strengthening the fledgling agency's foundations and improving workflow and business processes.

Xoo's chief executive officer, Paul Gathercole, said: "David's appointment takes Xoo to the next level. With David on board we can offer clients a greater range of services and take on bigger and more demanding projects."

Mr Brewis played a key role in the growth of Agency.com from its beginnings as Online Magic, an independent agency, to the 250-strong Agency.com, part of the Omnicom-owned global network.

Xoo has worked for British Airways, XRefer, Poptones and London's Camden council.

webTitle: BBC news to come in from the cold

fields.headline: BBC news to come in from the cold
fields.trailText: 8am: The BBC plans to end months of speculation by announcing that its London-based news operation is to move back to the heart of the city, writes Matt Wells.
fields.body:
The BBC plans to end months of speculation by announcing that its London-based news operation is to move back to the heart of the city after being marooned for three years in west London, where some heavyweight guests refused to travel to interviews.

Tony Hall, the director of news, has told employees that the proposals would be revealed next month and gave them a strong indication that they would be moving from White City back to the West End in central London.

The most likely location is Broadcasting House, from where news staff were ousted in 1997.

Over the past three years, staff on Radio 4's Today and World at One programmes in particular have complained about not being able to persuade big-name interviewees to make the trip out to White City.

The move back to central London will not happen before 2007. World Service staff are also likely to move from Bush House at Aldwych into Broadcasting House at the same time. The Guardian has learned that BBC executives have secured an extension to the Bush House lease, which was due to run out in 2005.

An announcement will not be made until a decision has been taken on where to house the other departments whcih are currently at Broadcasting House. Some may move to White City, but radio, music and senior management will remain at the historic Portland Place site.

John Humphrys, the Today presenter, said staff on the programme would welcome a return to central London. "We used to have a regular parade of politicians through Broadcasting House. Now they are mostly done in a radio car."

Interviewing someone in another studio is much less satisfactory than face-to-face, he said. "We like to see the whites of their eyes." A BBC spokeswoman said no final decisions had been taken.

webTitle: Egg upbeat despite third quarter losses

fields.headline: Egg upbeat despite £115m third-quarter losses
fields.trailText: 10am: Egg remains bullish despite posting third-quarter pre-tax losses of £115.1m. By Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Internet bank Egg says it has not been affected by the launch of competitors' internet offerings, and remains bullish despite posting third-quarter pre-tax losses of £115.1m.

While losses widened by 7% year-on-year, Egg said this was because it had been busy acquiring customers. Over the period, Egg acquired 120,000 new customers, bringing its tally to 1.2m.

Mike Harris, chief executive of Egg, said the results put the company "bang on track" to break into profit during the fourth quarter of 2001.

Analysts have been heartened by the growth of multi-account customers, with the cross-sale ratio now standing at around 1.25 products per customer.

Shares in Egg, which is 80%-owned by Prudential, have fallen by 26.5% since its IPO in June. Shares this morning rose by 4.5p - to 130.5p - on the back of the results announcement.

The money Egg has spent on marketing appears to be hitting the mark, with the company's internal research showing that the Egg brand is the one most associated with internet banking in the UK, and that brand awareness stands at 84%.

The launch of Abbey National's Cahoot, Co-op's Smile and Halifax's IF (although this has yet to hit the internet) does not appear to have dented Egg's customer figures or slowed down its acquisition rate.

Egg is planning a swift move into Europe and has said it is speaking to a number of potential partners about possible joint-ventures.

webTitle: Freudenstein takes COO role at Sky

fields.headline: Freudenstein takes COO role at Sky
fields.trailText: 10.30am: BSkyB's general manager, Richard Freudenstein, has been promoted to the newly created position of chief operating officer, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
BSkyB's general manager, Richard Freudenstein, has been promoted to the newly created position of chief operating officer, reporting to chief executive Tony Ball.

Mr Freudenstein, 35, joined BSkyB as general manager last November and has been part of the team managing the roll-out of digital satellite TV offering Sky Digital.

Before joining BSkyB he was director of operations and business development at News Corp's Australian pay-TV subsidiary Foxtel.

Mr Ball said: "This promotion is recognition of a very skilled business professional who has helped improve the company's performance in so many areas."

fields.headline: Robert Campbell
fields.standfirst: Exposing the sordid side of the city of angels
fields.trailText: After almost a lifetime of writing screenplays and well-received novels, Robert Campbell, who has died aged 73, turned to a genre that gave the term "La-La Land" to the seedy underside of Los Angeles
fields.body:
After almost a lifetime of writing screenplays and well-received novels, Robert Campbell, who has died aged 73, turned to a genre that gave the term "La-La Land" to the seedy underside of Los Angeles.

He wrote a quartet with the term in all four titles, and featuring a detective known only as Whistler. They were in the hard-boiled tradition of such LA operators as Raymond Chandler (with whom he shared a hatred of the city's nether world), though Campbell's city of angels intruded even more into the narratives of his books.

His first was In La-La Land We Trust, published in 1986, which examined child pornography and prostitution. The following year came Alice In La-La Land, about a late-night television talk-show host with a compulsion for murdering street-girls. In 1990, Campbell published Sweet La-La Land, about runaway children and murder. The final book, The Wizard Of La-La Land (1995), dealt with satanist cults. A San Diego critic wrote of the quartet: "The city, in fact, is the real protagonist . . . violent and shocking, somewhat improbable yet endlessly fascinating."

Campbell was born in New Jersey, and, at first, studied painting. He was drawn to Los Angeles in 1952, after being told by his actor brother that he could expect to make "about $50,000" by writing a screenplay. He turned out 14 film scripts, 10 scripts for television series and four stage plays. Many of the movies were westerns and one, The Man With A Thousand Faces, won an Academy nomination. He later acknowledged that his Hollywood career had been "not that illustrious" - but that the money had lived up to his hopes.

In 1975, Campebll moved to the idyllic seaside village of Carmel, in central California, and began writing novels. That year he published The Spy Who Sat And Waited, about a German "mole" living through the inter-war years in the Orkneys. It was nominated for the National Book Award.

More novels followed, but they made no money. Then, aged 57 and broke, but having conquered his excessive drinking habit, Campbell was contemplating a return to Hollywood when a novelist friend suggested mystery thrillers.

His first effort, Junkyard Dog (1986), won an award from the Mystery Writers of America; the civil servant hero of his second, about machine politics in Chicago, was based on his father. The La-La quartet followed - fuelled, he said, by the hatred he still felt for the horrors of LA.

Campbell was nothing if not prolific, and launched another mystery series in 1988, featuring a railway detective. Altogether, he wrote 27 fictional works, but prized the LA series for enabling him, he said, to make "socially significant" points.

He never married.
