fields.headline: Keith Roberts
fields.standfirst: Science fiction writer whose much-praised stories stayed hidden in the genre
fields.trailText: Science fiction writer whose much-praised stories stayed hidden in the genre
fields.body:
Keith Roberts, who has died aged 65, was a remarkable writer who never found the audience he deserved. Unlike his contemporaries JG Ballard and Brian Aldiss, whose novels are now acceptable to critics as fiction rather than ghettoised as science fiction or fantasy, his talents were only ever recognised within the genre.

Yet the SF editor Algis Budrys considered him the best short-story writer in Britain, he won four British SF Association awards in three categories (novel, short story and artist) and his alternate history novel, Pavane, was praised by Anthony Burgess as one of the best novels of the 20th century.

What held Roberts back was almost certainly Roberts himself. He was not especially prolific, writing some 120 stories (a third of them in the period 1964-67), which were gathered into nine collections; four of his nine novels were actually mosaics of interlinked novellas. Nor was he easy to categorise. His first novel, The Furies, was a failed attempt to produce a catastrophe novel in the vein of John Wyndham or John Christopher.

His next, Pavane, was a virtuoso work, in which Elizabeth I was assassinated in 1588 and the reformation and industrial revolution never took place; by 1968, the Catholic church had held power for 400 years, suppressing all technological development as heresy. This was Roberts's first mosaic novel, each part of the story told from a different viewpoint but building a picture of a world extraordinarily different to our own. Much of it is set in a beautiful southern England, where hauliers ply the roads in steam-driven locomotives and giant semaphore stations dominate the countryside.

He wrote evocatively of these strange times, as a challenge to the rigidity of the church begins to grow, awaiting the spark of an invention to begin the process of revolution.

Roberts's later novels were no less challenging: The Inner Wheel dealt with gestalt minds and an encroaching world war, The Boat Of Fate was a historical novel of Roman Britain, and The Chalk Giants saw struggling loser Stanley Potts try to escape visions of post-nuclear cataclysm, which all, in some form, feature Martine, the girl he loves.

Girls played a large part in Roberts's stories, from his earliest humorous tales about a young witch named Anita to the adventures of Kaeti, whose slightly skewed England is also the home of vampires, ghosts and other odd denizens.

In Molly Zero, his heroine Molly rebels against the bureaucratically complex future England, and in Gráinne, the narrator, writer and adman Alistair Bevan (a pen-name used by Roberts in some of his early stories), finds his fate entwined with that of the girl-goddess of the title.

Roberts himself seemed unable to form steady relationships, professional or personal. Unmarried, and living alone in a rented flat, for years he refused to deal with major publishers, accusing them of creative accounting over the royalties of his early books. Even when he dealt with small-press publishers, the relationship would often sour, their quality not helped by Roberts's sudden mood swings and self-destructive tendencies.

He could be withdrawn and uncommunicative, yet on other occasions would be a good companion. He remained close-lipped about his private life, and even the autobiographical Lemady is an idiosyncratic mixture of fact and fantasy as he draws sketches from his life, focusing largely on his arguments with publishers, and interacts with the fictional woman of the title.

Roberts was born in Kettering, Northamptonshire, and studied for his national diploma in design at Northampton School of Art, later attending Leicester College of Art. He worked in advertising and illustration before selling his first story. He was closely associated with the magazines Science Fantasy and New Worlds, drawing covers and contributing stories to both. When Science Fantasy changed its name to Impulse, he became associate editor and then managing editor. As an illustrator, he later produced covers for books by Philip K Dick and John Brunner, two other science-fiction writers who struggled to find their proper place in literature.

A new short novel, Drek Yarman, was serialised in the magazine Spectrum SF earlier this year, and Roberts had recently signed a deal with Wildside Press, which would have brought much of his work back into print, perhaps to wider recognition. Unfortunately, only three titles had appeared by the time he died, of complications arising after he had been hospitalised for a chest infection.

fields.headline: Campaign Media Business round-up
fields.standfirst: Publication date: October 16.
fields.trailText: October 16: Peugeot-Citroen has awarded its entire £75m planning and buying account to BBJ, only months after saying it would split the account. .
fields.body:
Peugeot-Citroen has awarded its entire £75m planning and buying account to BBJ, only months after saying it would split the account. PSA, owner of Peugeot and Citroen, originally split the account between Carat and BBJ - both owned by the Aegis group. But the company reopened talks with rival agencies after Carat last month took on the planning and buying business for rival car maker Renault.

webTitle: News at Ten - bull's eye for the Beeb?

fields.headline: News at Ten - bull's eye for the Beeb?
fields.standfirst: In moving its news bulletin to 10pm, the BBC is hoping for a new dawn, but as Media Medium Maggie Hyde warns, there are clouds overhead.
fields.trailText: In moving its news bulletin to 10pm, the BBC is hoping for a new dawn, but as Media Medium Maggie Hyde warns, there are clouds overhead.
fields.body:
Planetary oppositions of Jupiter and Pluto across the Gemini-Sagittarius axis are shaking up the worlds of media and publishing, and the BBC's News at Ten heist plugs into this symbolism.

The programme's launch on October 16 has the Moon at eight degrees of Gemini, next to Jupiter. They are straddling the fixed star Aldebaran, the angry red eye of the Bull. With expansive Jupiter involved, the BBC should boost its ratings and Greg Dyke may think he has pulled off quite a coup.

The degree ascending at the launch is the same degree as the Sun for its ITV predecessor (July 3 1967). This is rebirth imagery, a new dawn as the BBC captures the spirit of the ITV original.

However, there are troublesome long-term indications. The symbolism suggests this will be a defining moment in government and public attitudes over the thorny dilemma of funding public service broadcasting alongside commercial channels.

The BBC is in war mode and alongside henchwoman Heggessey, Greg Dyke is spoiling for a fight. His Mars has progressed to eight degrees of argumentative Gemini, triggered by the News at Ten Moon. Backing him all the way is BBC chairman Sir Christopher Bland (May 29 1938), who was born on the day of an eclipse of the sun at the same Gemini degree.

Eclipses put us in the dark and often show up as an irrational, blind response. Curiously, Greg Dyke was also born on the day of a solar eclipse, so it is a case of the Bland leading the blind. Bland's gratuitous riposte to criticism from the culture secretary - "Chris Smith is a licence fee payer and therefore entitled to his view" - could cost the corporation dear. Chris Smith is a minister of the Crown (the Sun) which has granted the Royal Charter, and the attitude of the BBC governors will not be forgotten by a future government.

In winning this battle, the BBC may be losing the war. Its astrology suggests that holding to a public service ethos would be better than giving ITV one in the eye.

webTitle: Aegis launch into e-marketing with eVerger VC fund

fields.headline: Aegis launches into e-marketing with eVerger VC fund
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Aegis makes its first splash into the e-marketing sector through new eVerger VC fund. By Dan Milmo .
fields.body:
Aegis, the UK-based marketing group, has made its first splash in the e-marketing sector through its new eVerger venture capital fund.

The group, which owns the Carat marketing company, is investing $12.6m in three start-up companies as it attempts to capitalise on a market expected to generate revenues of $72bn by 2004.

The eVerger fund was established in April this year by Aegis and the Warburg Pincus investment fund, with $100m earmarked for upcoming dot.com advertising and marketing firms.

The fund's first investments are NetUsability, a London-based market research company, NewWorld Commerce, an e-marketing firm from Dublin, and Dynamic Logic, an advertisement-rating company based in New York.

Andrew Burke, chief executive of eVerger and founder of the LineOne internet service provider, brushed off concerns that the e-advertising market is showing signs of a downturn.

He said: "Most big internet companies have got their advertising space booked between now and Christmas. A lot of money is going online and eVerger will add value to advertising space. It is not a question of when the money will dry up, but making sure it is spent better."

He expects eVerger to have a portfolio of 12 companies from the UK, Europe and the US by the end of 2001, with the firms receiving investments in the $5-10m bracket.

"I think the old style of spray and pray dot.com investing is a thing of the past. eVerger will make sure that every single investment is a winner," he added.

webTitle: OMD drops out of Unilever pitch

fields.headline: OMD pulls out of $700m Unilever pitch
fields.trailText: 9.45am: OMD has dropped out of the $700m (£492m) Unilever global media review, leaving Initiative Media and MindShare to fight it out, writes Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
OMD has dropped out of the $700m (£492m) Unilever global media review, leaving Initiative Media and MindShare to fight it out in a final head-to-head.

Brad Simmons, Unilever's vice-president US media services, has confirmed the move.

Initiative has roughly twice the Unilever business that either MindShare or OMD handle and is the incumbent in the US. MindShare is Unilever's media partner in many key markets around the world and a unit of J Walter Thompson, MindShare's WPP sibling, handles the company's internet business.

On that basis, it is understood that OMD would have been the least likely to secure the account. A final decision is expected by the end of the year.

webTitle: Sharm el-Sheikh summit: the sticking points

fields.headline: Sharm el-Sheikh summit: the sticking points
fields.standfirst: World leaders meeting in Egypt to try to resolve the violent conflict between Israel and the Palestinians face many obstacles, writes former Middle East correspondent Derek Brown
fields.trailText: World leaders meeting in Egypt to try to resolve the violent conflict between Israel and the Palestinians face many obstacles, writes former Middle East correspondent Derek Brown
fields.body:
The first and biggest obstacle facing the Sharm el-Sheikh summiteers is the lack of a common agenda. Usually, such meetings are prepared well in advance by teams of officials known in the diplomatic trade as sherpas. The final negotiation is often no more than a wrangle over the punctuation in the final statement.

This time they are all going to be singing from their own hymn sheets, and the words they are using could not be more different.

Israeli prime minister Ehud Barak has the simplest mission: to end the violence in the Palestinian territories. He insists that the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, started it, and that he must now stop it. Only when that happens will Israel be able to talk about resuming negotiations for a final peace settlement.

Such a settlement is far from Arafat's mind. He wants to wrongfoot Israel by securing some kind of international inquiry into the violence, and specifically into the massive firepower used by Israeli soldiers.

Even if Arafat could switch the violence off like a tap, as the Israelis claim, he seems in no mood to do so. Nearly 100 Palestinians have been killed in little more than two weeks, and the West Bank and Gaza territories are ablaze with anger. Should Arafat direct his puny police force to intervene in the rioting they would, at best, be swept aside - as they were by the lynch mob in Ramallah last week.

Arafat is well aware of that anger, and he shares it. He knows that even before he sat down with Barak, his own people were protesting angrily that the summit itself is a betrayal of the "martyrs" of the latest intifada (uprising).

Israelis argue that Arafat is cynically using violence to squeeze further territorial concessions in a final settlement. In fact, the process has gone several ominous steps beyond that.

At Camp David in the summer Israel and the Palestinians came tantalisingly close to a final settlement, making startling progress on some of the knottier issues, including refugees and final boundaries. On Jerusalem, the greatest sticking point of all, Barak played his boldest card, offering Arafat a share of the city and guaranteeing the autonomy of the Muslim holy places.

That wasn't nearly enough to satisfy the Palestinian president, who wants the Old City and the eastern, Arab, suburbs.

At Camp David, Barak in effect told Arafat to take it or leave it. In Israel such bluntness is considered a virtue. In the Arab world it is deeply offensive. The blue paper was already smouldering when Ariel Sharon, the leader of the Israeli rightwing opposition Likud party, paid his notorious visit to the Haram al-Sharif complex, surrounded by hundreds of Israeli troops. That was the spark which ignited the powder-keg.

The best hope of the outside world now is that President Clinton retains his fiercely held ambition to broker a lasting peace in the Middle East. He has just three months left to achieve his goal before his term in office ends.

The US president will need all his charm and powers of persuasion to heave the peace train back on to the rails. Specifically, and unprecedentedly, he will have to use some very plain language to explain to the Israelis that they can no longer rule three million Arab subjects by brute force.

Time is not only short; it has run out. The chances are that if this summit fails, Arafat will finally do what he has always threatened, and unilaterally declare Palestine a free and sovereign state. And that will be the day that war truly breaks out.

fields.headline: Today's media stories from the papers
fields.trailText: THE GUARDIAN
fields.body:
THE GUARDIAN

Lord Hollick is expected to receive a bid of £100m for the Express newspaper titles today from the Hinduja group (p2)
Matt Wells reports that the BBC plans to end months of speculation by announcing that it will move its London-based news operation back into the heart of the city after three years in west London, where some heavyweight guests refused to travel to interviews. (p7)

MEDIA GUARDIAN:
http://www.mediatheguardian.com/mediaguardian/index/0,7622,382124,00.html
Duncan Campbell interviews Lowell Bergman, the 60 Minutes producer whose exposure of corruption in the tobacco industry inspired the hit film, The
Insider. Bergman talks about how US journalism beats ours. (p2)
Fiona Morrow asks if there is still a place for authored documentaries on UK television. (p3)
Maggie Brown interviews Jane Tranter, the BBC's new drama commissioner. And Matt Wells asks, what is the magic formula that will rescue TV drama? (p4)
Roy Greenslade looks at the ABC figures and the newspaper publishers' practice of giving away freebies in an article headlined, "Bulks ? Just Say No" (p6)
There is a double-page report on Star, the BBC's new magazine aimed at teenagers. (p8)
And Mark Borkowski, managing director of Borkowski PR, on why newspaper reviewers should not break the unwritten code of conduct between the media and the publicists by reviewing a preview performance of a play. (p10)

NEW MEDIA GUARDIAN
The AOL-Time Warner merger has European approval. Has it changed the internet for ever? David Teather and Jane Martinson report. (p60)
Meg Carter asks whether the BBC is selling out with its commercial internet service, beeb.com
Lindsey Roberts on marketing the internet

THE FINANCIAL TIMES

The lead story on the FT's Companies and Markets section is devoted to the news that David Montgomery and the Hinduja brothers are preparing rival bids for Express Newspapers. Mr Montgomery, a former chief executive of the Mirror Group, has put forward a £90m offer backed by the venture capital group 3i and HSBC Bank, while the Hinduja brothers are expected to table a bid of about £100m. (p33)
The FT also reports that Reuters has abandoned plans to float its Greenhouse Fund before the end of the year because of difficult market conditions. The fund was set up to invest in internet start-ups and new media companies. (p33)

THE DAILY TELEGRAPH

The Telegraph reports that the BBC has sparked a ratings war on a scale not seen since the launch of EastEnders in 1985 with its new-look evening schedule. ITV has been forced onto the back foot by a strong evening line-up that includes new series of The Royle Family and One Foot in the Grave. ITV has responded by ditching existing programmes to run an hour-long episode of Who Wants to be a Millionaire? in the 9-10pm slot.(p3)

THE INDEPENDENT

The Indie also has the story about David Montgomery and the Hinduja brothers' plans to bid for Express newspapers.(p9)
And on the City pages the paper covers the Institute of Practitioners in Advertising's quarterly Bellwether report, which shows that growth in advertising spend is likely to slow in the second half of the current financial year. "A recent easing of business confidence has caused the rate of growth to slow," according to the IPA.(p16)

THE TIMES

Media editor Ray Snoddy reports that ITV has asked the Independent Television Commission to reopen the issue of its evening news bulletins following the BBC's decision to move its main nightly news to 10pm. The ITV companies are to ask for a six-month delay before implementing any change. BBC staff have reportedly dubbed ITV's nightly news broadcast the News at When? (p14)
The Times also reports on the Hinduja brothers' planned bid for Express Newspapers, adding that it is expected to be worth about £100m ? the highest bid so far in the public domain. (p26)

THE DAILY MAIL

The Mail covers the Hinduja brothers' planned bid for Express Newspapers in its City pages, focusing on the controversy surrounding the family. The Hindujas have been accused of accepting bribes during an arms deal in 1986 but have denied the charges. (p62)

THE DAILY EXPRESS

The Express reports that Peter Wood, the man who launched Direct Line, has been named chairman of a multi-million pound joint venture between Telewest and the nternet services firm CobWeb. Blueyonder Workwise will provide broadband digital internet connections and online services to small and medium-sized businesses. (p51)

THE MIRROR

The paper claims an exclusive with the story that television gardener Charlie Dimmock has left the man she met before her rise to fame - even though the Star also covers the story and it was in several papers yesterday - presumably on the grounds that they've got a quote from a "close friend" of one of the key figures. The Ground Force star reportedly walked out on John Mushet following a passionate fling with BBC technician Andy Simmons, who worked on the hit show. (p9)
And Michael Parkinson has used his not inconsiderable charms to persuade Madonna to appear on his show. The one-hour special will appear as part of the BBC's Christmas schedule. (p19)

THE SUN

The Sun also reports on the fierce ratings battle between BBC1 and ITV, with ITV chiefs accusing the Beeb of using up all its best shows to prove itself in the week in which it moves its main evening news. (p8)

AND FINALLY <BR
The Star reports that "busty" telly garden queen Charlie Dimmock's new lover is claiming she tricked him into bed by telling him she had already finished wit her long-term lover. (p1)
The paper also reports that a third of the BBC castaways want to stay on Taransay when the television series ends. Show producer Chris Kelly said 10 of the 29 stars of the show had inquired about staying on. (p7)

fields.headline: Teachers could get £2,000 by Christmas
fields.standfirst:
Blunkett Christmas pay rise offered to teachers

Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Performance-related pay rises for teachers worth £2,000 could be delivered by Christmas, the education secretary, David Blunkett, said yesterday.
fields.body:
Performance-related pay rises for teachers worth £2,000 could be delivered by Christmas, the education secretary, David Blunkett, said yesterday.

But the National Union of Teachers, which derailed the plan in July by persuading the high court that Mr Blunkett had acted unlawfully in failing to consult properly, warned that it may raise further objections if it is still unhappy.

The government was forced to return to the school teachers review body, which will report this week.

"We won't know this until the review body reports... but it is clear, I think, that the drift is in the right direction," Mr Blunkett told BBC 1's Breakfast with Frost.

"I look forward very much in the next fortnight to being able to ... get things back on track, so that teachers can get the £2,000 uplift." Ministers have already said that most of the 197,000 teachers who applied for the cash will receive it.

"I would very much like teachers to have got it by this Christmas for obvious reasons. If we can't we will do so as quickly afterwards as we can," Mr Blunkett said.

Doug McAvoy, general secretary of the NUT, said: "If the system is not equitable, if it is not fair, if there is no proper appeal system, there will continue to be concerns." The NUT also wants about 50,000 eligible teachers who did not apply last term to have the chance to do so now.

Today Mr Blunkett will extend the testing regime by "actively encouraging" secondary schools to re-test 12-year-olds who fail to reach accepted standards at primary schools. Schools will be invited to provide remedial tuition for those who fail to reach level four in key stage three tests at 11 in English, maths and science. This year 28% of pupils failed to reach that standard in maths, 25% in English and 15% in science. The scheme is being piloted in 200 schools. The tests, extra training and materials needed are being backed by an extra £80m.

Mr Blunkett said it was "not a test for its own sake but a test of whether that lost year has been recovered, the lost year being the first year of secondary schooling where we know that over 30% of youngsters actually end up after that first year further behind on key areas like English and maths than when they came up from primary".

John Dunford, general secretary of the Secondary Heads Association, said the move would limit schools' freedom and narrow the curriculum at a point where they needed to expand it.

"There is a danger if schools are judged by their performance in three subjects that they will put more emphasis on those. What I am looking for is more flexibility in testing.

"If we had a bank of tests that children could take when they had reached the right stage I would welcome that. But if we are going to have to jump through tests every May, every year, it is going to hold some children back."

Mr Blunkett will also announce an extension of his excellence in cities programme and more help for schools in combating truancy. Money will be provided to employ non-teaching staff to chase up truants in problem schools, and Mr Blunkett and Jack Straw, the home secretary, will encourage police to use their powers to round up truants.

The government was forced to return to the school teachers review body, which will report this week. "We won't know this until the review body reports... but it is clear, I think, that the drift is in the right direction," Mr Blunkett told BBC 1's Breakfast with Frost. "I look forward very much in the next fortnight to being able to ... get things back on track, so that teachers can get the £2,000 uplift." Ministers have already said that most of the 197,000 teachers who applied for the cash will receive it. "I would very much like teachers to have got it by this Christmas for obvious reasons. Doug McAvoy, general secretary of the NUT, said: "If the system is not equitable, if it is not fair, if there is no proper appeal system, there will continue to be concerns." webTitle: Comment: The BBC changes the time of its main news. Oh dear

fields.headline: Knives are out at the Borgia Broadcasting Corporation
fields.standfirst:
The BBC has altered the time of its main news near an election. Oh dear

Special report: the future of the BBC
MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Here is a prediction about tonight's BBC news at 10pm. It will be better than last Friday's news at 9pm. Not because the tenor of the news itself will necessarily have changed - it will probably be pretty dire as usual - but because the extra hour counts.
fields.body:
Here is a prediction about tonight's BBC news at 10pm. It will be better than last Friday's news at 9pm. Not because the tenor of the news itself will necessarily have changed - it will probably be pretty dire as usual - but because the extra hour counts. Time (attention Chris Smith) matters.

There are two kinds of news. One, chattering over an agency wire, rolling 24 hours a day on cable TV or beeping across the net, is instant. Something's happened: something goes out. But that is not the essence of daily newspaper life, nor of terrestrial television's big bulletins. Here a single deadline rules, and that often permits a moment or two to think, to weigh, to assess. You get a certain rough judgment as well as the facts.

ITN's News at Ten - before the moguls shunted it - always had the edge on the BBC at 9pm because, in the normal rhythm of things, its editors had been able to pause for thought, to construct an agenda which wasn't merely a summation of the day just gone but a half step into tomorrow's future. Now, as the moguls stew in their own juice, the Beeb has seized the slightly higher ground: late enough for reflection (and American and parliamentary completeness), early enough to catch the punters before they go to bed. Whatever the other scheduling advantages, however the ratings battle goes, a terrestrial 10pm works best for news.

But is our culture, media and sports compendium of a secretary of state happy? On the contrary, he seems darkly, volubly unhappy, jawboning away to the moguls in conference about his plans to bring the corporation to heel. If audiences at 10pm have fallen below audiences at 9pm after six trial months, then an affronted Smith will find the governors in breach of their charter obligations. And anyway - hint, hint - the BBC's governors are already signing their own death warrant. The secretary of state has a new broadcasting bill in the works and one of its much-trailed provisions will strip the governing board of its regulatory powers, handing them over to a single "new" regulator (which sounds strangely akin to the old independent television commission when he talks about it).

So size (of audience) matters. So quality (of the news) doesn't enter the equation. So due deference to politicians carries greater weight than the experience of news professionals, the inevitable demands of competitive channels, the opinion of governors appointed (by government) to exercise that opinion. What was insupportable when ITV wanted to shift the news from ten, now becomes insupportable when the BBC shifts its news to ten.

In the early days of Labour revival, there was much to admire about Chris Smith. He was intellectually crisp, courageously relaxed about his private life - and rather unlucky to get culture rather then health when the victory portfolios were doled out. He's not done badly since, either. For all his current desuetude, he was an early Dome sceptic. Sport has a few gold medals to wave.

But he lets himself down when he constantly hectors and lectures the broadcasters, a kind of latterday Gerald Kaufman with ministerial clout. That is not his job or his role. He's there to hold the ring, not keep leaping into it. He is not there for detailed prescription.

Of course, the present regulation of broadcasting doesn't make tidy sense. Any possibility of that vanished when Mrs T put Rupert Murdoch in her satellite club. Of course, as Mr Smith says, ITV's prolonged hassle with the ITC over News at Ten sits oddly with the swift acquiescence of the BBC's in-house regulators to a parallel news move (not to mention their junking, virtually overnight, of the Birt legacy they themselves superintended and defended). In a perfect world, the entirety of regulation might be less onerous and more equal - if, indeed, it is needed amid the proliferation of channels and choices.

There is a case for reform embracing technical change, for a green paper, a debate and even, in time, for a broadcasting bill. There is, though, no palatable case for considering any of this now, in the last months before a general election. When Mr Smith says that the BBC and its governors have six months to prove their case about the ten o'clock shift - and not the year that chairman Bland has nominated - what does he mean? He means that he anticipates another row, with menaces attached, before and not after an election: that the heat can be turned up to suit the government he serves.

Those on the outside are rarely able to see what happens inside television (and radio), but I've been an occasional spectator when the stakes are highest and an election is called. Think, benignly, of Mr Milosevic. The phones start ringing, the spin doctors go into orbit, the pressure mounts. Broadcasters don't complain much. How can they without looking like paranoid wimps? But nobody, when any government - and especially not this government - risks its electoral neck, should think TV a neutral, protected zone. It's a war zone; and the devices of ultimate defence - like the BBC's governors - are vital.

Now, however, we're voyaging into an election as the governors are steered on to the rocks (and commercial TV, to be fair and equal, faces a similar regulatory ordeal). That's hopeless - an apparent invitation to intervention which Chris Smith, on present form, won't resist. Do appearances matter? Absolutely. When appearances stink, the stench spreads.

And, inevitably, there's a personal edge to it all. The same old names, in this narrow little box, go round and round. The ITC has a new chief executive, Patricia Hodgson, who was John Birt's head of strategy and planning, the ultimate prophet of Birtism, until Greg Dyke arrived and pushed her to the periphery. Does Patricia revere Greg? How could she; and vice-versa? Nor is Ms Hodgson a fan of the BBC's governors - needed, she says, "to keep BBC management honest", but also in great need of their own accountability to greater authority.

The sentiments may fly suitably high, but the agendas aren't necessarily so elevated. How would it be if Chris made Pat his supreme regulator, the monarch of OfCom? There'd be surface smiles and fair words, of course, but the thought shivers timbers in the Borgia Broadcasting Corporation.

It seems a very long time indeed since (in Tory demonology) Greg Dyke was Tony Blair's stooge. Now we're back to knife work as normal, as real accountability approaches. Do you want to trust the assorted bulletins at 10pm? Then catch up with Jawbone Smith and his regulatory revels. They ought not to be happening. The time isn't remotely right. OfCom - its remit, its leadership - is in business for the first, relatively pure year of a fresh parliament. And probably (bong! bong!) for a new secretary of state.

fields.headline: Mandelson sought home loan - Robinson
fields.trailText: Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, took the lead in seeking the £373,000 home loan which led ultimately to his resignation from the cabinet, the former paymaster general, Geoffrey Robinson insisted today.
fields.body:
Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, took the lead in seeking the £373,000 home loan which led ultimately to his resignation from the cabinet, the former paymaster general, Geoffrey Robinson insisted today.

Mr Robinson, a multi-millionaire businessman whose version of the affair is included in an autobiography being serialised in the Daily Mail, said it was not the case that he initiated the loan offer, as Mr Mandelson has suggested.

The former Treasury minister, who was also forced to resign over the home loan affair two years ago, said there was a "marked difference of opinion" between his recollection of events and those of Mr Mandelson, who returned to the cabinet as Northern Ireland secretary last year.

Mr Robinson stressed he was not accusing Mr Mandelson of lying about the affair. But he told BBC Radio 4's Today programme: "There is very clearly, however, a marked difference of opinion between the accounts that he has given (and mine)."

Mr Robinson said that Mr Mandelson's account had implied ". . . that I put him up to it in some sort of way . . . gave the impression that I was the sort of person who might use my means, my money, to buy influence, power, even office.

"I felt I ought to give my own account of it, and that's precisely what I have done."

Mr Robinson insisted ". . . it was Peter taking the lead in these matters." But Mr Mandelson immediately defended himself. He said: "It is entirely a matter for Geoffrey Robinson as to why he should write and serialise a book of this kind at this time.

"For my own part, the sequence of events has been frequently stated. I had dinner with him in 1996 and during the course of the evening I told him of my problems trying to find somewhere to live in London.

"As a friend of many years standing, he volunteered his financial help if needed. I later took him up on his offer and I was grateful to him.

"I have never suggested or implied that he forced a loan on me. Nothing would be more ridiculous.

"I gave a full, faithful and factual account to the House of Commons standards committee, as did Geoffrey himself. They accepted it and I regard the matter as closed.

"I have a very difficult job on my hands in Northern Ireland, I intend to get on with it, and I will not allow anything to distract me from it."

fields.headline: Beware e-powered consumers
fields.standfirst: Hand-picked by Greg Dyke - partly to prevent her being poached - Jane Tranter says she got the job of BBC drama commissioner on her track record. She tells  Maggie Brown why her modern-retro recipe will work
fields.trailText: View from Here, by Lindsey Roberts.
fields.body:
How are businesses gearing up for the new consumer power that is emerging from the electronic revolution? I did some research for Marketing Forum 2000 to find out, and discovered real dilemmas for marketing and businesses.

The research, which was conducted among both marketers and consumers, found that the rules of marketing haven't changed fundamentally, but that many of the processes marketers use are now too bureaucratic and ponderous.

Some companies are simply hiving off their electronic division to keep the "e-types" from being too disruptive a force in the existing culture. This is, in effect, a kind of corporate denial. A better solution would be to embrace the need for change and become quicker to respond and less bureaucratic. Size is important in the e-world, but speed and agility are vital, too. The winners will be the companies that succeed in combining both.

There are also implications for ways of working. In the words of one senior marketer, "This is the death of precedent." Everyone in marketing will have to find quicker, more original ways of working, with more emphasis on creativity. This should, surely, be the perfect climate for agencies.

While the marketing community is undergoing a revolution, agencies - which have traditionally seen themselves as the natural business partners of marketing clients - are turning into dinosaurs. They have not risen to the challenge of adapting to meet the rapidly changing needs of their customers. The web agencies fared even worse and were seen by one respondent as "the dot.coms of the agency world: entrepreneurial, ambitious, but lacking substance".

However, the problem is not only one for agencies. As far as consumers are concerned, few companies are getting their electronic offering right. There is too much emphasis on design and too little on functionality in websites.

One of the consumer respondents summed it up: "Your website is your shop - whether or not you are planning to sell from it. Most people who visit are looking for information and help, and they need to be given it. Then they may stay to browse and even buy. If they don't like the feel of your place, they have the biggest shopping mall in the world on their desktop."

However, this pales into insignificance against the biggest single conclusion from this research. We are witnessing the start of a seismic shift in the balance of power in marketing. We are feeling only the first distant rumbles, but as more people become e-enabled, the closer we will get to the epicentre of a major earthquake that has the potential to shake the very foundations on which marketing has been built. The marketing industry may soon look back with nostalgia at the good "old" world which was ruled by brands and built on inspiring confidence and reflecting consumer aspirations.

Since the arrival of the e-world there has been much talk of building deeper relationships based on the previously undreamed of quality and quantity of data, providing a new depth of knowledge and the ability to anticipate consumer needs. Attractive as this model may seem to today's marketers, based on the consumer research, I believe it unlikely that this will be the future of marketing.

While it is not news that the new, emergent e-consumer is becoming empowered, marketing has not yet fully understood the implications of meeting the needs of consumers who feel omnipotence rather than awe. In fact, this sense of omnipotence is not usually a response to marketing. It often comes on the back of a bigger need, such as the desire to become knowledgeable about a medical condition affecting a member of your family. It takes persistence and a degree of acquired skill to become really competent on the web. But this type of stimulus leads consumers to push through the pain barrier, and once they have done so there is no turning back.

There is a glint in the eye and an almost belligerent attitude among consumers who have "cracked" the web. Marketers and brands really need to understand this phenomenon. Never before have consumers understood that they have the power over a medium and by extension over brands. What's fundamentally exciting is that consumers are controlling it, they are defining how it grows. They don't control the way the other media work, but they are controlling this and it's immensely exciting.

People power is on the increase. Governments can't afford to ignore it and neither can brands, and this means that marketing needs to change beyond recognition.

 Lindsey Roberts is founding partner of the FRESH ideas consultancy.

fields.headline: No more corpses
fields.standfirst: What is the magic formula that will rescue TV drama?  Matt Wells  finds out
fields.trailText: What is the magic formula that will rescue TV drama? Matt Wells finds out...
fields.body:
As the champagne bubbles fade and the new faces in TV drama land nurse their hangovers, the awesome challenge they face will soon become apparent.

Drama was always the heart of the ratings battleground, but as the two main channels enter an Olympian battle for audiences, the relentless search for popular series will get even tougher.

And just as the battle intensifies, it seems that the audiences are getting more sophisticated than ever. It is no longer simply enough to cast a well-known soap actor in a starring role and watch the ratings stack up: viewers want more. Today, it is not Cracker, Morse or Wexford which pulls in the crowds and the plaudits; it is ensemble drama such as the Royle Family, This Life, Queer as Folk and Clocking Off.

Paul Abbott, who was behind Clocking Off, says the BBC has a bright future under Jane Tranter, but urges a change in attitudes at the corporation if success is to return. "BBC drama still has the brand edge, even though this hasn't been matched by the audiences. People have got to think about how to entertain at the same time as producing distinctive drama." The BBC must no longer measure its hit rate by how cheaply it can achieve high ratings, he says.

Holby City, the Casualty spin-off, has long been hailed a staple of the BBC's spartan success in returning drama; yet the edifice has crumbled with the latest series after ITV scheduled Who Wants to be a Millionaire? against it. A two-year-old quiz show should not have caused such a catastrophic ratings collapse at Holby. There has to be a question mark over its future.

Abbott says the BBC and ITV must end the practice of churning out poor-quality drama just because they have recognisable stars: Harbour Lights and Sunburn (Nick Berry and Michelle Collins) and ITV's In Defence (Ross Kemp) are examples of ill-thought out concepts that started with the star rather than the idea. "It's just not good enough for the audience," he says.

While the BBC tackles its own tribulations, Andy Harries, the newly-installed controller of drama and comedy at ITV production powerhouse, Granada, says the commercial network can not simply bask in its drama success. ITV insiders take the Tranter threat seriously, and Harries urges a drama rethink. "Drama is the battleground of British TV at the moment, and we have to think whether we are doing the right range of shows."

He cites Cold Feet, Meet the Braithwaites and Bad Girls as the biggest ITV hits of recent years - all are the "ensemble" pieces that Abbott cites as the future of TV drama. ITV must abandon the elusive search for the family sitcom, a genre he describes as "dead", and tap into the success of family drama such as Carlton's Goodnight Mister Tom and The Railway Children. "I for one will not be making any cop shows or any violent programmes. There will be no bodybags or headless corpses - there's too much of it. We should be making more 'warm' drama."

Drama was always the heart of the ratings battleground, but as the two main channels enter an Olympian battle for audiences, the relentless search for popular series will get even tougher. And just as the battle intensifies, it seems that the audiences are getting more sophisticated than ever. It is no longer simply enough to cast a well-known soap actor in a starring role and watch the ratings stack up: viewers want more. Today, it is not Cracker, Morse or Wexford which pulls in the crowds and the plaudits; it is ensemble drama such as the Royle Family, This Life, Queer as Folk and Clocking Off. Paul Abbott, who was behind Clocking Off, says the BBC has a bright future under Jane Tranter, but urges a change in attitudes at the corporation if success is to return. "BBC drama still has the brand edge, even though this hasn't been matched by the audiences. People have got to think about how to entertain at the same time as producing distinctive drama." The BBC must no longer measure its hit rate by how cheaply it can achieve high ratings, he says. Holby City, the Casualty spin-off, has long been hailed a staple of the BBC's spartan success in returning drama; yet the edifice has crumbled with the latest series after ITV scheduled Who Wants to be a Millionaire? against it. A two-year-old quiz show should not have caused such a catastrophic ratings collapse at Holby. There has to be a question mark over its future. Abbott says the BBC and ITV must end the practice of churning out poor-quality drama just because they have recognisable stars: Harbour Lights and Sunburn (Nick Berry and Michelle Collins) and ITV's In Defence (Ross Kemp) are examples of ill-thought out concepts that started with the star rather than the idea. "It's just not good enough for the audience," he says. While the BBC tackles its own tribulations, Andy Harries, the newly-installed controller of drama and comedy at ITV production powerhouse, Granada, says the commercial network can not simply bask in its drama success. ITV insiders take the Tranter threat seriously, and Harries urges a drama rethink. "Drama is the battleground of British TV at the moment, and we have to think whether we are doing the right range of shows." He cites Cold Feet, Meet the Braithwaites and Bad Girls as the biggest ITV hits of recent years - all are the "ensemble" pieces that Abbott cites as the future of TV drama. ITV must abandon the elusive search for the family sitcom, a genre he describes as "dead", and tap into the success of family drama such as Carlton's Goodnight Mister Tom and The Railway Children. "I for one will not be making any cop shows or any violent programmes. There will be no bodybags or headless corpses - there's too much of it. We should be making more 'warm' drama."

fields.headline: You've got to play fair
fields.standfirst: The threat of having your liver torn out might seem a bit harsh, but, says PR to the stars,  Mark Borkowski, it's what a critic might expect if he reviews a play at a preview - even if it is a vehicle for a Hollywood star.
fields.trailText: The threat of having your liver torn out might seem a bit harsh, but, says PR to the stars, Mark Borkowski, it's what a critic might expect if he reviews a play at a preview - even if it is a vehicle for a Hollywood star.
fields.body:
I lost my temper with one newspaper's arts correspondent last week. I won't tell you what I threatened to do to his liver, but on reflection, impassioned though I felt about the matter, it wasn't the best way to express my point of view.

Believe it or not (and most people don't), there are all sorts of unwritten codes of honour between the media and the publicists who provide a source of information, features, stories and news. He broke one of those codes, which is what imperilled the good health of his internal organs.

All my professional life, I've managed publicity on behalf of theatre companies and arts events. The groups have ranged from the uncontrollably anarchic and bizarre, through to the most dignified international institutions. But whatever the company, the press has always accorded all shows one simple, necessary courtesy. Namely, reviewers do not attend the production until the official press night, which occurs after a number of preview performances.

The previews allow the producers, actors and technicians to establish confidence, to carry out last minute fine-tuning, and to iron out any glitches unforeseen in the rehearsal rooms. Doors stick, sets shake, lights are miscued, props break. Run of the mill stuff, but guaranteed to distract the most hardened professionals from the task in hand.

All shows need to be run in before being exposed to the critics, and newspapers understand and accept this, and adhere to the protocol. Or they did. Now the rules of engagement have changed, because celebrity culture has arrived on stage, and established protocols have gone out of the window.

Much of the media has moaned about producers casting Hollywood stars in West End shows. Theatre, they say, is being dumbed down through the shameless exploitation of movie names and semi-naked supermodels to sell seats and attract attention. We're currently publicising Madame Melville at The Vaudeville. It stars Macaulay Culkin, and his involvement has understandably stimulated a huge and highly competitive interest within the press.

As a result, on the night of the very first preview performance, this correspondent chose to slip in, a minute before curtain up, on a paid-for ticket, to steal a march on the rest of the media. The next day he filed copy. It was, supposedly, a news piece. But it contained vox pops from audience members, and personal observations on the production from the reporter himself. In short, it offered subjective views on the show and Macaulay Culkin's performance and that, in anybody's book, is a review, not news.

I wouldn't have cared if it was a genuine news piece. But this was a critique masquerading as news. No one reviews a movie from the rushes, and then wraps it up as a news story. Why should a live show be any different?

Critics are passionate, informed enthusiasts and supporters of live theatre. It's in everyone's interests that they should be the ones to express the critical perspective. Celebrity culture is black and white: build your heroes, knock 'em down and keep the copy coming. That's always been the case. But if you knock a show down because it's the star you're after, the show could well stay down.

My first experience of this was with Cliff Richard's Heathcliff. It previewed in Birmingham. On the strict understanding that he was writing a news piece, a Times journalist was admitted to one of the shows. He filed a review. Now everyone knew that Heathcliff would be utterly mauled by the media, regardless of its quality, so in the end - provoked by the deception - we imposed a blanket ban on media attendance. We sold the show by calling the public to arms to watch it and to draw their own conclusions without the interference of a celebrity-cum-critical commentary from the media.

Last week's arts correspondent has delivered the critical equivalent of a grainy, long lens paparazzo picture. We see - indistinctly - the figure of Macaulay Culkin, we can't really grasp what he's doing or how he's doing it, but we're told anyway.

This is not some petty spat between a miffed publicist and a journalist who stitched him up. It's about respecting artistic endeavour, allowing productions the space to bed themselves in, and supporting theatre by reviewing work when it's ready to be reviewed. If a production has shortcomings on its press night, it deserves everything it gets. But the West End's most brilliant, long-running productions have all had shortcomings on the very first day they've played to the public, and it's unjust that they should be judged before teething troubles have been resolved.

That said, I will not be tearing his liver out with my teeth because I trust that in the best traditions of theatre criticism, he will return to watch the show and not the star.

 Mark Borkowski is managing director of Borkowski PR.

webTitle: Lowell Bergman, US star of The Insider

fields.headline: You can call me Al
fields.standfirst: Lowell Bergman has gone from CBS investigative reporter to screen hero, played by Pacino in The Insider. Over here to talk at the Sheffield TV documentary festival, he tells  Duncan Campbell  where US journalism beats ours.
fields.trailText: Lowell Bergman has gone from CBS investigative reporter to screen hero, played by Pacino in The Insider. Over here to talk at the Sheffield TV documentary festival, he tells Duncan Campbell where US journalism beats ours.
fields.body:
Last weekend, journalist Lowell Bergman and legal worker Erin Brockovich received awards from the California First Amendment Coalition in recognition of their work on behalf of "freedom of information, freedom of expression and open government". This must surely have been the first time that the awards have been won by people who had been portrayed on screen within the previous year by, respectively, Al Pacino and Julia Roberts.

Bergman was the producer at CBS's 60 Minutes who worked with tobacco industry whistle-blower Jeffrey Wigand to expose the dishonesties of the business, but found his bosses unwilling to run the story until it had already been published in the press. The story became the Michael Mann film The Insider, which won Oscar nominations for Russell Crowe, who played Wigand, and Christopher Plummer, who played CBS's veteran correspondent Mike Wallace in a not wholly flattering way. It focused attention not only on the duplicity of the tobacco industry but also on the whole issue of self-censorship in journalism and the timidity of the large news corporations. CBS and Wallace were less than happy with the way they emerged in the film.

Bergman, who is to talk at the Sheffield International Documentary Festival this Friday, has just been back on the front pages, but this time reporting the news rather than making it. His investigation into the failed drug war in the United States, which showed that major US companies were routinely used for laundering Colombian cocaine profits, was on the front page of the New York Times. It was included in a two-part television documentary on the public broadcasting channel last week.

He left CBS at the time of the row over The Insider, but has found that one of the predictions in his film did not come true. "The movie helps to get people to return my phone-calls," he says, noting that there is a line in the movie where Al Pacino says to his wife "Take the 60 Minutes out of 'Lowell Bergman from 60 Minutes' and no one will return my phone-calls." In other ways, being played by Al Pacino (who made the character more manic and intense than this rather cheerful and easy-going man appears to be) has not dramatically changed his life. "I figure I'm a minor celebrity for a relatively short period of time. I'm old enough to know this ain't going to last."

Some of the bad blood left by the film, which showed CBS executives dodging the confrontation with tobacco giants Brown and Williamson, has not dried. Bergman says he made an attempt at rapprochement with Wallace - now 82 and something of an American institution like, say, the late Sir Robin Day was in Britain - who has angrily denounced both Bergman and the film. "He [Wallace] said a lot of things he shouldn't have said but - he's Mike."

Bergman said he had read an article after what he had thought was a fairly friendly meeting in which Wallace claimed that Bergman had come to his house on his hands and knees begging for his job back. "It's much more important for him to prove somehow that he's the top ape on the hill. Maybe at some point he will be willing to have a conversation that is reasonable."

He had seen Wigand recently, now part of a small anti-smoking foundation and testifying to the World Health Organisation in Geneva. "He is still followed around by a team of tobacco industry 'truth-tellers' who try and undermine him." Bergman says Russell Crowe's portrayal of Wigand as an ordinary, sometimes flawed, character was important. "He's just a person, not someone who set out to blow the whistle on the industry. He was scared, he said some things that he didn't really mean to the company, he had all the problems the average person would have. For reporters, it's important to have that up there. People assume that sources are somehow different, that they're not real people."

The Insider also highlighted the sometimes delicate relationship between television documentary producer and reporter in a world where the on-camera face often takes all of the kudos for an investigation. "The producer takes care of the correspondent, you feed them lines, you feed them research, you make sure they don't have dandruff on their shoulders. Basically, you are a maintenance person on top of being a reporter and and the rest of the stuff. That's the job I was paid for."

Bergman works freelance now for Frontline, the documentary news series, and teaches at the Graduate School of Journalism at Berkeley, where we met. He likes working with students, who make eager researchers even if they also make him feel old.

He was born in 1945, to a Hungarian emigre father and a mother of central European origins, and grew up in Brooklyn and Queens. He did a PhD on the history of philosophy at University of California in San Diego, under the radical German philosopher Herbert Marcuse - who was then facing death threats from rightwing vigilantes - at a time when the city was the main staging area for the war in Vietnam. Bergman's involvement in the civil rights and anti-war movements gave him a taste for muck-raking and he soon discovered that there was plenty of muck to rake.

He abandoned academia for journalism with the underground San Diego paper, the Street Journal. Unable to join the official journalists' union, he and his colleagues formed what became at that time the largest chapter of the Wobblies (the legendary Industrial Workers of the World). "We thought it was hilarious, but the local anti-communist conspiracy people couldn't figure us out."

He worked on Rolling Stone during its days in San Francisco but did not want to move to New York when it relocated and on Christmas Eve 1976 was fired by its editor Jann Wenner - himself portrayed in the new film Almost Famous, the story of then RS jounalist Cameron Crowe. "He did give me a letter, though, saying I was still employed, so I got my mortgage."

Bergman helped found the Centre for Investigative Reporting, which eventually brought together like-minded journalists from around the world to produce documentaries.

After All the President's Men, the book and film about the Watergate expose by Washington Post reporters Bob Woodward and Carl Bernstein, fashions had changed in journalism and the mainstream wanted the new brand of reporter. He was offered a job at ABC, where he stayed until he joined 60 Minutes in 1983, a post he held with a short break until his departure.

He feels that American television journalism is at a crossroads now, with many of the networks, led by Rupert Murdoch's Fox, feeling they have little or no obligation to cover major international stories that may be time-consuming, expensive and unlikely to figure on the ratings which increasingly drive the stations. He is hopeful that the growth of cable and the internet may open the way for more documentaries such as his recent project about the drug wars.

"The big dilemma here is defining what is news. Is it news to chase a car with the police? Is it news to go to the latest Hollywood parties, to do the latest violent incident?" He fears that the special legal and constitutional status that American journalists have, unlike their British counterparts, could be undermined by the trivialisation of current affairs. "If you start to say that we'll spend any amount of money chasing the motorcycle paparazzi around Princess Di, but we're not going to spend a dime on the massacres of East Timor, then why should you have any special privileges?"

Working in both print and television, he has had a chance to see the tensions between the two. "Print journalists generally look at television producers as dangerous because they take your print story, put pictures to it and take the credit. Television journalists will often look at print journalists as seeing only the micro-story - they don't step back and see the thing that people would really care about. But, more or less, the television journalists are scavenging the print people a lot, especially in the magazine show area. Television doesn't deal well with grey areas or with developmental stories that span a period of time."

He has been in Britain before, mainly to work, often on arms-dealing stories; he was fortuitously in a taxi going past Harrods when it was blown up by the IRA and spent the next 72 hours reporting for ABC. Of the differences between the British and American press, he says: "you [British] get away with personalised reporting that I don't count as real reporting. I suppose the Brits have been repressed a lot longer than the colonials.

"There is a great tradition of serious social reporting [in the US] that is over 100 years old, so we take ourselves somewhat more seriously than maybe you guys do. Journalism actually became a kind of profession in the United States at a certain point, particularly in the wake of Watergate." And maybe in the same way that a generation of young journalists were inspired by All the President's Men to get out and get digging, so a new generation may see The Insider and decide to go and be that bloke played by Al Pacino.

fields.headline: Shopping with Auntie
fields.standfirst: The BBC's commercial internet service is enlisting retailers to provide an online shopping service. But, as  Meg Carter  reports, there are cries of unfair competitive advantage.
fields.trailText: The BBC's commercial internet service is enlisting retailers to provide an online shopping service. But, as Meg Carter reports, there are cries of unfair competitive advantage.
fields.body:
Shopping on the internet is as easy as A, B, C. So says the BBC which, although best-known as Britain's public service broadcaster, last Sunday week began a two-month bus roadshow to help the public shop online, and next week, in partnership with children's imprint Ladybird Books, publishes How it Works, Shopping on the Internet.

How kind of Auntie to hold our hand while we shop online. Except that this initiative has little to do with altruism: the hope is that by encouraging a greater number of people into e-commerce, more money can be raised to help fund BBC radio and TV.

It's a curious rationale, but the BBC is no stranger to such logic. In this case it's all about beeb.com, the corporation's three-and-a-half-year-old commercial internet service overseen by BBC Worldwide, reinventing and better positioning itself to turn a profit.

From its launch, beeb.com has comprised a selection of the BBC's more commercial brands - mainly magazine spin-offs from BBC programmes - revised for online consumption. Limited e-commerce has been available to surfers clicking on banner ads through which they were whisked off to advertisers' own websites.

A strategic review, however, concluded that this in itself was not maximising the potential for a commercial BBC online service. The upshot was the decision to reposition beeb.com, a process that started in December 1999 and culminated in a high-profile, £7m national advertising campaign which kicked off last month.

The beeb.com roadshow and Ladybird book (the latter idea taken from the current advertising, to stress how anyone can learn the best way to shop online) is part of this re-positioning initiative.

"The idea is to establish the [beeb.com] brand with the message that there is a degree of safety and a certain naturalness about doing e-business with the BBC," says Julian Turner, chief executive of Beeb Ventures, the majority-owned subsidiary of BBC Worldwide which runs the beeb.com site. "As a shopping intermediary we offer the safety of a trusted environment and approved third-party partnerships."

So from now on beeb.com is to be known as an internet shopping portal. Surfers visiting the site can select from a variety of subject areas, all of which are directly linked to pre-existing BBC brands ranging from magazines such as Top of the Pops and Gardeners' World to programmes such as BBC Holiday. Each themed area provides online editorial content related to specific types of product. Users can ask experts for advice on which product to buy, or call up other related information.

The next step, however, is the nub of the new beeb.com service. Once users know what they want, they can call up details of different online suppliers - each of whom is a commercial partner in the beeb.com site - to compare price and delivery times. They then click on a preferred supplier to go direct to its site to complete the transaction online. To date, beeb.com has struck deals with 37 commercial partners which are featured on the site. Turner expects this figure to have risen to more than 60 by Christmas.

It is through such commercial partnerships and banner advertising that beeb.com hopes to make money. Partners pay for the BBC association. In return, however, they must provide a good-quality, reliable and fairly priced service that reflects well on the BBC brand. No such relationship will be entered into with any commercial partner on an exclusive basis, Turner adds: "It's not about the BBC becoming an e-tailer," he claims. "It's about being a shopping intermediary which can offer a safe and trusted shopping environment and approved third-party relationships."

Although not funded directly by the licence fee, the programme brands on which it is cashing in are, critics lament. Angela Mills of the British Internet Publishers' Alliance, whose members include not only traditional media owners with online interests but also pure internet-only businesses, expresses concern at the BBC's latest move.

"Because its positioning is 'shop here without trawling around lots of other websites', and because the brands it promotes heavily are all BBC brands developed by licence-fee funding, it's another example of the unfair competitive advantage the BBC has over its commercial competitors," she says.

The BBC's public service sites, meanwhile, should provide no direct link with beeb.com, she adds: "It's not as if they do so for any of beeb.com's commercial rivals." Although Turner stresses that all surfers are doing is moving from the corporation's public service to commercial online sites, and also insists beeb.com gives no undue prominence to BBC brands, Mills counters: "This is little more than paying lip service to open access."

Rob Hersov, chief executive of internet sports service Sportal, meanwhile, does not believe that the BBC should be on the net at all - either in a public service or a commercial capacity. "It is impossible to name one public service they are giving [on the net] that a privately funded company is not providing already," he says. And of the corporation's commercial online activities, Hersov adds: "They should not be doing any of these at all. [BBC Worldwide] should be sold off."

fields.headline: What's up doc?
fields.standfirst: The authored documentary has never been more popular, but  Fiona Morrow  asks, why don't we see them on television?
fields.trailText: The authored documentary has never been more popular, but Fiona Morrow asks, why don't we see them on television?
fields.body:
The seventh annual Sheffield International Documentary Festival begins today, with a week of screenings of the best in contemporary documentary film-making as well as classics from the archives, masterclasses with names such as Frederick Wiseman, and industry sessions debating the state of the art. At first glance, it would appear that the feature-length documentary has never been stronger, but only a handful of the films being shown will ever make it to our television screens, and yet fewer will be given their chance in the cinema.

Partly because British television has sported its "Best TV in the World" badge with such pride and for so long, the documentary tradition here is indelibly linked with the small screen - not in any way a problem when broadcasters are keen to celebrate diversity and offer their audience choice. But, in the ever-shifting sands of the television landscape, the future of the more challenging aspects of the schedules are increasingly uncertain. Feature-length documentaries have always given broadcasters trouble: necessarily long, often about "difficult" subjects, they tend to reach a limited audience. Yet, they regularly win awards at home and abroad.

With the onset of digital, the position of this relatively expensive, low-rating and, some might say, unwieldy form is once again under discussion, most imminently at the BBC, where the BBC2 documentary strand Storyville is set to become part of the "serious" digital channel, BBC4.

Nick Fraser, commissioning editor for Storyville, has had some big-hitters - Kurt And Courtney, Hoop Dreams, the Oscar-winning One Day in September - and is hoping that the strand he has been instrumental in shaping can survive the transition.

Fraser has faced crisis point before, when the then controller of BBC2, Michael Jackson, cut Storyville's predecessor Fine Cut practically out of existence. But Mark Thompson took over and feature-length docs were once again in favour, and Storyville - with more money, and more slots - was born.

Hardly surprising, then, that on arriving at Channel 4, Jackson was less than enthusiastic about its long-standing, well-respected strand True Stories. "If I look back through my diary, in 1995 True Stories transmitted on Thursdays at 9.30pm, in 1997 on Tuesdays at 9pm, but by 1998 it was all over the place, going out at different times and different nights," says Peter Moore, former head of documentaries at Channel 4.

The present controller of documentaries, Peter Dale, doesn't see scheduling decisions as indicative of less commitment: "I don't believe that audiences are as concerned with strand identity," he explains. "What counts to someone choosing their evening's viewing is not whether there is a True Stories film on, but that there is a documentary about something they are interested in."

He also regards time slots as mattering in terms of individual films, rather than across a strand: "In commercial terms our impression of audience habits are changing - by 10.30pm people are ready to sit down and watch something more challenging. I fight for the best position in the schedules on an individual basis."

He does admit, however that his is not a view always welcomed by film-makers: "I do find it frustrating that many film-makers who have been around a long time don't accept that the broadcasting environment is more competitive than it once was, and find it hard to accept that that has implications for where their work is placed."

Such a close consideration of ratings is something Nick Fraser is hoping to avoid: "What I'm worried about is the prospect of an A list and a B list. If BBC2 changes in the manner of C4 and decides to go for popularity, then there will be only certain subjects and certain big-name film-makers who will hold up in peak time. The danger is that the most challenging, most innovative films won't make it to the main channel."

Not that Fraser believes in being worthy for the sake of it, in fact he's keen to encourage film-makers to consider the impact that their choice of subject-matter can have. "They just don't sit down and make the connection that if they are going to make a long film, it should be a film that people will find especially intriguing and be willing to commit their time to. There is a kind of puritanism to do with documentaries, which keeps people away from popular culture and showbiz subjects."

There are notable exceptions, of course: Nick Broomfield's Kurt and Courtney, Molly Dineen's Geri - even Kevin MacDonald's One Day in September was put together as a com mercial package. "It was made to attract profile," Fraser admits. "It's made to knock you over. It tries very consciously in every way to have that effect. And that is a new approach. Here are people setting out to invest over $100m in a documentary, and they are constantly thinking about the impact it will have in a cinema. So when documentary steps into that arena it becomes as calculated a project as any other movie. And maybe it has to be."

"There was a time when people imagined that documentary meant something that involved hard work, and would be good for you, but now people are aware that they can be moved and drawn into an unexpected world," Kim Longinotto, the director of Divorce Iranian Style, suggests. What time her films are transmitted does matter to her: "You want them to go out at a good hour, you want them to be seen." Her latest film, Gaea Girls, is screening at Sheffield, before going on tour with a number of other docs around the BFI's regional film theatres and London's independent cinemas, something she finds very encouraging: "If people will turn out at the cinema to see a documentary, I'm sure they can be encouraged to switch on at home."

If the commercial pressures on terrestrial broadcasters are pushing feature documentaries to the margins of the schedules then the digital option may yet prove their saviour. Caroline Cooper, director of this year's Sheffield Festival, agrees: "We are finding that the public's appetite for these documentaries is increasing. Last year's festival saw an increase of 35% in attendance, and the Docs On Tour programme was incredibly successful. If people can be enthused and excited about the documentary form, then perhaps a dedicated channel would concentrate and hold that interest."

Nick Fraser agrees, albeit cautiously: "It seems to help that the films are called Storyville, and it seems that that will continue on the new channel. I just have to keep from going completely crazy until the hierarchy at the BBC is sorted out and then I can begin commissioning films across two channels with a blank slate - in a way it's perfect, if it can be made to work. If the money's good enough, and it's distributed properly across both the terrestrial and digital channels, it could be a much better situation than I was in two or three years ago."

fields.headline: New Media diary
fields.trailText: • British Airways makes its second appearance here in as many weeks. It seems BA is taking the concept of service to extremes, and is offering loyal customers something no other airline has thought of. Imagine the surprise of Executive Clubbers when, logging on to the new BA members' website and calling up the number to redeem Air Miles, they found themselves on a gay chat-line, being introduced to cheeky Carl. Carl claims he has something for everyone - "It's clean, safe and loads of fun" - while also managing to be triple X-rated. Is this a case of BA getting its wires crossed, or has the airline decided customer service needs to get more personal?
fields.body:
 British Airways makes its second appearance here in as many weeks. It seems BA is taking the concept of service to extremes, and is offering loyal customers something no other airline has thought of. Imagine the surprise of Executive Clubbers when, logging on to the new BA members' website and calling up the number to redeem Air Miles, they found themselves on a gay chat-line, being introduced to cheeky Carl. Carl claims he has something for everyone - "It's clean, safe and loads of fun" - while also managing to be triple X-rated. Is this a case of BA getting its wires crossed, or has the airline decided customer service needs to get more personal?

 Different media worlds collided at last Wednesday's second Match: Unmatched, an event that brought together the great and the good, and tried to filter out the omnipresent liggers. Some nevertheless managed to crawl through the net, and unsuspecting networkers found themselves the victim of business pitches from people who have clearly spent too long at First Tuesday. No one could have missed the Channel 4 product placements - pens, matches, wall-projections and flashing drink adornments which made fabulous belt buckles - and most new-media types were encouraged by the suggestion of Channel 4 boss Michael Jackson that we drop the "new" in new media. A few were a little confused by deputy managing director Duncan Edwards's assertion that it was all about "Deliverance". "Was he calling us confused sexual-preference hillbillies?" asked one. Diary is not sure.

 The best-kept secret of the Streaming Media Conference was the party at the Commonwealth Institute on Wednesday, the first night of the event. The specially invited VIPs danced the night away in their designer suits, surrounded by what everyone assumed was hired totty - "They're too hot to be Streaming chicks," said one onlooker. Why was it such a secret? Because the organisers had somehow managed to pull in high-profile bands and DJs, such as Seb Fontaine and Judge Jules. They even got that dancer girl from the Nokia ads. Diary wonders if the organisers decided to tell the talent exactly what type of audience they would be playing to before the event - why else would Reef bottle out at the last minute? Luckily the Bluetones were on hand, and thought their street cred could handle playing to a bunch of techies in suits.

 Londoners will have noticed something plop out of the Evening Standard last Wednesday - the first issue of the Industry Standard Europe (no relation). Diary wonders which astute marketing brain figured out that tie-up?

 Amy Vickers is new media editor of mediatheguardian.com.

fields.headline: My new media: Catherine Ostler
fields.standfirst: Catherine Oster, editor of Peoplenews.com, is interviewed by Carolyne Ellis.
fields.trailText: Catherine Oster, editor of Peoplenews.com, is interviewed by Carolyne Ellis.
fields.body:
Favourite sites? Hintmag.com - they've got a very good weekly fashion column called Chic Happens. I like inside.com. It's basically a sort of inside track gossip on the media industry. Although it's very American, it's very thorough, and it's all done with a twist. I like fuckedcompany.com. It captures the madness of the industry. I would read all those anyway, because I'm a gossip, but there's also a really moronic one called emode.com. It's just silly quizzes, but they're really well done, sort of things like, if you were a dog, what breed would you be? Everyone in our office loves that. We've got games on our sites, so we're always searching for new ones.

Last online purchase? A British Airways plane ticket to Paris, on britishairways.com.

Most recent technological faux pas? I don't really know where to start. I think forgetting your own password isn't good news. I'm not joking, but every day I do something that makes the techies stare at me.

Main news sources on web? For straight news, thisislondon.co.uk. If you're doing what we're doing which is quite London, gossip and fashion-centred, then it's the most relevant. Also page.six.com for good New York gossip, pa news and fashionwiredaily.com.

Most persistent spam emailer? Well, the one I always get, which bugs the hell out of me, is the Hotmail one telling me my account is too large.

Time spent on web? Oh god, endless, hours and hours. All day, every day in the week, and then I log on at the weekend to check it out too.

Next boo.com/clickmango? I think it will probably be one of the women's portals.

Least useful site/s on web? The women's portals, because I think they're sort of very old-fashioned - cheesy, frumpy and slightly patronising.

Most useful site/s? In terms of utility, I love the travel sites. Much better on the web, much quicker and much more efficient.

What screensaver do you use? It's a kind of deep sea image with fishes on it. It really annoys me actually.

Most irritating thing about the web? Because I spend so much time on it I worry about my eyesight. I had perfect eyesight six months ago.

Do you bother with old media? Yeah, absolutely. I've worked in newspapers and magazines, and I'm still addicted to both. I like W Magazine, the Weekend FT and Vogue. I read all the redtops every day.

 Catherine Ostler is editor of PeopleNews.com.
