fields.headline: Hello! for teens
fields.standfirst: Another title launched into the already packed teen market? You bet!  And its publishers at the BBC say they've found a gap in the market just aching to be filled!  Merope Mills  checks it out!
fields.trailText: Another title launched into the already packed teen market? You bet! And its publishers at the BBC say they've found a gap in the market just aching to be filled! Merope Mills checks it out.
fields.body:
There is nothing more likely to set editorial and publishing teeth on edge than the prospect of a new magazine being launched into the market. The threat to readership, advertising and story exclusives is not one to be taken lightly. Yet the announcement, three months ago, that BBC Worldwide was to introduce another teen title into its range was greeted, perhaps not with a shrug, but certainly with a coolness that said the market felt confident that it had all bases covered.

"They obviously think there is some sort of niche - I can't think there is one," said Rebecca Martin, editor of Jump. "It's hard to imagine what they could have uncovered that could be different," concurred Bliss editor Liz Nice. All of which had the BBC staff virtually apoplectic with excitement. As far as they were concerned it was staring them straight in the face.

This week, Star magazine will be adding its weight to an already fat array of teenage glossies and glaring right back at the publishers who, as Jeremy Mark, editor-in-chief of the BBC's teenage projects, says, "just couldn't see it". Tapping into the age-old interest in celebrity, the new fortnightly takes inspiration from American magazines US Weekly, Entertainment Weekly and Teen People, but is best described as a younger, Americanised Hello!, OK! or Heat. In the first issue Melissa Joan Hart (Sabrina the Teenage Witch) "invites us into her stunning Los Angeles home", while Nick Carter "exclusively takes us scuba-diving with the Backstreet Boys in the Bahamas." For the cover story, Buffy actress Sarah Michelle Gellar opens up about "the price of fame and why she has absolutely no regrets".

Star enters the arena at a time of much activity. In an effort to reflect the fact that their readers are getting older younger, magazines are being launched and relaunched all the time. Preparing to make an entrance on the teen scene some time next year are CosmoGirl, ElleGirl and Teen Vogue. Yet, despite targeting a similar age group, these are not developments that particularly irk Lindsaye Fox, group publisher for the BBC teenage products. "Like the magazines that currently exist, these new entries are predominantly girl lifestyle titles. Sure, they have a smattering of celebrity content. But really their focus is on problems, relationships, fashion, beauty and other lifestyle issues."

By contrast, Star's focus is pure celebrity. Where fashion and beauty exist, it is solely as a guide on how to mimic the look of the stars. Star is a magazine tapping exclusively into this all-intriguing and aspirational attitude to celebrities. "In our research, we found a lot of teenagers weren't buying OK! or Hello! because they had Les Dennis or Catherine Zeta Jones on the cover, but they were reading it if they found it lying around because it had the odd bit about Gwyneth Paltrow or Westlife in it," says Fox. "At the same time their lifestyle magazines were delivering them with what they wanted for lifestyle but weren't really satisfying that hardcore need to know everything there is about celebrities."

An additional comfort for the Star team is the knowledge that this thirst for celebrities is one which transcends all age boundaries. While the content relevancy of magazines such as J17 or Bliss can only last so long, celebrity scoops remain a pull throughout the teenage years.

Fox puts her target age group at 14-16, while the publicity cites a more ambitious 12-19. Jeremy Mark, who doubles up as editor of the title, isn't keen to pinpoint an age: "I'd hate to put an age limit on it simply because there are elements of the magazine which have such wide appeal. A lot of my friends would read it," he says, "and I'm 33."

With an older, cleaner, simpler style, Star stands out from the loud and garish covers of its teen title rivals. However, Mark believes his product is unique in that it has no competitors. Emap, by contrast, haven't seen it that way. In a recent interview, Smash Hits editor John McKie admitted the £2m Star launch was giving Emap bosses "a bit of a headache." Yet with a look and content that could draw young adults into the bargain, the beleaguered Heat could be equally troubled. At present Heat editor Mark Frith denies losing much sleep over it: "It's going to be stocked alongside teen mags," he says, "and if it's not a teen mag then there's going to be a perception problem. There are no headaches here. We're totally bouyant."

Heat has had trouble sustaining the big names and big circulation figures that it initially aspired to. With an ambitious 200,000 target readership (and promises of cover stories like Gellar to live up to), Star could conceivably do the same. However, with an additional Los Angeles office behind him, Mark is convinced he'll be able to draw the crowd-pullers to his pages. "We capture that slightly older celebrity element. People who want to address the teen market but don't want to do baby girl glossies. We do well-styled shoots and candid interviews. The American publicists really like the kind of coverage can we give them."

The youth market is known for its constant thirst for novelty and freshness so, in the short term at least, there is certainly room for something new. The real challenge for a magazine like Star is to sustain a level of originality that sees it through the novelty factor and the threat the internet poses. Teen titles were badly hit in recent ABCs with big names like Bliss, Smash Hits, J17 and TV Hits down year-on-year. Again, Fox brushes off the losses, pointing to the rise in the market value, due to higher priced titles. "The volume sale may have fallen," she says, "but the actual profitability in the market is very, very strong."

Still, she remains aware "it is an incredibly competitive market," and knows that her media-savvy audience are frequently drawn online. "As internet sites become more aggressive we'll need to adapt, but, at the moment, as far as our audience are concerned it's just another media choice," says Fox. Which is why the magazine feels at ease with pointing its readers towards the net and recommending specific sites like hollywood.com or popboys.com which serve their readers with similar celebrity tittle-tattle. But Fox will not be moved from her confident stance. "We'll keep an eye on it," she says, "but at the moment teenagers don't seem to have any issues at all about mixing and merging their media."

Teen scene: what Star is up against

CosmoGirl

Likes to be known as: "A cool new magazine for teens".

Typical content: Totally humiliating sleepover stories, look hotsy-totsy in braces, the easiest workout ever, Boy-O-Meter, Mandy Moore's fashion must-haves, get to college for free.

Typical cover: Boy-band hunk styled in sexy muscle-exposing pose.

Random quote: (To actor Bryce Johnson) "Okay, Bryce, tell us the truth: You were, like, totally popular when you were in high school, right?"

Britney factor: Not a high Britney presence evident in the American CosmoGirl. More Britney stories are anticipated in the British launch next year.

Star

Likes to be known as: "The celebrity magazine".

Typical content: Stephen Gately at the Billy Elliot premiere, Ronan Keating filming a TV ad for his autobiography at Luton Hoo, Jason Behr on Dawson's Creek, movies and on-screen smooching.

Typical cover: Young Hollywood actress/singer styled in pouting seaside pose.

Random quote: "They chat and share a private joke. Although these two EastEnders stars may not have the same passion their characters share on-screen they truly are friends."

Britney factor: Good potential.

Bliss

Likes to be known as: "The mag that makes you famous".

Typical content: The girl who snogged Becks before Posh, Paris fashion with Precious, 100% Boys (Hot Posters!, Michael Owen exclusive, snogging sorted, the best and worst chat-up lines ever!)

Typical cover: Natalie Appleton!!!!

Random quote: "They called me a slag!"

Britney factor: High. Including a "How to look like Britney when you look nothing like Britney!" feature.

J-17

Likes to be known as: "The world's coolest mag...definitely".

Typical content: My Gossip Hell! (How bitchin' ruined three girls' lives), Divorce - it's not the end of the world, six foxy lad posters, 15 pages of sussed advice and lad chat.

Typical cover: Fresh young model of the Britney ilk.

Random quote: "I love the purple glitter socks. They're cool."

Britney factor: Full page dedicated to how Britney gets her hair so super sleek. Interview with Billie Piper comes a close second

webTitle: Media: Daily national circulations go down

fields.headline: Bulks - just say no
fields.standfirst: Cutting prices, giving away freebies and encouraging cheap pre-paid subscriptions might pull the punters in, says  Roy Greenslade, but why can't newspapers transform them into genuine sales?
fields.trailText: Cutting prices, giving away freebies and encouraging cheap pre-paid subscriptions might pull the punters in, says Roy Greenslade, but why can't newspapers transform them into genuine sales?
fields.body:
A new chart, but the old story. Despite a growing reliance on bulk sales, the downward sales trend continues. To get some idea of the underlying problem, consider these unpalatable facts. In September last year the circulation figures of the 12 national dailies were boosted by a total of 279,182 giveaway copies. In September this year, that total had risen to 348,981, an increase of 25%.

Making the same comparisons for the 12 Sundays (247,823 a year ago and 379,181 now) reveals a 53% rise. As the former Sunday Mail editor Jim Cassidy was fond of saying: "Bulks are like drugs. Papers get addicted to them and then they can't break the habit."

That analogy is so true. As with junkies, even those who sincerely seek to break their habit, the opposite inevitably happens: dependency increases. Having discovered a way to maintain their headline sales figures, papers have become indiscriminate in using bulks.

Incidentally, the polite term for bulks is "sampling". It's claimed that the exercise is designed to put the paper into the hands of those who would not otherwise see it, therefore luring them into becoming regular buyers. After years of giving away papers in planes, hotels and fast-food restaurants, and still managing to lose sales, the transparent falsity of this claim is exposed. It is about massaging sales, not winning readers.

Looking at the problem from the other direction, comparing genuine sales - the ones where people pay the stated cover price - shows how badly the industry is doing. In September last year the 12 dailies sold 11,237,974 copies at the full rate. In September this year that had fallen to 10,778,457, a decline of 4.1%. A similar comparison for the Sundays records a fall of 5.8%. Let's look at how this works in practice at one title.

The Times's phenomenal circulation rise began in 1993 when its price was cut to the bone. Reluctantly, after years of selling below cost, its News International management was forced to raise the cover price. By the time it did so, the paper was able to exploit other gimmicks invented by rivals, such as the cheap pre-paid subscriptions pioneered - at enormous cost to its own bottom line - by the Telegraph group. Despite official pressure, the Times also realised it could go on using price-cutting on a regional basis.

The result is revealed in the ABC figures for last month. The Times's total sale is declared to be 730,679. Of these, only 478,505 were sold at the full rate. More than 100,000 were sold at a discount, a further 67,000 were cheap subscription copies and more than 43,000 were given away for nothing.

Even so, sales of the Times are falling. A year ago, when it was selling 50% more at full rate, relying on fewer subscriptions and fewer bulks, its overall sale was 12,000 higher than last month. It's hard not to conclude that the marketing initiatives have not been matched by editorial expertise. The paper has reached out to people and many of them, trying it at 10p or picking it up from a pile in an airport lounge, have rejected it. Executives will be hoping that the expensive relaunch of the Saturday sections nine days ago will stop the rot.

For some indefinable reason, the Daily Telegraph - another paper living within the circulation drug culture - remains a more readable paper for a right-of-centre audience. Even its absurd leader page redesign hasn't put people off.

The Times, meanwhile, is all over the place. The front page is often too jazzy, relying on visual impact at the expense of words, and this sense of the paper being "over designed" extends to the inside pages too. The news pages lack coherence, mixing the light and the serious in a confusing manner, and, whether true or not, there is a perception that, compared to the Telegraph, there is less to read. As the leader and op-ed pages remain much as they have been for years, the contrast between their sobriety and the rest of the paper is even more pronounced. There is much for editor Peter Stothard to think about when he returns from his enforced medical break to take back the reins from his stand-in Ben Preston.

Another Wapping editor who should be thinking hard is the Sun's David Yelland. He will be delighted that he appears to have seen off the Mirror's sales challenge for the moment. His paper extended its lead last month and, year on year, is 2% up while the Mirror is 2% down. But what does the Sun stand for? Its political ambivalence, illustrated to an extent in the Media Guardian interview with the paper's political editor Trevor Kavanagh two weeks ago, must baffle readers.

Worse, perhaps, is the way it warps its news values. Did anyone really think the childish reincarnation of William Hague as a parrot merited the front page on the day that Milosevic was overthrown in Serbia? Its enthusiasm for Tony Blair's New Labour has now reached the point at which former Mirror political guru Joe Haines, if he was still writing his column, would inevitably comment: "The Sun's support for the Labour government resembles the way in which the executioner supports the hanged man."

Apart from the Sun's obsession with Europe, which provides it with weekly, sometimes daily, leaders savaging Blair, there is no central thrust to its views on the government's policies. This, by the way, could equally be said of the Mirror, especially during the petrol crisis. But the Sun is more confusing because, though we know where the Mirror is coming from even when it misreads situations, Yelland's paper seesaws hopelessly.

This ambiguity, stemming from the Tory prejudices of its senior executives and many junior staff too, leads it to make colossal errors. On Friday, for instance, it was obliged to publish a humbling apology to Alastair Campbell, and pay money to one of his children's schools, for a totally false story the day before.

This claimed that Campbell "put the boot into Britain" by defending the Runnymede Trust's report which suggested the word "British" was racist. It repeated the claim in its leading article. In fact, Campbell's briefing, as reported by every other paper, reflected the disappointment of both Blair and home secretary Jack Straw at the report's conclusion.

Why did the Sun get it so wrong? It could be a journalistic error, though I think it unlikely. In reality, the nation's best-selling red-top is true blue. Despite the facade of backing Blair, any stories which undermine him, even untrue ones, are grist to the mill.

webTitle: Media: Maggie Brown on Jane Tranter, BBC drama commissioner

fields.headline: 'If I say it will happen, it will happen'
fields.standfirst: Hand-picked by Greg Dyke - partly to prevent her being poached - Jane Tranter says she got the job of BBC drama commissioner on her track record. She tells  Maggie Brown why her modern-retro recipe will work
fields.trailText: Hand-picked by Greg Dyke - partly to prevent her being poached - Jane Tranter says she got the job of BBC drama commissioner on her track record. She tells Maggie Brown why her modern-retro recipe will work.
fields.body:
She's the 11-plus failure who went to a top university. The BBC secretary who rose to take charge of all its drama. A woman who even rivals describe as "very personable, very credible". "You will be hard pressed to find anyone with a bad word about her," says Andrew Davies, TV writer and adapter. Last Thursday, months of negotiation and five years of recrimination ended when Jane Tranter, 37, was named BBC drama commissioner - a new title for an old idea.

She is the BBC's supreme drama leader, the creative champion at its most critical hour. "The BBC can claim a piece of your heart," says Tranter, in a line that could fit one of her trademark costume dramas. What was her manifesto? "What got me the job was the programmes I made. My manifesto is my work." In the past three years Tranter's serials department has produced the goods - Warriors, Wives and Daughters, David Copperfield, Care, and Other People's Children.

Such is her standing that director general Greg Dyke preferred her modern take to the more traditional tastes of ITV's drama controller, Nick Elliott."She seems to enjoy herself. And she has the confidence to back her own judgments. She's actually like Elliott," says one observer. It is also said that the BBC simply could not afford to lose her to rival Channel 4.

Tranter's mission is to rescue the BBC's reputation from inconsistency and downright bad programmes (Badger, Fish), while turning the huge spending boost on popular drama conjured up by Dyke into successful hour-long series for BBC1 at 9pm, supporting the move of the news. BBC1 has to double the amount of hour-long dramas it shows each week from two hours to four. "We have to decide what makes a popular BBC drama," says Tranter, wearing black leather trousers, jumper and silver jewellery. "To decide how to fill the hours with unique, distinctive dramas, that are BBC as opposed to what any other channel does. Our audience expectation has been dulled in the last decade."

Harbour Lights and Sunburn, she believes, might have been done well by ITV. From now on, dramas as star vehicles are out. "We have to do it fast, but not by panicking, without knee-jerk commissioning. If we think we need to stuff the autumn full of overly popular things we'll fail. We need to re-present ourselves to the audience with the very best ideas, based on the very best scripts."

But Alan Yentob and Mark Thompson have also recruited two very substantial players, ex-Granada drama controller Simon Lewis and his deputy Sue Hogg, to make popular drama series for BBC1, fresh from creating the ITV series Grafters and Always & Everyone.

But here lies some confusion more reminiscent of the old-style BBC drama department. Much has been made over the past few months of Tranter's anxiety to clarify her position in relation to the Granada importees, before accepting the big job. Lewis believes the pair report direct to Thompson, while working with Tranter. Tranter, meanwhile, says, "I will commission projects from Simon Lewis, [I will commission] everything from everyone, apart from the soaps."

Examples of BBC1 dramas which fit her bill? Holby City, Casualty, EastEnders, David Copperfield, Wives and Daughters, Pure Wickedness, Down to Earth (the new Sunday night hit) and The Sins, a forthcoming series starring Pete Postlethwaite, a pure Tranter product. "Look what the BBC has grown up with - Z Cars, Edge of Darkness, early Bergeracs, Boys from the Blackstuff." These, she says, are the traditions and influences to build on. "I call it modern-retro, look at the best we have been and sharpen up what we're doing now."

She is not a well-known face. Too busy working, she's never courted outside attention. "I can't think of an argument I've had which is not about a programme. I think if you have arguments with people about getting the programmes made, and your only agenda is to get the best possible result on screen, then people understand why sometimes you're tough." Those who work with her say she defuses rows with cutting humour.

Born in Oxford, Tranter is the daughter of two teachers. Both were strong Methodists from families where the industrious, pious tradition went back generations. When she failed the 11-plus, her parents paid fees for St Helen's & St Margaret's School near Oxford, and then Kingswood School, Bath, the Methodist public school. She is poised rather than posh.

Wanting to be an "urban chick", she headed for King's College, London and an English degree only to find it "not very interesting - I was really cross about it." Dickens was the most modern author she studied. She also took "hideously uncool plays to Edinburgh - like a Man for All Seasons."

With a certificate from an Oxford secretarial course, she joined the BBC in 1985, camouflaged as a secretary at BBC Radio Drama. But at 24 she became an assistant TV floor manager for EastEnders and Bergerac, and was launched. "It was old-fashioned - a way to learn everything about TV while disguising your intent. The whole time I was interested in scripts and how they came to be commissioned."

One criticism is that her experience is too concentrated on the words, rather than the overall production - yet producers say she knows when to intervene if stars play up. Her second BBC break came in 1987 when she moved to be assistant script editor on the fourth series of Casualty, and the third break when David Thompson, now head of BBC Films, took her on as a script editor, working on Screen One and Two. Her reputation grew, leading Carlton to headhunt her for its new TV franchise, as a drama commissioner. "I could not resist. I'd never get that opportunity again," she says.

At Carlton she backed Timothy Spall in the comedy drama, Frank Stubbs Promotes, Bramwell - the then-rising writing star Lucy Gannon's surprise hit about a Victorian woman doctor - and the regional soap, London Bridge. Her return to the BBC in 1997 coincided with the disastrous split between broadcasting and production which encouraged channel controllers to turn to independent producers.

As she joined, several of the BBC's most respected drama executives were quitting the chaos ("shouting 'see you, suckers!'" Tranter recalls) for the independent sector. "I'd always thought I would return to the BBC. I couldn't bear it when I was in ITV and it was considered great sport to pull BBC dramas to pieces, even if frequently they deserved to be." When Michael Wearing left, she took over the BBC serials department, home of Our Friends in the North and Pride and Prejudice.

"An executive producer has a finger in many pies, you have an overview, provide a safety net, quality control; you get all of the blame, none of the credit. I love it. It is a job without boredom, you're in production 365 days a year, working at a cracking pace. I love the adrenalin of production going on all around you."

Tranter says of the recent arid period: "Part of the problem was that BBC drama had allowed itself to get overgrown and unventilated. It's always easy to look inward, into a bureaucracy. As soon as you do that, you're done for. You have got to understand the structures, but you have to look outside, to the audiences, concentrate on making programmes. I never changed my modus operandi.

"So [in serials] we put our heads down and made the programmes. Coming from ITV, the BBC was simple. I wrote out commissioning forms for development funds [for new dramas]. To have them green-lit I went across the road to [BBC1 controller] Peter Salmon, who'd joined at same time. He gave backing for Peter Kosminsky [Warriors] and William Ivory [The Sins]."

webTitle: Analysis: government's fuel tax policy hits some households hard

fields.headline: Tax disc losers
fields.standfirst:
While the cost of motoring has fallen in real terms, the government's policy of high fuel tax has hit some households particularly hard

Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: After September's protests, the government is having to give a public justification for both the level and structure of taxes on motoring for the first time.
fields.body:
After September's protests, the government is having to give a public justification for both the level and structure of taxes on motoring for the first time.

There is a sound case for shifting the burden of tax from vehicle ownership to vehicle use. But taxes are blunt and it is important to be aware of who wins and who loses. The proportion of the price paid at the pump that goes to the Treasury rose steadily from 44% in 1980 to 82% in 1999 - hence the fuel protests. But the history of the relationship between motorists and the fisc contains a surprise: the index of the overall cost of motoring has hardly changed at all in a generation, after allowing for general retail price inflation.

The chart shows what has happened since 1964. Although the real price of fuel has been rising for more than a decade, petrol has been nearly as expensive on occasions in the past as it is now. Furthermore, the real cost of purchasing vehicles has fallen steadily - and the government has been successfully pushing for further cuts.

Relative to rising real incomes, the cost of motoring has fallen by 30% since 1964. For instance, the Austin Mini cost £497 (heater extra) when first sold in 1957. That was the equivalent of 30 weeks average household weekly income. This year you could buy one of the last new Minis for about 20 weeks' income - and it was a better quality, longer-lasting vehicle (heater taken for granted).

Technology has cut the costs of manufacturing and improved vehicle quality. The modern vehicle is also more fuel efficient and, if properly maintained, many times less polluting. Car makers have agreed to continue with these improvements. High fuel prices give incentives to us all to adopt best practice.

How do we change our behaviour when fuel prices rise? Evidence from across the west suggests that if real fuel prices rise by 10%, then after a period of adjustment (several years perhaps) one can expect a fall in fuel consumption of between 6% and 8%.

But for every 10% increase in real incomes, fuel consumption and traffic increase by more than 10%. Thus, to hold consumption constant and offset the effect of the normal 2.5% annual growth in real incomes, the price of fuel to the consumer would have to rise by more than 4% above inflation every year.

The effects of petrol prices on traffic levels tend to be less than their effects on the amount of fuel consumed. A price increase of 10% would reduce vehicle mileage by about 3% in the long term. To hold traffic constant the price would have to rise by about 10% a year. That is hardly likely.

Relationships of this kind are taken into account in the government's recent 10-year transport plan. This is welcome but the various policy options are not fully explored. If the government adopted different taxes, there would be significant changes in the predicted balance between rail and road.

It is tempting to assume that raising fuel taxes will disadvantage the rich more than the poor but that view is over-simple. Car ownership and use depend upon urban density (which affects average distance to facilities and the availability of public transport and other alternatives to the car). The structure and age of households also matters.

Even among poorer households, there are some for whom fuel costs form a significant part of the household budget. They are going to be particularly hard-hit by fuel price increases. When the price of petrol goes up, in order to keep on buying their usual amounts of fuel people living on their own on a state pension would have to spend twice the proportion of their household income as would a two-adult family or a retired couple not on a state pension. Household types that are adversely affected by petrol price rises include the unemployed; those in Northern Ireland; and single-adult, childless, working households, which account for more than 8% of all households affected.

At the other end of the scale are people living in Greater London who have higher-than-average incomes. They are less affected because they are significantly less likely to run a car; those that do own a vehicle tend to spend less than the average on petrol. In London, public transport provides an alternative. Outside London, it is those living in areas of medium and low density who feel some pain. Such areas constitute 31% of affected households and they are somewhat more badly affected in relation to their incomes than the national average.

If the chancellor were to move towards taxing the use of vehicles rather than their ownership, he would make a modest contribution towards moderating the growth of traffic and resulting pollution. But this would not be enough to remove the need for building new roads. In deed, government plans (made prior to September) accept this.

The government has yet to recognise that fuel taxation does hit certain households particularly hard. If government resolves to keep the costs of using vehicles high in order to reflect the long-term costs of road traffic to society in general, it would be right to divert part of the growing revenue from fuel tax towards compensating the categories of losers outlined above. There probably need to be cuts in the cost of ownership. Reducing the tax disc (vehicle excise duty) to a nominal registration fee would be easy to implement and would start to help some of the right people.

Stephen Glaister is professor of transport at Imperial College London. The Effect of Fuel Prices on Motorists by Stephen Glaister and Dan Graham is published by the AA

fields.headline: Deals calm oil markets
fields.standfirst: Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: Unsettled oil markets received a double boost at the weekend with news of a settlement in a potentially damaging strike in Venezuela and a signal that Saudi Arabia is ready to take further action to bring down the price which climbed above $35 a barrel last week.
fields.body:
Unsettled oil markets received a double boost at the weekend with news of a settlement in a potentially damaging strike in Venezuela and a signal that Saudi Arabia is ready to take further action to bring down the price which climbed above $35 a barrel last week.

Saudi oil minister Ali al-Naimi said that the producers cartel Opec could act to curb price pressures ahead of its scheduled November meeting.

"If there is demand, Opec and other producing countries are more than ready to give the market what it needs," he said.

Earlier attempts by Opec to curb an oil price rise had been meeting with modest success until the recent escalation of tension in the Middle East which sent the price scurrying to a 10-year high.

The Saudi minister said that if the price exceeded the limit Opec had laid down production would be stepped up to counteract the rise.

"I believe supply today is higher than demand but under the current political and military events... speculators have raised prices on fears of what might happen in the future," he said.

On Saturday leaders of Venezuela's biggest oil union Fedepetrol decided to call off a four-day strike after a deal with state oil company PDVSA. The union's president, Carlos Ortega, told a local TV channel that a preliminary deal had been reached. "We call on all oil workers... to return to their normal duties."

The industrial action - seen as part of a wider struggle between the country's president Hugo Chavez and the trade unions - had threatened to disrupt supplies from the world's third largest oil exporter. Mr Chavez had earlier refused to negotiate with union leaders.

PDVSA had been maintaining normal output but estimated that it would only have been able to maintain supplies for a few more days in the face of continued action by the workers.

If the strike had continued it would have threatened Venezuela's economic prospects and added further upward pressure to the price of oil.

Market worries that a higher oil price would fuel inflationary pressures and feed through into higher interest rates and slower growth were underlined by a senior US central banker at the weekend.

William Poole, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of St Louis, said that the authorities could not look only at non-oil inflation. "It is clear that oil matters to people", noting that higher oil prices were already having an impact on shipping costs and air fares.

Financial analysts will be keeping a close eye on a series of speeches due to be delivered by top federal reserve officials over the coming week for further clues about the central bank's thinking.

The most eagerly awaited are comments from fed chairman Alan Greenspan, who has speaking engagements today and on Thursday.

webTitle: The forgotten flashpoint between nuclear powers

fields.headline: The forgotten flashpoint between nuclear powers
fields.standfirst: Never mind Pakistan - it's India's relationship with China which should most concern the west, says Luke Harding in New Delhi
fields.trailText: Never mind Pakistan - it's India's relationship with China which should most concern the west, says Luke Harding in New Delhi.
fields.body:
The Tawang valley in India's north-eastern state of Arunachal Pradesh is a remote place. A few tribal farmers live here. The occasional hunter can be seen slogging up its hillsides. Were it not for the fact the Buddhist mountain region occupies a pivotal place in India's relations with China, the valley would remain one of the country's most obscure and underdeveloped areas.

As it is, the roads leading deep into its interior are in excellent condition, even during the monsoon months. Their construction is a legacy of the war which China and India fought in the Tawang Valley in 1962. The war saw the Chinese invade the valley and press on as far as Tezpur in Assam, inflicting heavy casualties and humiliation on Indian troops. The Chinese eventually withdrew to what is now known as the Line of Actual Control (LAC).

Nearly four decades later the area is still a flashpoint between the two nuclear powers. Confirmation of this came last Friday, when Arunachal Pradesh's chief minister, Mukut Mithi, alleged that Chinese troops had been making regular forays across the highly sensitive border.

"Maybe they have crossed the border without knowing where the LAC stands - but in any case this has to be stopped," he said.

Over the weekend Mr Mithi escorted a party of journalists up to the Sino-Indian border to prove his point. He showed them what he said was a new Chinese-built mule trail in the Dibang valley district, and claimed that "repeated incursions" were taking place. "Normally they come in the guise of graziers or hunters by encroaching on the LAC. Sometimes they claim that the land belongs to them," he said.

Whether the incursions are genuine or imaginary, they speak volumes about the continuing mutual mistrust which exists between New Delhi and Beijing. India still lays claim to 40,000 sq kms (16,000 sq miles) of territory occupied by China in Kashmir, while China lays claim to a wide swathe of territory in Arunachal Pradesh, which shares a 650-mile border with China.

Unlike the disputed border between India and Pakistan in Kashmir, where rival troops shell each other every day, the Sino-Indian frontier does not ring with gunfire. Postal workers from both countries even exchange letters for villagers who live next to the LAC. China and India recently set up a working party to clarify the issue. But the tension continues: in 1986 the Red army allegedly constructed a helipad at the frontier, only for it to be demolished by Indian troops.

On the diplomatic front, relations between Indian and China remain outwardly cordial. India's president paid a successful visit to Beijing earlier this year. China's foreign minister, Tang Jiaxuan, came to India in July.

But there exists plenty of suspicion too, most of it concerning the nuclear issue. India continues to accuse China of helping its archrival Pakistan to acquire advanced nuclear missile technology. US intelligence and military sources confirm that Pakistan's nuclear programme is more advanced than India's because of assistance from China and North Korea.

In 1998 India and Pakistan carried out tit-for-tat nuclear tests. India's defence minister, George Fernandes, defended the action on the grounds that India faced a nuclear threat from China. Last month he announced that India's latest inter-continental missile, Agni III, would be ready for testing "sooner than expected". The missile has a range of 2,500kms - enough to hit targets in central China. In turn, the Chinese have complained of Indian navy patrols in the South China sea.

Though India's relations with Pakistan dominate the attention of foreign policy analysts in the US and Europe, the country's relationship with China is in many ways more intriguing.

And more complex. The two most challenging postings for Indian diplomats abroad are widely held to be Beijing and Islamabad. "In the short term the problem is Pakistan," one diplomat said. "But in the long term it is the Chinese we need to worry about."

Confirmation of this came last Friday, when Arunachal Pradesh's chief minister, Mukut Mithi, alleged that Chinese troops had been making regular forays across the highly sensitive border. "Maybe they have crossed the border without knowing where the LAC stands - but in any case this has to be stopped," he said. Over the weekend Mr Mithi escorted a party of journalists up to the Sino-Indian border to prove his point. He showed them what he said was a new Chinese-built mule trail in the Dibang valley district, and claimed that "repeated incursions" were taking place. "Normally they come in the guise of graziers or hunters by encroaching on the LAC. Sometimes they claim that the land belongs to them," he said. Whether the incursions are genuine or imaginary, they speak volumes about the continuing mutual mistrust which exists between New Delhi and Beijing. India still lays claim to 40,000 sq kms (16,000 sq miles) of territory occupied by China in Kashmir, while China lays claim to a wide swathe of territory in Arunachal Pradesh, which shares a 650-mile border with China. Unlike the disputed border between India and Pakistan in Kashmir, where rival troops shell each other every day, the Sino-Indian frontier does not ring with gunfire. Postal workers from both countries even exchange letters for villagers who live next to the LAC. China and India recently set up a working party to clarify the issue. But the tension continues: in 1986 the Red army allegedly constructed a helipad at the frontier, only for it to be demolished by Indian troops. On the diplomatic front, relations between Indian and China remain outwardly cordial. India's president paid a successful visit to Beijing earlier this year. China's foreign minister, Tang Jiaxuan, came to India in July. But there exists plenty of suspicion too, most of it concerning the nuclear issue. India continues to accuse China of helping its archrival Pakistan to acquire advanced nuclear missile technology. US intelligence and military sources confirm that Pakistan's nuclear programme is more advanced than India's because of assistance from China and North Korea. In 1998 India and Pakistan carried out tit-for-tat nuclear tests. India's defence minister, George Fernandes, defended the action on the grounds that India faced a nuclear threat from China. Last month he announced that India's latest inter-continental missile, Agni III, would be ready for testing "sooner than expected". The missile has a range of 2,500kms - enough to hit targets in central China. In turn, the Chinese have complained of Indian navy patrols in the South China sea. Though India's relations with Pakistan dominate the attention of foreign policy analysts in the US and Europe, the country's relationship with China is in many ways more intriguing. And more complex. The two most challenging postings for Indian diplomats abroad are widely held to be Beijing and Islamabad. "In the short term the problem is Pakistan," one diplomat said. "But in the long term it is the Chinese we need to worry about." webTitle: Welcome to Yemen - but take care

fields.headline: Welcome to Yemen - but take care
fields.standfirst: Most Yemenis treat foreign visitors well, reports Brian Whitaker in Sana'a. Even the kidnappers
fields.trailText: Most Yemenis treat foreign visitors well, reports Brian Whitaker in Sana'a. Even the kidnappers.
fields.body:
You are welcome. I have lost count of the number of time I have heard those words since arriving in Yemen. The Yemenis say it all the time to foreigners.

"Please, come to our house. Come to have lunch. You like to chew qat? You are welcome ... welcome ... welcome."

But the hotel where I am staying, a wonderfully atmospheric old palace in Sana'a, is at least two-thirds empty.

Last night, four of the guests - two Belgian women, an American woman and her Italian boyfriend, all first-time visitors to Yemen - gathered round my laptop to look at a CD showing pictures of Yemen.

They gasped at the beauty of its landscapes and architecture, knowing they cannot visit many of these places. For some, they need a police permit; others are completely out of bounds, because too many foreigners have been kidnapped - 149 in the last four years.

Last Thursday, an American warship, visiting the southern port of Aden for a four-hour refuelling stop, was attacked by suicide bombers. The blast killed 17 people, injured 35 and blew a 20ft x 40ft hole in the side of the ship.

Next morning, the British embassy in Sana'a was bombed. "I'm not nervous," says the American woman. But she is. She has decided that whenever she goes out of the hotel she will pretend to be Italian, but wonders what will happen if she has to show her passport at an army checkpoint. Would the soldiers tip off the kidnappers? Most unlikely, I say.

Her boyfriend is studying a map, supplied by the Italian embassy, with circles drawn on it. These are the places where foreigners have been kidnapped. Today, they have plucked up the courage to travel to Kawkaban, a pleasant village just a few miles outside Sana'a. They have hired a Yemeni driver who insists it's perfectly safe.

"But he would say that, wouldn't he?" the American woman says. "He needs to earn a living."

I do my best to reassure them, saying I have been to Yemen six times without any problems. But I would be lying if I said there is no risk at all.

"Look," I tell her, "We have the IRA in London. Would you worry about that? You just need to take care." The American woman grimaces.

Yemenis in general have nothing against foreign tourists. Even the kidnappers normally treat their hostages well, sometimes showering them with gifts when they are released - usually within one or two weeks - to show there are no hard feelings.

Most of the kidnappers are tribesmen trying to impress their grievances upon the Yemeni government.

Two years ago, in one kidnapping, carried out by the Islamic Army of Aden-Abyan (not the usual tribal kidnappers) four hostages died when Yemeni security forces tried to free them. Last June, a Norwegian hostage died in a shootout when his abductors' car was stopped at a checkpoint. But these incidents, though tragic, were exceptions.

In the last couple of weeks, Yemen - in common with other Arab countries - has witnessed demonstrations in support of the Palestinians. Flags have been burned outside the American and British embassies. The two recent bombings were also clearly directed against governments.

Foreign visitors do not represent foreign governments, and most Yemenis recognise that. The fanatics who threaten to attack western "infidels" in Yemen - as the Islamic Army did a couple of years ago - are a tiny handful, though the problems they have caused for Yemen are enormous.

Welcome. But take care.

fields.headline: Flightless birds no longer
fields.standfirst: A junk email sent to young Kiwis who have chosen to take up better-paying jobs overseas has ignited a fierce debate about the country's 'lost generation', and the very future of New Zealand. Patrick Barkham looks at New Zealand's brain drain
fields.trailText: A junk email sent to young Kiwis who have chosen to take up better-paying jobs overseas has ignited a fierce debate about the country's 'lost generation', writes Patrick Barkham.
fields.body:
Junk email is not usually considered to be the sharpest political weapon. But in New Zealand, a piece of email spam has precipitated a fierce debate about the country's future that is troubling its Labour government.

A 27-year-old Kiwi, Richard Poole, sent an email to some of the 600,000 New Zealanders who work abroad, urging them to donate NZ$30 (about £8.50) for a newspaper advertisement calling for the country's leaders act on the issue of the 'lost generation' - young New Zealanders fleeing the country for better paid jobs in Australia, the US and the UK.

More than 600 signatures were collected and placed in an advert in the New Zealand Herald. The ad blamed the Labour government's tax regime, union-boosting labour laws and "flaky" assistance for new businesses for the Kiwi brain drain. Hot on its heels came another full-page advert from an exiled tax accountant calling on the prime minister to make New Zealand's economy more enticing to foreign business.

Claiming to be the non-political fears of twenty-somethings, the Poole email was exposed by the government as being backed by money from the Business Roundtable, a pro-business pressure group. Roundtable chief executive Roger Kerr has admitted his organisation paid NZ$10,000 (about £2,800) for the ad up-front, while Poole collected his donations from the 600 signatories. Prime minister Helen Clark, believing it to be a business-led conspiracy against her government, has called for Kerr to be sacked.

But the brain drain debate has been ignited. Reports of staff-starved institutions such as the NHS luring foreign professionals to the UK added fuel to the fire. With its weak currency and small economy, most New Zealanders can expect to earn 30% more in Australia, while anyone with decent IT skills is guaranteed a lucrative job almost anywhere.

In the year to August, New Zealand had a net loss of 10,030 permanent migrants, 10% less than the previous year, but still significant to a country with a population of less than 4m people. The country is concerned that overseas experience - for years a rite of passage for many young New Zealanders - is becoming a more permanent venture than a mere six month globe-trotting trip. An increasing number spend most of their 20s away and, when they return to the southern hemisphere, choose to settle in Australia rather than New Zealand.

Statistically, the New Zealand economy may not be damaged by the departures just yet, but with the anti-Labour business community and the opposition National Party seeking to extract political capital from the debate, it could segue into a critique of the Clark government's economic record.

Poole's email and the controversy it has triggered is a facet of globalisation. Depopulation in the west is associated with the mass departures from Ireland in the 19th and 20th centuries, driven by famine and impoverishment. For developed countries, it is a relatively new phenomenon, brought about by the mobility of economic capital and the ability to fly around the world in 27 hours.

Other modern economies are also falling victim to it, regardless of their government's political hue. More than 62,000 Canadians headed south last year, driven partly by the 95% of computer graduates who were gobbled up by American companies, resulting in a five-year high in emigration to the US. Canada's ruling centrist Liberal party has faced calls from economists to bring its income tax rates in line with the US.

However, the Kiwi brain drain is also a cultural process. Reinforced by a dismal performance in the Olympics and the constant anti-Kiwi sniping by Australia, its larger, in-love-with-itself neighbour, New Zealand is facing a crisis of self-image. And as its citizens start to see it as a backwater, they are more likely to drift off elsewhere.

Some young Kiwis argue the brain drain is not just about money and have spoken out against the business-led calls to do something about the disaffected twenty-somethings. Adventure lured her away and New Zealand's quality of life will draw her back, says Elinore Wellwood, a New Zealander currently working in London.

"Kiwis would love to come home, but life is more exciting, with wonderful jobs that whisk you to Nice, Berlin, and small villages in Poland," she told the New Zealand press.

But the cheap, airy, outdoor lifestyle offered by the spacious and spectacular landscape of New Zealand will lure many home when they want to start families. Or simply, as Wellwood puts it, "when the yearning to escape the pollution, the crowds, the dark, the hour-long trips to work, the dirty public transport, and the grumpy shop assistants becomes too much."

webTitle: Comment: Madeleine Bunting on environmental apathy

fields.headline: Let it rain
fields.standfirst:
Apathetic about climate change and out of touch with the environment, Britain needs a short sharp shock

Special report: the weather
fields.trailText: Apathetic about climate change and out of touch with the environment, Britain needs a short sharp shock.
fields.body:
With apologies to the residents of Uckfield, Lamberhurst, Lewes and a host of other villages and towns across southern England who are surveying the mud-silted wreckage of their homes and businesses this morning, the floods couldn't have come at a better time. Indeed, a conspiracy theorist might concoct a notion that a bunch of eco-terrorists had sabotaged sluice gates to ensure the scenes we've had of flooded fields and high streets turned to churning rivers à la Mozambique. The timing is excellent. We are only a month away from the Hague convention on climate change when the promises of Kyoto are supposed to be nailed down, and there is a real danger that the convention will go belly-up, in large part owing to US truculence.

Climate change induces a strange apathy. Everyone knows about it, few people do anything about it. If an environmentalist group launches a campaign to save a cuddly animal, it will get plenty of support, but only the really dedicated will write letters to their MP demanding a 20% cut in carbon emissions. An air of unreality has settled over the whole subject. Kyoto asked for cuts of 5% below 1990 levels, which the scientists assert is hopelessly inadequate. They say we need cuts of 60-80%.

Yet even Kyoto may prove impossible. A decade after it was universally accepted that climate change was caused by carbon emissions, they are still rising. Not even scare stories seem to have had much effect. To cap it all, the fuel tax protest a month ago seemed the coup de grace, pre-empting the whole debate in the Hague. It could have been a textbook PR exercise on the part of the oil companies to demonstrate the power and stubbornness of the electorate: don't mess with our petrol.

Just when it seemed that all was lost, rivers we had nearly forgotten about with richly redolent names such as the Beult, Uck, Ouse and Tiesse spring their wondrous revenge on our indifference. The rivers we had thought we had safely corralled proved our hubris. Seventeen severe flood warnings, 47 flood warnings, 97 flood watches: virtually the entire country was threatened by the worst floods in 40 years. The sense of outrage and anger from those affected suggested that we had forgotten that rivers flood. They always have done from time to time; what has changed is that they are now flooding frequently. We have to learn again the folk knowledge that was lost for a couple of generations about how rivers behave: where they flood, how they can suddenly rise and the destructive force of a river in spate. It was not for nothing that our ancestors worshipped water spirits; they knew their power, for creation and destruction.

We lost this knowledge because we believed that such chances of nature could be ironed out by a combination of technology and government raising and applying the necessary revenue. Sue Tapsell, a fellow at Middlesex's Flood Hazard Research Centre, has done research on the impact of floods in County Durham and the Thames Valley; the common theme is the impulse to blame - it is someone's fault. What quickly follows is the angry comment of a man quoted last week who has been flooded three times this year: "Something has got to be done." He is absolutely right. It has, but - here's the catch - it won't stop the floods. Even if we magically managed to cut our carbon emissions tomorrow, we will be reaping the results of the carbon we have already put into the atmosphere for generations to come. The consequences of all this for the faith and trust we have in government are legion - the environment does not pay dividends within an election cycle.

The million-dollar question is how you close the gap between the angry "something must be done" and the dramatic shift in lifestyle and political priorities (investment in renewable energy before the NHS) that is necessary. Platform, a London-based group of activists and artists, advocates a process of reconnecting individuals and communities with their environment, which in cities is often buried under their feet. They have been running a campaign on London's rivers - Still Waters - many of which are no more than bricked over drains. On the river Wandle, a micro-hydroturbine powers some of the local primary school lights, and a bell is triggered on high tide.

The task is herculean. Tapsell has done research with London schoolchildren on their attitudes to the countryside. Some had never been there; some didn't know what a river was; some said they'd prefer it if it was tidier and there were benches; some said the countryside scared them, they might be snatched by strangers or catch a disease. Country Life's survey of children's attitudes to the countryside last week revealed similar themes.

One poignant comment indicated how regimented and confined is children's interaction with nature: "You cannot sit on grass in case there are dog faeces." When Tapsell took a party of children to a river, they revelled in being allowed to get wet and muddy. Once it was in that intimate, intensely sensual experience of nature (on wasteland or in the countryside proper), that most children experienced their first taste of freedom. The exhilaration of building a den or climbing a tree is about escaping adult control. Our interaction with materials used to start with the mud and the puddles. Now it's in the hygienic playschool's water play. Somewhere along the line, we've lost the link between nature and freedom and drilled a fear of open spaces into children. They're relegated to the confines of the playground under a watchful eye, while the countryside is as real as video tape as it flashes past the car window.

The twin principles which govern children's attitudes (and probably many of their parents) to the countryside are fear and sentimentalisation. Human life has never lasted so long, and never have so few lives been lost to accidents and serious illness in Britain, and yet we are more preoccupied than ever about preserving life and reducing risk. Partly in response to that sense of danger, we have constructed a children's entertainment industry predicated on airbrushing out the unpredictable brutality of nature: Bambi and Percy the Park-keeper. What help is the Jungle Book to the generation who will have to cope with more of the consequences of environmental degradation than ever before?

The alternative, as environmental scientist James Lovelock has argued, is that we need a few really nasty shocks. If London, Hamburg or Washington DC were flooded, with a serious loss of life, we might finally start making connections between climate change and our unsustainable lifestyle. The problem about this argument is that by the time London floods, most of Bangladesh and the Nile delta will be long underwater. Rather, the best chance Britain has is a course of environmental ECT: lots of small, nasty shocks where it really hurts. So roll on the Uck, Beult and Tiesse, they've got a lot to teach us. The more floods, the merrier.

Rather, the best chance Britain has is a course of environmental ECT: lots of small, nasty shocks where it really hurts. So roll on the Uck, Beult and Tiesse, they've got a lot to teach us. The more floods, the merrier. madeleine.bunting@theguardian.com

webTitle: Arts: The Centre for Visual Art in Cardiff

fields.headline: The regeneration game
fields.standfirst: The Centre for Visual Art should have launched Cardiff into a new, culturally exciting era. But after just a year, it has flopped.  Jonathan Jones  on what went wrong
fields.trailText: The Centre for Visual Art should have launched Cardiff into a new, culturally exciting era. But after just a year, it has flopped. Jonathan Jones on what went wrong
fields.body:
The city of Cardiff is effortlessly dominated by the new rugby stadium, the one they decided to build instead of an opera house by Zaha Hadid. Built like a cross between a ship, a space station and a branch of Sainsbury's, it is a permanent reminder that in this city sport and populism count for more than culture.

With hindsight, the Centre for Visual Art was never going to make it here. The only major contemporary art space in Wales opened to a great fanfare in the Hayes shopping centre last summer. It was a converted Victorian library, but unlike the original institution it charged admission, and had a touchy-feely introduction to contemporary art for children on the top floor. It wanted to be the Millennium Dome and Tate Modern simultaneously, but had no chance of being either because its funding bodies - the Arts Council of Wales and the city council provided the bulk of the £9m cost - expected the centre to make up a serious financial shortfall from admissions in its first year. The financial crisis at the end of 12 months was not merely predictable. It is almost as if it were planned in advance. The CVA is to close in its present form on November 5.

Cardiff's political establishment went about the business of establishing the Centre so half-heartedly that it's hard to believe they wanted a modern art gallery at all. Instead of nurturing an audience for new art, the CVA acted as a proof to cultural conservatives that Welsh people don't want this modern art rubbish, see.

Instead, Cardiff has a world-class rugby stadium. It also has the £2bn Cardiff Bay Development - eventually to include an new cultural hub, the much-delayed Wales Millennium Centre - where the despised docklands have been turned into a genteel setting for businesses and fish restaurants. The aesthetics of the new Cardiff Bay, as with other waterfront reclamations from Sunderland to Liverpool to New York's Pier 17, are cosily retrograde. This kind of reclamation can create a pleasant setting for eating an ice cream. It cannot make a city feel like a city.

Cities are cultural entities. The texture of social and economic life in them is defined by their cultural energy or lack of it, and cities all over the world - Glasgow, Barcelona, Seattle - have demonstrated that by changing the way their cultural life is perceived you can change everything about them. The problem is that culture is not something that can be neatly delivered from above. It cannot - as the Welsh critic Raymond Williams argued, because it is complex and living. When city authorities - and in the case of Cardiff, national governments - try to regenerate a city by mixing up architectural, artistic and leisure projects, the results can be catastrophic. Sheffield ends up with a National Centre for Popular Music (aka the Unpopular Centre for National Music) whose shiny Nigel Coates design cannot conceal the poverty of its displays; Newcastle gets a vast, pointless life-science centre; Greenwich gets the Dome.

What these follies have in common is a patronising conception of popular culture. The question, as city after city tries to turn itself into a hip, swinging cultural metropolis, is what kind of culture do you want and why? To a city like Cardiff, the answer appears to be popular, mainstream culture. So opera was out, and contemporary art is out. Rugby is in. But what Cardiff's Taffia has done is to impose a boring cultural stereotype on the city, and on Wales, and then to build monuments to this stereotype. As a strategy for urban cultural regeneration, this is a disaster. Cardiff feels small - it is, with a population of 320,000 - and parochial. It has the commercial and leisure venues you see all over Britain. But this does not add up to any sense of metropolitan energy.

Architecture in Wales means, for many people, medieval castles perched on rocky crags over slate-built towns. The castles built by the English in the 14th century are architectural masterpieces - dense, raw structures that still speak of power. The problem for Wales is that there is no metropolitan tradition to compare with these rustic ruins. The urbanisation of south Wales only happened in the 19th century and a country that had always had a tiny population scattered across small towns and hamlets never really got used to the idea of the big city. Swansea, with its mid-20th-century cultural scene, was perhaps the closest to a Glasgow or Dublin - but Dylan Thomas spent his final days in faraway New York.

The Welsh have built towns that seem makeshift and frightened compared to the looming mountains. The interior world of the home has been valued more than public space; the national imagination is rooted in the village. For all these reasons, Cardiff's culture has shied away from the metropolitan and expressed itself until recently in a flight to the suburbs. That's why "cultural regeneration" has become necessary, with the Cardiff Bay scheme - including the construction of a £200m barrage to control tidal levels and the opening up of waterfront spaces for development - and the Millennium Stadium attempting to lure money into the city centre.

In too many cities in Britain the bright, shiny dream of "cultural regeneration" has been pursued without the courage to believe in culture at all. What is most wrong is the assumption that a cultural project in a city has to fit in with what is already there. Sheffield thought it was a pop city (The Human League! Jarvis!); Cardiff thinks it is Rugby Central. But where cities have exploded into cultural life it has been a surprise. Glasgow's 1980s literary scene and cur rent art scene had nothing in common with the way the city had always been imagined.

Good art is serious and difficult. It does not confirm what you already know. This is why so many of the new cultural spaces and projects in cities across Britain just turn into samey exercises of less interest than the opening of a new multiplex. At least multiplexes, music and book megastores give people access to contemporary culture. The lessons of success and failure in the cultural renewal of Britain's cities can be stated simply. Tate Modern or Millennium Dome?

Across the country, enterprises that respect their public succeed. Glasgow succeeds, public art commissions such as Alison Wilding's Ambit in Sunderland succeed, Norman Foster's glasshouse in the Welsh countryside succeeds. Intelligent avant-garde culture excites people. In a city it creates drama and possibility - the essence of the metropolitan. By contrast, local authorities who have assumed that everyone is an idiot have ended up with embarrassing follies.

If Cardiff wants to be a cultural mecca why not create something really wild? A John Cale Gallery of the 1960s Fluxus avant-garde, a Frank Lloyd Wright museum designed by Frank Gehry, a Gorky's Zygotic Mynci centre for bilingual culture - with a cafe called Bwyd Time. But then what's the point if the city can't even keep a modern art centre open for more than 12 months.

 The British Art Show 5 is at the Centre for Visual Art, Cardiff (029-2038 8922), till November 5.

webTitle: The best bicycle scene: Dancer In The Dark

fields.headline: The best bicycle scene: Dancer In The Dark
fields.trailText: Kathy (Catherine Deneuve), Bill (David Morse) and his wife Linda (Cara Seymour) are visiting the trailer belonging to factory worker Selma (Björk).
fields.body:
Kathy (Catherine Deneuve), Bill (David Morse) and his wife Linda (Cara Seymour) are visiting the trailer belonging to factory worker Selma (Björk).

"Selma, it's about the bike..." says Bill.

Selma shakes her head violently.

"No bike! When I was a child, I walked. Gene can walk."

"But he says he could make it to school in time on his own if he had a bike."

Selma's voice cracks in anger.

"So that's what he says?"

She catches Gene hovering by the door.

"You asked them to come here?"

"No_"

"Well, you can all save your trouble. I will not buy Gene a bike."

"I'm almost the only kid in my class who doesn't have a bike!" Gene protests.

"You know very well I don't have any money. Every time I make 10 bucks I send them to the folks back home. The money does more good there."

Kathy tries to intervene.

"But Selma..."

"No, he's got to get it into his head - and all of you for that matter - I will not spend the money on expensive presents for him. And not even when it's his birthday. That's the kind of mom he has for himself. I'm sure he'd rather have another."

Kathy turns to Gene.

"Your mother is only teasing. Look what she has bought for you."

Kathy points to the window. Selma's co-worker Jeff (Peter Stormare) appears outside, pushing a brand new bike.

See also: ET, Pee Wee's Big Adventure

Don't see also: City of Angels

Pointless trivia: Dancer In The Dark is the most expensive film ever to be shot in Sweden.

webTitle: Women: Dea Birkett on cross-dressing heroes

fields.headline: Act like a woman
fields.standfirst: As the 50s comedy classic Some Like It Hot hits our cinema screens again,  Dea Birkett reveals the lesson she learnt from its cross-dressing heroes
fields.trailText: As the 50s comedy classic Some Like It Hot hits our cinema screens again,  Dea Birkett reveals the lesson she learnt from its cross-dressing heroes.
fields.body:
The improbable story - part fantasy, part fairy tale - goes something like this. As a teenager, I saw a film that entranced me. The plot was simple: it's Prohibition time and two unemployed jazz musicians (Tony Curtis and Jack Lemmon) are chance witnesses of the Chicago Saint Valentine's Day massacre. Pursued by the mob, they make a rapid escape by disguising themselves as women and joining Sweet Sue and her Syncopaters all-girl band. Almost 20 years later, I abandoned my home and young daughter, hitched up my caravan and ran away to join an Italian circus.

It may be crude to claim I became a circus showgirl because of Some Like It Hot, even though by the time I reached Italy I had seen it more than 20 times. At a gala premiere last week of the new print made for cinema release, film critic Barry Norman declared Marilyn Monroe the undisputed star of the film; without this frothy vision of loveliness, it would be just another 1950s romantic comedy.

But even watching it today, I barely notice Monroe. It's Curtis and Lemmon - Josephine and Daphne - who hold me. They taught me what it meant to be a woman. They still do.

I was 18 when I first saw the film. Then an androgynous student, my uniform was dungarees and a short dark crop, rather like Lemmon's. Some Like It Hot seemed to put forward a thesis that reinforced the lessons of my Edinburgh University Women's Group. Women don't exist, they are created. Anyone can become one.

It was many years before I put that lesson into practice. I tried Biba blue eyeshadow, a blonde bob and skimpy Lycra dresses at mid-80s discos. Later I attempted, but never got a grip on, foundation cream and underwired bras. But the circus offered a chance truly to transform. In the ring, the extremities of womanhood could be acted out as in no other place.

I chose an Italian circus because I knew that, so far from home, I could not be unmasked. If I had joined Billy Smart's, touring Britain, someone who knew me might turn up in the audience and my deception would be discovered. "She's not a showgirl," they'd shout. "She's just Dea Birkett in a sequined G-string. She's a fake," not realising fakery was my purpose.

In the 1959 film, we never see how Curtis and Lemmon become women. One minute they're in jacket and trousers, the next in lipstick and stockings. The only time male and female mix is when Lemmon is dressed as Daphne, all made-up but without his wig. It's a disconcerting moment. He's neither male nor female; it's as if he's deciding which he will become. There's a knock on the door. He pulls on his wig. We are relieved. We're in safe - all-female - territory again, sure of where and what we are.

Yet it is the transformation, rather than the finished product, that is the most crucial element. It is also the most secret. Women rarely put on make-up in front of men. It's important to perpetuate the deceit that our femininity isn't a construction at all - we were born that way.

In the circus showgirl's dressing room - an old railway carriage - no men were allowed. One wall was lined with lockers containing everything we needed to become a woman: scant sequined costumes, impossibly long wigs, piles of putty-coloured tights. The other was nothing but mirrors. We could watch ourselves being transformed.

First we had to strip, shed any remnant of who we were. "Ignore your face," said the Bulgarian elephant girl, watching me trace liner around my thin lips. "This has nothing to do with what you're like. You can be anything. Just paint on the face you want."

She guided me through the steps to becoming a showgirl. My pale skin became a yellowed tan. My poppy eyes were made almond-shaped by cats' whiskers drawn from the corners. My thin eyebrows were thickened; false eyelashes were applied. My lips were full and pouting, my short hair hidden under a tight skullcap, topped with ostrich feathers exploding from a diamanté crown.

And yet, despite the immense effort, it was a fragile disguise. A tender finger traced across my cheek and my artifice would fall apart.

Next, attention had to be paid to my body. My legs were squeezed into three pairs of tights, each more supportive than the last, until they curved where they had bulged and were smooth where they had been dimpled. These were topped with fishnets. Becoming a woman wasn't easy. It took a full two hours to get ready for just five minutes in the ring.

Everything about me was indelibly dated: the tan of my foundation, the spidery false eyelashes, the dark beige fishnets. I could have been in a 1950s film. I could have been in Some Like It Hot. But even contemporary female impersonators - Edna Everidge, Lily Savage, Mrs Merton - portray women rarely, if ever, still seen on the street.

It wasn't only how I looked that had to be altered - how I moved had to be learned. Lemmon, as Daphne failing to conquer high heels, describes women's movements as: "Jello on springs ... Is there some sort of motor or something?" adding wryly: "I tell you, it's a whole different sex."

I had to learn to keep my mouth open as I smiled and waved, to show the white of my teeth. My chest and bottom had to be thrust out, making my arched body an S. Gallina, the Russian Hula Hoop artiste, used to practise smiling and waving in the dressing room mirror before she went on, greeting her own reflection as if seeing it for the first time.

Some friends were appalled that I had abandoned my androgynous attire to become a showgirl, conniving in such sexist posturing. But we all, in little ways, contrive at being female. We try out being femme, put on a dress when we rarely wear one, perm and dye our hair, and stand in front of a full-length mirror, wondering at ourselves. We've been doing it since we were small girls. Because that is what being a woman is all about, making yourself up as one.

I was playing at being a woman. Becoming a showgirl just threw that make-believe into sharp relief because it was so blatant. I was exposing the construction of femininity, not conforming to it. I was as subversive as Jack Lemmon playing Daphne.

And still now, watching Some Like It Hot in my combats, with a can of Carlsberg, legs akimbo on the sofa, I long to return to the circus. Impersonating a woman was so much fun.

 Some Like It Hot goes on release on Friday.

webTitle: 'Horse race' for Express after new £100m bid

fields.headline: 'Horse race' for Express after new £100m bid
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The Labour peer Lord Hollick is expected today to receive a bid of at least £100m for the Express newspaper titles from the Hinduja Group.
fields.body:
The Labour peer Lord Hollick is expected today to receive a bid of at least £100m for the Express newspaper titles from the Hinduja Group.

The imminent bid by the group, run by brothers Srichand and Gopichand Hinduja, will turn the tussle for control of the Labour-sympathising Daily Express, Sunday Express and Daily Star stable into at least a three-horse race.

United News & Media, which owns the newspapers, rejected an approach last week by two other rich brothers, the twins David and Frederick Barclay, as too low at £75m.

It is understood that informal talks have also been held between Lord Hollick and David Montgomery, former chief executive of the Mirror Group.

Rumours about other potential bidders, including Mohamed Al Fayed, the owner of Harrods, were also circulating last night.

Confirmation of the imminent bid by the Hinduja Group, which has a wide range of businesses from banking to oil and media, prompted one source to comment last night: "There does appear to be a horse race emerging."

Lord Hollick is understood to want more than £150m for the Express group. Its main title sells approximately 1m copies a day, a little more than the Sunday title.

Speculation about the future of the Express group intensified after its parent, United News & Media, was forced to back down from its television ambitions after regulatory intervention. As a result, the group sold its TV franchises to Granada, and while Lord Hollick has denied that the Express is up for sale, major shareholders in United believe the titles are on the market.

Lord Hollick is said to have told the Barclay brothers that he wanted double the £75m offered, but it is understood that he intends to hold out for an even higher price for the papers, which he has turned from Tory supporters to enthusiasts for New Labour.

The latest bid for the Express comes from two brothers who rank eighth in the Sunday Times rich list, and who also have close connections to the government.

The Hinduja brothers, who are based in London, said that their bid would aim to counter any claims of political bias by setting up a board of trustees that would guarantee the editorial independence of the newspapers. They are British citizens and have two other brothers, one Swiss and one Indian.

It is understood that informal talks have also been held between Lord Hollick and David Montgomery, former chief executive of the Mirror Group. Rumours about other potential bidders, including Mohamed Al Fayed, the owner of Harrods, were also circulating last night. fields.headline: My media: Naomi Klein
fields.body:
Favourite new album: Kid A - and not just because Radiohead has banished corporate sponsorship from their tour, although I think its incredibly cool for a band to reclaim some unbranded cultural space for their fans.

Favourite new band: Dead Prez, from Brooklyn.

Favourite television programme: The Daily Show - you don't get this brilliant news satire in the UK, tragically.

Favourite documentary (besides the one on Channel 4 tomorrow night): This Is What Democracy Looks Like, produced by the Independent Media Centre. It will be coming to Britain soon. This is the first work to capture the energy of the camcorder activists. It is the story of the anti-World Trade Organisation protests in Seattle cut together with footage from 100 video cameras.

Least favourite magazine:

The Economist. They are on a mission to misrepresent the anti-corporate protesters as greedy rich kids who want to take food out, the mouths of the world's hungry. Why is it so very difficult to imagine that political alliances can cross borders as easily as Nike trainers and foreign currency?

Scariest new website:

www.chrisandluke.com. This is a site built by two brothers who want to be "the first sponsored college students." They are looking for corporations to give them money in exchange for advertising on their bodies - sort of like racing car drivers and rock stars.

Favourite website:

www.openletters.net: "A daily magazine of first person writing in the form of personal correspondence." One letter is posted per day on topics ranging from being the most popular girl at school, to what it's like to interview for a job at Microsoft. All that unites the letters is the intimacy of the writing.

Best new media device:

I don't do product endorsements - at least not for free.

 Naomi Klein is the author of No Logo. Her 24-minute film on brands and the anti-capitalist movement will be shown on Channel 4 News tomorrow night.
