fields.headline: Media Monkey's Diary
fields.body:
 AA Gill is the latest celebrity journalist to flog his skills to the credibility-hungry world of new media. Having read all about Gill's new travel website in Press Gazette, where he is quoted authoritatively musing on the need for travel websites ("travel on the web needs a map... People want first-hand knowledge on destinations from people they can trust"), monkey was hugely impressed at this example of an old media dinosaur embracing the new. So we rang Mr Gill to invite him to participate in the "My New Media" column (see p59). Imagine Monkey's amazement when he declined, saying he knew nothing about the internet and never uses it...

 Monkey was taken by surprise on Friday by the sudden resignation of Matthew Bannister, the BBC's director of marketing. Particularly because Monkey had only just finished digesting the full details of his marvellous reorganisation of the corporation's legendary press and publicity department, as revealed in an internal email. But surely the three day gap between the dispatch of his memo, the reaction of the staff and the announcement of his departure is merely a coincidence?

 Early indications that Matthew Bannister was on his way came on Thursday when he pulled out of a recording of C4's Right to Reply, where he was due to face the wrath of viewers (and ITV news chief Steve Anderson) over the news move. The BBC offered director of television Mark Thompson instead - but only if ITV put up David Liddiment. Right to Reply refused to play the game, so the BBC dropped chief scheduler Adam Macdonald into the bearpit instead. Poor Macdonald was forced to defend a decision over which he had no influence, but full marks for loyalty, Adam.

 The soon-to-be-launched glossy for divorced women, New Era, has run into trouble even before it hits the news-stands. The publishers have been forced to change its name - it is now Vive - after they discovered a namesake. In fact - and this is true - New Era is the teen magazine of the Church of the Latter-day Saints, better known as the British arm of the Mormons. Oops.

 BBC chiefs are having still more trouble deciding whether Jeremy Bowen looks better dodging the bullets in Jerusalem or dodging Moira Stuart's hairdo on BBC Breakfast. For the second time in a week, the 'tached one is back on location in the Middle East. His Breakfast co-host Sophie Raworth is said to be missing her new TV partner already - these wrenches so early on in their relationship can't be good for the chemistry.

 A decision is expected soon on whether BBC News staff should move back from the wilds of White City to Broadcasting House. The issue has dragged on for months, not helped by Greg Dyke's restructuring process. One wag suggested Dyke apply the same principles to his property strategy as to his scheduling decisions: "We could be back in Broadcasting House in a fortnight."

 Although the Radio Times, TV Times and every listings magazine are huffing and puffing at the strain of junking covers and changing spreads as the schedules are juggled for the BBC news move to 10pm tonight, there is a note of cheer in the air. "No one knows when anything is on, so they are going to need us even more" says TV Quick editor, Lori Miles. It's an ill wind...

 Extraordinary scenes at BBC Television Centre last Thursday, as news of ex-BBC1 controller Peter Salmon's affair with Sarah Lancashire was splashed across the front pages. Monkey witnessed the paper frenzy as tabloids were passed from hand to hand while groups huddled together to read the news. One senior BBC executive was overheard saying: "He kept telling me how the job had stressed him, how he needed to spend more time with his family. I feel really stupid. Do you think I missed a cry for help?"

 Travelling to TV Centre is all very well, but sometimes all monkey has to do is sit in the office and wait for the foibles of the media industry to come to us. Monkey was deeply flattered last week to receive a phone call from the agent of one Michael Buerk - the newsreader who featured in Media Guardian's front page caricature. Anxious to purchase the artwork for her client, the agent asked Monkey to get out the pencil crayons and produce the original - drawn lovingly by the world renowned Stephen Lee. But when Monkey quoted the (really very reasonable) cost of such an exercise, the agent backed off. "Oh, well, in that case, could we just have a copy instead?" As times are clearly hard for Mr Buerk, we therefore reprint the cover here. A laser photocopier and a magnifier should do the trick for free.

Catch up with the Monkey every day at: www.mediatheguardian.com email the Monkey at: monkey@mediatheguardian.com

webTitle: James Meek reports on the mission to Mars

fields.headline: Mission to Mars
fields.standfirst: In 2003, two probes will attempt to land on the fourth planet from the sun. One will be a $400m Nasa creation. The other, built for a fraction of the cost, will be British. And it is the UK team that claims it has the best chance of settling the age-old question: is there life on Mars?  James Meek reports
fields.trailText: In 2003, two probes will attempt to land on the fourth planet from the sun. One will be a $400m Nasa creation. The other, built for a fraction of the cost, will be British. And it is the UK team that claims it has the best chance of settling the age-old question: is there life on Mars?
fields.body:
There are more exclusive destinations than Le Saint Geran in Mauritius or Little Dix Bay in the British Virgin Islands. No star name and billion-dollar bank account will get you a ticket to Maja Vallis or Tritonis Lacus for the spring of 2003. There is, however, one man who is going. A man convinced that, when the early sun begins to warm the rusty flood channels of Chryse and the dusty expanse of the Elysium plains, he and his team will be exploring them. His name is Colin Pillinger, and he works in Milton Keynes.

This spring is not on Earth, and much as he would love to be, Pillinger is not going to be there in person. What he is attempting to do is almost as extraordinary: pull together a diffuse group of scientists and engineers, on a wee budget and a tight timescale, to build the first British spacecraft to land on another planet. That, and answer a question which has bothered us for a few hundred years: is there life on Mars?

Pillinger, professor of planetary sciences at the Open University, believes the Mars lander he is building, Beagle 2, will be able to sniff out the evidence of life, if there is any to be found. But Beagle, on board the European Space Agency mission Mars Express, will not be alone. The vessel of a richer, older space power, Nasa, will be cruising through space hard on the heels of Mars Express, with its own, more expensive and elaborate set of landers - the Athena project - on board. A race has begun.

The public face of space science tends to be all smiles and friendship between nations. But Pillinger has been making some distinctly undiplomatic remarks in public about the virtues of his budget Beagle against the $400m (£272m) Athena, which will consist of two labs mounted on wheels, able to roam across the Martian surface. (Accounts of the cost of Beagle range from a 10th of this to a third, if you include the whole Mars Express mission.)

Pillinger's most scathing remarks came at the British Association science festival last month, when he said: "Athena has what I believe to be an inferior package of scientific instruments to search for life." It was a bold attack, and a hostage to fortune. "It was an entirely valid criticism delivered in the way I delivered it, when I was supposed to be saying what was good about British science," he says now. "I wouldn't want to labour the point." But he won't withdraw it, either. He is disappointed by his rival's tactics, which he says will only yield measurements indirectly showing the existence of water, a prerequisite for life. Beagle will directly sample the air, rocks and soil for carbon compounds which are the products and components of life.

"It's very difficult to see how [Athena] is going to further our study of Mars," Pillinger says. "They're going to show they have the technical ability to move around the planet but it isn't going to look for life."

Pillinger's opposite number on the other side of the Atlantic, Steven Squyres of Cornell University, is too courteous to admit to anything so crude as rivalry. But it would lead to some heavy angst at Nasa, with 35 years of missions to Mars to its credit, if a small country with a minimal track record in space managed to land a probe on the planet first time, and then announced to the world it had solved the mystery of whether it hosted life.

Nasa's history of successful Mars missions has been interspersed with so many disasters that as far back as 1969 a Nasa scientist wondered if there wasn't a "galactic ghoul" standing sentinel over our neighbour in space. Last year was so calamitous the agency had to rethink its whole programme: a Mars climate surveyor was lost because the engineers who built it mixed up metric and imperial measurements, and two months later a polar lander vanished without trace after starting its descent to the surface.

Which is why, of course, Squyres - who was involved in both missions - thinks Nasa should be taking it slow, careful and long. And why, perhaps, Pillinger might have bitten off a teeny bit more than he can chew.

"The nice thing about our programme is it really is a programme. It's not just one mission," Squyres says pointedly. "We did Mars Pathfinder (a successful mission) for a very low cost. Then we went back and did two missions for less than the cost of Pathfinder, and they both failed. The lesson we drew from that is that if you push too hard in terms of faster, better, cheaper, you have failed missions."

Squyres' point is that Nasa's rovers are scouts for other US missions to come, which will be more focused on the search for life. "We're not carrying biological instrumentation," he admits. "Our mission has a different focus."

Can Pillinger pull it off? "The Europeans aren't overreaching themselves by identifying something which is a key objective and going for it," says André Balogh, professor of space physics at Imperial College in London. "The Europeans can make a difference if - and it is a big if - Mars Express works. It remains a relatively high-risk project."

Squyres and Pillinger have never met. The American is younger - 44 to Pillinger's 57. Squyres grew up in a science family in Winona, New Jersey; his father had a chemistry doctorate from MIT. Pillinger, from Kingswood on the outskirts of Bristol, declines to talk about his childhood. But there is a symmetry. Both men went into science - Squyres into geology, Pillinger chemistry - with no clear idea of where they were going, only to be touched by the lure of space early on.

With Squyres, it was being taught as a student in the 1970s by a scientist who had worked on the Viking Mars landers. "As I got deeper into geology, I concluded there wasn't that much more real exploring to be done on Earth," he says. "I was captivated by the idea of being able to explore other worlds."

Just out of his postgraduate training, Pillinger was taken on by Bristol University in 1969 to analyse fragments of lunar rock from the Apollo missions. It was the start of a career which saw him become one of the world's leading experts on moon rocks and Martian meteorites, chips of Mars which were sent flying into space after an asteroid collided with that planet and which ended up bumping into Earth.

"It was good to go out at night and look at the moon and be able to say: 'I work on that,' " he says.

While Squyres was taken up rapidly into Nasa's sprawling space science establishment, Pillinger remained confined to earthly labs for decades. When in 1997 ESA began canvassing missions for Mars Express, he seized his chance.

Brushing aside the doubts of the European space bureaucracy about whether money could be found for a lander, he convinced them he would raise the funds himself. So Beagle 2 was born, funded by British universities and businesses, a sceptical government and a band of as yet unrevealed sponsors being corralled by Saatchi and Saatchi.

If all goes according to plan, around Christmas 2003, Beagle will separate from the Mars Express orbiter, descend to the planet by parachute and bounce to a halt in a coccoon of gas bags. A clamshell shield will unfold, exposing Beagle's scientific instruments, and the lander will beam back to Earth a Blur track specially composed for the event. Beagle's cameras will be calibrated by filming an image of coloured spots provided by Damien Hirst. If nothing else, Britscience is putting the first and probably last Britpop and Britart on Mars.

A few days later, the first Athena lander will drop onto another part of the planet. Given past experience, the odds are poor that Beagle and Athena will both perform flawlessly. It would be an extraordinary coup for Pillinger if a working British Beagle was merrily scratching and sniffing around in the Martian dirt when Nasa arrived. It would be a profound personal blow if something went wrong.

"Beagle 2 is very much Colin Pillinger's baby, and he has very much put himself on the line," says Balogh. "He's got an extremely distinguished background in analysing meteorites in the laboratory. This is a big departure for him.

"He's in a fairly exposed position. But I think that without people like him, science doesn't necessarily advance at anything but a pedestrian level."

Pillinger is aware of the risks. "It's ever so easy to land on Mars on paper," he says. "My answer is we've recruited what we think are the best possible players in Europe. We believe we have a strong, substantial team."

Speculation about whether life exists on Mars has been going on since the 17th century. No matter how many disappointments there have been - confirmation by the Mariner probes in the 1960s that Mars was a frigid desert with a thin atmosphere, the lack of evidence for life found by the Viking landers in the 1970s - there is an overwhelming desire on the part of humankind to believe we are not alone in the solar system.

The announcement in 1996 that researchers had found fossilised life in one of the Martian meteorites which fell to Earth received much greater attention than the subsequent chorus of scientific criticism saying the "fossils" were, in fact, natural geological features.

There is always a suspicion that space scientists cynically play up the chances of finding life on Mars or the Jovian moons to drum up public support, and hence funding, for their programmes - even when they don't, in their hearts, have any hope that life is there.

It seems to be another thing that Squyres and Pillinger have in common that they aren't like that. They both insist they will wait for the data to come in. But it is clear that they wouldn't be so interested in Mars if they were sure, personally, that the rocks were dead.

"One of the things that makes Mars a special place is the fact that it is so Earthlike, and the possibility that life must have arisen there," says said Squyres. "It's very hard to prove the negative, that there is no life."

Pillinger thinks the jury is still out on what the meteorites show. He is convinced that the "fossils" show evidence of water flow and carbon compounds, the building blocks of life. Beagle has to prove that the carbon compounds are native to Mars, rather than being the results of contamination of the meteorites, and to see what else it can find - like methane in the Martian atmosphere, which would be as clear an indicator of life as a sign in Maja Vallis saying: "Mars Welcomes Careful Landers."

If Squyres sees himself as an explorer, Pillinger is more of a sleuth. "At the beginning analysing extraterrestrial rocks turned out to be the job I was offered, but there were times when I could have said I'd like to do forensic science. Detective stuff," he says. "Working with extraterrestrial samples is like that. You don't have the clues in front of you. You have to use your ingenuity to find them."

With Squyres, it was being taught as a student in the 1970s by a scientist who had worked on the Viking Mars landers. "As I got deeper into geology, I concluded there wasn't that much more real exploring to be done on Earth," he says. "I was captivated by the idea of being able to explore other worlds." Just out of his postgraduate training, Pillinger was taken on by Bristol University in 1969 to analyse fragments of lunar rock from the Apollo missions. It was the start of a career which saw him become one of the world's leading experts on moon rocks and Martian meteorites, chips of Mars which were sent flying into space after an asteroid collided with that planet and which ended up bumping into Earth. "It was good to go out at night and look at the moon and be able to say: 'I work on that,' " he says. While Squyres was taken up rapidly into Nasa's sprawling space science establishment, Pillinger remained confined to earthly labs for decades. When in 1997 ESA began canvassing missions for Mars Express, he seized his chance. Brushing aside the doubts of the European space bureaucracy about whether money could be found for a lander, he convinced them he would raise the funds himself. So Beagle 2 was born, funded by British universities and businesses, a sceptical government and a band of as yet unrevealed sponsors being corralled by Saatchi and Saatchi. If all goes according to plan, around Christmas 2003, Beagle will separate from the Mars Express orbiter, descend to the planet by parachute and bounce to a halt in a coccoon of gas bags. A clamshell shield will unfold, exposing Beagle's scientific instruments, and the lander will beam back to Earth a Blur track specially composed for the event. Beagle's cameras will be calibrated by filming an image of coloured spots provided by Damien Hirst. If nothing else, Britscience is putting the first and probably last Britpop and Britart on Mars. A few days later, the first Athena lander will drop onto another part of the planet. Given past experience, the odds are poor that Beagle and Athena will both perform flawlessly. It would be an extraordinary coup for Pillinger if a working British Beagle was merrily scratching and sniffing around in the Martian dirt when Nasa arrived. It would be a profound personal blow if something went wrong. "Beagle 2 is very much Colin Pillinger's baby, and he has very much put himself on the line," says Balogh. "He's got an extremely distinguished background in analysing meteorites in the laboratory. This is a big departure for him. "He's in a fairly exposed position. But I think that without people like him, science doesn't necessarily advance at anything but a pedestrian level." Pillinger is aware of the risks. "It's ever so easy to land on Mars on paper," he says. "My answer is we've recruited what we think are the best possible players in Europe. We believe we have a strong, substantial team." Speculation about whether life exists on Mars has been going on since the 17th century. No matter how many disappointments there have been - confirmation by the Mariner probes in the 1960s that Mars was a frigid desert with a thin atmosphere, the lack of evidence for life found by the Viking landers in the 1970s - there is an overwhelming desire on the part of humankind to believe we are not alone in the solar system. The announcement in 1996 that researchers had found fossilised life in one of the Martian meteorites which fell to Earth received much greater attention than the subsequent chorus of scientific criticism saying the "fossils" were, in fact, natural geological features. There is always a suspicion that space scientists cynically play up the chances of finding life on Mars or the Jovian moons to drum up public support, and hence funding, for their programmes - even when they don't, in their hearts, have any hope that life is there. It seems to be another thing that Squyres and Pillinger have in common that they aren't like that. They both insist they will wait for the data to come in. But it is clear that they wouldn't be so interested in Mars if they were sure, personally, that the rocks were dead. "One of the things that makes Mars a special place is the fact that it is so Earthlike, and the possibility that life must have arisen there," says said Squyres. "It's very hard to prove the negative, that there is no life." Pillinger thinks the jury is still out on what the meteorites show. He is convinced that the "fossils" show evidence of water flow and carbon compounds, the building blocks of life. Beagle has to prove that the carbon compounds are native to Mars, rather than being the results of contamination of the meteorites, and to see what else it can find - like methane in the Martian atmosphere, which would be as clear an indicator of life as a sign in Maja Vallis saying: "Mars Welcomes Careful Landers." If Squyres sees himself as an explorer, Pillinger is more of a sleuth. "At the beginning analysing extraterrestrial rocks turned out to be the job I was offered, but there were times when I could have said I'd like to do forensic science. Detective stuff," he says. "Working with extraterrestrial samples is like that. You don't have the clues in front of you. You have to use your ingenuity to find them."

fields.headline: Donald Dewar
fields.trailText: During the 1997 election, I spent a day with Donald Dewar (Obituary, October 12) in his constituency. It wasn't very arduous campaigning, given his huge majority. He was shocked by my ignorance of the glories of Glasgow architecture, and spent much of the time educating me about Alexander "Greek" Thompson. But whenever we met people, one saw at once the regard in which he was held.
fields.body:
During the 1997 election, I spent a day with Donald Dewar (Obituary, October 12) in his constituency. It wasn't very arduous campaigning, given his huge majority. He was shocked by my ignorance of the glories of Glasgow architecture, and spent much of the time educating me about Alexander "Greek" Thompson. But whenever we met people, one saw at once the regard in which he was held.

Late in the day, we dropped in at a local bowling green, where we were greeted very warmly and offered tea and cake. As we drank up, Donald slowly ceased to be the centre of attention. No one was watching when we finished. But - instinctively, almost unconsciously - he grabbed my cup with his, went to the sink and washed them both up. It was just simple good manners.

So what? Well, I can't think of any other politician likely to have done the same.

webTitle: The optimism of living in a disinflationary age

fields.headline: The optimism of living in a disinflationary age
fields.trailText: Ever since the devaluation of the Thai baht in July 1997 set off a domino effect around south-east Asia, it has been obvious that financial instability would not and could not be confined to the minnows of the global economy. And so it has proved.
fields.body:
Ever since the devaluation of the Thai baht in July 1997 set off a domino effect around south-east Asia, it has been obvious that financial instability would not and could not be confined to the minnows of the global economy. And so it has proved.

Those who believed that there was something new and different about America's speculative bubble were deluding themselves and the mood has clearly changed since the International Monetary Fund said last month that 2000 would be the best year for the world economy in more than a decade. As Nick Parsons of Commerzbank noted caustically last week, that was the biggest sell signal of the lot.

The arrival of Wall Street at reality checkpoint has coincided with an escalation of the crisis in the Middle East. Corporate earnings are already being squeezed by a slowdown in consumer demand and companies now face the prospect of an increase in energy costs at a time when the tightness of the labour market means that they are less able to resist demands for higher wages.

Analysts, who at the beginning of the year were merrily ignoring traditional measures of stock market value, have suddenly rediscovered their faith in a relationship between the earnings of a company and its share price. Their calculations belatedly confirm what the Cassandras have been saying since the mid-1990s - Wall Street is grossly over-valued and heading for a big correction.

The bear market in equities was under way long before the attention of the world's media started to focus on what was happening in the Gaza Strip and the West Bank. But the prospect of Lebanon, Syria and perhaps even Saudi Arabia being sucked into a wider geo-political struggle has added to the sense of panic.

Even the dimmest dealer knows that it was a former crisis in the Middle East - the Yom Kippur war 27 years ago this month - that prompted the oil cartel, Opec, to raise the price of crude fivefold in late 1973 and early 1974, bringing first inflation and then recession to the west.

As such, it is no surprise to find that there are some who believe that history is about to repeat itself. The Anglo-Saxon countries have enjoyed a long boom since the start of the 1990s and look just as vulnerable to an oil shock as they were in 1973. Should the price of crude stay at its current level - let alone rise to $40 or $50 a barrel - then the consequence would be a surge of inflation that would be followed by a severe monetary tightening and wave after wave of redundancies.

After dabbling with 1970s music and 1970s fashion, we could complete the set with a dose of 1970s stagflation. What are the chances of this happening? Well, obviously, it would be utterly daft to rule it out.

The odds on a hard landing in the US are shortening by the day, with companies under pressure to justify their inflated share prices, the banking sector awash with bad loans and consumers borrowing heavily to fund their spending habit. Financial deregulation and capital liberalisation - forced down the throats of other nations by the US treasury and Wall Street - may not look quite so clever when the hot money flows into America are reversed, bringing down the dollar and adding to inflationary pressure.

We could, therefore, stand on the threshold of a new age of crisis. In years to come, we may look back on the last years of the 1990s as a brief oasis of prosperity in a desert of economic dislocation. However, let's try to look on the bright side. An alternative way of looking at recent events is to see them as a catharsis, with a crash on Wall Street not just the culmination of the financial turmoil that started in south-east Asia three years ago but the final thunderous chords of a symphony of darkness stretching back to the mid-1970s. Seen in this light, the trouble in the Middle East would not be the overture to a new crisis, but a coda to the last.

One important reason for optimism is that we now live in a disinflationary age. In Britain, even after almost nine years of economic growth, we have car makers cutting prices, the Halifax offering higher rates of interest to its borrowers, supermarkets involved in a price war. This is not just the consequence of a strong pound, even though the reduction in the cost of imports caused by sterling's rise have been a factor. Competitive pressures, consumer resistance to higher prices and higher investment in new technology has changed the rules of the game and made the west less vulnerable to higher oil prices than it was in the 1970s.

This point was made forcefully last week by Sushil Wadhwani, one of the nine members of the Bank of England's monetary policy committee. Taking advantage of the fact that the four "outsiders" on the MPC can now call on their own team of researchers, Mr Wadhwani has come up with some fascinating - if still tentative conclusions.

Firstly, he says that the trade-off between growth and inflation has improved in the past decade, with forecasters underestimating growth and overestimating inflation. These errors have been considerable - around 0.5% a year in the case of both growth and inflation. Globalisation has been one factor in putting downward pressure on prices but privatisation and tougher regulation have led to a much tougher competitive environment.

Mr Wadhwani says it is possible that "the tendency to over-predict inflation is related to not paying enough attention to the possibility that the intensification of product market pressure has been altering some of the relationships built into existing macroeconometric models". Including, presumably, the Bank's.

But if firms are being skewered by an intensification of product market competition, why is it that profit margins are broadly unchanged since the start of the 1990s? Mr Wadhwani says that there are conditions in which the profit share would remain constant even with an increase in competition - a weakening of the power of labour or a technology-driven increase in productivity growth where the gains were disproportionately captured by capital. Like many other economists, Mr Wadhwani is convinced that the balance of power in the labour market has been profoundly affected by curbs on unions and tighter benefit rules. As a result, the old equations determining wages are now out of date, with the actual level of earnings growth coming in lower than expected.

But it is the final part of the analysis which breaks new ground and is likely to cause most debate within the MPC. Mr Wadhwani argues that the increase in the capacity of the economy in the past decade may not have been picked up by official data. He says that using the stock of capital to measure the supply potential of the economy is difficult, and that too much emphasis may have been placed on fixed assets such as building and not enough on short-lived assets such as machinery, equipment and software, where growth rates have been much more rapid.

Comparisons between UK and US prices for computers and software suggest, according to Mr Wadhwani, that inflation in new technology has been overstated and volume growth understated. He points out that in the US, software investment has averaged 140% of computer investment, in the UK it has been only 39%. Unless computers are being used as ornaments, this would appear to be highly unlikely. Working on the assumption that investment in software has been unrecorded and actually represents the same proportion of GDP in Britain as in the US, Mr Wadhwani and one of his researchers, Nicholas Oulton, found that growth would have been almost 0.4% a year higher between 1994 and 1998. Such a finding would, of course, have knock-on effects on productivity, unit labour costs and inflation and help to explain why the improvement in the growth-inflation trade-off has not been picked up.

Mr Wadhwani's analysis is bound to raise a few eyebrows on the MPC. With oil prices rising and the claimant count measure of unemployment below 4%, there will certainly be those warning that there is a risk to inflation of leaving monetary policy too loose, particularly if the crutch of a high pound is knocked away. But he is right to point out the risks in the other direction. In the medium term an improvement in the growth-inflation trade-off could - with the right policy response - herald the start of a new golden age of full employment. But not if policy makers insist on fighting the battles of the past. Inflation in the UK excluding oil and petrol is 1.6% and prices of goods in the high street are falling. Japanese inflation is negative. There is little price pressure in Germany, and not a great deal - given the strength of the booming economy in the US. The immediate threat to the west may be inflation; the spectre in the shadows is deflation.

webTitle: Labour scorned for failing to select women

fields.headline: Labour scorned for failing to select women
fields.standfirst:
Special report: New Labour in power
Special report: Tories in opposition
Special report: Parliament
fields.trailText: The Tories could be on course to have more women elected as new MPs at the next general election than the Labour party, a prospect that will severely embarrass Downing Street.
fields.body:
The Tories could be on course to have more women elected as new MPs at the next general election than the Labour party, a prospect that will severely embarrass Downing Street.

An analysis of parliamentary selection lists for the two parties shows William Hague could be joined by six new Tory women MPs, a net gain of five. Labour, by contrast, is heading for only two new women MPs, a net loss of four.

The pattern is repeated among candidates from ethnic minority backgrounds. The Tories are fielding 12 Asian candidates, compared with three new Asian candidates for Labour. At least one is likely to be elected for each party.

Labour's selection of a handful of women was condemned last night by Harriet Harman, the former social security secretary. "We seem to have taken two steps back after the step forward we took at the last election," she said. "The system is unfair and unbalanced and must be changed because women in the country want to see more women MPs."

Tessa Jowell, the women's minister, admitted Labour was deeply unhappy with the figures. "We are in a very disappointing position," she said.

Her remarks underlined the embarrassment at Labour's Millbank headquarters at the party's failure to select women for winnable seats. The party, whose all-women shortlists were blocked in 1996, has instructed local associations to ensure all shortlists have equal numbers of men and women.

But this policy appears to have had barely any impact, judging by an analysis of Labour's preliminary candidates' list. Only two women have been selected so far in the 32 Labour-held seats up for grabs, marking a net loss of four because six of the 32 seats were occupied by women.

Labour has yet to select a further six seats on the list, which means there is a last chance for more women to be chosen.

Tony Blair responded to the growing anger in the party over selections by announcing at the Labour conference that he will consider legalising all-women shortlists if he wins the election.

But Ms Harman said the party should take action by ensuring women are selected for the "last-minute" seats likely to become vacant a few months before the election.

"The leadership can use the last-minute selections to make up some of the ground we have lost," she said. "They can draw up the shortlists for such seats to ensure that women are selected."

The Tories are pleased that they are on course to have more new female MPs elected than Labour. Six new Tory MPs will be elected if there is a 3.35% swing to the party, with the numbers doubling to 12 on a 5.8% swing. But the party has not selected any women in the 22 Tory-held seats that have become vacant.

Theresa May, the party's spokesperson on women, said: "We have a long way to go. No women have been selected for safe Tory seats and that is glaring."

She struck a cautious note because the Tories know that Labour is still a long way ahead. Although Labour is on course for a fall in its tally, it will still have up to 97 female MPs. The Tories have a mere 14 female MPs, which could increase to between 20 and 26.

Labour's embarrassment will be compounded by reports that black and Asian candidates are suffering discrimination. Valerie Vaz, an Asian lawyer who unsuccessfully contested the West Bromwich West nomination, and Elaine Blake, who has been rejected in five seats, were both told that Labour was scared of running ethnic minority candidates in predominantly white areas.

This was condemned by Simon Woolley, the national co-ordinator of Operation Black Vote. "What does this say about the rhetoric of an inclusive democracy which we heard at the party conferences?" he said. "This is a scandalous waste of talent."

webTitle: Hijack that sealed return of an outcast to world stage

fields.headline: Hijack that sealed return of an outcast to world stage
fields.standfirst:
London and Washington get left behind as ending of Saudi plane drama and violence between Israelis and Palestinians help Baghdad out of a decade of isolation

Special report: Iraq
fields.trailText: London and Washington get left behind as ending of Saudi plane drama and violence between Israelis and Palestinians help Baghdad out of a decade of isolation
fields.body:
Iraqi success in achieving a peaceful outcome to the Saudi Arabian Airlines hijack yesterday capped what has been a golden month for the Iraqi dictator, Saddam Hussein.

Two Saudi hijackers diverted the Jeddah-London flight to Iraq but surrendered after talks with Iraqi officials.

As the 90 passengers and 17 crew members left Baghdad for an overnight stay in Saudi Arabia before resuming their flight to London, the Iraqi regime viewed the hijack as one of the many blessings it has received in the last four weeks.

Only in their wildest dreams would President Saddam and his cronies have envisaged that events could have turned so swiftly to their advantage. Two major changes stand out: in the last month there has been a flurry of flights to Baghdad in defiance of US and British sanctions and, in the biggest shift of all, the Palestinian-Israeli confrontation has helped in part to improve President Saddam's standing in the Arab world.

By contrast, the last month has been a sensational failure for a US and British policy that stubbornly combines sanctions with the bombing of Iraq. In an extraordinary turnaround, Washington and London are losing out in the propaganda stakes to a dictator with one of the worst human rights records in the world.

Iraq's success in ending the hijack provided its president with a propaganda coup that he exploited to the full.

"We are taking all measures that would reflect the real image of Iraq and its greatness, and [avoid] any action - God forbid - that may hurt any of the passengers," a senior Iraqi interior ministry official said before the hijackers surrendered.

Early editions of the Sunday papers in Britain expressed fears that President Saddam might keep the freed British, Saudi and US passengers as hostages of his own. The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, echoed this fear when he said: "I hope now that the hostages will all be allowed to leave Iraq."

President Saddam had held western workers hostage as a protective shield after the invasion of Kuwait. The temptation this time was that he might use the 40 Britons, 15 Saudis and one American on the Saudi plane as a bargaining counter for the dropping of sanctions.

The fear proved groundless. The passengers were transferred to the Rashid, the best hotel in Baghdad, where Iraq's communications and transport minister, Ahmed Murtada Ahmed Khalil, visited them and said: "We will do our best to serve you and to enable you to make telephone calls to your families."

President Saddam has played the propaganda game so skilfully that Mr Cook was left looking churlish yesterday when he could not bring himself to offer thanks to Iraq for the safe return of the passengers. The best the foreign secretary could manage was to tell reporters outside his official London residence: "I would not thank any government for carrying out its clear international obligations."

Praise

A Saudi prince, one of the freed hostages, was less grudging. Prince Bandar bin Mohammed bin Saad bin Abdul-Rahman, 19, who was on his way to London to study English, thanked Iraq for the way it handled the crisis.

Relations between the Iraqis and the Saudis are poor, with Saudi Arabia repeatedly vilified by President Saddam for providing bases for US and British planes bombing Iraq.

The Saudi Arabian deputy interior minister, Prince Ahmed, said yesterday that his country would demand the immediate extradition for trial of the two hijackers, whom he identified as Faisal al-Biloowi and Ayish al-Faridi. It is unlikely that Iraq will agree to the Saudi demand - the countries have no diplomatic relations, although a pre-Gulf War treaty provides for extradition.

A Saudi academic admitted that the Iraqi action had been valuable in improving relations but said that by itself it did not go nearly far enough. "The trust that the Saudi leadership would be looking for is to see Kuwaiti and Saudi prisoners held by Iraq released," said Abdul lah al-Fozan, associate professor of sociology at King Saud University in Saudi Arabia. Proof would also be wanted that Iraq was no longer building up an arsenal of weapons of mass destruction.

More significant in the long run than the hijack is the way that the Israeli-Palestinian crisis has helped President Saddam. Over the last fortnight, Palestinians on the West Bank and Gaza and in the refugee camps in Lebanon have been parading pictures of the Iraqi leader as the hero who fired Scud missiles at Israel in 1991. "Beloved Saddam, destroy Tel Aviv," chanted thousands of Palestinians last week at the Ain al-Helweh refugee camp in Lebanon.

In response, President Saddam's tanks have been manoeuvring west of Baghdad over the last few days, a symbolic threat rather than a real one, and he has promised 1m volunteers for a holy war against Israel.

The Arab League, which represents 21 countries, has invited President Saddam to attend a meeting in Cairo next Saturday at which its members are expected to agree a statement supporting Palestinian independence. It is an extraordinary invitation, given that the Iraqi dictator is still regarded by most Arab governments as unpredictable and dangerous.

An Israeli government spokesman in London yesterday expressed alarm at the invitation. "The seas of the Arab world are very choppy and that is a very big worry." He admitted that events of the last month had left President Saddam stronger.

His good spell began when the first international flight into Baghdad since the Gulf war arrived on August 17. In the past month there has been a steady flow of planes, in defiance of UN sanctions.

Although the UN security council supported the sanctions, they are only being actively pursued by Britain and the US. Russia, China and, to a lesser extent, France, though security council members, are opposed to continuing with sanctions and bombing.

France and Russia have sent in flights and two Russian airlines, Aeroflot and Vnukovo, are preparing to begin scheduled flights, possibly as early as the end of this month, making Moscow the gateway for British, American and other businessmen heading for Iraq. President Saddam rightly sees these divisions within the security council as a sign of weakness.

In another significant erosion of Iraq's isolation, the Iranian foreign minister, Kamal Kharrazi, left Baghdad yesterday after meeting Saddam Hussein, saying they had reached agreement on several issues that have been sores between the two countries since their 1980-88 war. Among the deals is thought to be an agreement to stop providing bases for guerrillas operating against one another's regime. Underlining the way Iraq is rejoining the rest of the world, Mr Kharrazi left Baghdad aboard the first Iranian plane to have landed in Iraq since the Gulf war.

Changing days for Iraq, which even six months ago was still regarded as a pariah state by almost all its Arab neighbours.

fields.headline: Gloom falls on summit hopes
fields.standfirst:
Barak says peace with Arafat 'very difficult'
Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: President Bill Clinton arrives in Egypt today to try to salvage an Israeli-Palestinian summit from a failure that could resonate far beyond the region.
fields.body:
President Bill Clinton arrives in Egypt today to try to salvage an Israeli-Palestinian summit from a failure that could resonate far beyond the region.

On the eve of the summit in the Egyptian resort town of Sharm el-Sheikh, Israeli and Palestinian officials said they hoped for little more than a verbal understanding to end 18 days of rocket attacks, gunbattles and mob rule. The violence claimed its 100th victim yesterday, when a man died of a head wound in the West Bank city of Ramallah.

As for the seven-year peace process, Israel's prime minister, Ehud Barak, told his cabinet that it was all but dead. "In the end, we will make peace with the Palestinians, but the current Palestinian leadership is now showing that it is finding it very difficult to make the decisions related to an agreement," a cabinet statement said yesterday.

And so from the peace of the brave promised seven years ago when the process began, at Sharm el-Sheikh today it comes down to a ceasefire for the desperate. The summit guest list in itself reflects the gravity of a crisis that has spread far beyond the West Bank and Gaza, sparking angry protests from Jordan to Indonesia and attacks on synagogues in Europe.

In addition to President Clinton, Kofi Annan, the UN secretary general, and the European Union's Javier Solana, King Abdullah of Jordan and the Egyptian host, Hosni Mubarak - now on the defensive in the Arab world for having made a separate peace with Israel - will be marshalling their efforts to pull both sides back from the brink of all-out war.

"The crisis is not confined to the Palestinian territories or Israel but it threatens the whole region and extends beyond," Mr Annan said yesterday after meeting the Egyptian president yesterday.

Although the day brought a relative lull in the violence, tensions in the region remain high. In Beirut, the Hizbullah guerrilla group said that it had captured a colonel in Israeli intelligence.

In Jerusalem, a spokesman said the hostage was a businessman of Arab extraction who had been kidnapped in Europe.

Israeli officials warned of a risk of bombing attacks. In the Jordan valley, meanwhile, two Israeli soldiers were wounded when Jordanian soldiers fired across the frontier.

The summit, which could last for two days, is an enterprise handicapped from the outset. Mr Arafat's attendance is the result of intense pressure from Washington, and his mere presence at Sharm is fiercely opposed by his people.

Palestinian gunmen fired automatic rifles into the air outside Mr Arafat's office in Gaza last night to express their opposition. Mr Arafat came to the gate of the compound to explain his decision to the 200-strong crowd.

"We are going to Sharm el-Sheik, but taking with us the condition of the Palestinian people," he said. "We are on the way to Jerusalem until a Palestinian child raises the Palestinian flag on the walls of Jerusalem."

The crowd cheered, chanting: "With our blood, and with our soul, we will defend you."

Earlier, Mahdi Abdul Hadi, a Palestinian analyst, said: "Our blood is still fresh in the street, we are in a state of mourning, there are black flags on our houses. We have awakened all the horses in the Arab world. Why should Arafat turn up alone, and on a donkey? Why should we go to a summit whose main purpose is to save Barak?"

Mr Barak also has precious little room for manoeuvre, having opened negotiations with the rightwing Likud party to form an emergency government, an act that would definitively kill off the peace process.

Yesterday, Likud leaders said they would stay out if Mr Barak attempted to restart negotiations with Mr Arafat at today's summit.

The Israeli prime minister's demands, which were announced yesterday, reflect that hardening of positions. They include: an immediate end to the violence; the rearrest of Hamas and Islamic Jihad militants released at the weekend; punishment for Palestinian police and members of Mr Arafat's Fatah organisation who opened fire on Israeli soldiers; censorship of the Palestinian media, whom the Israelis accuse of inciting the violence; and preservation of Jewish pilgrimage sites at Nablus and Jericho, which have been attacked by Palestinians.

Mr Arafat met one condition by putting 34 Hamas militants back in jail.

However, he issued demands of his own: for Israel to withdraw its forces from the outskirts of Palestinian cities, and to end the closure of the West Bank and Gaza which has cut people off from the jobs in Israel that are the lifeline of the local economy. Mr Arafat also wants an international protection force, which Israel will certainly reject, and an international investigation into the violence, the demand that scuppered the last attempt to broker a ceasefire.

"I honestly don't want to raise anyone's expectations and I don't have high expectations myself," said Saeb Erekat, a Palestinian negotiator. "I think the situation is going to be nightmarish."

President Clinton's challenge now will be to reconcile those opposing demands, especially the divisions over the call for an international in quiry which wrecked the summit in Paris between Mr Barak and Mr Arafat.

If he fails, he risks the implosion of his Middle East diplomacy in the runup to the US presidential election on November 7, and the disastrous consequences from a unilateral declaration of Palestinian independence, on November 15 or later.

On Saturday, Mr Clinton expressed deep regret that the peace process he has nurtured throughout his presidency has all but collapsed. "We've had this terrible turn of events in the Middle East, which has really been heartbreaking for me," he said. "I've seen so much progress in the last seven and a half years, so it's been very painful."

Big names at the talks

The main participants in the summit at Sharm el-Sheikh today are likely to be:

Bill Clinton US president

Ehud Barak Israeli prime minister

Yasser Arafat Palestinian president

Hosni Mubarak Egyptian president

King Abdullah of Jordan

Kofi Annan UN secretary general

Javier Solana EU foreign policy chief

webTitle: Europhile Tories tell of climate of fear at selection

fields.headline: Europhile Tories tell of climate of fear at selection
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Tories in opposition
Special report: Parliament
fields.trailText: It is a sign of the climate of fear within the Conservative party that pro-Europeans hoping to stand for parliament insist on speaking anonymously.
fields.body:
It is a sign of the climate of fear within the Conservative party that pro-Europeans hoping to stand for parliament insist on speaking anonymously.

William Hague's lurch to the right on Europe has created such a poisonous atmosphere that pro-Europeans - known in the party as Europhiles - cannot risk putting their heads above the parapet.

One aspiring parliamentarian said that he was facing a virtually impossible task to win a nomination: "I am pro-European and I have moderate views, a lethal combination."

The candidate, who was so worried about being identified that he asked not to be described in any way, said: "Pro-Europeans are being excluded. But it is hardly a shock that Eurosceptics should be chosen when the party has become so strongly Eurosceptic."

Thatcherites in the Conservative Way Forward have destroyed the campaigns of countless pro-Europeans by organising local supporters to ask awkward questions at selection meetings.

Stretching the official Tory policy on Europe, they ask candidates whether they would rule out membership of the euro forever. Affirmative answers win applause - but breach party policy - while answers in the negative seal the fate of pro-Europeans.

The Europhile candidate said he has carefully prepared a set piece answer to the euro question which appears to support the Hague's position - to rule out membership for the next parliament - while staying true to his beliefs.

The candidate said: "I tell meetings that it would be wrong to join the euro today and it wrong for Labour to say it is inevitable and to try and bounce us into membership. Then I say that we should keep our options open, as William Hague proposes."

Amid what some pro-Europeans are calling the "ethnic cleansing of Europhiles", there is little comfort. Although no Europhiles have been selected for Conservative seats, there are a handful of Tories on the top list who would endorse a pro-European position if the leadership moved back to the centre.

Andrew Mitchell, a former minister who was blocked by rightwingers from securing the nomination for Peter Brooke's Westminster seat, is now in the safe seat of Sutton Coldfield. He endorses Mr Hague's position on the euro, but was secretary of the One Nation group.

"Everyone said that the 1979 intake of Tory MPs were Thatcher's children," one Europhile said. "But look what happened to Chris Patten and Stephen Dorrell."

webTitle: 'Ordinary people' in protest over Saudi rights abuses

fields.headline: 'Ordinary people' in protest over Saudi rights abuses
fields.standfirst: Special report: Iraq
fields.trailText: Two men who hijacked a Saudi Arabia Airlines jet carrying 90 passengers, including 40 Britons, disclosed yesterday that they wanted to protest against Saudi human rights abuses.
fields.body:
Two men who hijacked a Saudi Arabia Airlines jet carrying 90 passengers, including 40 Britons, disclosed yesterday that they wanted to protest against Saudi human rights abuses.

The two, who were under arrest in Iraq last night, described themselves as ordinary people rather than international terrorists. The incident was not related to the Palestinian-Israeli clashes.

The two hijackers surrendered in the early hours of yesterday morning at Saddam international airport in Baghdad after hours of negotiations with Iraqi officials. They had threatened to blow up the plane with TNT explosives.

The plane, which had 17 crew on board, was hijacked over the Mediterranean on Saturday night en route from Jeddah to London. The hijackers forced the pilot to change course, flying over Syria and on to Baghdad.

The freed passengers, who include 15 Saudis, 15 Pakistanis and various other nationalities, spent Saturday night at a hotel in Baghdad. Last night they left the hotel to fly to Riyadh in Saudia Arabia where they were planning to spend another night. They are expected to continue to London today.

The passengers had not realised that they had been hijacked until the plane landed in Baghdad.

One passenger, Jacky Doyle, a mother of two who works for the British Museum, said: "I was not aware of the hijacking until I realised that we were at another airport, not Heathrow."

One of the hijackers told reporters yesterday at the airport in Baghdad: "We are just ordinary people and we are calling for the rights of the Saudi people, such as decent education, decent health and other services."

They called for the abolition of the Saudi monarchy, which presides over a government with one of the worst human rights records in the world.

A recent report by the human rights group Amnesty International condemned the regime for a series of abuses, in particular public executions. One of those on board the hijacked plane was a Saudi prince.

The hijackers, who gave a press conference at the end of the seven-hour ordeal, said that they had chosen to force the aircraft to fly to Iraq because "the Iraqi people are under embargo and because we trust the Iraqis and they will not betray us".

Both looked relaxed and one of them covered his face with a handkerchief. They refused to give their names.

But the United Arab Emirates satellite television channel in Abu Dhabi identified the two men as Ayeish Ali al-Khalidi and Faisel Naji al-Bluey, both from Saudi Arabia.

The hijackers twice threatened to destroy the Boeing jet, once in the air and again on the tarmac of the airport in Baghdad.

"We carried out the operation because we believe in the principles of justice and equality," said one. The other added that the Saudi people were opposed to the presence of American troops in their country.

Both hijackers said they had not asked for political asylum and did not intend to stay in Iraq. Although Saudi Arabia has asked for their return, the Iraqi government hinted that it was unlikely to comply, given that there are no diplomatic ties between the two countries.

Passengers told how the hijackers had shown the captain a cache of three bombs and a gun.

Waqas Hussein, 21, a passenger from Pakistan going to study in the UK, said there had been little or no security at Jeddah airport when they began their journey. "There wasn't any checking of our luggage or ourselves," he said.

He added: "People were scared but nobody got rowdy. I saw some tense faces. After four hours sitting in the plane the captain announced that they had successfully negotiated with the hijackers.

"Everybody on board clapped as the hijackers left."

fields.headline: A Country Diary
fields.trailText: Wayland Wood, Norfolk
fields.body:
Wayland Wood, Norfolk

The mood was sombre as we walked along the network of paths crisscrossing this Norfolk Wildlife Trust reserve. Although the sky was virtually cloudless, the foliage allowed only a fretwork of sunshine onto the woodland floor. Otherwise the place was held in a dingy earth-toned light, and in Wayland's interior it was cold and still.

The rows of hazel coppice emphasised an atmosphere of decay. Leaves, smothered in dew, drooped around their network of branches like a sickly yellow umbrella. As well as screening off the busy road, they screened us off from one of the wood's most recent, exotic inhabitants, the golden pheasant.

These birds are a mixture of bright yellow, scarlet and royal blue, sumptuous colours crowned by a sequence of erectile feathers, barred orange and blue-black, that extends shawl-like around the head and neck. Few dispute that it is one of the country's most beautiful animals. More open to question is its status as a genuine British species. Its original home was the dense forests of central China, but, with its popularity as a cage bird, and hence free-flying colonies at country estates, it escaped to build up a small, precarious wild population centred on south Norfolk.

We crawled on all fours along a deer-track through the jungle-like hazel until we could glimpse several males strutting and crowing at one another in territorial display. Despite the nocturnal gloom, the pheasants' colours had a glowing, celebratory quality. It was as if, even in the midst of its decay, Wayland had revealed to us its mysterious powers of self-renewal.

webTitle: TV guide: Mark Lawson on The Royle Family, One Foot in the Grave and North Square

fields.headline: Sofa, so good
fields.standfirst: Tonight, the BBC plays two aces to support the rescheduling of the news to 10pm. The Royle Family and One Foot in the Grave, both critical and commercial successes, are comedy at its finest, says  Mark Lawson
fields.trailText: Tonight, the BBC plays two aces to support the rescheduling of the news to 10pm. The Royle Family and One Foot in the Grave, both critical and commercial successes, are comedy at its finest, says Mark Lawson.
fields.body:
When the first episode of the third series of The Royle Family (tonight, 9.30pm, BBC1) was recorded, its opening dialogue must have seemed merely a little jokey nip at the feeding hand. Watching BBC1, Jim Royle complains that "it's all shite" and the family are "going to have to get Sky".

Now Caroline Aherne's comedy forms, along with the final series of One Foot in the Grave (tonight, 9pm, BBC1), an emergency scheduling bridgehead before the first BBC News (tonight, 10pm, BBC1) to be transmitted in the old ITN News At Ten slot. In short, Jim Royle is charged with preventing the BBC1 audience from deciding it's all shite and buying Sky.

The only television comedy in which the dialogue is almost wholly about TV has found its perfect moment. A further irony is that Victor Meldrew in One Foot in the Grave is precisely the kind of middle-class grump who would regard a sudden switch in the timing of the news as a perversion of the natural order and phone the BBC to moan.

But, for the first six weeks of the new News, Royle and Meldrew should be able to divert the shite-watchers and switchboard-jammers, because these are among television's most brilliant and original comedies. And, in each case, a format now famous has been invigorated by a new plot-point. In One Foot in the Grave it's an impending death: Victor dies in the final episode. In The Royle Family, it's a recent birth.

The arrival of Denise and Dave's first child David Keanu perfectly illustrates the mixture of vulgarity and subtlety in Caroline Aherne and Craig Cash's writing. Jim Royle's terror of breast-feeding - flinching at a reference to "leaking in Top Shop" - might have been predicted, but Denise's post-natal depression and maternal indifference - leaving all nappy-changes and night-waking to her husband - are an unusually dark strain in domestic sitcom. The alarmed glances of the parents - a solidarity of horror at their daughter's state - are beautifully played by Sue Johnston and Ricky Tomlinson.

But the show's status as an anthology of popular culture is extended by the kitchen scene in which teenager Anthony Royle and his friend Darren laboriously swap Ali G impersonations. It's typical of the sharpness of observation that one of the boys is a terrible mimic and that both have the latest Beckham shave-cuts.

As co-writer, star and now director of this episode, Caroline Aherne is now approaching a Woody Allen or Warren Beatty level of multi-skilling. The only question over the series' classic status is whether its frequent sell-by references - Anne Robinson, Posh and Becks, Ali G - will prevent it from claiming new generations of viewers in the way that Dad's Army and Fawlty Towers have.

One Foot in the Grave reminds us that writer David Renwick understands (as with his other hit, Jonathan Creek) that TV is a visual medium. This may seem a truism but TV comedy can be - and frequently is - carried by dialogue. A writer with brilliant ears and lazy eyes can still become rich. Characteristically, however, Renwick's opening episode is built around visual images: a giant television set accidentally bought, two works of modern art, the apparent discovery of human remains in Meldrew's garden.

What's notable about both these shows - and what explains their unusual double success in attracting enthusiastic reviews and high ratings - is that they alternate broad and narrow comedy, appealing simultaneously to two audiences.

The tabloids enjoy Meldrew for his Alf Garnett-like rants and DIY disasters; the broadsheets acknowledge the nods to Samuel Beckett, which writer David Renwick has admitted are deliberate. There's even an episode in which Victor is buried up to his neck in earth like Winnie in Happy Days - an ironic Beckettian phrase which would be a perfect sub-title for One Foot in the Grave.

David Renwick has joked that he kept the literary inspiration for the show's tone quiet because you couldn't tell the Controller of BBC1 you were writing a Beckettian sitcom. But you wonder if he's the only one keeping this secret. The Royle Family also does to the sitcom what the Irish cricketer-dramatist did to the conventions of the boulevard stage comedy, again working through a cunning double structure.

Consisting almost entirely of references to very recent popular culture, The Royle Family seems on the surface a wholly mainstream show, but its lack of incident and the risk the dialogue takes with banality and repetition often render it surreal.

Indigence prevented Beckett's tramps from having television, but there is something very familiar in the Royle Family's attempt to avert tedium and fear through circular dialogue which frequently turns to discussion of sex and bodily functions. Beached on their sofa in front of their god of a box, they patiently but hopelessly wait for a revelation which will never come - Waiting For Dando, perhaps.

Who would have thought that a primary influence on sitcom at the turn of the 21st century would be Samuel Beckett? But, with many television programmes these days struggling to attract one audience, the BBC is lucky to be beginning its scheduling endgame on BBC1 with a pair of shows which can bring in two.

Class act

Those who dislike The Royle Family are usually uneasy about its attitude to the working-class; the allegation Mike Leigh has also faced. It's a fair concern - Caroline Aherne's stance seems to me at best cheer-sneer - and reminds us just how much of British TV has social standing as its subject even in an allegedly egalitarian era.

The legal drama North Square (Wednesday, 9pm, Channel 4) is advertised as and looks like a British version of LA Law and Ally McBeal, but the drama of the opening episode depends, to a perhaps surprising degree, on the clash of background and accent.

The temptation is obvious because the relationship between barristers and their clerks still generally obeys the stereotype of the toff-thug double-act. North Square encourages this by focusing on chief clerk Peter (Phil Davis), a chain-smoking cockney who rebukes a Blairite new barrister for inviting his clerk to first-name him rather than "sir" him. In another scene, a toffish lawyer is thumped by a Scottish one for a racist remark.

One of the strengths of American legal series has been the way they explained legal foible and detail, but, on the early evidence, North Square seems over-concerned with the Fair Employment Act as a source of dramatic tension. It's true that easy assumptions are undermined - the clerk proves more cultured than the barristers - but even these moments arise from consideration of class.

Peter Moffat's writing and Tim Fywell's direction are smarter and glossier respectively than Kavanagh QC, but, for a series billed as breaking the laws of the British legal series, it's worrying that the opening insight - juries coming back into court never make eye-contact with someone they've convicted - has previously been made by both Rumpole and Kavanagh. This could still be a classy number if only it had less class.

webTitle: Nicholas Watt on Tory women MPs

fields.headline: 'I wonder how many Thatchers they have missed'
fields.standfirst:
Election veteran finds it near impossible to find safe seat

Special report: Tories in opposition
Special report: Parliament
fields.trailText: Election veteran finds it near impossible to find safe seat, says Nicholas Watt.
fields.body:
Elizabeth Gibson is a model of the kind of professional woman William Hague says he would like to see as a Tory MP.

A veteran of two parliamentary elections, the energetic fundraiser for the Marie Curie Cancer Care charity fizzes with ideas about Westminster. Like hundreds of other women Tories, however, Ms Gibson, 49, is finding it virtually impossible to find a decent seat.

Male contemporaries with her track record - she fought Hampstead and Highgate in 1997 and Birmingham Hodge Hill in 1992 - have long since been selected. But Ms Gibson finds herself blocked by local Tory associations, often by women who cannot bear the thought of a female MP. At her most recent outing Ms Gibson reached the final six at Taunton - the Tories' 27th target seat - only to see a man win the nomination.

"It is very difficult to get selected for a safe seat," she said. "The female selectors tend to be of an age where they find it difficult to come to terms with a working woman. You have to ask how many Margaret Thatchers have they passed up?"

Ms Gibson, who is married with two young children, said selection panels are not allowed to ask pointed questions about combining life as an MP with raising a family. However, the attitude of some associations indicate many Tories have not moved on since the 1950s when Margaret Thatcher failed to secure the plum seat of Maidstone because she was a young mother.

"The older women cannot understand that women can combine life as an MP with raising a family," Ms Gibson said. "No credence is given to women who have to take time out from their careers to care for their children - it's just seen as a gap in the CV. But women can bring important experiences - I am a school governor for example."

But she does not believe all women shortlists are the answer "although we do need to take drastic action". She said: "I would favour shortlists with equal numbers of men and women because when women go to a wider meeting of the local party they tend to do well."

webTitle: Crisis of confidence for Israel's moderates

fields.headline: Crisis of confidence for Israel's moderates
fields.standfirst:
Activists claim betrayal by Arafat
Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Bewildered and horrified by the spiralling violence in the West Bank and Gaza Strip, Israel's peace camp is in the throes of agonised soul-searching about how to continue the weary quest for permanent peace with the Palestinians.
fields.body:
Bewildered and horrified by the spiralling violence in the West Bank and Gaza Strip, Israel's peace camp is in the throes of agonised soul-searching about how to continue the weary quest for permanent peace with the Palestinians.

Stunned by images of hatred and death on a grand scale, and especially by last Thursday's televised lynching of two Israeli soldiers in Ramallah, veteran campaigners are publicly questioning some of their own basic assumptions.

Many activists admit that the prime minister, Ehud Barak, and the army over-reacted and that excesses should be investigated. But they complain far more bitterly that the Palestinians they had come to trust as partners have betrayed them.

"This is the greatest crisis of faith for the peace camp that I can remember," said Janet Aviad, involved in Israeli-Palestinian dialogue since the late 1970s. "We really thought we were at the end of the marathon, the last 10 metres. Now I don't know if that 10 has become 100, or 15. It's too early to say."

On Saturday Ms Aviad and colleagues from the Peace Now movement crossed to East Jerusalem to renew contacts with Palestinian moderates which had been severed during the two weeks of mayhem in which 100 have died.

Mainstream peaceniks agree that there is much to criticise in the behaviour of the security forces in the occupied territories and inside Israel proper, where 13 Arab citizens were killed in clashes of unprecedented severity.

Everyone agrees, too, that the fatal spark was provided by the opposition Likud leader, Ariel Sharon, when he visited the Haram al-Sharif or Temple Mount on September 28. But they squarely blame Yasser Arafat for exploiting and encouraging the ensuing violence - and letting it go on.

Worse still, they say, this latest deadly outbreak came after last summer's abortive Camp David talks seemed to bring a final peace settlement closer than ever before.

But Mr Arafat's lack of leadership and duplicity, and the disturbing evidence of an Islamic dimension to the conflict have undermined confidence that there is a "partner" with whom Israel can deal at all.

"If so far most of the peace camp felt that Palestinian hatred of Israel was justified as long as the occupation continued, the hatred of the past weeks seems to threaten our very existence," commented Haaretz journalist Lily Galili. "It's not that they don't want us here as occupiers. They don't want us here at all."

Hawkish voices from the Israeli right claim vindication of their belief that the PLO leader was constitutionally incapable of making his peace with the Jewish state, seven years after his historic agreement with Yitzhak Rabin in Oslo.

"Personally, I had no illusions," said the historian Yehoshua Porat, who never trusted the Palestinians to accept a state alongside Israel or to surrender their right to return to the lands they lost in the 1948 war. "But my friends on the left are distraught."

Palestinians counter that mainstream peaceniks were not ultimately prepared to press Mr Barak to give enough, that the Oslo deal was always skewed too heavily against them.

"The Israeli peace movement is finished in the eyes of the Palestinians and in the eyes of Israelis too," said Ibrahim Dehebis of Al-Quds newspaper. "Where is Peace Now? Every moderate is finished."

And this war, wrote Nahum Barnea, a Yediot Aharonot columnist, whose own soldier son was killed in a suicide bombing by Hamas zealots, is like no other. "It has no front lines, no strategic goals and no victories. Just mutual bloodletting."

Peaceniks were jubilant after Oslo, but quickly found themselves in the wilderness after the assassination of Mr Rabin by a rightwing extremist and the election of the Likud's Binyamin Netanyahu as prime minister in 1996. Now Mr Sharon, his successor as Likud leader, is poised to join an emergency national unity government that seems certain to tie Mr Barak's hands if peace talks resume.

Yet even in their current despair, most doves insist that the violence proves that they must pursue their agenda with added vigour, since there is no alternative.

Israel's peace campaigners have seen bad times before: the start of the Lebanon war in 1982, and the Gulf crisis of 1991, when Palestinians danced and cheered as Saddam Hussein's Scud rockets hit Tel Aviv.

But unless something miraculous happens, this could turn out to be their bleakest moment.

webTitle: Capture of 'agent' adds to summit pressure

fields.headline: Capture of 'agent' adds to summit pressure
fields.standfirst:
Hizbullah claims it is holding an Israeli intelligence officer missing in Switzerland, as well as three kidnapped soldiers
Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Hopes of defusing the Middle East crisis suffered a new blow last night when Lebanon's Hizbullah movement claimed to have captured an Israeli intelligence officer - another card to add to three kidnapped soldiers it is already holding.
fields.byline: Ian Black  in Jerusalem and  Peter Capella  in Geneva
fields.body:
Hopes of defusing the Middle East crisis suffered a new blow last night when Lebanon's Hizbullah movement claimed to have captured an Israeli intelligence officer - another card to add to three kidnapped soldiers it is already holding.

It seemed likely to cast a further shadow over today's Sharm el-Sheikh summit in Egypt, called by President Bill Clinton as a desperate attempt to halt the two-week spiral of violence between Israelis and Palestinians.

Reports from Lebanon yesterday named the man as Hanan Tennenbaum, described as an agent of the Mossad secret service. But Israeli officials insisted he was a businessman who had gone missing in Switzerland several days ago.

Sheikh Hassan Nasrallah, secretary-general of Hizbullah, made the dramatic announcement at a meeting of Muslim leaders in Beirut.

In Jerusalem last night, an Israeli minister, Amnon Lipkin-Shahak, a former army chief of staff, hinted that tough action would be taken against both Hizbullah and Lebanon.

But he also signalled that Israel might be prepared to negotiate with the radical Shi'ite Muslim organisation.

Israeli Radio said that relatives of the businessman, who holds the army reserve rank of colonel, had reported him missing a few days ago after he had left for a trip abroad.

Another report said Mr Tennenbaum had been kidnapped by business partners and transferred to Hizbullah. Swiss officials said they were investigating the allegation.

"We are checking information and searching in Switzerland but we cannot confirm that action took place on Swiss territory," said Rolf Debrunner, a spokesman for the justice and police ministry.

The missing Israeli is understood to have been working for the Israeli electronics and telecommunications company Tadiran.

There is evidence that Switzerland is a fertile ground for a covert war between Israel and Islamic extremists. In June, the Swiss supreme court handed down a one year suspended jail sentence on a Mossad agent caught by Swiss police during a surveillance operation on a suspected Hizbullah activist three years ago. Several Islamic militants live in exile in Switzerland.

Ephraim Sneh, Israel's deputy minister of defence, confirmed that there was a man of that name, but described him as a private individual. Mr Sneh implied that Israel would be calling on the International Red Cross to take up the case, though it has so far failed to provide any information about the whereabouts of the missing soldiers, seized after a border gun battle earlier this month.

The brother of one of the three said yesterday that the family had heard nothing at all from any source.

Kofi Annan, the UN secretary-general, has interceded with the Lebanese authorities. On past precedent there is also likely to be a low-profile effort by Germany, exploiting its close relations with Iran, Hizbullah's most powerful patron.

A decade ago, quiet UN diplomacy did much to help secure the release of the last of the western hostages held by Iranian-backed groups in Lebanon.

Sheikh Nasrallah said further details would be announced "at the appropriate time". But his reference to a "complicated security operation" appeared to confirm suspicions of a kidnapping or sting operation.

Hizbullah has already said it wants to swap the three soldiers for Arab prisoners held in Israel. Israel is still seeking to clarify the fate of an air force navigator, Ron Arad, who was shot down over Lebanon in 1986.
