fields.headline: Mohamed Suffian
fields.standfirst: Fierce defender of Malaysia's independent judiciary
fields.trailText: Fierce defender of Malaysia's independent judiciary
fields.body:
Humility, compassion and fierce independence marked the career of the former Malaysian chief justice Tun Mohamed Suffian Hashim, who has died of cancer aged 82. At much personal cost, he never flinched from his criticism of the destruction of what was once a well-regarded judiciary in Malaysia, primarily by the prime minister, Mahathir Mohamed.

Suffian's unabashed belief in the best of the colonial heritage, especially in the administrative and legal systems, brought him into conflict with anti-western, third-world demagoguery which swept away time-honoured methods in favour of quick fixes. In Malaysia, this has meant dramatic changes in the legal system, without much thought, so that Islamic law is on a par with the common law system that the country still attempts to follow.

Malaysia changed course in 1981, when Dr Mahathir, on taking office, began to dismantle the status quo. He did it so deliberately - and so completely - that many, including the judiciary, were not aware of its significance until after the fact.

The rot began, Suffian often said, when the sixth lord president, Tun Saleh Abas, was removed from office so that Mahathir's political challengers could be neutralised. Since then, he felt, the judiciary had become handmaiden to Mahathir's political manouevres.

In 1988, Suffian raised his fears following Mahathir's sacking of judges he perceived as obstacles, and his moves to bring the federal courts under his control. When Mahathir wanted his deputy, Dato' Seri Anwar Ibrahim, destroyed politically, the judiciary performed the coup de grace by convicting him of sodomy and corruption.

Tun Suffian, or "Suff" to his friends, paid a heavy price for his criticisms. He was so isolated officially that to many he did not exist. The media ignored him.

The son of a kadi, a religious judge, Suffian was born in a remote village in Perak state. He read law at Gonville and Caius College, Cambridge, on a Queen's scholarship, and was called to the bar in 1941. At the outbreak of the second world war, he joined All India Radio, in New Delhi. After the conflict, he returned to London, where he joined the BBC.

Appointed to the Malayan civil service, he was posted to Malacca as magistrate and harbour master, a curious appointment justified on the grounds that while there was no provision for a magistrate's salary, there was one for the master of the non-existent harbour.

In 1959, Suffian became Malaya's first solicitor-general, and, two years later, a high court judge. In 1973, he became chief justice of Malaysia, and, the following year, lord president. In 1975, he was awarded the Ramon Magsaysay Award for government service, Asia's equivalent of the Nobel Peace Prize. After retirement in 1982, he became an adviser to Standard Chartered Bank, though official opposition prevented his advancement.

A private man, he was devoted to his wife, Bunny, whom he had met at Cambridge. Her death in 1997 devastated him, particularly since the Islamic authorities denied her the cremation she had wanted, insisting she be buried under Islamic rites in the Moslem cemetry at Kuala Kangsar.

When he became ill, Suffian was cared for by the niece of Malaysia's founding prime minister, Tengku Abdul Rahman, and her husband. He died a disappointed man, having spoken often, in public and private, of how what took generations to build could be destroyed in a day and would take years to rebuild. He had no children.

Tun Mohamed Suffian Hashim, judge, born November 12 1917; died September 26 2000

fields.headline: Monday briefing
fields.trailText: Observer
fields.body:
Observer

Big institutional investors are pressing for the resignation of Lord Marshall, chairman of Invensys, after losing faith in the troubled engineering company's management.

Lord Marshall, who is also chairman of British Airways among numerous other non-executive appointments, is now seen as a barrier to restoring shareholder confidence, City sources say. City and US institutions are understood to have communicated their concerns over Lord Marshall and the make-up of the board to Invensys broker, Cazenove, and some of the group's non-executive directors.

MPs are to summon David Edmonds, the telecoms regulator, for a grilling over his slow progress in opening up BT's local networks to competitors.

Rivals, including Energis and Colt, as well as US cable operators, have complained to Edmonds that BT is dragging its feet amid concern that he has not pushed it hard enough to open local telephone exchanges to firms wanting to offer high-speed broadband services direct to businesses and homes.

Sunday Telegraph

Siemens, the German electronics and engineering combine, is preparing a bid for all or part of Honeywell's industrial control and automation business in a deal worth up to $1.5bn.

Honeywell, which issued a profit warning in June, said three months ago that it would dispose of underperforming or non-core assets. But a sale of the industrial control systems business, seen as one of the core operations, will come as a surprise to the industry.

P&O, the transport and logistics group, is poised to announce a deal worth up to $650m (£450m) to acquire New York's largest container terminal. The acquisition of the 30-year concession marks P&O's most significant in the Americas, which the group has earmarked as an important region for future growth.

Members of the management team of British American Racing, the Formula 1 motor racing company controlled by BAT, are putting together a buy-out bid.

Sunday Times

One of the leading shareholders in Pilkington is proposing a financial reconstruction of the flat glass company currently valued at £933m on the stock market. The proposal by UK Active Value Fund would would involve Pilkington shrinking its balance sheet either by way of special dividend or a share buy-back. UK Active owns 5.4% of Pilkington.

Shares are experiencing their worst year for a decade and analysts say there is more turbulence to come in spite of Friday's strong bounce on Wall Street. The FTSE 100 share index rose by 77 points on Friday to close at 6,209.6 but the index is still down nearly 180 points on the week and down 10.4% on the year.

Sunday Business

Hopes for an open skies agreement between Britain and US have been dashed with the last minute cancellation of talks scheduled for this week between the two governments.

Industry insiders say there is now no realistic hope of a new aviation agreement between the two countries before the middle of next year.

Chevron Corporation's planned $36bn stock and debt acquisition of Texaco will face close scrutiny from US regulators concerned about the increased consolidation in the industry.

Mail on Sunday

The owner of London's Canary Wharf docklands office devlopment is emerging as a possible buyer for the Millennium Dome. If talks between the government and property developer Robert Bourne's Legacy consortium collapse, it would open the door to Paul Reichmann's Canary Wharf group which last week became the biggest property company in Britain.

Today

Interims Bank of Amercia Corp (Q3), Egg (Q3), Jarvis Porter Group. Finals Newcastle United. AGMs Mid Wynd International Investment Trust. EGMs BG Group, Molins, Primar-e, Trio Holdings.

Tuesday

Interims Airflow Streamlines, SurfControl (Q1), Walker Greenbank. Finals Bellway, Debenhams, Osprey Communications. AGMs None scheduled. EGMs None scheduled.

Wednesday

Interims Black's Leisure Group, Homestyle Group, Prowting, Parthus Technologies (Q3). Finals None scheduled. AGMs None scheduled. EGMs None scheduled.

Thursday

Interims Arcadia, Harveys Furnishing. Finals Albert Fisher, Air Partner, Sunderland. AGMs None scheduled. EGMs London Stock Exchange.

Friday

Interims Bristol & West Investments, Reuters (Q3). Finals Leeds Sporting. AGMs Fairplace Consulting, Photo-Me International. EGMs P&O.

Indicators this week

Today

Euro zone Finance minister's meeting. US Atlanta Fed conference. Japan Revised industrial output (August).

Tuesday

Euro zone Joint Ecofin, justice & home affairs council meeting, Luxembourg. US Industrial output, capacity in use (September). EU HIPC (September).

Wednesday

UK Minutes of Monetary policy committee meeting 4th/5th October. UK Labour market report (October). US Treasury announces size of 30-year bond buyback. US CPI (September). US Treasury announces size of two-year note auction.

Friday

fields.headline: Hutchings deal in question
fields.trailText: Tomkins' management yesterday made clear it would fight any attempt by former chief executive Greg Hutchings to pocket a bit pay-off.
fields.body:
Tomkins' management yesterday made clear it would fight any attempt by former chief executive Greg Hutchings to pocket a bit pay-off.

There has been speculation that Mr Hutchings might be eligible to secure a near-£2m payment as long as the review under way at the industrial firm does not produce evidence of laws or company regulations being breached.

Tomkins' board, led by chairman David Newlands, is aware of the anger felt by big shareholders over the "excessive" executive lifestyle enjoyed by Mr Hutchings, which led to his resignation last week.

A source close to the company said: "Greg left without prejudice and the company has not waived its rights to hold him accountable. It is not keen to make a big payment because it knows the shareholders would be unhappy."

Mr Hutchings refused to be drawn yesterday on whether he would risk the wrath the shareholders by trying to secure anything he felt he was entitled to or just walk away to avoid further embarrassing rows.

The review is likely to take until the end of November to complete. A separate review on the future of the company is also being undertaken with management hoping to complete this in time for scheduled public financial statements in January.

Although the inquiry by accountant Arthur Andersen has now being going on for a couple of weeks a Tomkins spokesman said it was still too early to say "with any confidence" whether it had got to the bottom of the abuses.

The weekend brought more allegations of unusual use of company money and speculation about how long it would be before some of the non-executive directors considered close to Mr Hutchings would feel obliged to go.

Mr Hutchings yesterday defended himself against allegations he gave a £85,000 political donation without proper declaration to a think tank, Greater London Forum, formed by his friend Lord Archer, which would have been against the Companies Act.

But Mr Hutchings, speaking through his public relations adviser Nigel Whitaker said: "The £85,000 was neither a political nor a charitable donation but it did go through the company's audit process."

fields.headline: Chevron plans $90bn merger with Texaco
fields.trailText: Chevron is expected to announce the takeover of its rival, Texaco, as early as today after the boards of the two US oil groups met yesterday afternoon.
fields.body:
Chevron is expected to announce the takeover of its rival, Texaco, as early as today after the boards of the two US oil groups met yesterday afternoon.

The deal is likely to be structured as an all-share transaction valuing the combined group at about $90bn (£62bn). By combining two of the largest US companies, the merger further consolidates a global industry already dominated by a handful of huge corporations.

Analysts yesterday expressed surprise at the timing of the merger, given the proximity of next month's presidential elections and the turmoil in the oil market. Consumer groups in the US have raised objections to further consolidation in the industry because of fears that it would increase prices.

The last wave of consolidation, which saw the marriage of Exxon with Mobil and BP with Amoco, started two years ago at a time when oil prices were a third of their present level.

Chevron and Texaco are expected to announce cost savings of as much as $1bn as a result of their merger.

Based on Friday's closing share price, Texaco was valued at $30.4bn, compared with $55bn for San Fransisco-based Chevron.

A combined Chevron/Texaco is likely to have to divest itself of certain assets in order to win anti-trust approval in the US. Chevron would also have to unravel a joint venture with Shell.

webTitle: Odds on Gala £250m offer for Hilton casinos

fields.headline: Odds on Gala £250m offer for Hilton casinos
fields.trailText: Hilton, the hotel and betting group formerly known as Ladbroke, is expected to announce to the stock market this morning that it has received a £250m bid for its casino business.
fields.body:
Hilton, the hotel and betting group formerly known as Ladbroke, is expected to announce to the stock market this morning that it has received a £250m bid for its casino business.

Confirmation of the approach, believed to be from the Gala bingo chain, could fuel speculation that Hilton is planning to split up its hotel and betting operations.

Despite denials that a demerger is on the cards, the move to change its name to Hilton has led analysts to believe that the group intends to focus on its hotels rather than on the Ladbroke betting arm.

Hilton confirmed yesterday that it had received "an unsolicited approach" from a group interested in buying the casino business, which includes 27 casinos such as Maxim's in London.

However, Hilton stressed that the deal was still being considered. "It's at a very early stage," a spokeswoman said. According to reports at the weekend, Gala, the bingo company, is interested in buying the casinos. Gala is privately owned af ter its management bought the business from Bass.

Analysts have pondered the possible demerger of Hilton since its attempts to expand its betting operations with the acquisition of Coral were thwarted by the competition authorities.

The group changed its name to Hilton last year, following the acquisition of the Stakis hotel and casino group, including the Glasgow Riverboat casino above, when speculation about a break-up of the group began Shares have fallen from 300p this year to below 200p.

Gala clubs was unavailable for comment. If it is successful in its approach, the acquisition might be regarded as a precursor to a stock market flotation.

webTitle: Comment:  Clinton should stay away from the Middle East.

fields.headline: Dishonest brokers
fields.standfirst:
Clinton should stay away from the Middle East. His pro-Israeli bias bedevils any attempt at peace

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: President Bill Clinton is threatening to interfere once again in the search for a peace settlement in the Middle East. If possible he should be kept at arm's length by the UN secretary general, Kofi Annan, whose quiet diplomacy has begun to make peace look like a possibility.
fields.body:
President Bill Clinton is threatening to interfere once again in the search for a peace settlement in the Middle East. If possible he should be kept at arm's length by the UN secretary general, Kofi Annan, whose quiet diplomacy has begun to make peace look like a possibility. If Mr Clinton now tries to elbow him aside and to reassert America's control of what should be an international operation, he is likely to fail as he has failed before. If that happens, it will be tragic for the people on both sides, Palestinians and Israelis, for whom a settlement would have brought relief from violence and misery and despair.

But one need feel no sympathy for Mr Clinton, whose motivation in bringing together Arabs and Israelis has always seemed to be his own personal ambition to score a foreign policy triumph that might rescue his tattered reputation. In pursuing that ambition, he has masqueraded as a mediator, an "honest broker", while all the time he and his team of Middle East advisers have worked, sometimes openly and sometimes surreptitiously, to advance the interests of Israel.

It would be more accurate to say that they were pursuing what they took to be the interests of Israel - whereas in fact they were helping to produce the result that we see today: a result tragic for the Palestinians, damaging to the Middle East and likely to be disastrous for the Israelis as well. Israel will never be secure until it can win the goodwill, or at least the tolerance, of its Arab neighbours. It must be obvious to everyone that this fictitious "peace process" has only intensified the frustration and bitterness that have found expression in the present Palestinian uprising.

The Americans have not merely failed to achieve their stated aim of an equitable settlement between Israel and the Palestinians. Ever since Mr Clinton persuaded Yasser Arafat to shake hands with Israel's prime minister, Yitzhak Rabin, on the White House lawn in September 1993, the American president and his advisers have actually made a just settlement harder to achieve.

Before that meeting there was already a perfectly adequate framework for peace, in the shape of UN resolutions 242 and 338. What was needed was to implement these resolutions, which called on Israel to withdraw from occupied territory in exchange for recognition by the Arabs of Israel and its right to exist behind secure borders. But as the Israelis built settlements all over the occupied territories it became apparent that they had no intention of withdrawing.

For a time, the Americans professed to regard the UN resolutions as the basis for the artificial "peace process". But gradually they dropped any mention of them, and as the years passed (and the Israeli settlements multiplied), they led the negotiations further away from the United Nations. They resisted every attempt to involve the Europeans or the wider international community in the search for peace in the Middle East. When the Palestine question was debated in the UN security council, the Americans invariably came to the defence of Israel, even to the extent of vetoing resolutions critical of Israeli policies that had the unanimous support of the other council members, including Britain.

All this has encouraged the Israelis to think themselves politically invulnerable. Confident of the unfailing support of the US, they could ignore UN resolutions, annex East Jerusalem, build Jewish settlements on Arab land, deny the Palestinians freedom of movement, invade southern Lebanon and bombard whatever targets they chose, up to and including Beirut - all this in defiance of their obligations as members of the UN. This is a scandalous catalogue of illegal activity, in which the underlying responsibility has been that of the US, made worse by the pretence that President Clinton, Madeleine Albright and the rest of them were acting in the interests of peace and justice.

So what next? A way must be found to break the US monopoly over Arab-Israeli negotiations and to return the search for peace to where it belongs: the UN. This is what the Europeans should aim for. They have never made use of the influence they possess, and it is time they - especially Britain - played an active role instead of tagging along behind the Americans.

It is not a matter of being anti-American or anti-Israeli. The fact is that between them Israel and the US have colluded in a policy designed to favour the Israelis, rather than produce a balanced peace that would take account of the interests of all the peoples concerned.

Whether such a peace is still possible, now that a spark has set light to all the pent-up resentment over the failure of the American "peace process", it is impossible to say. Certainly it will not be easy, so the sooner a new initiative is taken, the better. The fact that the secretary general of the UN has taken the lead makes a good start. Now let Britain lead the other Europeans in lending him their support. And, if possible, keep Mr Clinton and Mrs Albright out of the picture.

Michael Adams is a research fellow in the politics department of Exeter University and a former Middle East correspondent of the Guardian

webTitle: Leader: Tony Blair softens his position on pot

fields.headline: Spliffs v booze
fields.standfirst:
Tony Blair softens his position on pot

Special report: Tony Blair
Special report: drugs in Britain
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: A welcome softening of the government's hard line on drugs was made at the week-end. Tony Blair made two changes of tack in his interview with John Humphrys on Radio 4's Today programme.
fields.body:
A welcome softening of the government's hard line on drugs was made at the week-end. Tony Blair made two changes of tack in his interview with John Humphrys on Radio 4's Today programme. First he lifted his party's ludicrous ban on ministerial confessions - his public health minister, Yvette Cooper, had sensibly already ignored it by admitting on Any Questions that she had taken cannabis as a student. Second, and more important, he finally recognised his own hard line against drugs may not be the same as other parents'.

Asked whether he would prefer his children to "get drunk" or have "the odd spliff", the prime minister replied: "I really would prefer my children to have nothing to do with drugs at all and I think most - maybe, I don't know, I am wrong in this and other parents feel differently - but that is how I feel."

That last statement contains a glaring misconception. The prime minister clearly believes our hardline laws against cannabis help deter young people from using the drug. They don't. We certainly have the most stringent laws in Europe but, as British drug treatment specialists have argued for years, they have not deterred the young, only criminalised them. Ironically, we have the highest number of young users in Europe. In Holland, where cannabis is openly available in cafes under its liberal, decriminalised system, not only do fewer young people take cannabis but there is more success too in controlling hard drugs.

As for public perceptions, a Mori poll in the Mail on Sunday yesterday shows an overwhelming majority now accepts that cannabis should be decriminalised. Almost six out of 10 think the personal use of cannabis should no longer be treated as a criminal offence - with less than a third against. Calls yesterday for a royal commission were misplaced. We have already had one: the Police Foundation's national commission which reported in March. What we want now is action.

fields.headline: Delicate flower foils rail progress
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: The flowering of Britain's new modern railway is being stunted by the arrival of Dianthus armeria, the humble Deptford pink.
fields.body:
The flowering of Britain's new modern railway is being stunted by the arrival of Dianthus armeria, the humble Deptford pink.

This delicate plant grows in 30 different sites throughout Britain, protected by the Wildlife and Countryside Act. But on one particular site near Melton Mowbray in Leicestershire, it is preventing the testing and introduction of rolling stock, urgently needed to alleviate the misery of travellers crammed into old carriages.

Deptford pink grows in profusion along a 10 mile test track which fell into disuse during the 1990s. But the track has suddenly become a vital part of the industry's recovery programme.

Naturalists are concerned that the plant could be destroyed during the testing of new 140 mph tilting train rolling stock.

They have even suggested that Deptford pink could be replanted on nearby embankments. But it will take until the middle of next year to see if the experiment has succeeded.

Tim Evans, conservation officer at English Nature said yesterday: "It is a very important site for the plant, although we realise that there are important issues in testing rail safety equipment."

Alstom, the rail manufacturer which operates the track, said: "We want to proceed with the test track as quickly as possible, but we recognise that we have a responsibility to handle any environmental issues seriously."

Rolling stock failures account for 25% of delays, and only 320 new vehicles have entered service since privatisation. Over the next three months, about 300 new vehicles should be in passenger service, 250 of which should have been introduced more than a year ago.

The Gatwick Express will bring in 64 vehicles 14 months late, and ScotRail has yet to accept 120 vehicles. These are in sidings and are a year late.

A spokesman for the Association of Train Operating Companies, representing firms such as Virgin and National Express, said: "Company performance has been deteriorating for a number of months. One of the most important plans to halt this decline is getting reliable new trains onto the network."

Operators acknowledge that all the new trains represent the cutting edge of rail technology with new electronic systems that have not been tested on the rail network.

fields.headline: Rooms with a view
fields.standfirst: East Falklands guest house up for sale
fields.trailText: Boasting six bedrooms and a spectacular view of a remote stretch of coast, Blue Beach Lodge sounds a snip at £130,000.
fields.body:
Boasting six bedrooms and a spectacular view of a remote stretch of coast, Blue Beach Lodge sounds a snip at £130,000.

The only drawback is that it is a bit of a trek - an 8,000-mile trek to be precise - for a family keen to purchase a bolthole away from the grime and bustle of British city life.

Blue Beach Lodge is on the west coast of East Falkland overlooking the first landing place of British troops during the 1982 war and near the military cemetery.

But so keen are the islanders to attract the "right type" of owner that they have placed an advert in The Caterer And Hotelkeeper, a paper aimed at the British hotel trade.

Originally two farmhouses, the lodge at San Carlos was used to billet soldiers from 2 Para during the conflict. Its owners, William and Lynda Anderson, turned it from a farm house into a guesthouse in 1987. At first the spot was only accessible by four-wheel drive or by boat but now has a proper road.

Visitors began to arrive to view both the site of the landings and to pay their respects at the cemetery. The Falklands' booming population - it has risen by more than 10% to 2,500 thanks largely to oil exploration projects and fishing deals - has also helped boost visitor numbers.

The Andersons have now decided to retire, leaving a vacancy for a guesthouse owner, preferably one who can cope with the isolation - the permanent population of San Carlos is six - and the harsh weather. As well as the six guest rooms, the lodge has a residents' lounge and bar and dining room.

Richard Baker, acting general manager of the Falkland Islands Development Corporation, said: "We don't normally advertise overseas. It is not generally feasible to expect buyers from 8,000 miles away in the UK." Mr Baker joked that the six-strong population made San Carlos "quite a big settlement for us".

A glance at the Lonely Planet Guide, however, might put off prospective buyers. It says: "In an age of global access, it is nice to know there are still a few travel destinations where you can go your whole visit without bumping into a tourist."

fields.headline: Tajikistan on frontline of chaos
fields.standfirst: Afghan fighting spells serious trouble for frail Central Asia
fields.trailText: A sweeping Taliban military offensive across the mountains of northern Afghanistan threatens to unleash a refugee crises and a wave of Islamic insurgency and drug smuggling through Central Asia.
fields.body:
A sweeping Taliban military offensive across the mountains of northern Afghanistan threatens to unleash a refugee crises and a wave of Islamic insurgency and drug smuggling through Central Asia.

Four years after seizing power in Kabul, the Taliban Islamic militia has made crucial gains in the past two months in the only area of Afghanistan still outside its control. Now that Taliban troops are sitting along western parts of the 1,000-mile border with Tajikistan, the Tajik government and its backers in Russia are increasingly apprehensive.

Tajikistan has barely recovered from a five-year civil war that began only months after the collapse of the Soviet Union a decade ago. Unemployment runs at more than 50% and most factories have fallen into ruin. This year a severe drought threatens the lives of 3m people, half the population.

So far Tajikistan has kept its Afghan border formally shut, fearing the impact of a flood of refugees. Aid agencies in the capital, Dushanbe, say up to 100,000 Afghans would descend on the country's southern provinces, the area worst affected by drought, if the Taliban made further advances.

"The large humanitarian catastrophe could be greater than that in Kosovo, one of the biggest in the world," Sergei Ivanov, the head of Russia's security council, was reported as saying last week. Moscow opposes the Taliban and is keen to increase its own influence in Central Asia.

Radical Islamic groups in Tajikistan, it is feared, would be inspired if the Taliban seized the remaining 10% of Afghanistan. Islamic militants are believed already to be moving from Afghanistan through the narrow strip in the centre of Tajikistan and onward north into Kyrgyzstan and the Ferghana valley, where hardliners have long wanted a separate Muslim homeland.

"There is a very real threat of a spread of Islamism in Tajikistan," said an aid worker in Dushanbe. "There are a lot of different divisions of radical Islamists."

One of the region's leading rebel groups, the Islamic Movement of Uzbekistan (IMU), which has bases in the mountains of Tajikistan and wants to overthrow the secular Uzbek government, was added to the US state department's list of terror organisations last month.

Uzbekistan accuses one of the parties in the governing coalition of Tajikistan - the United Tajik Opposition - of supporting the rebels. In August IMU rebels fought their way to within 60 miles of the Uzbek capital, Tashkent.

In the northern Tajik province of Leninabad, the Hizut Tahir movement, an Islamic group based on small, independent cells, has been pushing for a separate state. Leninabad is cut off from in winter when snow blocks the only pass.

Although 25,000 Russian soldiers guard the Tajik border, drug smuggling from Afghanistan, estimated to produce 70% of the world's heroin, has increased five-fold this year. Rival factories in Afghanistan compete to refine the purest heroin, whose price rises exponentially on the smugglers' trail through Tajikistan to Russia.

Some of the most vulnerable parts of the border are guarded not by the Russian army but by soldiers from the United Tajik Opposition, the Islamic group which, though now in Tajikistan's coalition, fought against the government in the civil war. For the Taliban, opium production is a big source of income; this year alone it brought in at least $9m (£6m).

The most immediate threat remains the current drought and the danger of a flood of refugees. At least 70,000 people fled the Afghan city of Taloqan when it fell to the Taliban last month. Up to 100,000 more would flee if the Taliban takes the last opposition town, Faizabad.

In villages across southern Tajikistan people are on the brink of starvation. The UN's World Food Programme is launching a $62m emergency operation to feed 1m of the most at risk in the next nine months.

The drought reduced most of this year's crops to dust. What little water remains is diverted to the state and collective farms which for decades have been forcing a lucrative cotton crop out of an otherwise arid land.

Most villagers have used up their meagre savings and sold their livestock. Many were well off under Soviet rule, but now cars sit rusting in garages and even if the old fridges and black and white televisions are still working, there is rarely electricity.

Malakhova Bibigul, who works at the Maxim Gorky collective farm near Kurgan-Tyube, lost her husband in the civil war. She has eight children but an annual income equalling just a few founds from her work in the farm's cotton fields.

"I don't know what my future will be," she said, clasping the white shawl covering her head. "I hoped my eldest son would go to school and be able to support the family. But he doesn't go. We can't afford it, he has no money for books. I have lost hope."

Mrs Bibigul is one of a group of villagers who have been given half a hectare of land by the World Food Programme, together with flour, seeds and fertiliser to survive the winter and grow a crop for next year.

These Muslim villagers were once refugees themselves. More than 500,000 fled into Afghanistan during the Tajik civil war. Now they are likely to find families of refugees begging for help at their doors.

"It was difficult living in Afghanistan," said Qurbangula, 35, whose husband was also killed in the war. She is one of 60 widows on another collective farm close to the Afghan border who have been given land and seeds.

"But it is better to be hungry and thirsty in your own country than to have enough food but be forced to live abroad."

fields.headline: Missing boy, 3, found under bush
fields.trailText: A three-year-old boy who went missing at a remote beauty spot had spent the night huddled under a bush, his rescuers said yesterday.
fields.body:
A three-year-old boy who went missing at a remote beauty spot had spent the night huddled under a bush, his rescuers said yesterday.

Cameron Munro was found safe and well by a rescue dog and his handler after being missing for 16 hours. He had disappeared at the Highland beauty spot the Falls of Shin, near Dornoch, Sutherland at around 4.30pm on Saturday and was found yesterday about half a mile away.

Flight Sergeant Al Sylvester, from RAF Kinloss, one of 34 RAF rescuers who had spent the night searching for the boy, said: "He was perfectly fine. He wasn't hurt or upset at all. He was talking to himself about dinosaurs and he had been looking for dinosaurs in the woods when he went missing. He had only been out of his mother's sight for seconds."

Mr Sylvester added: "When he was found he was a little cold, he must have slept through the night. He was quite sheltered but it is still incredible he survived.

"He lives in a farm area and he must be a hardened wee boy with a real will to live."

Cameron, from Ardgay, was reported missing from a play area at the Falls of Shin visitor centre by his mother who was also with his two-year-old sister.

A full-scale search was mounted with three mountain rescue teams, helicopters fitted with heat-seeking equipment from the coastguard and RAF Kinloss, police officers, sniffer dogs and scores of volunteers.

Mountain rescue teams continued the hunt overnight and a full-scale search resumed at first light.

Mr Sylvester said a dog found Cameron sitting in the undergrowth yesterday morning. "The feeling is just fantastic but we were convinced that we were going to find him alive."

Cameron was released from Raigmore Hospital in Inverness after a check-up.

webTitle: Leader: Arafat and Barak must stop the killing

fields.headline: Looking to the summit
fields.standfirst:
Arafat and Barak must stop the killing

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Palestinian and Israeli leaders have been at pains to play down expectations ahead of today's planned summit in Egypt. That is wise. If it goes ahead, and that was still in doubt last night, the meeting is unlikely to produce anything more than a sticking plaster for the gaping wounds
fields.body:
Palestinian and Israeli leaders have been at pains to play down expectations ahead of today's planned summit in Egypt. That is wise. If it goes ahead, and that was still in doubt last night, the meeting is unlikely to produce anything more than a sticking plaster for the gaping wounds of the past fortnight. Yasser Arafat is clearly in two minds, as has been the case throughout this crisis. He spent part of yesterday with representatives of Hamas and Islamic Jihad, militants who reject the Oslo peace process outright.

Mr Arafat's release from jail of 65 members of these two groups has enraged Israel. But his decision reflects the extent to which the recent, all-consuming violence has pushed him into the arms of the radicals. In Gaza, thousands of supporters of Mr Arafat's own Fatah organisation urged their leader to boycott the summit altogether. The two recent terrorist incidents in Yemen, another Hizbullah kidnapping, attacks on synagogues in France and Britain, and (in a less directly connected way) the weekend hijacking of a Saudi airliner to Baghdad, have all underlined the way in which extremists in the Arab world are emboldened by the current confrontation.

Assuming he does show up in Egypt, the Palestinian leader is expected to demand an international inquiry into the events of the past 17 days. While the violence appeared to have subsided yesterday, Raed Hammouda Yaacoub died in a Ramallah hospital of a bullet wound received last week.

He became the 100th person to die, all but seven of whom were Palestinians or Israeli Arab citizens, and about one in five of whom were reportedly children or teenagers. This carnage does indeed demand a full, impartial and urgent investigation, and Israel should not continue to obstruct it. Mr Arafat also wants an Israeli military pullback from the outskirts of Palestinian cities, an end to the economic siege of West Bank and Gaza workers and, of course, agreement by the Israeli army to cease fire.

For his part, Israel's prime minister, Ehud Barak, is insisting that Palestinian violence end, that the freed militants be rearrested, that Palestinian-controlled media cease what Israel sees as incitement, and that guarantees be given protecting Jewish holy places. If he does not get what he wants, he will act on his threat to bring one of Israel's leading rejectionists, Ariel Sharon, into a government of national unity and take the "war" to the Palestinians. Thus is Mr Barak, like Mr Arafat, driven to extremes.

The question of whether the peace process can be revived in its present form is one that may only sensibly be addressed once the violence is halted. All the same, Bill Clinton's administration should already be asking itself some hard questions. It was Mr Clinton who pulled out all the stops for an ambitious, comprehensive Israeli-Palestinian agreement, applying extraordinary, personal pressure at the Camp David summit last July. Although all sides admitted it was a high-stakes gamble, Mr Clinton's Dayton-style tactics raised expectations to fever pitch.

The past fortnight has, in one sense, been the bitter result of that great disappointment, the extreme reaction to America's all-or-nothing, headbanging diplomacy. The US, if it ever was, is no longer viewed by much of the Arab world as an even-handed peace-broker. And Mr Clinton, in any event, has but three months left to fret about his "legacy". Since the Oslo process began, it has been a given that peace will only come through US-led mediation. Maybe that perception is one, among many others, that is now changing. But first things first. Today's priority is to stop the killing.

webTitle: Mbeki's vow of silence on Aids policy

fields.headline: Mbeki's vow of silence on Aids policy
fields.trailText: The president of South Africa, Thabo Mbeki, has bowed to unrelenting criticism of his Aids policies and told other African National Congress leaders that he is abandoning a public defence of his views on the causes of the disease because it is damaging him and his government.
fields.body:
The president of South Africa, Thabo Mbeki, has bowed to unrelenting criticism of his Aids policies and told other African National Congress leaders that he is abandoning a public defence of his views on the causes of the disease because it is damaging him and his government.

But Mr Mbeki has not changed his controversial opinion that factors other than HIV, such as poverty and malnutrition, play a primary role in causing Aids. He has merely decided not to discuss the issue in public.

The Johannesburg Sunday Times reported yesterday that Mr Mbeki was concerned at rising public disillusionment with the ANC for its Aids policy and the divisions this is creating between the party and its allies in the trade-union movement and the Communist party.

Three weeks ago the president admitted to parliament that his views had created "confusion" among South Africa's 43m citizens. About one in 10 are HIV-positive.

The government has tried to portray the criticism as media-manufactured, but in recent weeks powerful voices have joined the chorus of dissent from doctors. They include Nelson Mandela, the Anglican archbishop of Cape Town and the head of the trade union confederation, Cosatu.

Mr Mandela spoke in favour of the "dominant opinion that prevails throughout the world" that HIV causes Aids. Archbishop Njongonkulu Ndungane called the government's refusal to supply drugs to HIV-positive people "as serious a crime against humanity as apartheid". Cosatu said the link between HIV and Aids was "irrefutable".

Mr Mbeki's attempts to defend his position have only weakened it. Earlier this month, he told ANC members of parliament that the CIA was working with US drug companies to discredit him because he was challenging the world economic order and threatening profits by questioning the link between HIV and Aids.

Then it was revealed that while the government refuses to prescribe AZT and other anti-Aids drugs in public hospitals, members of parliament can get them through their health-insurance scheme at taxpayers' expense.

The opposition accused Mr Mbeki of gross hypocrisy, not least because the government has told doctors that it is illegal to provide anti-retroviral drugs to rape victims and pregnant women as a preventive measure, but also because the health scheme for members of parliament specifically offers treatment in both cases.

The Sunday Times said that Mr Mbeki told ANC leaders he will leave his controversial health minister, Manto Tshabalala-Msimang, to publicly defend the government's policy and to liaise with the presidential Aids advisory committee, which was set up this year to establish whether there is a link between HIV and Aids.

Mr Mbeki's administration has backtracked several times in the past week. Ms Tshabalala-Msimang announced that HIV-positive pregnant women would be given the anti-Aids drug, Nevirapine, at seven hospitals in a significant expansion of tests. The government has also belatedly launched an education campaign to curb the spread of HIV by encouraging abstinence, monogamy and the use of condoms.

 A regional education minister has abandoned her duties, claiming that her predecessor cast a spell on her office.

Faith Gasa, a member of the Inkatha Freedom party which governs KwaZulu-Natal, has not been seen at her office for three weeks. Her husband, Enoch, a university professor, blames his wife's predecessor, Eileen KaNkosi Shandu, who was fired from the post in August for nepotism.

"Her two cars have been in accidents and if she had been in [them] at the time she would have been dead," he said. "Ms Shandu is a thorn in my wife's flesh. Even the premier knows there is something unholy in that office and he has ordered it to be repainted."

Ms Gasa says she will return to her office today to sack the staff for being in league with Ms Shandu, who denies she has cast a spell.

webTitle: Leader: Labour needs many more women

fields.headline: A few good women
fields.standfirst:
Labour needs many, many more

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: One of the several propaganda coups offered to Labour by this month's Conservative party conference was the parade of Tory candidates for the next election. They marched on stage in their hundreds, smiling and waving, in what was meant to be a vote-winning photo-op. The trouble was, they all looked alike: row after row of white men in blue suits.
fields.body:
One of the several propaganda coups offered to Labour by this month's Conservative party conference was the parade of Tory candidates for the next election. They marched on stage in their hundreds, smiling and waving, in what was meant to be a vote-winning photo-op. The trouble was, they all looked alike: row after row of white men in blue suits. The party's planners were obviously aware of the problem: that's why they herded the handful of women candidates to the front and ordered them to wear bright colours. That trick only made matters worse: the women stood out, drawing attention to how few they were.

Labour allowed itself a smug smile at that sight; after all, it arrived in Westminster in 1997 with 101 women, a record presence. But it can rest on those laurels no longer. As our investigation today reveals, far from building on that advance of three years ago, Labour has taken a woeful step back: if the 1997 result were to be repeated, Labour would send four fewer women to the House of Commons. How distant Labour's 1990 commitment to a 50-50 gender balance seems now.

Happily, this is not a problem that requires a three-year commission to solve. For Labour has cracked this nut before. The answer is all-women shortlists, of the kind which produced the 1997 intake. No one doubts that mechanism works; the difficulty is the 1996 ruling which declared them unlawful. Tony Blair has said he will consider overcoming that obstacle, by legalising all-women shortlists. Our report shows that merely to "consider" action is not good enough. Mr Blair should promise to act.

So much for mechanistic solutions. The deeper task, as the women's minister, Tessa Jowell, says, is to alter the "culture of politics". It is not just too macho, it is often guilty of outright discrimination. The Commons is a prime example - whether it be working hours hostile to family life, or sexual harassment from male MPs who know they are protected by parliamentary privilege. This cultural problem extends to our second, depressing revelation: that Labour is shutting out black and Asian candidates as well as women. Last year's Macpherson report into the murder of Stephen Lawrence alerted us to institutional racism even in those bodies that pride themselves on tolerance and anti-racism. Labour needs to realise that it, like every other major institution, is susceptible to prejudice - and then resolve to change its ways.

Mr Blair should promise to act. So much for mechanistic solutions. The deeper task, as the women's minister, Tessa Jowell, says, is to alter the "culture of politics". It is not just too macho, it is often guilty of outright discrimination. The Commons is a prime example - whether it be working hours hostile to family life, or sexual harassment from male MPs who know they are protected by parliamentary privilege. This cultural problem extends to our second, depressing revelation: that Labour is shutting out black and Asian candidates as well as women. Last year's Macpherson report into the murder of Stephen Lawrence alerted us to institutional racism even in those bodies that pride themselves on tolerance and anti-racism. Labour needs to realise that it, like every other major institution, is susceptible to prejudice - and then resolve to change its ways.

fields.headline: Beastie who?
fields.trailText: Tom Paternoster (Letters, October 14) has inadvertently hit the nail on the head when it comes to teaching "contemporary" music.
fields.body:
Tom Paternoster (Letters, October 14) has inadvertently hit the nail on the head when it comes to teaching "contemporary" music. If you are 12 years old, then a 1986 Beastie Boys album may as well have been released in 1886 or 1786 - it's from before you were born and therefore "irrelevant".
Gary Austin
Swanage, Dorset
jeep@jeep73.fsnet.co.uk

With reference to Sean French's piece (Mum, what's a cow? October 12), never mind children, could farmers answer any of the questions set by Country Life? Or didn't they ask the price of fuel?
Roderick Oates
Tabley, Cheshire

I wonder how many of those of a Widdecombe persuasion in the cannabis debate were among the throng ridiculing the beef-on-the-bone ban as an infringement of informed personal choice in spite of the danger.
Tom Hardy
London

My clarinet teacher once showed me how a Rizla can be folded and placed over the lower front teeth as a sort of gumshield in the event of a bloodied lip from overpractice. (I overpracticed once but didn't enjoy it.)
Roger O'Keefe
Cambridge

I have just seen, in a programme called Trade Secrets on BBC2, a butler ironing a copy of the Guardian. Please arrange for deliveries to that address to be terminated.
David Boadle
Leeds
Boadles@compuserve.com

While I am opposed in principle to the idea of cloning human beings, I think that in the case of Nancy Banks-Smith (Letters, October 14) we should make an exception.
Eric Thomas
Hastings

fields.headline: Israel's irreconcilable differences
fields.trailText: Jonathan Freedland (Why Israel's peaceniks feel betrayed, October 14) explains in eloquent terms why the Israeli left feels let down by its Palestinian peace partners.
fields.body:
Jonathan Freedland (Why Israel's peaceniks feel betrayed, October 14) explains in eloquent terms why the Israeli left feels let down by its Palestinian peace partners. While I think he is right, I think he fails to account for the reason for this, which lies in the different goals each side had in the peace process.

While for Israel the process was a means to consolidate and legitimise its ill-gotten gains of war, for the Palestinians it was meant to be a means of restitution for injustice. These two goals are incompatible.

If the international community is to play a constructive role, it must affirm the principle that the illegitimate gains of war cannot stand. In the case of Israel this means the territories that it has illegally occupied since 1967, including East Jerusalem, and the ethnic cleansing within its own borders since 1948. The return of territory acquired by force and the right of refugees to return home are the very principles that the US and Britain have been loudly asserting in the context of the Balkans. Why should they not apply in the Middle East?
A Dawar
Robinson College, Cambridge

Katharine Viner writes: "If Palestine became a state, if Israel withdraws from all of the West Bank, Gaza and East Jerusalem ... then the Palestinian community seems likely to accept the loss of pre-1967 Israel" (Fear and rage in Palestine, October 14). So the Palestinians reserve the right never to have to spell out exactly what they want and to resort to violence when they don't get it. Is that because, in their heart of hearts, what they still really want is the destruction of Israel?
David Kalisch
Budleigh Salterton, Devon

With your fly-on-the-wall reporting of the alleged mobile phone conversation on the mob killing of two Israeli soldiers ('I have just killed your husband' wife was told, October 14), the Guardian follows the tabloids in ghoulishly embellishing reports of an already grim event. Only the bereaved wife or the mob speaker could have had first hand knowledge of that conversation, and neither would be reliable enough to quote without attribution.
Peter Reina
London

Whenever there is conflict in Israel-Palestine the west puts on a grave face and urges restraint on both sides. The assumption is that there are two equally valid moral positions in this dispute, and that we must not take sides.

Yet what lies behind the Israel-Palestine conflict is the systematic colonisation and ethnic cleansing of a piece of land, all of which used to be called Palestine.

Theodor Herzl rightly foresaw more than 100 years ago that this would be a necessary precondition for the creation of a Jewish state. The rapid expansion of settlements and exclusive connecting roads in the West Bank and Gaza during Ehud Barak's "liberal" period of office is clear evidence, if any were needed, that such a policy is not just an unfortunate historical relic.

Would it be going too far to suggest that successive Israeli governments bear more responsibility than the Palestinians for the present unrest?
Dr Francis Clark-Lowes
Palestine Solidarity Campaign

A week before Ariel Sharon's cheap political stunt, I attended a conference of the International Society for Justice Research on the outskirts of Tel Aviv. The last speaker was a Palestinian journalist, who gave an account of the harassment of Palestinians at the hands of Israelis, of the mockery made of legal due process when Palestinian lawyers are kept waiting outside the courtroom while their Israeli counterparts confer with the judge, of the abrogation of civil, legal and human rights.

But most of all, she brought tales of routine humiliation and contempt of Palestinians. With the help of video footage, she told how the Israeli Defence Force sets up armed posts on the roofs of Palestinian houses. There is no attempt to minimise the noise or the disruption. People just have to live with it. In the case on the video, the soldiers were happy to use the roof of a house as their latrine. Their voices could be heard clearly laughing and joking together as one told the other that the latter had just pissed on the head of whoever was below.

When injustice and deprivation are perceived as based upon group identity, the response is collective action. If such treatment is routine, then the expressions of frustration and fury in response to a cheap political gesture are not surprising.
Rosamund Stock
London School of Economics

Once again (Letters, October 14), we see the old canard that wars are caused by religion. In the 20th century we have seen millions butchered by atheistic regimes, such as those of Nazi Germany and Stalinist Russia, giving the lie to the notion that all we need to do to have peace is to eradicate religion. Humanity will always find an excuse for war - religion has simply been a convenient one throughout history.
Paul Thompson
Friends in Christ (Primitive Quakers)

fields.headline: Prevention is better than cure for our rubbish, too
fields.trailText: Paul Brown makes many good points about Britain's appalling waste problem, (What a waste", October 11), but he fails to explore one avenue that would stop us having to send so much rubbish to landfill or incineration in the first place - namely reducing the rubbish we actually put in our bins.
fields.body:
Paul Brown makes many good points about Britain's appalling waste problem, (What a waste", October 11), but he fails to explore one avenue that would stop us having to send so much rubbish to landfill or incineration in the first place - namely reducing the rubbish we actually put in our bins.

The rubbish in the average household bin in Britain weighs about 16 kilos, roughly the same weight as a three-year-old child. Approximately 40% of that rubbish consists of glass, kitchen and garden waste - materials that could easily be composted. If local councils offered residents composters at a drastically reduced price, as Stoke-on-Trent city council did recently, think of the difference it would make to Britain's waste mountain. Residents without space for a composter could be encouraged to use wormeries that are small and relatively cheap to buy.

The public also need to become far more actively involved in solving the problem, by changing their shopping habits and buying greener. They could also be more imaginative about re-using items, by donating old clothes, CDs, cartridges, printers and spectacles to charity. These may sound like simplistic suggestions but they might just be the answer to Britain's burgeoning waste problem. In a recent experiment we did in Bristol, one family managed to reduce its rubbish by 80%, through encouragement and better information. Let's look at a pre-bin solution backed by government and councils - it has to be better than "burning the waste or dumping it in landfill sites".
Alan Woods
Chief executive, Going for Green

For the many thousands of householders who have been flooded and the millions whose premiums will be raised to cover the claims (Low lying homes may become uninsurable, October 14), it would be helpful if you printed the name of the minister who signed the letter to local authorities telling them that the decision on whether or not to allow planning permission to develop on flood plains was being left to the "commercial judgment" of the developer.

The letter was one of the few stimulated by Michael Heseltine in his damp bonfire of red tape.
Ian Campbell
Borth, Ceredigion

The complacency of the environment agency is bewildering. Within a month of "flood action week", one of the worst floods in recent history hits the south-east of England. Despite warnings from a range of expert scientific witnesses that flooding will get more frequent and severe, the EA still supports planning applications by landowners to build on flood plains.

The agency's own flood week message: "Flooding. You can't prevent it. You can prepare for it," is no cure for the incremental effects of flood plain development. Milton Keynes council, in a new town with acres of space already allocated for further expansion, has granted developers permission to build in the Ouse Valley flood plain.

It is the same up and down the Ouse flood plain. Why does the environment agency believe it is wise to prepare for flooding by building on flood plains?
Richard Skellington
Milton Keynes

fields.headline: Beautiful losers
fields.trailText: Is there a media conspiracy of silence to ignore the claims of Glenn Hoddle to be England's next soccer manager (A job that turned into a lottery with no punters, October 14)?
fields.body:
Is there a media conspiracy of silence to ignore the claims of Glenn Hoddle to be England's next soccer manager (A job that turned into a lottery with no punters, October 14)? If one examines the records of the 11 England managers (including Howard Wilkinson) and ranks them according to success (three points for a win, one point for a draw, and expressed as a fraction of possible points) then Hoddle comes out as number two, being beaten only by Sir Alf Ramsey. The journalists' favourite, Terry Venables, appears only in fourth place.

Hoddle left the job because of religious prejudice, which one would have thought was illegal. Personally I think his beliefs are odd, to say the least, but what has that got to do with footie?
Norman Shepherd
Bristol
Norman.T.Shepherd@iname.com

Mark Lawson thinks "it's unlikely that Kevin Keegan attends the theatre very often or that Trevor Nunn spends many weekends on the football terraces" (Cold comfort in the hot seat, October 14). I can't speak for Kev, but Trev has been a life-long fan of Ipswich Town, a club that represents a veritable triumph of cultured football over underfunding, a club that consistently sticks by its managers, a club that bred England's two most successful holders of that post, Sir Alf Ramsey and Bobby Robson. Currently Trev is able to study the massive talents of a future Scotland - or even England - manager, George Burley.
Nick Shearman
Bristol
Nshearman@aol.com

In his review of Goose Nights (October 14), Michael Billington said we must "nail the lie that young people don't go to the theatre", and yet only five days before, in his assault on Trevor Nunn's regime at the Royal National Theatre, Mr Billington reported that as recently as September 1998 the average age of patrons on their database was 78. Are we alone in spotting a contradiction here?
Mike Bradwell,
Tim Fountain
Bush Theatre, London

fields.headline: Broken English
fields.trailText: The old Welsh adage "A hedge up to one's midriff is a safe hedge" may appear obscure and even Zen-like to Simon Hoggart (Saturday Review, October 14), who, in spite of his longish sojourn in what I think he calls "Ulster", remains incorrigibly, if often charmingly, Anglo-Saxon.
fields.body:
The old Welsh adage "A hedge up to one's midriff is a safe hedge" may appear obscure and even Zen-like to Simon Hoggart (Saturday Review, October 14), who, in spite of his longish sojourn in what I think he calls "Ulster", remains incorrigibly, if often charmingly, Anglo-Saxon. Its meaning will however be crystal clear to all those who have received a hard kick where one doesn't want it in the fiercely competitive world of Celtic small farming.

Might I also recommend to him the old Irish proverb - a warning perhaps to over-sophisticated smart-arse newspaper columnists, though framed many centuries before such creatures were ever heard of: "Is iomaí gur bhris béal fhear a shrón" - It's often that a man's mouth broke his nose.
Enda O'Doherty
Dublin

I was surprised to see the acronym Wasp (white Anglo-Saxon protestant) being used (Leader, October 10). This term was coined by an American sociologist E Digby Baltzell in 1964 to describe upper-class descendants of English settlers in America. As most school children know, the Anglo-Saxons were a bunch of heathen Germans. It was the Normans, aka the French, who knocked them off their pedestal. Why white Americans claim to be the descendants of Bede and Alfred is perplexing. It can only be explained by a massive ignorance of history coupled with a desire for a monosyllabic word to describe upper-class whites.
David O'Connor
Cork

fields.headline: Sainsbury's launches upmarket range
fields.trailText: 8am: Sainsbury's is to launch a range of upmarket foods under the new "Taste the Difference" brand, writes byClaire Cozens.
fields.body:
Sainsbury's is to launch a range of upmarket foods under the new "Taste the Difference" brand.

The range makes its debut in Sainsbury's stores on November 15 and will rival other premium supermarket own brands such as Tesco's "Finest" range. "Taste the Difference" was developed with the design agency, Brewer Riddiford, and will carry distinctive purple and yellow branding.

The move comes as Sainsbury's seeks a return to its traditional middle-class market, which has been slowly eroded by rivals such as Tesco.

The supermarket's marketing has seen a move away from the focus on value featured in its infamous John Cleese advertising. The campaign, in which Mr Cleese wandered round the supermarket bawling prices through a megaphone, was seen as a marketing disaster after it alienated wealthier customers while failing to convince consumers that they could get but their groceries for less at Sainsbury's.

fields.headline: Publicis picks up Videoportal account
fields.trailText: 8am: Videoportal.com, the satellite video service, has appointed Publicis as its first advertising agency without a pitch, writes Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Videoportal.com, the satellite video service, has appointed Publicis as its first advertising agency without a pitch.

Publicis will help the company develop a corporate image and carve out market share.

The first part of the campaign will be a mixed media push including internet links to the company's services. Budget figures were not released.

Both VideoPortal.com and its main rival, Videoportal.it, were founded this year and have yet to start providing services.

Given the similarity of the names and services of the two companies - they use different technologies to deliver video-on-demand - advertising will be one of the only ways the rivals can differentiate themselves in the eyes of potential consumers.

Videoportal.it has yet to announce an agency appointment.

fields.headline: Mirror claims web guide first
fields.trailText: 8am: The Mirror is launching what it claims is the first ever web guide in a popular daily newspaper, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
The Mirror newspaper is this month launching what it claims is the first ever web guide in a popular daily newspaper.

The advertising-based web directory, called Quick Click, will launch in the Saturday supplement, The Look, on October 28.

In an email memo sent to advertisers last week, the Mirror said it was making a "significant editorial investment in the internet". The paper claims that 1.6m of its readers are internet users and attributes its web-savvy audience to the paper's daily column, Kelly's I, and Carol Vorderman's Friday four-page guide to websites.

The new section will be split up into different categories including travel, leisure, shopping and lifestyle, and organised by small box advertising-like entries. Rates have been set at £450 per week for a four-week package or £400 per week for an eight-week package.

The advertising-based web directory, called Quick Click, will launch in the Saturday supplement, The Look, on October 28. In an email memo sent to advertisers last week, the Mirror said it was making a "significant editorial investment in the internet". The paper claims that 1.6m of its readers are internet users and attributes its web-savvy audience to the paper's daily column, Kelly's I, and Carol Vorderman's Friday four-page guide to websites. The new section will be split up into different categories including travel, leisure, shopping and lifestyle, and organised by small box advertising-like entries. Rates have been set at £450 per week for a four-week package or £400 per week for an eight-week package.
